HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
BILLIONS IN HELP FOR EAST GERMANY APPROVED BY BONN

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Leaders of both Germanys today welcomed the agreement of the wartime Allies to join in shaping a united Germany. As if to begin the process, Bonn approved a supplementary budget of $4.1 billion, most of it to shore up East Germany until reunification could be achieved.
The aid package included a reserve fund of $1.2 billion (2 billion marks), and $1 billion for East German resettlers arriving in West Germany. An additional $1.4 billion was designated for immediate use for specific purposes, ranging from credits for small and medium-size businesses to currency exchange for East German visitors.
 
Agreement by Allies
The vote on the additional aid came the day after Germany's main adversaries in the war - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France -agreed in Ottawa to shape a negotiating framework for German reunification. 
It also coincided with the conclusion of a visit by the East German Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, who failed in his effort to get $9 billion, or 15 million marks, in emergency money, and left showing his disappointment. None of the money in the supplemental budget was to be dispersed by Mr. Modrow's interim Government, which ends after parliamentary elections March 18.
Before leaving, Mr. Modrow welcomed the Ottawa decision, which he said was the best means of protecting German and Allied interests. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's spokesman declared that Bonn ''greets the creation and contents of the Ottawa agreement.''
 
Bonn Aide Is Pleased
The strongest plaudits came from a spokesman for Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who played a major role in shaping the agreement. ''We see this as an exceptionally important development and a great success for the West German Foreign Minister, an important step toward German unity,'' the spokesman said. [In Ottawa, the Polish Foreign Minister, Krzysztof Skubiszewski, called for a unified Germany to remain in the NATO alliance, warning that the nation might otherwise become ''a power or superpower on the European stage.'' Page A18.] The concurrence of these various events underscored the hectic pace of the German drive toward unity. But there was also a sense in Bonn that the agreement in Ottawa, following by two days a go-ahead to unity from Moscow, had lifted the last major historical obstacles to unity, and left the Germans clear now to start patching together their severed land. But even as these hurdles were cleared, signs were gathering that the mechanics of reunification could prove at least as difficult and contentious as winning the political green light.
On the international front, the Ottawa decision still left unresolved the critical issue of the place of a united Germany in the security alignment of Europe. The Western allies continued to insist that it could not be neutral, and therefore that Germany had to remain in NATO. Moscow insisted that it could not be other than neutral.
Also lost in the swirl of the moment were the repeated signals from Moscow that it would insist on maintaining as much influence as possible over the future Germany. The Kremlin's repeated insistence that ''everything must be done so that the threat of fascism never again emanates from German soil,'' for example, was likely to prove more than an oratorical flourish once the talks began.
''These six-power negotiations are going to be brutal,'' a Western diplomat said. ''Things have happened so quickly that many Germans seem to think the rest will be as easy. But the next six to nine months are going to be a very nervous and tense time.''
There was a faint echo in this warning of the first postwar years, when the victorious Allies haggled inconclusively for years over Germany's fate, until in 1948 the three Western Allies agreed on a central Government for their occupation zones, which came to form West Germany. East Germany was formed in the Soviet zone soon after.
 
Allies Trying to Keep Up
The difference, however, was that a defeated Germany had little say over its fate then. Now, it is the Germans who were setting the agenda and leading the way to their union, and the Allies seem to be struggling to keep up.
For now, Mr. Kohl and Mr. Genscher joined NATO in insisting that Germany must remain in the Western camp. But a public-opinion poll by the Wickert Institute found that 9 out of 10 East Germans, and more than half of West Germans, thought a reunified Gemany should be neutral. Such sentiments were not likely to be ignored in an election year.
On the internal side, the mix of intense election-year politicking, a continuing exodus from East Germany and uncertainty over the cost and effects of union tempered expectations with anxiety.
At the center of the action, Mr. Kohl appeared to be barreling ahead toward unity with a single-mindedness that bordered on the aggressive.
 
Cavalier Treatment of Modrow
The attitude was demonstrated in his cavalier treatment of the visiting Mr. Modrow. Evidently sensing that East Germany's caretaker Prime Minister was politically powerless, Mr. Kohl gave him a negligent welcome and used the meeting largely to announce a preparatory committee for monetary union.
Mr. Modrow made no secret of his disappointment. Both he and his delegation seemed especially to bridle at Mr. Kohl's refusal to grant the 15 billion marks that they had requested in ''solidarity aid.'' Asked directly if he was disappointed, Mr. Modrow answered, ''If you say it that way, yes.''
In pressing for monetary union, Mr. Kohl argued that the step was critical to stem the exodus from the East and to prevent the disintegration of East Germany. But to many in both East and West his eyes seemed fixed more on the gathering political race for West German national elections Dec. 2.
Some economists and diplomats in West Germany argued that the call for quick economic union glossed over the complexity and dislocation of the move. Both in East and West Germany, people increasingly worry over the social benefits so dear to the Germans.
 
'Who Is Going to Pay?'
Der Spiegel magazine featured an article on the subject on its cover this week. The magazine cited the popular slogan, ''Germany, United Fatherland,'' and added, ''It could become an expensive one.'' West Germans, the magazine said, were wondering ''who is going to pay for all this,'' if the East Germans' ''wages, pensions and subsidies are also paid in Deutschemarks.''
''And if the strong mark is threatened and Bonn has to go deeper into debt, will taxes rise?'' the article asked.
The anxiety was even sharper in East Germany, where the introduction of the Deutschemark threatened to upset not only savings and pensions, but to drive uncompetitive enterprises rapidly out of business and their employees out of work.
''Someone who speaks quickly and happily only of an unstable G.D.R. or its troubled economy must be asked in the end if he does not want to lower the price of unification to the disadvantage of the people,'' Mr. Modrow said at a news conference Tuesday.
But many West Germans seemed increasingly to accept the prospect that whatever the cost of monetary union, there was no other choice, and to feel that it was best to act quickly.
 
'What Does Economics Count?'
''What does economics count in times like these?'' asked Edzard Reuter, the head of Daimler Benz. ''It's a political decision. I think it's politically correct, and we all have to support it.''
Part of such thinking was based on the fact that little anyone did in East or West seemed to have any effect on the exodus of East Germans. More than 1,800 continue to leave every day, and polling by West German officials showed increasingly that the resettlers simply saw no reason to remain in East Germany, whatever happened there.
The prospect of a democratically elected government's coming to power after the March 18 elections held out little hope for a quick improvement in morale. Officials in Bonn said it would take time for the new leaders to find their way, and West German politicians, locked in their own campaign, were in any case likely to continue trying to direct affairs in the East.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A supplementary budget of $4.1 billion, most of it to shore up East Germany until reunification, was approved by Bonn yesterday, but none of it will go to the interim government of Prime Minister Hans Modrow, who ended his visit to the West after falling in his bid for $9 billion in emergency money. (Reuters) (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: Marseilles Journal;
Murder, Racism, Drugs, Graft: Fact or Folklore?

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARSEILLES, France, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The good citizens who are dedicated to rescuing Marseilles from its image as a violent, corrupt, racist and generally-to-be-avoided city are understandably gloomy these days as they try to explain that things are not the way they look.
The problem this time is a body, a body of the bullet-riddled variety that has a way of evoking gang warfare. The victim was a local politician who, the police say, was ordered killed by another politician, all of which also suggests something is amiss in public life here.
Then there is the link to a supposed ''war'' between private health clinics since the latest victim and a man slain here 20 months ago were doctors and two of the men now under arrest for involvement in both killings are also doctors. Control of lucrative clinics, it would seem, was a factor. 
But the problems facing the image builders of Marseilles run deeper. It is not simply that this case has won headlines around France because it fits into what the distraught Mayor of Marseilles, Robert Vigouroux, calls the country's ''caricatured view'' of this proudly cosmopolitan Mediterranean port.
 
More Than Meets the Eye
It is also that the natives of Marseilles are avid students of politics whose daily bread comprises speculation, rumor-mongering and conspiracy-building. And for them, at least, there are enough other loose elements around to convince that much more - not less - is involved than meets the eye.
In the bars that circle the old port, one line of logic leads to drugs. Marseilles's role in the French connection of heroin flowing into the United States ended early in the 1970's, but more recently Government officials have warned that traffickers may be laundering drug money through here.
Political foes are trying to incriminate Mr. Vigouroux, not only because he visited Panama when it was still run by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but also because he appointed the murder victim to be a district mayor and received campaign contributions from one of the suspected killers.
Then there are doubts whether the slain politician, Jean-Jacques Peschard, was after all ''the good doctor'' he was made out to be. Six years ago, his mistress, Christine Barras, disappeared mysteriously and while Dr. Peschard was never charged in the case the police dug up his back garden in search of a body.
 
'It Is All False'
All this has provided a field day for French newspapers intent on showing Marseilles the way most Frenchmen think it is - a mixture of Chicago in the 1930's and Medellin today where life is cheap, politics are crooked and the natives are innately dishonest. ''It is all false,'' the Mayor said.
Two years ago, convinced that Marseilles's poor image was keeping away private investors and contributing to the city's economic troubles, a group of business and civic associations formed an organization called New Outlook on Marseilles dedicated to fighting back. The local Bar Association, which joined last month, has now pledged to sue newspapers that defame the city.
''Why do people get indignant?'' asked Laurent Gilardino, news editor at the daily Le Meridional. ''First, they feel vulnerable. Second, what happens here is often not the fault of the people of Marseilles but of geography. Third, if this happened elsewhere, it would not be blamed on the people.''
Charges of racism, for example, stem from the fact that, in the first round of the 1988 presidential elections, Jean-Marie Le Pen, head of the xenophobic National Front, won 28.4 percent of the votes here. Yet while migrants from North Africa represent almost one-quarter of the port's one million population, racial incidents here are rare.
Having served as the main port of entry of successive waves of invaders and migrants since its foundation 2,600 years ago, Marseilles in fact seems comfortable with its role as melting pot. Its main complaint is economic, seeing the burden of absorbing migrants as one reason for high unemployment.
According to the national police, even Marseilles's reputation for violence is undeserved, with murders and armed robberies here proportionately no higher than, say, in Paris. ''Organized crime is much less structured than people think,'' a police spokesman said.
Michael Anselme, a local sociologist, agreed. ''Criminals don't exercise political influence here,'' he said. ''The underworld is violent but the city is not. There is gang rivalry, they settle their accounts with guns, but they shoot straight.''
Nonetheless, the ''war of the clinics,'' as it is known here, may take some unraveling. A shady underworld figure, Roger Memmoli, has confessed to killing both Dr. Peschard and Dr. Leonce Mout, the owner of a large clinic gunned down in May 1988. He said he did so on orders of Dr. Armand Gallo, who is also a municipal councillor.
 
No Drug Connection Found
The police have also arrested Marcel Long, who supposedly acted as Mr. Memmoli's driver, as well as Marc Galeazzi, who worked for Dr. Mout, and Dr. Jean Couraqui, who owns four health clinics and was rebuffed in his attempts to buy Dr. Mout's clinc. They have denied the charges, although Dr. Gallo has admitted asking Mr. Memmoli to give Dr Peschard ''a fright.''
So far, no drug connection has been found, while Mr. Vigouroux has explained that he visited Panama in 1986 to support a bid for a contract by a local company and received General Noriega in Marseilles when he traveled to France a few months later to be honored by the French Government.
But whatever the final outcome in this case, all the stereotypes about Marseilles have already been recycled. The weekly Le Point even opened its coverage with what it said was the latest joke in the city.
''Herbert von Karajan is dead,'' a man told his wife, referring to the late conductor. ''Who bumped him off?'' his 4-year-old son inquired innocently.

GRAPHIC: Photo: French newspapers have used events like the murder of Jean-Jacques Peschard, a local politician, to portray Marseilles as a generally-to-be-avoided city where life is cheap, politics are crooked and the natives are innately dishonest. Policemen inspected Dr. Peschard's car after his assassination last month. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Cheney Begins Asian Trip Seen as a Prelude to Military Cuts

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney arrived in Asia today for 10 days of talks that allies of the United States see as a prelude to a major reduction of American forces in the Philippines and South Korea, and to renewed tensions with Japan over its contribution to the American military's huge presence here.
The trip is expected to be particularly tense for Mr. Cheney, especially in the Philippines, where President Corazon C. Aquino said Sunday that she would not meet the Defense Secretary in a widening dispute with the United States over military aid and criticisms of her performance.
But it will also be delicate in South Korea, where Mr. Cheney arrived tonight. Anti-Americanism often runs high in Seoul, where a giant United States base still dominates a hilltop in the middle of the city, but the South Korean Government has been anxious in recent weeks that a large pullout might be particularly dangerous now. 
 
More Reductions Expected
Mr. Cheney has said repeatedly that he has no plans for immediate, dramatic changes in 120,000 forces in the Pacific, but he has also left open the possibility of significant reductions.
So far the only big reduction announced by the Pentagon has come in South Korea, where two air bases are being turned over to South Korean forces and about 2,000 jobs - mostly support staff - are being eliminated.
But there is a widespread expectation that in the next few months Mr. Cheney will announce reductions of another 4,000 to 5,000 of the 43,000 American military personnel there. Both South Koreans and Americans in Seoul agree that such cutbacks can be made without hurting American strength.
 
How Much Seoul Pays
But there are significant differences remaining. The United States says that South Korea currently pays about $300 million a year for stationing American military in the country; South Koreans say the figure is closer to $2 billion. Most analysts expect that South Korea will eventually be given the choice of paying more or watching half or more of the Americans go home.
South Korean officials say it will be a particularly dangerous time to cut the forces. Kim Il Sung's 42-year-old Government is one of the few Communist regimes so far unaffected by Eastern Europe's upheavals. When he dies, some experts predict a power struggle that could lead to a show of force on the DMZ, or demilitarized zone.
The Secretary's trip to the Philippines promises to be far less collegial. The leases on Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Station, two of America's biggest installations in the Pacific, expire next year and a majority of the Philippine Senate opposes renewal. Worsening matters, Congress recently reduced aid to the Philippines by $96 million, from the scheduled $360 million.
 
An Angry Reaction
The action led to widespread anger in the Philippine Government and accusations that Washington was failing to live up to its commitments. Mrs. Aquino, who has not said publicly whether she favors extension of the base leases, has said that Mr. Cheney should meet only with his counterpart, Defense Secretary Fidel V. Ramos.
The announcement was a slap at the United States, prompted not only by the aid cuts but also by recent American criticism of her failures to curb graft and corruption. Those were also the complaints of dissident military officers who unsuccessfully tried to oust her in a coup attempt in December; the coup failed when the United States called in two fighter jets. That intervention may also complicate matters, because Mrs. Aquino is now widely viewed as owing her tenure to the United States.
American officials say they are scurrying to develop alternatives if they lose the bases. But the bases pump about $1 billion a year into the local economy, a fact some politicians are considering.
Mr. Cheney has said he is not bringing any messages about the base negotiations, but he decided to cut his trip to the Philippines short. ''It's too bad Mrs. Aquino didn't want to host me,'' he said in Honolulu earlier in the week. ''That's her choice. I've got plenty to do there to keep me busy.''
In Japan, Mr. Cheney expected to press for further modernization of the Japanese military.
''We want them to pay more, but they are already covering more than any other country does,'' an American official said here.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;
In Choice of Ambassadors, Prague Leans Toward the Symbolic

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Rudolf Slansky, a disenchanted former Communist whose father, the General Secretary of the party, was hanged in 1952 after a Stalinist show trial, has been appointed Ambassador to the Soviet Union.
''It is an excellent idea,'' President Vaclav Havel said in an interview, approving Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier's nominee. ''It is exactly in my symbolic and metaphoric way of political thinking.''
Not much less symbolic of Czechoslovakia's radical reorientation of its foreign policy, which until the overthrow of the Communist leadership last December was dictated by the Soviet Union and consistently hostile to the United States, was the appointment of Rita Klimova as Ambassador to Washington. 
Mrs. Klimova owes her survival to the asylum that the United States gave her and her family in 1939, after Germany seized Czechoslovakia. Her father, the late Stanislav Budin, was a noted Communist journalist, and because they were Jews, all the family's lives were at risk.
 
Deep Anti-Semitism
The elder Slansky, also named Rudolf, was chief defendant in a trial that occurred at the height of Stalin's drive against Jews and was marked by virulent anti-Semitism. Mr. Slansky and virtually all his co-defendants were Jews. He was falsely condemned as a Zionist and ''imperialist'' agent.
The new Ambassador spent the war years in the United States, where his father served as an international Communist functionary. He joined the Communist Party even after his father's execution, because he believed the idea of communism to be purer than Communists.
Mrs. Klimova was also a Communist - ''very fanatical, I might even say'' - and both the new Ambassadors were purged from the party after the Soviet-led invasion in 1968, which they condemned. They were enthusiastic supporters of the reforms that brought on the invasion and dissidents until the peaceful revolution of last autumn.
Last November and December, Mrs. Klimova served as the voice of Civic Forum, the movement that led the overthrow of the Communist Government. She was the interpreter at the many news conferences in which Mr. Havel and his supporters proclaimed the goals of their movement.
The future Ambassador was regarded as more than a mere interpreter of the opposition's words into her fluent English, which bears the stamp of her formative years on New York's Upper West Side, together with the lilt of Czech singsong. By her tone of voice and her expressive features, the 58-year-old former economics lecturer added drama and conviction to words that stirred her and disdain to questions that she deemed unsympathetic.
 
'Embassy About-Face'
Mrs. Klimova is expected to have the easier task of the two. ''My main job will be to make the embassy about-face,'' she said as she sorted a chaos of papers in her apartment a few days before her departure on Feb. 12. ''It was concerned primarily with making Americans uninterested in Czechoslovakia and keeping them out of this country.''
Mr. Slansky's assignment will be more delicate. ''The great issue is to finish changing our relationship from unequal to equal,'' he said. The difficult present negotiations over Czechoslovak demands that the Soviet Army withdraw illustrate the difficulties of the 55-year-old Mr. Slansky's mission.
The Ambassador acknowledged ''mixed feelings'' over what lies ahead. But he emphasized that despite the personal and political harm he suffered under earlier Soviet leaders, he bore no resentment to the nation and its present head.
 
Deep Ties to Moscow
''I have of course a personal attitude toward the Soviet Union, but I never linked what Soviet leaders do or what happened to my family to the Soviet people,'' he said, in slow but exact English. ''I always made that difference.'' Whatever his sentiments toward those who decided the invasion of 1968, he said, ''I didn't hate the soldiers on the tanks.''
Mr. Slansky said that above all the Soviet Union must be seen as a superpower on the border. ''Our contacts with that country are part of our lives,'' he said. ''We need to look at it very realistically, not emotionally. Emotionally is possible, but not useful.''
Mr. Slansky said his reflections after the invasion led him to speak for pragmatism instead of political dogma. ''The lesson that I learned was that democracy is completely incompatible with rule by one, totalitarian party, even if people in it have good intentions.'' he said. ''A pluralistic political system is the only way.''
An economist, Mr. Slansky stressed the importance of relations with the country with which Czechoslovakia does 40 percent of its trade. While Prague is seeking to reorient exports to capitalist countries, the Ambassador said its national interest required that it remain on good trading terms with the country that provides 87 percent of its energy needs and most raw materials.
''We need the Soviet Union more than it needs us,'' he said. ''Our interest is to have the best possible relations, politically and economically.''
 
Aid From Washington
Mrs. Klimova hopes to attract American educational and technological assistance, as well as investment. Speaking of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's visit last week, she said: ''We told Baker that for the previous Government, the exchanges specified in our cultural and technological agreement were the ceiling. Now we would like to perceive this as the floor.''
The Ambassador was married to Zdenek Mlynar, a top Communist official until he, too, became a dissident and was expelled to Austria. Mr. Mlynar was a friend of Mikhail S. Gorbachev during their student days in Moscow.
''Whenever he went to visit Moscow, I bought shirts and shoes for Gorbachev here for him to take along,'' she recalled. Mrs. Klimova, who has two children and one grandchild, was widowed after her second marriage.
Her commitment to Communism, which made her interrupt her education to work for a year in a factory after her return from the United States in 1946, ''to get close to the working class,'' weakened while she taught the history of economic thought at Charles University in the 1960's.
Ousted as a lecturer after the invasion, she was relegated to the university's accounting office and finally dismissed. She earned a living for herself and her children as a simultaneous interpreter. But when the Charter 77 dissident movement was born she was reduced to written translating only, until she re-emerged as the English voice of the Civic Forum movement.
''My English saved my life,'' the Ambassador said.

HEADLINE: Moscow Pays the Price

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
For months now, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been playing a poor hand so deftly that it has often looked like a good one.
But by giving in to President Bush on troop levels and to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany on reunification, he has laid bare the strategic weakness of his country in a dramatic way. Beset by economic problems at home, by the growing independence of the onetime satellite nations in Eastern Europe and by the decline of Communism almost everywhere, the Soviet leader has abandoned important Soviet objectives and fallen in line with positions long held in the West.
''They seem ready to to pay almost any reasonable price for peace and stability in Europe so that they can concentrate on their other problems,'' a senior European official said of Mr. Gorbachev and his Kremlin allies. 
Yuri V. Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador in Washington, objected mildly to the suggestion that his country had ''caved in'' to Mr. Bush, but he conceded: ''It's a kind of interpretation. We have difficulties in our country.'' New Challenge for Bush Unlike his predecessors, who had to calculate their policies on the basis of Soviet strength, taking care to avoid inadvertent provocations, President Bush is increasingly faced with a wholly different problem. Soviet weakness presents the United States with a panorama of opportunity, but he must not exploit his openings so aggressively that he weakens Mr. Gorbachev - or at least so his advisers figure.
Great powers do not ordinarily agree, and agree quickly, to let their erstwhile (and possibly future) enemies maintain more troops in an important area than they are permitted to maintain - especially when the new levels mean a complete reversal of a balance that has prevailed for 45 years.
But Mr. Gorbachev has not only agreed to cut his forces in central Europe by about 375,000 troops, while the United States cuts only about 80,000; he has agreed to allow the United States to keep 30,000 troops in Europe that will not be offset by Soviet forces.
Four days ago, in a last effort to maintain parity, Mr. Gorbachev had said he could not accept the extra 30,000, which struck many Western analysts as reasonable enough.
Only after lengthy negotiations did it seem likely that President Bush could put his proposal across, if at all. Indeed, while Mr. Bush was saying publicly on Monday that he would stick by his proposal and insist on the imbalance, one of his key advisers was saying that perhaps some other way would have to be found to make the point that the allies wanted American troops to stay in Europe, regardless of Soviet troop levels.
It turned out that no other way of delivering the message was needed.
 
A Vast Concession on Germany
On Germany, likewise, Mr. Gorbachev has given up something of tremendous importance. The de facto partition of Germany was carried out in the first place largely because of Soviet fears that a united Germany would seek once more to dominate Europe. Devastated by German arms in World War II, two generations of Russians saw East Germany as the key buffer to the west.
Now Mr. Gorbachev has not only given his hesitant blessing to an eventual reunification, but has agreed to the creation of a structure to oversee security aspects of the state.
That, too, surprised Mr. Bush, who said on Monday that it was too early for a four-power meeting on the future of Germany. Today he conceded he had been taken aback and commented a bit ruefully, ''Things move quite fast there.''
In both instances, Mr. Gorbachev's hand was forced by the disaffection of the former Soviet satellites.
With Czechslovakia and Hungary and Poland all asking that Soviet troops be called home, and negotiations on that subject under way, the deal that Mr. Bush offered may be better, however unequal, to what he could get a year from now. What Mr. Gorbachev has agreed to confers a certain legitimacy on the presence of 195,000 Soviet troops in the so-called central zone of Europe at a time when there are prospects that the actual figure might soon fall below that.
 
Holding the Line at 195,000
As defined in arms negotiations, Europe's central zone embraces West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Denmark and all of the countries in Eastern Europe except Romania and Bulgaria.
Mr. Bush's critics at home have suggested that 195,000 is too high. But the Soviet acceptance of that level makes it more likely that the President will be able to hold the line there, at least for a few months - which is an eternity in European affairs these days.
With East Germany agreeing to a common currency with West Germany and moving rapidly toward informal unification on a dozen fronts, a supervisory role for the Soviet Union in company with the western Big Three may be the most Mr. Gorbachev could ever expect in the way of a brake on any German expansionary tendencies.
Once again, then, Mr. Gorbachev has shown himself the supreme realist, a man prepared to ratify reality when events threaten to get away from him, rather than railing at the moon. But he is fighting a rear-guard action; what he can realistically hope to achieve from his position of weakness at home and abroad keeps shrinking. Softening on German Neutrality? Perhaps the most vivid evidence of that is the significant softening, little noticed in the rush of news in the last 24 hours, of Soviet insistence on a neutral status for a new Germany. Asked today whether the Soviet Union would continue to oppose any association with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, sounded less than confident.
''I think that the ideal solution would be a neutral Germany,'' he said. ''How realistic that is is a question. I would not rule out some NATO role and some Warsaw Pact role.''
East German subservience to Moscow is gone. The next Soviet line of defense, wholehearted East German adherence to the Warsaw Pact, has been breached, and so has the next, the survival of East Germany in almost any form. Now Moscow is apparently even prepared to contemplate some form of affiliation for a unified Germany with the once-hated enemy, NATO.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Who's Z? A Former Student Points to a Berkeley History Professor

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
A history professor at the University of California at Berkeley has been identified by other scholars as a likely author of a pseudonymous article asserting that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will bring neither democracy nor a market economy to the Soviet Union.
The article, a sharp critique of Mr. Gorbachev's policies, was published in the quarterly Daedalus under the pseudonym Z. A person who identified himself as a former student at the university said the author was Prof. Martin E. Malia, a professor of European intellectual and Russian history at Berkeley.
The former student, Ken B. Gleason, said he took a seminar from Mr. Malia in 1988 and later assisted him by retyping part of a manuscript used for the article in Daedalus. An essay adapted from the Daedalus article was published on the Op-Ed Page of The New York Times on Jan. 4. 
In a telelphone interview today, Mr. Malia would not confirm authorship, but said he had given a ''long interview'' to Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, discussing ideas in the essay.
 
Authorship 'a Bit Complicated'
''To me, the interesting problem is not who wrote the article, but what's in it,'' Mr. Malia said. He said he was pleased that the people at Pravda ''took the trouble'' to study the article and analyze its ideas. By contrast, he said, Americans have focused on the question of authorship and paid less attention to the substance of the article.
Daedalus is published in Cambridge, Mass., by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. The editor, Stephen R. Graubard, would not identify the author, but said today that the question of authorship was ''a bit complicated.''
''Whoever the author or authors were, there must have been a very compelling reason for the anonymity,'' Mr. Graubard said, hinting for the first time that there could have been more than a single author.
In a letter to The New York Times, Mr. Gleason said, ''Professor Malia's intellectual rigor is widely known.'' He also said that Mr. Malia ''is extremely conservative and strongly anti-Communist.''
The article by Z says that Mr. Gorbachev's policies of economic restructuring and political openness, perestroika and glasnost, have ''only aggravated the systemic crisis they were intended to alleviate.'' The ''instrument of Mr. Gorbachev's reform,'' the Soviet Communist Party, is the basic cause of many Soviet problems, it says.

HEADLINE: As the Fears of Famine Grow in Ethiopia, War Imperils Relief

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SENAFE, Ethiopia

 BODY:
The intensity of the Ethiopian civil war is seriously threatening efforts to deliver famine relief to peasants afflicted by a drought even more severe in some areas than during the catastrophic famine and mass starvation of 1984-85, Western officials say.
Enough food has started to arrive in Ethiopia to stave off starvation on that order, the officials say. But they are losing confidence that as each side in the conflict tries to deny the other food, the relief will reach the neediest. [Heavy fighting in the last week at the port of Massawa, the main entry point for Western-donated food, halted the delivery of 50,000 tons, enough for three million people for a month. Western relief officials were uncertain whether they could come up with alternate delivery routes before Ethiopians became too weak to walk to distribution points. ''This has the potential of being extraordinarily dramatic and catastrophic,'' said Willard J. Pierson, the head of the United States Agency for International Development in Addis Ababa.] Militia Gets Food First Western officials in Addis Ababa say the Government's relief arm, the Relief and Rehabilitation Agency, started distributing Western relief food to its armed militia before it made its first major distribution to civilians. 
In another incident, a United Nations monitor stood by helplessly at a distribution point in a Government-held part of Eritrea as soldiers rounded up teen-age boys for military service. The boys had come with their families to a food distribution in January.
Here in Senafe, the last Government-held town before the border of rebel-held Tigre, a group of visitors saw militiamen, Kalishnikovs slung over their shoulders, being given large sacks of grain from the depot of the Relief and Rehabilitation Agency. Four United Nations trucks with Canadian and European Community wheat pulled up outside the depot as militiamen heaved bulging grain sacks across their backs or onto the backs of donkeys.
In Asmara, the provincial capital of Eritrea, the deputy administrator of the province, Yishak Tsgaye, said the militia was ''given priority because there is no fixed salary or privileges.'' It is the militiamen's duty to patrol their village in return for the food, Mr. Yishak said.
About ''20,000 peasants are armed on the side of the Government,'' he said. These are given enough food for themselves and their families, a total of 100,000 people.
 
Rebel Warns of Attack
The leader of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, Isaias Afwerki, warned in an interview at his rebel headquarters in Sheeb in northern Eritrea recently that an attack on Massawa was imminent. Besides famine relief, the Government receives military supplies, mainly from the Soviet Union, at Massawa.
''We can't be sitting around while military preparations are going on around the cover of relief activities,'' the rebel leader said.
The Eritrean leader also expressed irritation that while many more peasants affected by the drought live under rebel control, more Western relief food was being transported to the Government side, particularly through Massawa. Because of rebel military victories in the last two years, only about one million of the more than four million affected peasants are in Government areas, according to Western estimates. Yet about four times more food has been pledged to the Government side.
This lopsided delivery puts the onus on the Addis Ababa Government to permit food to travel into rebel-held territory. So far, the militarily pressed Marxist-Leninist Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam has sent mixed signals.
Late last year the Government ordered a warehouse south of Addis Ababa to be emptied of 25,000 tons of Western food so that the building could be used for stepped-up military training. A United Nations official said that a protest was made but that the United Nations had still not been allowed to visit the warehouse to find out where the food went or what condition it was in.
The Western aid officials say part of the price of entering into the relief business with the Government is putting up with such behavior. Who Gets Fed First? Foreign donor governments have known since the 1984-85 famine that relief food was going to the militia. This was overlooked then, a senior United Nations official said, on the theory that the militias were made up of poor farmers who had no other way of getting food.
But with much more serious fighting in the present drought and food playing a crucial role in the war - the side who can amass the most feels the most powerful - food aid to the militias is not quite as benign as United Nations officials argued it was in 1984-85.
''The issue is: who is going to get fed first,'' a United Nations official in Addis Ababa said. ''We don't condone it, we try to stop it, but we don't know that we can.''
Curiously, leaders of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front do not object to famine relief food being given to the Government militia. Mr. Isaias said that virtually every member of the rebel front had a relative on the Government side who was a member of the ''wheat militia.'' They had to belong to the militia to survive because of the scarcity of jobs, he said, adding, ''They are a good source of intelligence for us.''
A senior official in Addis Ababa, Ashegre Yeletu, denied that the Government gave wheat to the militia. ''The R.R.C. assistance goes directly to the needy,'' he said.
 
Distribution Called Justified
The supply of more food to the Government side than to the rebels who control more people is justified on a number of counts, Western officials said. First, the United Nations is the largest contributor of food from Western sources and without agreement from the Mengistu Government it will not deliver food to the rebels. The Government has always denied this permission.
Second, the Government has controlled Massawa, through which large quantities of food can be most efficiently handled. And third, the Western donors have gambled that they will be able to persuade the Government to allow food to cross from Government territory into rebel-held areas.
But the Government has declined to allow the United Nations to carry food across the lines. Instead, it has offered a limited program that would allow a consortium of Ethiopian churches to deliver food to 400,000 people in rebel-held Tigre, where the United Nations says about 1.4 million of the more than four million people in need of food live.
Many of the Western governments, including the United States, are sending food directly to the rebels, although in smaller quantities. So far, 100,000 tons of Western food has been pledged to the rebels and about 390,000 tons to the Government side. The food for the rebels is shipped to Port Sudan, where it is picked up by rebel-owned trucks, many of them Mercedes-Benz's donated by the West, and taken over long and dangerous routes into Eritrea and Tigre.
The United States gives food to the rebels - 50,000 tons so far compared with 115,000 tons for the Government -but does not publicly acknowledge it. Officials say they fear that out of pique that the West is helping the rebels the Government will cut back or halt humanitarian aid to its own side.
Relief officials have described satellite images of Eritrea, Tigre and Wollo, the parched Ethiopian provinces largely under rebel control. The drought this time is more narrowly focused in area than in 1984-85 but is even more intense where it has hit.
 
The Rains Fail to Come
Outside a stone storehouse in Afabet, a forlorn rebel-held town wrecked by battle, about 1,000 Eritreans, many of them gaunt but not yet severely malnourished, milled around waiting for food handouts from the rebel relief operation, the Eritrean Relief Association.
Osman Ali, the 37-year-old father of five children, a tall bearded man with sunken cheeks, said he planted sorghum last August and waited for rain that never came. ''We had only one rain, an hour maybe,'' he said.
The 1984-85 famine was not as bad for him as this year. ''Then we had grass and the goats could feed,'' he said. ''Half my animals died last year. I have two goats left. But I can't sell the goats because they are too thin and no-one will buy them.''
''Anyway,'' he added, ''there's no one to buy them.''

LENGTH: 1207 words

HEADLINE: Some Find Mandela's Vision Limited

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Since Nelson Mandela emerged from prison Sunday, his public remarks have generally fallen short of the expectations of many whites and some blacks who had anticipated the kind of inspirational vision that distinguished the late Dr. Martin Luther King in the American civil-rights struggle of the 1960's.
It appears that Mr. Mandela has been addressing his message primarily to those blacks loyal to the African National Congress, the organization to which he devoted his life, and only afterward to the broader nation. A notable exception has been his assurances voiced over the last three days that whites should not fear a democratic and nonracial South Africa.
''We are aware of the fears of the whites in this country of being dominated by blacks and we are addressing that very seriously,'' Mr. Mandela told reporters waiting outside his Soweto house today. He expressed the conviction that a solution acceptable to everyone could be worked out between his movement and the Government. 
 
'Loyal' to His Movement
The black nationalist leader, dignified and articulate, has cut an impressive figure as he has clearly evinced a a lack of bitterness over his lost years. But his first words, delivered at a rally in Cape Town, revealed that he has not changed much since he was jailed more than 27 years ago, and neither has the African National Congress.
''I am a loyal and disciplined member of the A.N.C.,'' Mr. Mandela announced. ''I am therefore in full agreement with all of its objectives, strategies and tactics.''
But if Mr. Mandela reflected the views of the Congress through his language, he was by the same token distancing himself from the outlook and style of black groups that have formed during his imprisonment. Mr. Mandela, who abounds in the appeal of a national leader, said he would journey to Lusaka, Zambia, to ask exiled leaders how his movement planned to use him.
He called for continuing guerrilla warfare and Western sanctions to bring down the white Government that freed him and confirmed that he supported the nationalization of mines and other vital areas of the economy, which sent waves through the Johannesburg stock and foreign-exchange markets this week. Here he was articulating policies long advocated by the African National Congress and its ally, the South African Communist Party, which Mr. Mandela also praised.
 
A White Deplores Raised Fist
Mr. Mandela failed to follow the practice, common among Western politicians in a television era, of having different speeches for their political constituencies and the larger world. He displayed consistency in his language, even if it was not what most white South Africans wanted to hear.
''When he came out, I had tears in my eyes,'' said a middle-aged white woman in Johannesburg who had watched the Mr. Mandela's release on television. ''He seemed so dignified and contented. Then his fist went up and I was disappointed.''
Some whites felt that President F. W. de Klerk, who took a political risk in releasing Mr. Mandela, had been damned with faint praise. The black leader called Mr. de Klerk ''a man of integrity,'' then qualified that by saying that he had not done enough.
A white lawyer from Pretoria who voted for Mr. de Klerk said that if Mr. Mandela reaches out to Mr. de Klerk, he might succeed him as President of South Africa. But he added:
''If Mandela comes in with this kind of jargon, he's going to cause de Klerk to lose his power base, and de Klerk's the only man that can save this country,'' the lawyer said, referring to pressure on the President from the white right wing.
 
Missed Opportunity
Other whites sympathetic to Mr. Mandela said he had missed a prime opportunity to galvanize all South Africans. On Monday evening, a disk jockey told listeners of Radio 702, a popular rock-music station in Johannesburg, that the speech delivered by Mr. Mandela ''could have been written for him by Karl Marx.''
Some blacks also confessed to being disappointed by Mr. Mandela's remarks. ''He paid much more attention to what the A.N.C. stands for than what he stands for,'' said a 20-year-old woman. ''He should have come out as an individual because we already know what the A.N.C. stands for.''
So far, Mr. Mandela has barely reached out to other political currents among the country's blacks. By some estimates, the African National Congress may have the support of 45 to 60 percent of black South Africans. But other support goes to the rival Pan-Africanist Congress, which puts strict emphasis on black unity; the Black Consciousness Movement, the Zulu political movement Inkatha, and conservative religious groups like the evangelical Zion Christians.
 
A Call for Unity
At his Monday news conference, Mr. Mandela recognized that Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, who leads Inkatha, was ''a figure with a following,'' if not one as large as that enjoyed by the African National Congress. On Tuesday, he called on all blacks to ''unite against the perpetrators of violence'' in Natal province, the scene of factional fighting between supporters of Inkatha and the United Democratic Front.
The Azanian People's Organization, which preaches an ideology of black consciousness, welcomed Mr. Mandela's release in a statement Sunday but hoped he would aspire to a broader black leadership role.
''Mandela would do the struggle a great service if he were to rise above the confines of his organization and preside over the greater whole in striving for the unity of the oppressed,'' it said.
A similar view was express by the National Council of Trade Unions, which is aligned with the Pan-Africanist Congress.
By Tuesday, Mr. Mandela seemed to broaden his message at a major rally near Soweto. His unqualified condemnation of the crisis conditions that apartheid had created in the segregated townships, from inferior education and housing to a high crime rate, was cheered by blacks who knew better than whites what Mr. Mandela was talking about.
Later that day, Gerrit Viljoen, the Constitutional Development Minister whom President de Klerk has entrusted with starting negotiations on a new constitution that would give blacks a political voice, conceded that Mr. Mandela's remarks on armed struggle had not been helpful but observed that he was speaking ''within the confines and discipline of A.N.C. policy.''
Analyzing his first speech Sunday, Business Day, a newspaper based in Johannesburg, said: ''The address for which the country has waited for nearly three decades did not lend stature to a momentous event. It showed how little the A.N.C. has learned in that time, and how little it has moved.''
Why Mr. Mandela chose to give a partisan political speech when a far-larger audience was waiting has been the subject of debate. Some political commentators said he wanted to prove to the African National Congress and its followers that he had not sold them out in his discussions with the Government while he was in prison.
An acquaintance of Mr. Mandela said he had written his speech in prison, but left his copy with his reading glasses in his prison bungalow when he departed and had to rewrite it from memory. If that is so, it is not clear whether it differed from the original.

LENGTH: 761 words

HEADLINE: M.I.T. Selects Highly Regarded Biologist on Its Faculty as President

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14

 BODY:
The governing board of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has decided to name a highly regarded biologist from its own faculty, Phillip A. Sharp, as the school's new president, university officials disclosed today.
The officials said Dr. Sharp, a 46-year-old cancer researcher who was a surprise choice, had been picked by the board's executive committee as its nominee for president. The governing board's formal approval is still needed, and it will vote at its next meeting on March 2. But Dr. Sharp is the sole nominee and is not expected to face serious opposition, the officials said. 
The choice of Dr. Sharp, a professor of biology and director of M.I.T.'s Center for Cancer Reseach, ends a heated search that began last summer after the current president, Paul E. Gray, announced he would retire this June. Two of the original leading candidates for the post took themselves out of the running, while professors, administrators and students saw the selection process as a forum to debate issues like the school's close ties to military-related research and a perceived national decline in the influence of scientists.
 
'A Superb Scientist'
Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics who served as chairman of the faculty advisory committee on the search for a new president, said Dr. Sharp had been picked because he was ''a superb scientist.''
''One of the most important things for the presidency of M.I.T. is to have the complete respect of the faculty, and Phil Sharp will have it,'' Professor Solow said in an interview today.
Professor Solow said Dr. Sharp had also been chosen with an eye to making the president of the university more of a national spokesman for science and improving the prestige and influence of scientists. ''We have the feeling that science and engineering need to regain the confidence of the country, and Phil can speak from an unassailable perspective,'' Professor Solow said.
Lucien Pye, a professor of political science at M.I.T., said there had been a widespread feeling among the faculty that the influence of scientists in Washington had been slipping since the glory days of the late 1940's, 50's and 60's. In those years James R. Killian Jr. was president of M.I.T. and served as science adviser to President Dwight D. Eisenhower. President John F. Kennedy picked another M.I.T. scientist, Jerome B. Wiesner, who later became the school's president.
Despite his outstanding reputation as a scientist, Dr. Sharp was a surprise choice because he has not been active in campus administrative politics. Professor Pye and several other M.I.T. professors interviewed today did not immediately recognize Dr. Sharp's name.
The selection was also regarded as something of a break with M.I.T. tradition because his field is biology. Most of his predecessors were electrical engineers, physicists or management experts.
But his choice underscores the increasingly prominent role of biology at M.I.T., the nation's premier technological university. Four of M.I.T.'s eight Nobel laureates are in the biology department, and much of the school's new research financing has gone into biology in the past decade with the explosion of interest in biotechnology.
 
Native of Kentucky
Dr. Sharp, who was born and brought up on a small farm in Kentucky and received his undergraduate degree from Union College in Barbourville, Ky., is widely considered one of the nation's top molecular biologists.
For his work in clarifying the functions of genetic material inside cells, Dr. Sharp received the presitigious Albert E. Lasker Basic Medical Research Award in 1988.
David Eisenberg, a professor of molecular biology at the University of Southern California at Los Angeles, who has the co-author of a research paper with Dr. Sharp, described him as ''a scientist's scientist.'' ''I think of him as an extremly able pure scientist,'' Dr. Eisenberg said. ''He is also very good at working with people.''
Dr. Sharp, who received his Ph.D., in chemistry, from the University of Illinois, said he would not comment until he had been officially confirmed.
The initial front-runner for the job was John Deutch, a chemist who is M.I.T.'s provost. But last month Mr. Deutch, who had come under criticism from some professors and students for close ties to the military and to private businesses, withdrew as a candidate.
The other major candidate, Dr. David Baltimore, a Nobel laureate and director of M.I.T.'s Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research, became president of Rockefeller University in New York.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Phillip A. Sharp, a professor of biology, has been selected as the new president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Moynihan Befuddles Democrats With Idea

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
When Democrats don't know what to do, they form a task force. The latest one includes all the top party leaders and committee chairmen from the Senate and the House. It is supposed to decide how the party should respond to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan to lower the Social Security tax.
After the last meeting, just before Congress left town for a 10-day vacation, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said a consensus had been reached on two points: ''One, we ought to act in concert. Two, we can't agree on what we should do.'' 
Here are some choices:
Adopt the Moynihan proposal. This is attractive politically. It would give middle-income working families a tax cut of about $500 a year. Democrats could compare that with President Bush's proposal to lower the capital-gains tax rate, from which 83 percent of the benefits would go to taxpayers with annual incomes over $100,000, according to Congressional tax specialists. Democrats could also argue, with some good statistics to back them up, that a cut in the Social Security payroll tax (half of which is paid by employers) would generate more jobs and economic growth than a cut in the capital gains tax.
But there is a problem. The Moynihan plan would cost the Government $62 billion over the next two years in lost revenue. For that reason, no influential Democrat has supported the plan. The tax committee chairmen, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, actively oppose it. The Moynihan plan will not become law.
Adopt the Moynihan proposal and make up the lost revenue by imposing a value-added tax, or national sales tax. This is what Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina has proposed. But the Congressional Budget Office has found that the Hollings plan would result in a 20 percent tax increase for the poorest one-fifth of Americans. Upper-income Americans would get an overall tax cut. So this won't become law either.
Adopt the Moynihan proposal and make up the lost revenue by raising the income tax rate paid by the wealthy. This is what the old liberal Democrats would have sponsored. You can almost hear them on the stump: ''Who gets the benefit? You do, the working men and women of America. Who pays for it? They do, the fat cats who live in the big houses and drive the fancy cars.''
The problem here is that the Democrats are gun-shy. For a decade now, Republicans have beaten them about the head and shoulders for wanting to raise taxes. Even though, counting their employers' share, three-quarters of Americans pay more in Social Security taxes than in income taxes, polls show that a vast majority would rather have a cut in income taxes than in Social Security taxes. Why? Presumably because they tally up their income taxes each spring, and so they know how much they pay. Few people pay attention at the end of the year to how much was taken out of their pay in Social Security taxes. So this idea probably won't fly either.
Adopt President Bush's proposal. Following the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit limits, the President would have a balanced budget over all by 1993. After that, he would begin using the surplus in Social Security revenue to retire the national debt.
Even if this did not have Mr. Bush's name on it, the Democrats would probably oppose the plan because it would continue to allow Social Security revenue to pay general operating expenses of the Government through 1996 and because its primary aim is to require further cuts in domestic spending. Since it is Mr. Bush's proposal, the Democratic lawmakers will reject it out of hand.
Remove Social Security from the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings calculations. This is what the smart money says the Democrats will propose. It would mean that the true size of the Government's operating deficit would be immediately apparent, and presumably embarrassing to President Bush. And it would mean the annual budget deficit targets would have to be rewritten.
The last thing the President wants to do now is change the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit targets. Democrats supported those targets when they were drawn in 1987 because they required equal cuts in domestic and military spending. But now military spending is being cut anyway. So the targets have become a way to insure cuts in domestic programs.
If the Democrats propose this plan, President Bush will veto it.

HEADLINE: Courage in Colombia

 BODY:
President Bush journeys today to what may be the most security-conscious ''summit meeting'' in history: a six-hour conference on drug trafficking at a heavily guarded naval base in Colombia. To assure his safety, hundreds of undercover agents worked the streets, bars and beaches of nearby Cartagena, frogmen searched the waters offshore for explosives, and handlers of Presidential aircraft tuned up their defenses against shoulder-fired missiles.
Mr. Bush's meeting with the Presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia isn't likely to produce much more than photo opportunities. So why take the risk? Because there is a clear and urgent need to support Andean countries in their struggle with cocaine cartels. The real challenge for the White House, apart from protecting the President, is to follow a symbolic visit with substantive help. 
For years Washington and the cocaine-producing countries did little more than trade excuses. The Andean governments aren't trustworthy, the Americans said. The Americans ought to curb their appetite for drugs, the Andeans responded. Then last summer, Colombian traffickers brazenly assassinated Luis Carlos Galan, a presidential candidate, arousing President Virgilio Barco to retaliate.
A string of successes followed: arrests and extraditions of traffickers; confiscations of real estate, vehicles and airplanes; destruction of cocaine laboratories; huge seizures of finished cocaine and chemicals used to manufacture it. The cartels fought back with bombings and kidnappings, but President Barco stood firm. A leading kingpin, Pablo Escobar, was forced into hiding; another, Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, died in a shootout with Colombian police.
These accomplishments make clear that the Colombians are no longer satisfied with excuses. That puts Washington on the spot. The time for symbolic gestures has passed. The moment for a major U.S. investment is at hand.
The Colombian offensive disrupted supply networks, thereby devastating the price of raw coca leaves from Peru and Bolivia as growers found it harder and harder to sell their crops. The price of 100 pounds of leaves declined from about $80 to about $40, and may now be as low as $10 in some places. That vastly reduces the profitability of coca, which once gave humble campesinos plenty of money for four-wheel-drive Toyotas and VCR's; it even threatens coca's viability as a cash crop.
American aid could speed that process. Military support would help sustain the offensive in Colombia and further disrupt the cartel's efforts to shift operations elsewhere. And an infusion of economic aid could energize nascent programs of crop substitution. Reduced profitability of coca greatly enhances their promise.
The drug strategy President Bush announced in January provides $423 million for anti-drug efforts in the Andean countries. That's a big increase over the $61 million budgeted only a year ago, but it's still far short of the need. Some experts estimate that it would take up to $1 billion annually to cure the Peruvian economy alone of its coca dependency.
Washington, of course, need not go it alone; funds could be marshaled from other international sources. But the progress so far holds out a tantalizing opportunity that ought not to be squandered for the sake of America's budget deficits. By going to the summit, Mr. Bush recognizes Colombia's courage - and underscores the need for stout-hearted leadership back home.

HEADLINE: Yes, Cut Social Security Taxes

BYLINE: By Robert W. Kasten Jr.; Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, is a member of the Senate Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I became a Republican in large part because the G.O.P. offered a responsible alternative to Big Government. And by standing with the American people - liberating them from high taxes and government encroachment - the G.O.P. won three consecutive national landslides.
That's why I can't understand my party's reluctance to support Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in his effort to roll back Social Security taxes. The issue for Republicans is simple: Are we going to go forward or are we going to turn back? 
Two years ago, then-Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of New York, and I went forward by proposing a payroll tax cut as part of an omnibus jobs and economic growth bill. It was as clear then as it is now that the payroll tax is an outrageous burden on middle-income families.
Since 1955 the basic payroll tax has risen nearly 400 percent. Today, 74 percent of taxpayers pay more in combined payroll taxes than they do in income taxes.
The impact on family budgets has been devastating: from 1955 to 1988, the Federal tax burden on middle-income Americans rose twice as fast as their income. In 1955 a median-income family of four paid Federal taxes at an average rate of 9 percent a year. In 1970 it paid 16 percent, and by 1988, 24 percent.
While we've cut income taxes during the 1980's, most of those savings have been eroded by the 22 percent payroll tax increase. The maximum payroll tax for a one-earner family is now a whopping $6,360 a year.
Moreover, payroll taxes have hurt businesses and workers by increasing labor costs and the prices of goods - which hurts competitiveness -and reducing take-home pay. The high payroll tax has been especially burdensome to the self-employed, who have to pay both portions of the tax. Welfare recipients have been discouraged from taking entry-level jobs by the high tax on their first dollar of earnings.
So, I agree in principle with Senator Moynihan's proposal. However, I believe a more modest tax-cut plan has a better chance of passage. Therefore I recently introduced legislation that would cut the payroll tax for both employers and employees from the current 6.2 percent to 5.3, compared with 5.1 percent under the Moynihan plan. This would save families up to $519 per worker by 1992, while leaving a healthy reserve.
Allowing Americans to keep more money would boost the economy and raise private savings and investment. The Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation estimates that by the year 2000 this tax cut would add between 450,000 and 920,000 new jobs, raise the gross national product by almost $300 billion and increase investment capital by $180 billion.
We all cheered when President Bush told us not to ''mess'' with Social Security. He's right. Social Security is a compact between generations. We must not imperil the benefits that our current and future retirees are counting on - and we will not. But that compact does not provide for tax increases in the name of Social Security that only serve to mask the Federal deficit.
So I appeal to President Bush: Join us in enacting this pro-growth tax cut. Millions of Americans want to believe that the Administration is on their side. We can't let them down.

HEADLINE: In Trump v. Trump, the Focus Is on Lots of Fine Print

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
If and when Trump v. Trump goes to court, the main attraction in what already promises to be the most talked about and written about divorce proceeding in years could be four documents of about 35 pages apiece, each filled with paragraph after paragraph of fine print.
These are the prenuptial agreement that Donald J. and Ivana Trump worked out before their 1977 wedding and their three postnuptial agreements.
Regular readers of gossip columns, as opposed to law journals, may have the idea that only the rich and famous bother with pre- and postnuptial agreements as a way of keeping vast and complicated holdings from being divided in a divorce. But new divorce laws that redefined marriage as an ''economic partnership'' have made these agreements increasingly common among middle-income couples in New York and other states, lawyers say. 
Adding to the popularity of pre- and postnuptial agreements, said Lester Wallman, who served on the New York State Bar Association committee that helped write the new divorce law, were two 1988 appeals court decisions that made them ''almost irreversible.''
J. Michael Kennedy, the lawyer for Mrs. Trump in her attempt to undo her agreements with Mr. Trump, calls the accords ''unconscionable'' and ''fraudulent.''
 
Reams of Press Releases
Just what the Trumps' agreements say is unclear. Though both sides have issued reams of press releases since Mr. Trump said over the weekend that the marriage was over, neither side has made details of the matrimonial agreements public.
The prenuptial document was drafted with the aid of Roy M. Cohn, the lawyer, who died in 1986. Mr. Trump's spokesmen maintain that it and the postnuptial provisions entitle Mrs. Trump to $20 million and their house in Greenwich, Conn.
Divorce lawyers not involved in the case say Mrs. Trump may have a hard time challenging the validity of the documents.
''She's outside of the ball park seeking to get in,'' said Raoul Lionel Felder, who has represented Robin Givens, the former wife of the heavyweight boxer Mike Tyson; Lisa Gastineau, the former wife of the New York Jets defensive end Mark Gastineau, and Nancy Capasso, the former wife of Carl A. Capasso, companion of Bess Myerson.
Not many cases have made it into the ball park, Mr. Felder said, since a 1987 court decision involving Sol Goldman, who, like Mr. Trump, is a New York real-estate developer. ''The percentage is very small. It's rare for one to be set aside.'' Another Manhattan lawyer who specializes in divorce cases, Eleanor Alter, said she knew of only two cases in which a prenuptial agreement had been overturned in court, and both decisions came before New York State revised its divorce law 10 years ago. One case, she said, involved a woman, a patient in a mental hospital, who signed a prenuptial agreement while out on a weekend pass. In seeking to have the agreement nullified, Ms. Alter said, she testified that she had not understood what she was signing.
The way the law was revised, specialists in matrimonial law say, the principle of equitable distribution would apply if Mrs. Trump succeeded in having the agreements nullified. The law directs judges to make equitable -not necessarily equal - divisions of marital property, which is broadly defined as all family assets acquired during the marriage. Since 1980, when the equitable-distribution divorce law took effect, prenuptial agreements have increased by 20 percent, said Herman Tarnow, a Manhattan divorce lawyer.
 
Guidelines in Law
''Prenuptial agreements are to protect the have and limit the rights of the have-not,'' said Harriet N. Cohen, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in matrimonial cases.
To aid trial courts in distributing assets, the law sets forth guidelines about how long the marriage lasted and what contributions each partner made while they were married. This lets judges take into account whether one partner was primarily a wage earner and the other was primarily responsible for home life and children, if any.
Other lawyers said postnuptial agreements are often drawn up when a husband makes more money than he ever expected to, and he wants to demonstrate that his wife is entitled to more than was outlined in the prenuptial agreement.
But Mr. Tarnow said postnuptial agreements sometimes evolve after a wife discovers that her husband is having an affair. To mollify the wife, the husband agrees to sign over more than the prenuptial agreement called for. ''What a postnuptial does is eliminate jeopardy for a wife,'' Mr. Tarnow said. ''Sometimes that puts romance and relationship back in the marriage.''
In the Trumps' case, Mr. Trump said yesterday that he was the one who suggested the first postnuptial agreement. ''I thought it was appropriate,'' he said. ''I was upwardly mobile.'' ''This was not something done on the back of a matchbook,'' he added, ''but a lengthy document negotiated by a very competent woman, Ivana, and me and an attorney.''
 
Final Agreement
When asked why the couple had more than one postnuptial agreement, Mr. Trump said: ''We did it for whatever reason. Maybe she wanted.''
He said the final agreement, signed two years ago, promised ''many millions of dollars more and houses that weren't in the first one.'' He refused to give the specific terms, saying, ''It provides for everything, not only money, but future support, for the house, for apartments in New York City.''
''Three belongs in the Guinness Book,'' William D. Zabel, a Manhattan lawyer, said of the multiple postnuptial agreements. ''I've had substantial people break up in the negotiations. It's terribly sensitive. To do it so many times is terribly unusual, and I have to say it makes it harder for her to attack. She has to say they're all invalid because if the most recent one's invalid, it might revive the previous ones. It depends on how they're worded.''
As for Mrs. Trump's lawyer's claim of fraud, some lawyers doubt that he could make it stick.
''The fact that she signed them makes it almost impossible to show fraud or duress,'' Mr. Wallman said.
''If she is, on the one hand, asserting she has a tremendous business acumen and has helped her husband increase his wealth,'' said Louis I. Newman, another lawyer who handles divorces, ''it would be difficult to claim she didn't understand what she was signing. It's a very fine line she presently walks.''
