HEADLINE: Active or Passive Iran-Contra Role? Point-Blank Questioning for Reagan

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
When Ronald Reagan appears in a Federal courtroom on Friday, he is likely to be asked point-blank the fundamental questions about his role in the Iran-contra affair, which have gone unanswered for three years.
The videotaped testimony he is to give for the criminal trial of John M. Poindexter, his former national security adviser, may reveal with greater clarity than ever whether Mr. Reagan was an easily manipulated President, largely ignorant of the actions of his subordinates, or whether he assumed the much more active role in the affair that Mr. Poindexter has depicted.
A definitive account of Mr. Reagan's role has eluded investigations by a Presidential review board, the Iran-contra Congressional committees and an independent prosecutor. Mr. Reagan's own fragmentary and sometime contradictory statements have added to the confusion. And the conflicting accounts of his aides have left the precise nature of his role in doubt.
 
Image of Passive President
But the continuing inquiries have eroded the image of the passive President, which was described by a Presidential review board headed John G. Tower, the former Texas Senator. 
In the trial of Oliver L. North, a former National Security Council aide, defense lawyers unearthed previously undisclosed documents indicating that Mr. Reagan played an important part in plans to aid the contra rebels in Nicaragua at a time when Congress had banned direct aid.
Mr. Poindexter's lawyers, who sought Mr. Reagan's testimony, have gone even further. They have described the former President as a crucial witness who often met alone with Mr. Poindexter to provide him with direct policy guidance in the affair.
Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene has ruled that Mr. Poindexter's lawyers may ask Mr. Reagan 154 questions along with followup questions. The questions, which Mr. Poindexter's lawyers submitted to the judge and turned over to Mr. Reagan's lawyers, cover a wide range of topics, emphasizing contra aid activities. When defense lawyers complete their questioning of Mr. Reagan, lawyers for the special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, will cross-examine him.
Mr. Reagan's deposition comes a week after his lawyers declined to invoke executive privilege and said that the former President would comply with the judge's order compelling him to testify on videotape. Still unresolved, however, is whether Mr. Reagan must also turn over to Mr. Poindexter excerpts of his private diaries.
Mr. Poindexter, a retired rear admiral in the Navy, served as Mr. Reagan's national security adviser from December 1985 until he resigned in November 1986. In a trial scheduled to begin March 5, he faces five criminal charges, including accusations that he obstructed Congressional inquiries and made false statements to Congress about the Iran arms sales and efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels at a time when official assistance was banned.
Mr. Reagan's deposition could also shed further light on other issues. Did Mr. Reagan closely he oversee the sales of arms to Iran? How much did he know about his Administration's efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels? Did he ever authorize his subordinates to defy Congressional inquiries into the affair? Did his Vice President, George Bush, play a role?
Judge Greene has not yet ruled on whether the deposition will be taken in an open or closed session, but he expressed misgivings about holding the proceeding in public because of concerns about the inadvertent disclosure of classified information.
Today, lawyers for a group of news organizations urged Judge Green to take the deposition in public, saying adequate safeguards had been imposed to protect against such disclosures.
Whatever the judge decides, the videotapes will become public when they are played at Mr. Poindexter's trial.
In its final report, the Tower panel helped create the image of Mr. Reagan's hands-off role, criticizing him as a poor manager who placed too much responsibility in the hands of aides.
The commission reported that in January 1987 Mr. Reagan told the panel he was unaware of the role played by the National Security Council staff in supporting the contras. But in May 1987, Mr. Reagan said of his Administration's efforts to aid the contras: ''There's no question about my being informed. I've known what's going on there.''
Even so the aloof image remained largely intact through the Congressional hearings in 1987. In a final report in November 1987, the Congressional committees concluded that ''the central remaining question is the role of the President in Iran-contra affair.'' On this critical point, the report said that shredding of documents and death of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, ''leave the record incomplete.''
But there were suggestions that Mr. Reagan possessed greater knowledge. In his Congressional testimony, Mr. Poindexter told of once briefing Mr. Reagan in detail about the contra aid operation, but he said the President did not recall it. ''I frankly don't find that surprising,'' Mr. Poindexter said. ''It would not frankly, at that time, have been a matter of great interest as to exactly how we were implementing the President's policy.''
Robert C. McFarlane, Mr. Poindexter's predecessor in the post, testified that he briefed Mr. Reagan on ''dozens'' of occasions about contra activities, including battlefield actions and attitudes in Congress.
In the North trial last year, documents indicated for the first time that in 1985, Mr. Reagan approved an operation to send specialized intelligence equipment and weapons to rebel units inside Nicaragua so they could attack ships carrying weapons to Sandinista Government troops.
Other documents suggested Mr. Reagan approved a plan to provide millions of dollars in military and economic aid to Honduras on the condition that the country's Government allow contra bases on its territory and permit arms shipments to those bases at the time of the ban on direct aid.
 
Bush's Trip to Honduras
The documents contained notations that appeared to suggest that Mr. Bush was considered as a possible ''private emissary,'' who would be designated to travel to Honduras to seal a ''quid pro quo'' deal with Roberto Suazo Cordova, who was then the Honduran President. In March 1985 Mr. Bush traveled to Honduras to meet with Mr. Suazo. After the documents were disclosed in the North trial, Mr. Bush denied that he was the intermediary and insisted, ''There was no quid pro quo.'' Mr. Bush has said that he did not know about the contra aid effort until after it was disclosed in late 1986.
Mr. Reagan will probably be asked again whether he had a role in the Iran arms sales because one charge accuses Mr. Poindexter of obstructing Congress by helping to prepare a false chronology indicating that no one in the Government knew about the Israeli arms shipments to Iran in November 1985 until January 1986.
Mr. Poindexter testified at the Congressional hearings that Mr. Reagan approved the shipment of arms in November, when it took place. Mr. Poindexter said that in December 1985, Mr. Reagan signed an order retroactively authorizing American participation in the deal.
Mr. Poindexter said that after the affair became public in November 1986, he destroyed the signed authorization order because it appeared to describe the deal explicitly as an arms-for-hostage exchange. At his trial, Mr. North said he watched Mr. Poindexter tear up the order.
Mr. Reagan's statements have been contradictory. He first told the Tower panel that he signed an authorization for the initial Israeli shipments of arms to Iran, as required by United States law. Later, he said he did not approve such an order. Finally, Mr. Reagan said he could not remember whether he approved the initial Israeli arms shipments.
''Try as I might,'' he said, ''I cannot recall anything whatsoever about whether I approved an Israeli sale in advance or whether I approved replenishment of Israeli stocks around August 1985. My answer, therefore, and the simple truth is, I don't remember. Period.''

HEADLINE: Perrier Widens Recall After New Finding

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Source Perrier announced today that it was withdrawing every bottle of its sparkling mineral water throughout the world after traces of benzene, a toxic chemical, were reported in bottles tested in Denmark and the Netherlands.
The new recall comes after Perrier was removed from stores and restaurants in the United States last weekend, also because traces of benzene were found in a few bottles. The company said 160 million bottles, worth around $70 million before taxes, would be taken off the market and destroyed.
Distributors in Japan and West Germany have also ordered the withdrawal of millions of the familiar green bottles, in some cases as a precautionary measure, while the local health authorities test the carbonated water. 
The French company exports 60 percent of its production.
The health scare and the accompanying financial loss for the company pushed down the value of Perrier's shares on the Paris Bourse by 4.1 percent today. The price per share has fallen by 16.5 percent - from 1,692 francs, or $297, to 1,413 francs - since Friday's closing, one day before 72 million Perrier bottles were withdrawn in the United States.
The company announced the worldwide recall as a step to regain consumer confidence.
''I have built up this company over the past 40 years around an image of perfection,'' Perrier's chairman, Gustave Leven, told a news conference here. ''I don't want the least doubt, however small, to tarnish our product's image of quality and purity.''
''Our image and the respect and confidence of consumers have no price for me,'' the 75-year-old businessman said in his first public appearance since the company crisis erupted last weekend.
The statements made today also changed the company's account of how the benzene got into the bottles.
Stressing that the source of the mineral water, a spring at Vergeze in southern France, remained pure, Mr. Leven said the contamination problem was the result of ''a human error'' when filters in its bottling plant at Vergeze were not replaced on schedule.
He said that benzene, which has caused cancer in laboratory animals, and other chemicals were naturally present in minute amounts in the spring. The company uses filters to remove such impurities, but for some reason they were not changed when they should have been.
''There was therefore an accumulation of benzene in the product,'' Mr. Leven said.
When benzene was found in the Perrier in the United States, company officials said it got into the bottles of water because a worker had mistakenly used a cleaning solvent containing the chemical to remove grease and grime from some production equipment.
Mr. Leven said today that all the filters had been changed and that since last weekend normal production of around six million bottles a day had resumed. ''The machines will work at full blast, six days a week, 24 hours a day, until we have rebuilt our stocks,'' he said.
In addition to the decline in the Perrier shares today on the French stock market, the Bourse's Commission of Operations, equivalent to the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States, said it would investigate possible insider trading in the company's stock amid reports there was heavy buying of options to sell the stock Friday before the company's announcement.
The options, called puts in United States markets, give holders the right to sell shares of the stock at the Friday price, and those who acquired them could have made a large profit when Perrier's shares slumped on Monday. Reuters quoted traders as saying about 300 sell options were bought last Friday against a daily norm of around 50.
The company's vice chairman, Jacques Vincent, said Perrier would again be available within days in some countries and within three weeks in others. When the withdrawal of bottles was announced in the United States last weekend, the company's American distributor estimated that it might be three months before stocks were replenished.
Trying to strike an optimistic note, Mr. Leven said that Perrier was already back in business. ''We will be even stronger because our image is intact,'' he said of a brand that has 5.7 percent of the United States bottled water market. ''Our consumers will know just how far we're willing to go in our battle for the truth and perfection.''
Also at the news conference was a platoon of scientists who vouched for the purity of Perrier's water at its source and reiterated statements made by the Food and Drug Administration in the United States last week that the amounts of benzene found in 13 test samples were not enough to be harmful.
 
No Damage Seen
Marketing analysts and competitors of Perrier in the United States, where the company sells about 15 percent of its main brand, said the wider recall would not be fatal to the brand whose marketing image is based on purity.
David S. Daniel, chief executive of Evian Waters of France Inc., said the wider recall ''sure isn't great for the brand, but it is not a death blow for Perrier because the recall really serves the cause of product integrity. The move will serve them well in the future.'' Evian is the No. 2 bottled-water import in the United States after Perrier.
Perrier's American subsidiary, Perrier Group of America Inc., said it would take no new marketing steps or other actions because of the wider recall.
The company is developing an ''environmentally sound way'' to dispose of the 72 million bottles of water it is collecting, which could include simply dumping the water into a local sewer system.
The glass bottles and cardboard will be recycled, officials said.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
What NBC Sees In Notre Dame

 BODY:
EXCEPT for end-of-the-season bowl games, NBC has been shut out of the college football market since the 1960's. In one bold stroke last week, NBC filled that hole, luring the University of Notre Dame away from the other major football powers that have a deal with ABC, starting with the 1991 season.
NBC and Notre Dame officials have not disclosed the terms of the deal, but some broadcasting analysts have said Notre Dame will receive at least $35 million, or $7 million a season. The contract gives NBC the exclusive television rights to all games played by Notre Dame at its stadium in South Bend, Ind. 
The network has declined to say how much it expects to make from the games or what advertising rates it will charge. Ken Schanzer, the executive vice president of NBC Sports, said it was too soon to make such projections.
''We've got an integrated package, a single, one-stop package,'' Mr. Schanzer said. ''If you're an advertiser, you're going to buy Notre Dame football.''
The advertising rates will reflect the ratings for the games. Notre Dame is a frequent competitor for the national championship - it won in 1988 and was No. 2 behind the University of Miami last season - and it commands a broad national following. During the 1989 season, CBS carried four Notre Dame games and they had ratings ranging from 7.3 to 14.9, compared with the average rating of 6.8 for all college football on CBS. A rating point is equal to 921,000 homes with televisions.
''Notre Dame wields this unique market power,'' said Larry Collette, a visiting instructor at Michigan State University whose study on the economics of college football broadcasting was recently published in The Journal of Media Economics. ''They're the one school that could do this.''
He added: ''College football is a pretty unique property. It offers access to an otherwise hard-to-reach market, the young, higher-educated males.''
Although the three networks do not make public their advertising rates for college football, Mr. Collette's study found that advertising rates for a 30-second network spot ranged from $30,000 to $66,000 between 1980 and 1987. Some marketing executives said a 30-second ad on a nationally televised game could now cost as much as $75,000.
Notre Dame's six home games each year are certain to fetch top prices, broadcasting and marketing executives agree.
The NBC-Notre Dame deal could also help to restrain advertising rates for other college football games, because ABC, which also has a contract with the Big 10 and Pacific 10 football conferences, will not have a monopoly on the best games.
''I think it's going to be used as leverage by the advertisers,'' said Barry Frank, senior vice president of the International Management Group, a sports marketing concern. ''When you control all the inventory, as ABC thought it would, you can control rates much better than if you split the inventory.''
Until signing the deal with NBC, Notre Dame had participated in the football package signed by the 64 universities of the College Football Association. That group's contract with CBS has one more season to run, and the association has agreed to a five-year contract with ABC, starting in 1991.
Jim Spence, a former ABC Sports executive who is president of Sports Television International, a production and consulting company, observed that how well NBC does with Notre Dame will be determined at least in part by how ABC schedules its games. ABC could choose to schedule games at the same time that Notre Dame is appearing on NBC or it could schedule them earlier or later. At Notre Dame's insistence, its home games will start on Saturdays at 1:30 P.M., Eastern time.
Mr. Spence predicted that NBC would try to bolster the rest of its Saturday afternoon programming, which will be strengthened by the ''terrific lead-in'' from Notre Dame's presence on the schedule. Currently, NBC broadcasts a variety of sports programs on Saturday afternoons, and it said it had made no decision yet on how it might change that programming.
ABC also responded to the Notre Dame-NBC deal by renegotiating its contract with the football association. The contract now calls for $175 million over five years, rather than $210 million when Notre Dame was part of the package. The ESPN cable network also renegotiated its contract with the group, from $140 million for five years to $125 million for six years.
Another ripple effect of the NBC-Notre Dame agreement is that CBS now contends that it has the right of first refusal to match ABC's revised contract with the football association. CBS says that under its contract with the association, it has the right to match any offer of less than $40 million a year for the college games. The revised ABC deal is now valued at $37 million a year. The College Football Association and ABC, however, believe that their agreement is binding.

HEADLINE: Inventories Fell by 0.2% In December

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Business inventories fell in December for the first time in more than a year, while sales remained unchanged, the Government said today.
''It's a reflection that the economy has slowed down,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ''It slowed during the fourth quarter, and we expect it to remain slow until the summer.'' 
The Commerce Department said inventories were down two-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $795.2 billion, after rising five-tenths of 1 percent in November and three-tenths of 1 percent in October.
It was the first decline since a drop of one-tenth of 1 percent in October 1988 and the largest since inventories slipped six-tenths of 1 percent in December 1986.
 
Sales Are Flat
At the same time, sales were flat at a seasonally adjusted $522.5 billion. November sales were revised downward from a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent to an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent. Sales fell by five-tenths of 1 percent in October.
Mr. Runiewicz said the fact that inventories fell at the same time that sales were flat meant businesses were cutting back on production. But he and other analysts agreed that while the economy was weak, it was not nearing a recession.
''It would take a significant decline in sales to tip the balance of economic activity in a negative direction,'' said Richard W. Rahn, chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''But Government reports on retail sales yesterday already suggest that such a decline is not in the cards.''
The Commerce Department reported on Tuesday that retail sales, which represent a third of the nation's economic activity, jumped 1.6 percent in January.
 
Inventories in 'Good Shape'
The December business activity produced a slight decline, to 1.52, in the ratio of inventories to sales. That means it would take 1.52 months to exhaust inventories at the December pace. The ratio was 1.53 in both October and November.
''On the whole, inventories are in pretty good shape,'' said Evelina Tainer, an economist with First National Bank of Chicago. ''It suggests that even though the economy is sluggish, we shouldn't need much of a correction in the near term.''
If inventories pile up excessively, it could mean severe cutbacks in production and a loss of jobs - a situation already found in the automobile industry.
 
Auto Industry Layoffs
Chrysler, Ford Motor and General Motors all had temporary layoffs in January to reduce the number of vehicles on back lots.
Retail backlogs dropped one-tenth of 1 percent in December, but sales fell two-tenths of 1 percent.
Both inventories and sales at the manufacturing level, which represents about 45 percent of the total, slid by four-tenths of 1 percent.
Wholesalers' inventories were down two-tenths of 1 percent, while sales rose 1.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Posts 0.22-Point Rise as Volume Dips

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Drexel Burnham Lambert's woes did not spill over to the stock market yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average edged up by 0.22 point, to 2,624.32.
At the same time, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outpaced declining ones by 749 to 681.
Volume on the Big Board was relatively stable, at 138.5 million shares, down from the 144.4 million shares that changed hands on Tuesday. 
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose by 0.99, to 332.01, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 0.36, to 183.21.
 
Programmers in Control
''Yesterday was another low-volume affair, with investors having little conviction as to what to do in the face of the Drexel situation and the 'junk bond' fiasco,'' said Edward P. Nicoski, the chief technical analyst at Piper, Jaffray Inc. in Minneapolis. ''With liquidity virtually nil, program traders were able to move the market up and down as they pleased. The net result for the day was zero.''
Mr. Nicoski said another disconcerting factor had been the upward pressure on oil prices, which affects the outlook for inflation.
''Ironically, however, should crude oil prices drop sharply, we could then see downward pressure on energy issues, which have represented the market's primarily leadership in recent months,'' the analyst added. Energy stocks ended mixed yesterday after being up early in the day. Exxon slipped by 1/4, to 47; Chevron rose by 1 1/4, to 69 5/8, and Mobil was unchanged at 61 1/2.
Another analyst indicated that yesterday's performance might be misleading.
Among individual issues, Great Northern Nekoosa jumped by 2 points, to 64, in active trading. The company has asked its investment bankers to begin discussions with interested parties, hoping to avoid a hostile offer from Georgia-Pacific.
 
First Interstate Gains
First Interstate gained 2, to 34 7/8, also in active trading. The company said a partnership affiliated with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company would buy about 3.4 million of the 7.5 million common shares to be offered by First Interstate Bancorp at $33 each.
The active glamour stocks included Chase Manhattan, up by 1/2, to 27 1/2; I.B.M., up by 1/2, to 103 3/4; Philip Morris, up by 3/8, to 39 1/8, and Citicorp, up by 1/2, to 23 1/2.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index added 0.33 point, to 358.78, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index moved up by 0.81, to 426.56.
In Tokyo, stocks closed marginally higher in what some of the traders there termed a ''wait-and-see'' day. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose by 48.86 points, to 37,155.89, after dropping by 181.11 points on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
World Bank's Global Bonds

 BODY:
The World Bank said it would price today its second $1.5 billion issue of global bonds. The offering will be made simultaneously in the Euromarkets and in the domestic markets of the United States and Japan.

HEADLINE: Ruble Contest: Prize Is Dollars

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
An official of the Soviet Union today announced a prize of $25,000 to the person who devises the best plan for making the ruble convertible into hard currencies.
Dimitri Levchuk, an adviser to Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin, told reporters that the contest would be held in Washington in May. ''The prize money will be paid in hard currency,'' he said.
The contest is being organized by private United States foundations and by a non-governmental organization in the Soviet Union, a Soviet spokesman said. The United States economist Wassily Leontief, who received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1973, is to head the panel of judges.
Western economists believe the Soviet Union cannot significantly increase trade with the West until its currency is made convertible.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Down; Political Uncertainties Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened slightly against most major currencies in uneventful trading yesterday.
Traders said there was little direction in the currency markets, reflecting uncertainty about political and economic developments, including the potential reunification of East and West Germany, President Bush's trip to Colombia and Japan's general election. 
''We're just at a standstill,'' said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. ''The financial markets are very calm.''
Traders continued to monitor the difficulties of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday. Drexel has begun what appears to be an orderly liquidation of some financial portfolios.
In New York, the dollar closed at 144.35 yen, unchanged from Wednesday. It cost $1.6960 to buy 1, more expensive than $1.6895 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.6750 West German marks, down from 1.6763; 1.4940 Swiss francs, down from 1.4975; 5.6965 French francs, down from 5.7015; 1,244.75 Italian lire, down from 1,245.75, and 1.2075 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2010.

HEADLINE: Bush's Tax Plan Faulted

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Congressional economists said today that President Bush's proposed capital-gains tax cut would increase the Federal budget deficit by $11.4 billion in the next five years and would continue to lose revenue far into the future.
The estimate by the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation disagrees with that of the Treasury Department, which has said the tax cut would increase revenues by $12.5 billion in the next five years. 
The two estimates agree that the capital-gains reduction would raise tax collections for 1990 and 1991. The Congressional staff estimates the 1990-91 gain at $3.9 billion, and the Administration forecasts a $5.4 billion increase. Capital gains are profits from the sale of stock and other assets.
Under current law, capital gains are fully taxed at the same rates as wages and other income. Under the Bush proposal, only 70 percent of the profits from the sale of assets owned three years or longer would be taxed at those rates. Property owned between a year and three years would qualify for a smaller tax break.

HEADLINE: Edward Bursk, 82; Taught at Harvard In Business School

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: COHASSET, Mass., Feb. 14

 BODY:
Edward C. Bursk, a former editor of the Harvard Business Review and an emeritus professor at the Harvard Business School, died Monday at his home here. He was 82 years old. 
Mr. Bursk edited the monthly review from 1946 to 1972, when its circulation increased from 2,000 to 150,000. He retired last year as marketing professor at Harvard, where he had taught for 47 years.
He had been a member of the faculty at Dartmouth College and Franklin and Marshall College, and had also taught at Boston University.
He was a member of the Council of Economic Advisers in President John F. Kennedy's Administration. In 1958 he founded the International Marketing Institute of Boston, which trains foreign business executives, and became its educational director.
Mr. Bursk wrote a number of business books, including ''Low Pressure Selling'' and ''Reading Habits of Business Executives,'' and was the co-editor of ''World of Business.''
He also published the monthly Advanced Management Newsletter, served as chairman of the Browne and Nichols School in Cambridge and was the moderator of ''Marketing on the Move,'' a series on WGBH-TV, the public television station in Boston.
Mr. Bursk received a bachelor's degree from Amherst College and a master's from Harvard.
He is survived by his wife, the former Catherine Irwin; three sons, Edward Jr., of Cohasset, John H., of Mercersburg, Pa., and Christopher, of Langhorne, Pa.; two sisters; eight grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

LENGTH: 1276 words

HEADLINE: 4 PRESIDENTS IN COLOMBIA;
3 ANDEAN LEADERS AND BUSH PLEDGE DRUG COOPERATION

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, Feb. 15

 BODY:
President Bush and the leaders of three Andean nations concluded the first top-level regional conference on drug trafficking today with ambitious promises of cooperation, but skirted most of the major disputes among their nations.
A joint statement by the four leaders appeared to reject the idea of expanding the use of the United States military to help stop cocaine smuggling from South America. Washington has favored such an expansion but the Andean leaders have been cool to it. [Excerpts from statement, page A12.] Mr. Bush and the Presidents of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru stressed the need to help coca growers in the Andean countries find substitute crops and they called on European countries and Japan to help provide economic aid to drug-producing countries. Mr. Bush pledged to find ways to expand United States markets for substitute crops like coffee and cut flowers.
 
'First Anti-Drug Cartel'
''We've committed ourselves to the first common, cooperative drug control strategy,'' Mr. Bush declared before he left. ''We've in fact just formed the first anti-drug cartel.'' 
The final document issued by the conference included few specific economic, military or law-enforcement agreements. And as expected, Mr. Bush left Colombia after the nine-and-a-half-hour visit without offering any increase in the $2.2 billion, five-year regional aid program he has already sent to Congress.
The final document did not discuss that aid program, which is already under attack by Democrats in Congress. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has offered his own program, which would shift Mr. Bush's emphasis on military and law-enforcement programs to economic aid.
 
Lunch at Naval Academy
The four leaders met for nearly three hours and then ate lunch together under heavy guard in the Naval Academy of Cartagena, a coastal city that was flooded with the most intensive security ever mounted for a trip by Mr. Bush. Thousands of Colombian soldiers guarded the streets and stood guard in the trees on the edge of the airport in this city 60 miles to the southwest, where Mr. Bush landed and took off.
The President roared into the meeting site in a fleet of three Marine Corps helicopters, which skimmed the treetops and conducted a series of high-speed maneuvers to foil any possible attack. Colombian and United States warships patrolled offshore while United States counterterrorist units and frogmen guarded the land and sea approaches to the meeting site.
In between meetings, Mr. Bush and President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia strolled along the walls of an old fort in the sultry weather and posed for cameras amid the orange trees and palm groves while parrots and delicate songbirds called picaflores screeched in the background. The other Presidents at the meeting were Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru.
Like Mr. Bush's decision to override security concerns and travel to Colombia to demonstrate his personal support for President Barco, the conference was largely a symbolic exercise. It was intended to show that the United States, as the major cocaine-consuming nation, was accepting responsibility for reducing demand and that the Latin American countries were working to halt the cocaine production that has become a mainstay of their troubled economies.
 
'New Era in the Struggle'
In a joint appearance after the conference, Mr. Barco declared that the conference ''opened a new era in the struggle against drugs.''
He noted that the meeting had underscored the need ''to adopt commercial measures to strengthen our economies'' and that, in a conceptual sense at least, the four countries recognized that ''each link of the cocaine trade must be attacked simultaneously'' -production, distribution and consumption.
The communique, whose contents were largely known before the conference began, did mark the culmination of an evolving departure from the anti-drug program of the Reagan Administration, largely repudiating the old policy of concentrating on eradication of cocaine crops in favor of efforts to interdict drug shipments.
But the final document offered few specific programs to accomplish its sweeping goals, leaving that to bilateral negotiations.
 
Major Issues Not Discussed
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the four Presidents did not discuss any ''specific amount'' of increased aid from Washington and the final document committed Mr. Bush only to his current proposal for the Andean anti-drug program. ''We're going to stay with this figure for now,'' Mr. Bush said, adding that he was not prepared to help the cocaine-producing countries replace that illicit industry ''job for job'' with legal enterprises.
The four Presidents also did not talk in their group session about two other major issues: the extradition of cocaine traffickers to the United States and the use of the United States military to monitor and interdict cocaine traffic from South America.
Before Mr. Bush came to Colombia, Administration officials said he was likely to try to revive a plan to use aircraft carriers to form a ''radar net'' that would monitor drug flights. But, worried that this would inflame Latin American opposition to the idea, Mr. Bush did not raise the subject.
Last month, a plan to send an aircaft carrier to the Colombian coast on such a mission was shelved after it was disclosed in news reports and Mr. Barco strongly protested. Today, Mr. Barco was asked if he now was willing to endorse such a mission in international waters, but he did not answer directly. ''It is not necessary,'' he said. ''Colombian territorial waters are being patrolled by us and controlled by us.''
 
A Law-Enforcement Matter
Mr. Bush said he did not raise the military issue because ''there was so much misunderstanding over what was intended in the first place.''
The final document of the conference said narcotics control ''is essentially a law-enforcement matter.''
''The armed forces of each of the countries, within their own territory and national jurisdiction, may also participate,'' it said, adding that participants could work out their own ''understandings for cooperation.'' But there was no reference to the general principle of the armed forces of one country operating in another.
The four leaders seemed friendly in their public appearances, but their differences were apparent in their statements.
Mr. Bush said he came away with an enhanced understanding of the concerns of the three other Presidents. But he said, ''They were very frank with us on things that maybe they wanted me to do more of or disagreed with.''
 
Need to Reduce Demand
Although Mr. Bush came here citing a new study that indicated a general decline in drug use among high school students in the United States as a sign that he was serious about reducing demand, Mr. Barco suggested in his opening statement that he was not satisfied.
''We must do everything in our power to stop the demand for this illicit narcotic,'' he said. ''I have said many times that every tactic and every weapon pales into insignificance compared to the need to reduce demand.''
The United States also signed six bilateral agreements with Bolivia and Peru.
 
Awacs for Puerto Rico
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Special to The New York Times) - The Pentagon said today that Awacs radar surveillance planes had been dispatched to Roosevelt Roads Naval Base in Puerto Rico to help track possible drug-smuggling aircraft.
''There will be Awacs based now on in Roosevelt Roads for an indefinite period of time,'' Bob Hall, a Pentagon spokesman, said.

PUB-DATE: February 16, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2377 words

HEADLINE: ACCORD ON EUROPE: ANATOMY OF A DECISION - A SPECIAL REPORT.;
Steps to German Unity: Bonn as a Power

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN with MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Early Tuesday morning, as foreign ministers from the 23 NATO and Warsaw Pact nations milled around the main hall of the Ottawa Congress Center, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d stood off in a corner, whispering to one another through a Russian translator.
Mr. Shevardnadze reported that the Soviet Union would back down and accept President Bush's proposal for troop cuts in Europe, which would leave the United States with a 30,000-man advantage.
This conversation was the culmination of several days of diplomacy that was kept secret not only from the public but from many allied governments as well. The talks resulted in a new United States-Soviet understanding on troop levels in Europe.
But probably more important, they also resulted in an arrangement for how the four World War II Allies -Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union - would deal with the other major development on the continent: negotiations for a seemingly inevitable reunification of Germany. 
In these latter negotiations, the Big Four, once the undisputed overseers of Germany's fate, found themselves having to negotiate with Bonn as a real equal. West Germany used its weight in world affairs, as well as the political momentum of change within its borders and in East Germany, to help shape many of the terms of the Ottawa framework for determining how a united Germany will fit into a post-cold war European order.
 
How It Happened
A reconstruction of the negotiations, based on dozens of interviews today and in recent weeks, found these steps:
* Bush Administration officials consulted separately and in private with British, French and West German leaders to forge a consensus on dealing with German unification - before discussing the matter with Moscow.
* Britain, France and the Soviet Union initially preferred that the four Allied powers discuss the future of Germany among themselves - and not, at first, with the Germans - but Washington talked them into bringing the Germans in from the start.
* Once the Germans were brought into the process, Bonn insisted on excluding the other nations of the 16-member North Atlantic Treaty Organization from these discussions. The West Germans, in a bit of muscle flexing, wanted to make it clear that they would deal only with those Allied powers that had postwar legal rights in Berlin. Setting the Stage The Wall Falls, The Allies Respond After the opening of the Berlin wall on Nov. 10, Administration officials assumed that the unification process would unfold gradually, and that no serious moves on their part would be required until the East German elections, then scheduled for May.
But on Jan. 28, with thousands of East Germans still flocking to the West every day, East German authorities announced that they were advancing the election date to March 18. They simply could not hold the country together until May. Since pro-unification parties were expected to sweep the elections, Administration officials realized that a unified Germany was no longer a possibility - it was all but a certainty.
So the Administration decided to come up with its own plan to manage reunification. President Bush consulted with his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and the deputy adviser, Robert M. Gates, and Mr. Baker with his key aides - Robert Zoellick, State Department counselor; Dennis B. Ross, the department's Director of Policy Planning, and Raymond G. H. Seitz, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs. Mr. Seitz eventually produced a version of the plan adopted at Ottawa. It became known as the ''two-plus-four'' concept.
 
Sequence of Talks
Under this formula, after the East German elections were over the two Germanys would get together and discuss their economic, political and legal unification. After that, the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union would sit down with the two Germanys and discuss the size of the army their unified state might have, its relationship to NATO and security guarantees for its neighbors.
Mr. Baker and President Bush decided that they would keep the two-plus-four idea closely held and begin secretly polling the three other Allies, one by one. They would not tell the other members of NATO, until and unless there was an agreement among the four, plus the two Germanys.
The first serious discussion of the idea took place on Jan. 29, when the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, met with Mr. Baker in Washington. Mr. Hurd, who had been thinking along similar lines, indicated that his Government's preference would be ''four plus zero'' - that is, the four Allied powers getting together to discuss the fate of Germany, at first without the Germans. Nevertheless, he gave London's backing to two plus four.
 
Bonn Wants Guarantees
Four days later, the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, flew to Washington for a private chat with Mr. Baker, during which the Secretary first laid out the two-plus-four idea to him. Mr. Genscher liked it, but he wanted to make certain that it was two plus four, and not four plus two. That is, he wanted to make sure that the two Germanys would first determine the nature of their unification on their own, and then deal with the other powers on external security issues.
Mr. Genscher also told Mr. Baker that his Government would have nothing to do with a ''2-plus-15'' arrangment - the two Germanys and the 15 other members of NATO deciding the German future. Nor would he accept ''four plus zero.'' He also said that West Germany would not put its future in the hands of the 35 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Two plus four, he said, was just right.
On Feb. 5, Mr. Baker began a trip to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. At the last minute, his schedulers added a stop in Shannon, Ireland, at 5 A.M. for a meeting with the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas. During the one-hour talk, Mr. Dumas also signed on to the ''two-plus-four'' concept, but only after saying that his first preference was also ''four plus zero.''
As the reunification negotiations progressed, pressure was building in the United States and in Europe for Mr. Bush to propose a deeper cut in Soviet and American conventional forces in Europe than he had presented to NATO leaders in May. At the urging of Mr. Scowcroft, Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, developed the plan to cut American and Soviet troops in Central Europe to 195,000, with the United States keeping 30,000 soldiers elsewhere in the European region. Meetings in Moscow Visit by Baker A Turning Point On Feb. 7, Mr. Baker flew into Moscow. That night, he had a private meeting with Mr. Shevardnadze and tried to bring up Germany, but the Soviet official said that topic would have to be taken up with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev himself. The next morning, Mr. Baker presented the two-plus-four concept to the Soviet leader as they sat around a huge table in the Kremlin's Catherine Hall. Mr. Gorbachev was intrigued by the two-plus-four idea, but noncommittal. He too made it clear that he shared the British and French preference for ''four plus zero.''
''One of the things that is very striking about dealing with Shevardnadze and Gorbachev right now is that they will listen to your arguments,'' a senior State Department official said. ''These are not stylized discussions. They tend to be very relaxed. When you make a case that they think is reasonable, they will come right back and tell you: 'Well, you know, that's reasonable.' And there was quite a bit of that in the discussion on the Germanys.''
 
Distinction Between Armies
But the German question was not the only issue Mr. Baker had to discuss with the Soviets. There was also the question of how they would respond to President Bush's troop proposal, with its insistence on American troop superiority in Europe. This was to drive home the point that the Soviets, who were in Europe as occupiers, might have to leave at the behest of their allies, but that the Americans were there by invitation and would not be leaving entirely.
Mr. Gorbachev accepted the basic principle of lower troop levels, but gave Mr. Baker a counterproposal: both sides would go down to either 195,000 men or 225,000 men, but not 195,000 for the Soviets and 225,000 for the Americans. Administration officials say they believe that this idea may have been generated by the Soviet arms-control bureaucracy and that Mr. Gorbachev decided he had nothing to lose by seeing if he could bluff the Americans into accepting it.
Mr. Baker left Moscow without a Soviet answer to the German question, and with the troop proposal in limbo. Just as Mr. Baker was packing to leave, the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and his Foreign Minister, Mr. Genscher, were arriving for their own meeting with Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Baker decided that to avoid creating any impression of the United States and the Soviets - without the British and the French -deciding the fate of Germany, he would avoid any personal contact with Mr. Kohl in Moscow.
Instead, Mr. Baker sent Mr. Kohl a three-page, for-your-eyes-only note, laying out Mr. Gorbachev's reactions to the two-plus-four idea. Mr. Baker then took off for Bulgaria and Romania on his way to a conference in Ottawa on the ''open skies'' proposal for air missions over other nations' territories.
Success in Ottawa A Deal Is Struck On Troop Cuts While in Ottawa, Mr. Baker, Mr. Genscher, Mr. Hurd, Mr. Dumas and Mr. Shevardnadze, who were supposed to be dealing with ''open skies,'' were in fact simply going from one meeting with each other, to another. Most of the other NATO and Warsaw Pact foreign ministers did not have a clue as to what they were talking about.
Mr. Baker's private secretary, Karen Jackson, carried around the schedules of each of the other ministers, which were constantly being updated. For instance, the Soviets would call to say that Mr. Shevardnadze was going to be at his embassy for 30 minutes, and then in his suite for an hour, and after that back in the conference hall, so that Mr. Baker could track him down at any moment.
A Baker aide mused that if anyone was tapping the phone calls between the ministers, they would have heard some of the most momentous issues in postwar politics being discussed with stunning frankness. At several points, Mr. Baker was jogging back and forth between meetings with Mr. Genscher and Mr. Shevardnadze.
On Tuesday morning, Mr. Baker, Mr. Hurd, Mr. Dumas and Mr. Genscher had breakfast at the West German Embassy in Ottawa and hammered out the proposed language of the two-plus-four arrangement. They decided then that if they could get Mr. Shevardnadze to sign on to it now, they should do it. Events in Germany were moving too fast, they reasoned, and if they broke up in Ottawa without an understanding, it would be that much more difficult later.
From that breakfast, Mr. Baker drove back to a full session of the open-skies conference. As ministers milled around the oval meeting table, Mr. Baker walked over to Mr. Shevardnadze with a scrap of paper in his hand. With Mr. Shevardnadze's translator standing between them, Mr. Baker, reading from the paper written in his own handwriting, whispered to the Soviet Foreign Minister the proposed language the Western Allies were suggesting for two plus four. Mr. Shevardnadze's translator wrote it all down in Russian, and Mr. Shevardnadze said he would have to call Mr. Gorbachev. A Dizzying Speed German Disunity, Other Loose Ends It was at this juncture that Mr. Shevardnadze also informed Mr. Baker that Mr. Gorbachev was ready to accept Mr. Bush's original troop offer.
Mr. Baker was pleased but somewhat taken aback. No one had really expected Mr. Gorbachev to come around so soon. The Soviet leader was apparently playing from a much weaker hand than anyone thought. Mr. Baker walked out of the hall and telephoned President Bush with the news. Mr. Shevardnadze phoned President Gorbachev to get his reaction to the two-plus-four language.
Meanwhile, the President had been conducting his own telephone diplomacy on Tuesday morning, speaking twice with Chancellor Kohl. Mr. Bush - knowing that Mr. Genscher and Mr. Kohl, political allies of necessity in Bonn's governing coalition, dislike each other and often do not even tell each other what they are doing - decided that he had to personally make certain that Mr. Kohl approved of the two-plus-four deal that Mr. Genscher was striking with Mr. Baker. Mr. Kohl told the President that he was willing, and the President gave Mr. Baker his green light.
 
Concessions to Soviets
Two hours later, Mr. Shevardnadze and Mr. Baker met again in a private conference room. Mr. Shevardnadze said that Mr. Gorbachev supported the idea but that he needed some changes in the text. First, it could not mention the March 18 East German election date, or suggest that this was the event that would trigger the two-plus-four meeting. This was done to mollify his East German allies and to avoid treating unification, or the dissolution of East Germany, as a foregone conclusion.
Mr. Shevardnadze also insisted, apparently on behalf of the Poles, that the statement contain a line saying that the two-plus-four discussions would deal with ''issues of security of the neighboring states.''
Once this language was approved, news photographers were summoned for pictures of the two German Foreign Ministers and those of the four Allied countries standing together. No one was told why. Moments later, their two-plus-four announcement was released. Members of the press got it before most other NATO ministers. The Dutch, Italians and Belgians were incensed and began asking for some changes in the text, particularly for some reference not only to the security of states neighboring Germany, but also in the rest of Europe.
''They were told in no uncertain terms that this was a matter for the Allied powers with legal rights in Germany and nobody else,'' an Administration official said. ''That is why the deal was cut this way, we told them, and if you don't like it, I'm sorry, but you have no legal rights.''

HEADLINE: Sonargaon Journal;
Where Politics, Like the Rivers, Can Turn Nasty

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SONARGAON, Bangladesh, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Sirajul Islam, who makes his living selling bamboo poles, said he was having breakfast with his assistants early this morning when the political goons came for him. The local leader of Bangladesh's ruling Jatiya Party wanted to see him, he was told.
He stumbled home about an hour later, his shirt torn, a welt on his head and a threat still ringing in his ears: ''If you don't join the Jatiya Party, we will put you under detention.'' His shop's cash box was empty. 
Mr. Islam's crime was to volunteer to help an opposition candidate seeking election as head of a rural council in the first local elections in five years. His candidate, Abul Hasnat, is a member of Bangladesh's founding party, the Awami League.
Although the elections are ''partyless'' in the sense that party symbols cannot be used, everyone knows the affiliations of the candidates running for chairmanships of 460 upazila, or subdistrict, councils in the Bangladeshi countryside.
 
Previous Elections Boycotted
Five years ago, most parties opposed to President H. M. Ershad boycotted the local elections. Their reappearance this year poses a quandary for General Ershad, who seized power in a 1982 military coup.
The President has been luring opposition parties into the electoral process to give greater credence to government at all levels. Foreign donor nations, including the United States, have urged him to demonstrate more genuine democracy. But the participation of opposition groups with strong regional followings threatens his party's grasp on power at the local level.
The subdistrict councils, whose chairmen will be elected from March 13 to 24, disperse development money, which gives them considerable powers of patronage. The councils are now dominated by the Jatiya Party because of the opposition boycott in 1985. Rural voters, about 177,000 of them in Sonargaon subdistrict, became disgruntled because they believed their demands were being ignored by a party in more or less a monopoly position.
''Why should Bangladesh be the last country left in the world with a one-party system?'' a supporter of Mr. Hasnat asked, as he marched with his candidate along the rutted main street of Sonargaon town, about 20 miles east of Dhaka, in a demonstration of defiance and courage.
Voters here are quick to respond to a question about what they want from their council: they need more wells, culverts, bridges and new roads. Sonargaon's only thoroughfare is passable for nothing larger than a bicycle rickshaw as it dwindles into dunes at the edge of the Meghna River.
The Meghna is licking away Sonargaon, chunk by chunk, citizens say, while the Government does nothing to fortify the banks. Shamsuddin Bhuyan, a young farmer whose cabbage fields are precariously close to the precipice, took a reporter along the riverbank to view the changes.
In the lifetime of his father, who he thinks is about 70 years old, the river has shifted course by a mile or more. Out there in the middle of the stream, he said, used to be the police station, and over here a row of houses, and over there a shop.
 
'Creating Trouble for Us'
Mr. Hasnat, the owner of a small garment-manufacturing business, thinks he would win this vote easily if it were an honest poll. ''But they are creating troubles for us,'' he said of the Jatiya Party. ''Today two people were beaten brutally.''
President Ershad, who created the Jatiya Party to give himself a civilian political base, promises repeatedly that the voting will be ''free and fair.'' If these elections can pass muster, there may be national parliamentary elections in the next year or two.
In Sonargaon, only Jatiya Party members seem to believe the Government's pledge.
Political loyalties here and elsewhere in Bangladesh, with 110 million people one of the world's most densely populated nations, tend to remain divided along traditional party lines or family and regional loyalties.
 
'Something New' Is Wanted
Apart from the Jatiya and the Awami League, the party of Bangladesh's first Prime Minister, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, there are three other major political organizations in Bangladesh. They are the Communist Party; the Jamat-e-Islami, a militantly pro-Muslim group, and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, headed by the widow of Gen. Ziaur Rahman, who was President from 1977 until his assassination in 1981.
Human rights advocates and development experts often lament the lack of originality in party platforms at a time when the country is slipping backward, its economic growth slowed by floods and low commodity prices.
''The people are looking for something new,'' Abdur Rahman Chowdhury, a retired Supreme Court judge, said in Dhaka. He has been approached by citizens asking him to challenge General Ershad if there is another presidential election. He has declined, believing that no election is likely to be fair if held under this Government's control.
In Sonargaon, Mr. Hasnat's supporters all want to talk about the rigging they have seen. ''Don't believe what the Government says about fair elections,'' Mossaraf Hussain said. ''The last time, the Government also promised on television and radio that voting would be fair. But we all saw what happened.''

GRAPHIC: photo: The presence of opposition parties in this year's Bangladeshi elections demonstrates democracy, but may threaten the local power of the ruling Jatiya Party. Abul Hasnat, candidate of the opposition Awami League, left, discusses strategy in Sonargaon with Haji Sultan Ahmad, a local party elder. (The New York Times/Barbara Crossette); map of Bangladesh

HEADLINE: U.S. Suspends Food Aid to Afghan Guerrillas

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The United States has suspended a $30 million food aid program for Afghan guerrillas because of ''unique problems'' in keeping track of where the food went, a State Department spokesman said today.
A department spokesman, Richard Boucher, would not specify what the problems were, but a Congressional aide said the program was halted after some supplies were stolen or sold to the Soviet-backed Afghan Government.
He said the food aid, which is 30 percent of total American humanitarian aid to the rebels, had been suspended in November and again more recently. ''This was done as a result of difficulties encountered by U.S. Government officials in meeting our requirements in allocating and monitoring of those shipments,'' Mr. Boucher said at a news briefing. 
He said a team from the Agency for International Development had recently traveled to Pakistan, a staging area for the guerrillas, to set up a better monitoring network for the aid. He said shipments would resume soon.
The United States has long supplied military aid to the Islamic gueriilas battling Kabul Government forces.
Vaughn Forrest, an aide to Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, said the Congressman was urging the Bush Administration to resume the aid and insure that it got to the rebels.
Mr. Forrest confirmed a Washington Post report that deliveries of wheat to the rebels were suspended after 2,400 tons were diverted by members of Pakistan's military intelligence agency, apparently for private gain.
 
Afghan Aide Accuses Pakistan
NEW DELHI, Feb. 15 (Special to The New York Times) - Ending a four-day visit to India, the Afghan Foreign Minister renewed accusations today that Pakistan had plans to take over his country in the guise of an Islamic confederation ruled from Islamabad.
The Foreign Minister, Abdul Wakil, the first high-ranking Afghan to visit New Delhi since the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh took over in December, also accused a Saudi-based militant Islamic sect, the Wahabis, of ''large-scale aggression'' in Afghanistan. But he stopped short of blaming Saudi Arabia itself.
Mr. Wakil's visit was apparently intended to reaffirm Indian support for the Kabul Government of President Najibullah. India backed the Soviet intervention in Aghanistan in 1979 and has supported all subsequent Communist Governments there.

HEADLINE: Seoul Agrees on Withdrawal of Some Troops

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 15

 BODY:
In talks with Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, the South Korean Defense Minister today accepted in principle the gradual withdrawal of about 5,000 noncombatants from the American force of more than 43,000 soldiers in South Korea.
The details and timing of the reduction remained to be worked out. One American official who attended the meeting said that the figure of 5,000 to 6,000 was used as an ''order of magnitude'' in the troop withdrawal discussions, but that there was no firm agreement on the number. Mr. Cheney assured his South Korean counterpart at the talks, Lee Sang Hoon, that any troop withdrawal would not harm the capacity of the two countries' combined forces to deter a North Korean attack.
''We are not going to move precipitously,'' Mr. Cheney said at a news conference after the meeting ''Our commitment remains strong. The threat remains undiminished.'' 
 
Military Changes Being Weighed
Mr. Cheney is on a two-week tour to explore changes in the American military presence in South Korea, Japan and the Philippines before a required report to Congress on April 1.
Last month, the United States announced that it would cease operations at three of its five South Korean air bases and withdraw about 2,000 Air Force support personnel from the country.
Mr. Lee's acceptance of additional troop cuts was part of a larger shift in attitude emerging in the Korean-American military relationship. Both sides agreed that the American role would gradually diminish while Seoul assumes more leadership, including the eventual command of key units of the combined forces of the two countries.
One high-ranking American official traveling with Mr. Cheney said this was the strongest statement yet by South Korean officials that they would take over the leading role in their defense.
At the news conference, Mr. Cheney said, ''As a sort of guiding principle, we talked about playing more of a supportive role than we have in the past as the Republic of Korea takes the lead.''
The two defense chiefs discussed transferring to a South Korean general the operational control of the two nations' joint field army and appointing a Korean general to head the southern side's delegation to Military Armistice Commission meetings held in the truce village of Panmunjom. Both positions are now held by American generals.
In an earlier lunch meeting, President Roh Tae Woo was quoted as telling Mr. Cheney that South Korea would consider taking over operational control of its own armed forces during peacetime, with the Americans resuming command in times of war.
South Korea responded coolly, however, to an American request for a substantial increase in the amount of money Seoul contributes to the stationing of American forces. Mr. Lee pledged only that Seoul would give ''positive consideration'' to increasing direct financial support.
 
The Korean Contribution
Pentagon officials had earlier suggested that South Korea should double its $300 million in annual direct contributions to the costs of the American forces, but Mr. Cheney shied from pressing specific proposals in his discussions with Mr. Lee. American officials estimate that it costs the United States $2.4 billion to maintain its troops in Korea.
With its rapid economic growth, technological advances and improved military training, ''the Republic of Korea can now do more in providing for its own security,'' Mr. Cheney said.
A four-member committee consisting of Mr. Lee, Foreign Minister Choi Ho Joong, the United States Ambassador, Donald P. Gregg, and Gen. Louis Menetrey, commander of American forces in Korea, will work out the details and hard numbers of the proposed new arrangements.
The purpose of Mr. Cheney's visit was to consult with American allies and reach general agreements, said Pete Williams, the Defense Department spokesman. ''Today was not numbers day,'' he said. ''Today was principle day.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: SOVIET UNION;
Lifeline for Moscow: Diplomats Believe Gorbachev Wants To Salvage Access to West's Economy

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 15

 BODY:
As Communism collapsed in country after country in Eastern Europe last fall, it became clear that what all of them wanted was to join the Western cultural, political and economic traditions from which they had been cut off for 40 years.
With the ruins of seven decades of Communism in the Soviet Union now lying all about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, some Western diplomats believe that if he hopes to salvage anything at all from the disintegrating Soviet position in Europe, it will be the hope of access to the Western economic mainstream.
The most direct route for such access would be right behind East Germany, if it decides after elections next month to unite with West Germany, something the Soviet Union is no longer determined to prevent at any price.
The consensus among many Western diplomats is that Moscow will not insist on neutrality for a united Germany, though in public it says it will. An authoritative Communist Party official confirmed that demilitarized neutrality for a reunited Germany was no longer the soviet bottom line. 
 
'No Time for Long-Term Strategy'
''We have lost our ability to exploit German domestic politics,'' the official said. ''We no longer have time for a long-term foreign policy strategy.''
The Soviet Union is not yet prepared to agree with Bonn and the three Western Allied powers in West Germany -the United States, Britain and France - that a united Germany should remain a full member of NATO, he said, not even if Western troops stayed out of what is now East Germany and the 400,000 Soviet troops stationed there now could remain for a time.
Moscow consented in Ottawa on Tuesday to accept a framework for negotiating unity with the two German states and the three Western Allies. Some Soviet experts say that under some conditions, the Soviet Union could agree to NATO membership for a united Germany, if like France it had no foreign troops stationed on its soil and did not subordinate its own troops to the NATO military command in peacetime.
That would hardly be acceptable to the United States and Britain. But Moscow believes that demands for guarantees against the danger of renewed German aggression will be understood and supported, for other reasons, by Germany's other European neighbors, which remember what such aggression did to them in World War II.
 
Negotiating From Weakness
Though his country was victorious in that war, Mr. Gorbachev is negotiating from a position of weakness now. On Friday, in talks here with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, he turned down President Bush's proposal for a conventional arms treaty that would give the United States the right to keep 225,000 troops in Europe, but allow the Soviet Union to station only 195,000. On Tuesday, to the surprise of Western diplomats here, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze suddenly accepted the proposal in Ottawa.
A Western diplomat speculated that with Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland all eager for the Soviet Union to withdraw its troops in those countries, Moscow was under pressure to reach a quick agreement with the West. He speculated that the Soviet Union might even want a floor under American troop withdrawals to guarantee its own security.
Some Soviet citizens here believe that the West has not yet grasped just how close to disintegration the Soviet Communist Party and the Soviet economic and social system are, or how desperate are Mr. Gorbachev's attempts to reshape it.
The mood among many Russians who were among his greatest admirers a few years ago has turned pessimistic and disappointed.
''He didn't move fast enough with economic reforms,'' a Central Committee bureaucrat said. ''The party leadership is close to collapsing at the local and district level all across the country.''
 
Afraid Gorbachev Will Fail
Anatoly N. Rybakov, who denounced Stalinism in his novel ''Children of the Arbat,'' published in 1987, said: ''Gorbachev is trying to save the country. But now I'm afraid he will fail.'' After the Central Committee voted last week to give up the party's constitutional monopoly on political power, criticism of the party has become surprisingly open.
''I think the C.P.S.U. is unable to break with its past,'' Mikhail Chulaki, a non-Communist, wrote in the weekly Moscow News this week, using the initials for the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. ''Was there ever a 'vanguard role?' When? Under Stalin, under Khrushchev, under Brezhnev. I.e., under regimes that either dripped with blood or were more liberal but always totalitarian.''
Now, with the economy in a shambles, the Communist Party's authority rapidly vanishing, separatism growing in at least 6 of the 15 constituent republics and Soviet military might irrelevant to any conceivable solution, Mr. Gorbachev has apparently decided that he cannot save the system that held the country together by force for 70 years.
 
Economic Bid to West
The question, in many minds, is whether he can even get it to survive long enough to replace it with a freer economic and political system capable of being integrated with the Western economy. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, on a visit to Australia this week, said that he hoped that the Soviet Union could be ready by 1995, but that full integration might take 10 to 15 years.
''They can't force it,'' a Western diplomat said. ''They can only get it through cooperation.''
Thus, he explained, Moscow has one more reason not to stand in the way of unification of the two Germanys, which together constitute a little less than one-sixth of total Soviet foreign trade.
''Would they rather have 77 million Germans with them or against them?'' this diplomat asked rhetorically.
But Soviet officials concede, privately, that they lost control over events in Germany in October, when Erich Honecker lost control to the demonstrators in the streets in Leipzig and East Berlin.
 
Threat of 'the Streets'
The streets here have begun to be trouble, too. On Feb. 4, as many as half a million people took to the squares of Moscow in support of various causes, including faster change. On Feb. 26, the masses are expected to converge on the capital again, and some Communist officials fear that eventually ''the streets'' will go out of control.
In Azerbaijan, Tadzhikistan and Armenia, they already have, and the results are ethnic strife and bloodshed. The Communist parties there are under attack and collapsing almost as fast as their equivalents did in Eastern Europe last fall, and perhaps for the same reason: They were artificial Russian implants.
Now, as the streets deteriorate, oil production falls, feed grain runs out and meat disappears from the stores in the Ukraine, in Russia, all over the country, the worry is that all state authority may soon be in danger.
Few diplomats here think Mr. Gorbachev has much time to think up devious strategies to hoodwink the West into giving up its own interests in Western Europe. He is just hoping to salvage what he can of his own.

HEADLINE: 4 PRESIDENTS IN COLOMBIA;
Excerpts From Cartagena Statement

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CARTAGENA, Colombia, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the statement issued here today at the summit conference on drugs:
The parties consider that a strategy which commits the parties to implement or strengthen a comprehensive, intensified anti-narcotics program must address the issues of demand reduction, consumption and supply. Such a strategy also must include understandings regarding economic cooperation, alternative development, encouragement of trade and investment, as well as understandings regarding economic cooperation, on attacking the traffic in illicit drugs, and on diplomatic and public diplomacy initiatives.
The parties recognize that these areas are interconnected and self-reinforcing. . . It is clear that to be fully effective, supply reduction efforts must be accompanied by significant reduction in demand. The parties recognize that the exchange of information on demand control programs will benefit their countries. 
The parties recognize that the nature and impact of the traffic in and interdiction of illicit drugs varies in each of the three Andean countries and cannot be addressed fully in this document.
The parties will negotiate bilateral and multilateral agreements, consistent with their anti-narcotics efforts, specifying their responsibilities and commitments with regard to economic cooperation and intensified enforcement actions. ...
The parties recognize that trafficking in illicit drugs has a negative long-term impact on their economies. In some of the parties, profits from coca production and trade and from illicit drug trafficking contribute, in varying degrees, to the entry of foreign exchange and to the generation of employment and income. Suppression of coca production and trade will result in significant, immediate and long-term economic costs that will affect, in various ways, each of the Andean countries.
The President of the United States will request Congress to authorize new funds for the program during fiscal years 1991 to 1994, in order to support the Andean parties' efforts to counteract the short- and long-term socioeconomic impact of an effective fight against illicit drugs. . . . The United States is also prepared to cooperate with the Andean parties in a wide range of initiatives for development, trade and investment in order to strengthen and sustain long-term economic growth. ...
The parties are convinced that a comprehensive fight against illicit drug traffic will disrupt the market for coca and coca derivatives and will reduce their prices. As success is achieved in this fight, those employed in growing coca and in its primary processing will seek alternative sources of income, either by crop substitution or by changing jobs. The parties will work together to identify alternative-income activities for external financing. The United States is ready to consider financing of activities such as research, extension, credit and other agricultural support services and support of private-sector initiatives for the creation of micro-enterprises and agro-industries.
The United States will also cooperate with the Andean parties to promote viable domestic and foreign markets to sell the products generated by alternative development and crop substitution programs. ...
The parties reaffirm their will to fight drug trafficking in a comprehensive manner attacking all facets of the trade: production, transportation and consumption. Such comprehensive action includes the following:
Preventive actions to reduce consumption and therefore demand.
Control and law enforcement activities against illegal cultivation, processing and marketing of illicit drugs.
Control of essential chemicals for the production of illegal drugs and the means used for their transport.
Seizure, forfeiture and sharing of illegal proceeds and property used in committing narcotics-related crimes.
Coordination of law enforcement agencies, the military, prosecutors and courts, within the framework of national sovereignty of each of the parties.
Actions to bring about a net reduction in the illegal cultivation of coca. ...
The control of illegal trafficking in drugs is essentially a law enforcement matter. However, because of its magnitude and the different aspects involved, and in keeping with the sovereign interest of each state. . . the armed forces in each of the countries, within their own territory and national jurisdictions, may also participate. The parties may establish bilateral and multilateral understandings for cooperation in accordance with their interests, needs and priorities.

GRAPHIC: photo: A U.S. Secret Service agent stood guard with an automatic weapon in a shoulder bag yesterday as President Bush's fleet of three Marine Corps helicopters arrived Colombia for a one-day conference on drug trafficking. (Reuters)
