SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 674 words

HEADLINE: 4 PRESIDENTS IN COLOMBIA;
Peasant Grower Fails to Get Opportunity to Talk to Bush

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARTAGENA, Colombia, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Justo Silva Ballon, a Peruvian who represents one of the world's largest groups of peasant growers of coca, the essence of cocaine, came here today hoping to tell President Bush that his people were ready to switch to other crops. But he never got the chance.
''They didn't want to receive me,'' Mr. Silva said. ''All I wanted was five minutes with the President.'' 
Mr. Silva, who had come here as part of President Alan Garcia's delegation, said the 200,000 peasants that he represents received only a tiny fraction of the street price of cocaine and felt trapped in a violent world of narcotics traffickers, leftist guerrillas and the security forces.
''Our campesinos are all for Mr. Bush,'' Mr. Silva said. ''They are all for eradication of coca and producing something else.''
But he said that transforming the rich Upper Huallaga Valley of Peru, perhaps the largest coca growing area in the world, would cost billions of dollars and that so far no one had been willing to provide the money. The United States, he said, seemed to prefer spending its money on law enforcement, which sometimes drove peasants into the arms of the guerrillas.
 
Security Is Heavy
As President Bush and the leaders of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia began their summit meeting this morning, soldiers and the police had taken up positions along the main streets of Cartagena. A half-dozen Colombian warships and patrol boats maneuvered in the bay surrounding the peninsula where the talks were held and helicopters loaded with anti-terrorist teams clattered overhead.
As Colombian and American officials here had predicted, the summit meeting went off without even a hint of violence. The deployment of about 5,000 soldiers and police officers, however, had made some residents jittery. Schools and many businesses closed today, and traffic was unusually light.
Elsewhere in Colombia, however, students at several universities protested against Mr. Bush's presence, and in Cali, one of the main trafficking centers, guerrillas of the National Liberation Army kidnapped an American priest, the Rev. Francisco Amico Ferrari. The guerrillas said the kidnapping, like that of two other Americans earlier in the week, was intended to show their resentment toward the American President.
Late this afternoon, the National Liberation Army declared that it now considered every ''American interest'' in Colombia to be ''a military target of our organization.'' Military analysts said that while the National Liberation Army, with an estimated strength of 2,000, had carried out a series of kidnappings recently in Bogota, Medellin and Cali, it was doubtful that the organization is capable of carrying out major attacks.
 
Comment by U.S. Embassy
A spokeswoman for the United States Embassy in Colombia said she did not know anything about Mr. Silva's attempts to see Mr. Bush. She said she also had no information on an assertion by Mr. Silva that the American Embassy in Lima had denied him a visa to attend a special session of the United Nations on drugs next week in New York.
Some United States officials in Washington speculated this week that President Garcia, who had threatened not to attend the summit meeting in protest against the United States invasion of Panama, might have invited Mr. Silva to the meeting in an effort to embarrass Mr. Bush.
Mr. Garcia has argued that the United States should be spending less on the police and military in the fight against cocaine and more on economic development. Mr. Bush has pledged more than $2.2 billion in aid to Colombia, Peru and Bolivia over the next four years, but the proportion designated for economic development is far lower than the amount Peru and Bolivia say is needed.
Mr. Silva said that while no other crop gave peasants more profit than coca, income from fruits and vegetables could be multiplied with the establishment of food processing plants.
''What we need is the machinery to process and can foods,'' he said, ''and the assurance that someone would buy the products.''

HEADLINE: Mayor Barry's Career and Troubles

 BODY:

1974: Marion S. Barry Jr.is elected to the District of Columbia City Council; he is re-elected two years later.
PUB-DATE: March 9, 1977:
Jan. 21, 1978: Mr. Barry announces his intention to run for Mayor.
Sept. 12, 1978: After receiving a last-minute endorsement from The Washington Post, Mr. Barry wins the Democratic primary with 35 percent of the vote over two opponents.
Nov. 7, 1978: Mr. Barry is elected Mayor. In his first term, the city deficit mushrooms, forcing him to cut jobs and services and press for more Federal aid. He wins re-election in 1982 and his second term sees sees improved fiscal health, renewal of the downtown area, a decline in unemployment and crime and growing crowding of the city's jails and prisons. But scandals begin to take their toll as 10 top city officials are convicted of various financial crimes.
Sept. 25, 1983: The Mayor is stricken with chest pains while attending a meeting in a downtown hotel; hospital officials attribute the pains to a a hiatal hernia.
Nov. 4, 1986: Despite his mounting troubles, Mr. Barry is re-elected to an unprecedented third term, taking 61 percent of the vote.
PUB-DATE: May 22, 1987:
Dec. 22, 1988: Police officers planning to attempt a drug buy from Charles Lewis, a former Virgin Islands official and an acquaintance of Mr. Barry, are called back when it is discovered that the Mayor is in Mr. Lewis' hotel room. Traces of cocaine are found in the room.
Jan. 19, 1989: Mr. Barry appears under subpoena before grand jury investigating whether the Mayor interfered with the police drug investigation and testifies for three hours. He tells reporters he has done nothing wrong.
PUB-DATE: April 24, 1989:
PUB-DATE: May 15, 1989:
Nov. 6: Mr. Lewis pleads guilty in a plea bargain to two counts of conspiring to distribute cocaine and names Mr. Barry as a person for whom he bought crack cocaine while staying at the hotel where Mr. Barry visited him in 1988.
Nov. 27, 1989: A local television station reports that the 1983 hernia episode was reported to the police as a drug overdose, but the police say they investigated at the time but found no substantiation.
Jan. 18, 1990: Mr. Barry is arrested on a drug charge in a downtown hotel.
Jan. 22, 1990: The Mayor checks into Hanley-Hazelden Treatment Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. His spokeswoman says he will be treated for alcoholism.
Feb. 15, 1990: A federal grand jury indicts Mr. Barry on eight counts of perjury and possession of a controlled substance.
 
Source: Associated Press

SECTION: Section A; Page 34, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 550 words

HEADLINE: Lessons in Capitalism - From Poland

 BODY:
You're unemployed. What kind of help do you want from your Government? How about unemployment insurance that starts high but falls over time? The benefits would remain high if you enrolled in a training program but drop to zero if you refused legitimate job offers.
Perhaps that sounds too meager. Then how about a government loan to help you start your own business? Or a subsidized loan to a company that offers you a job? That kind of help might sound utopian, at least in the United States. 
But it's not utopian for Poland. Poor, brave Poland, which has just started the struggle to capitalism, has adopted exactly such a program to deal with the unemployment caused by its radical economic reforms. Americans have presumed they have a lot to teach the Poles about capitalism; perhaps it's also the other way around.
As of Jan. 1, the Solidarity-led Polish Goverment ended price controls and subsidies. Forced to make it on their own, many businesses are failing; others are laying off excess workers. Bankruptcy and unemployment are becoming commonplace. By the end of the year more than a million Poles are likely to be jobless - in a country that had not before known unemployment.
The January burst of inflation was severe: prices went up 70 percent and real incomes went down more than one-third. But the recent news is not so grim. Inflation is no longer soaring; milk and meat prices have even fallen a bit. The value of the zloty is stable and shortages are disappearing. Yes, Polish workers are paying higher prices for supplies. But at least there are supplies to buy, and without waiting hours in line. Essential to the Polish plan is the ongoing support of workers. Laid-off workers will eventually be retrained and rehired. But that is small comfort to families facing stiff inflation and no paycheck. To earn labor's patience, the Government had to establish a generous safety net.
Starting from scratch, and listening to Western advisers, the Poles adopted a remarkably smart program. It provides ample help to displaced workers but with elegant incentives to match them to new jobs. Unemployed workers are rewarded for retraining or accepting reasonable offers; companies are rewarded if they create new jobs.
Will the program work? That's unclear. It will be expensive, perhaps too costly for this poor country to bear. The Government will probably have to rein in benefits. But if it retrenches too much, it will lose political support for the rest of the economic reform.
That is why upcoming visits to Poland by the World Bank are crucial. Just last week the bank announced new project loans for Poland. But the Government's immediate need is for cash, not projects. Poland is trying to do overnight what it took industrialized Western countries decades to achieve. The Government needs cash to pay for its safety net, without which workers will not tolerate the painful transition to economic revival.
Solidarity's safety net is compassionate yet disciplined. A nation stifled for more than 40 years by a sclerotic bureaucracy is on the verge of teaching the West about how markets work best. Can the World Bank recognize this startling fact and respond accordingly? It will have to do so, and fast, or else Solidarity's sensible compassion will go down the drain.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Let's Get Serious About Pentagon Cuts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am puzzled by Irving Kristol's arithmetic in ''There Is No Military Free Lunch'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 2). He states that fixing the United States military budget at its current level would mean that, in 10 years, its buying power would be about 33 percent less than now - a fair projection, given the rate of inflation. 
But Mr. Kristol states that the United States military establishment will then ''probably be slightly superior to Japan's, though perhaps not quite a match for Syria's tanks and air power.''
Now Japan spends about 1 percent of gross national product on defense, the United States more than 6 percent. Our G.N.P. is almost double Japan's; hence, we must be spending 10 to 12 times as much. Even if United States expenditures decline one-third in constant dollars, as Mr. Kristol projects, they would be seven to eight times current Japanese expenditures. Slightly superior? Is the real problem how much the United States spends on the military or how efficiently it uses the funds?
The comparison with Syria is even more ludicrous. The Syrian military is inferior to that of Israel, a country whose gross national product is a tiny fraction of the American and which must also contend with the Palestinian uprising and with threats on its Lebanese border.
Such scare projections, designed to protect the military budget at the expense of other needed programs, deflect from a reasoned consideration of just how much defense spending can be cut in the new international situation.
 
>SEYMOUR MAXWELL FINGER
 New York, Feb. 2, 1990
The writer is senior fellow, Ralph Bunche Institute, CUNY Graduate School and University Center.

SECTION: Section A; Page 34, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 381 words

HEADLINE: Adult Illiteracy Is as Dangerous to the U.S. as Substance Abuse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Recently, a group of adults learning to read in the Brooklyn Public Library's literacy program wrote to urge me to work for passage of H.R. 3123, the adult literacy and employability bill. I was so moved by their letters that I decided to visit the library's Williamsburgh adult learning center and learn more about the program.
One of the students I met, a retired man who had worked his whole life and helped raise a family without being able to read, told me, ''I'm not stupid, I just couldn't read.'' 
That distinction captures the situation of most adult nonreaders. They have to be intelligent to hide their inability from friends, co-workers and even family members year after year. They just can't read. But they want to, desperately, and we as a nation must give them the opportunity.
Twenty-five hundred adult nonreaders are enrolled in the Brooklyn Public Library program. Some work with volunteer tutors, others in small study groups, while still others learn independently on computers in the learning centers. The Williamsburgh center is one of five, all in communities with large numbers of unemployed youth, adults with low reading levels and adults wishing to learn English. My visit reinforced my belief in a national literacy initiative. I am proud to be a co-sponsor of the adult literacy and employability bill.
Almost 30 million Americans are functionally illiterate, unable to use reading, writing and computational skills in their lives. The bill would provide coordination of adult, family and work force literacy programs at the national and state level.
H.R. 3123 would make literacy a national priority, establishing a Cabinet council, a national literacy center and state resource centers. It would increase aid to state programs for English as a second language and institute challenge grants and funds for library literacy demonstration programs.
According to the Department of Education, 60 percent of all prison inmates are illiterate, and 85 percent of juvenile offenders have problems reading. Illiteracy is closely correlated with poverty, crime and unemployment. It is as much a threat to our national security as substance abuse.
 
EDOLPHUS TOWNS
Member of Congress, 11th Dist., N.Y.
 Washington, Jan. 19, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Whom to Root For

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Tyson flattened. Drexel Burnham disappears. De Klerk springs Mandela. Trump bounces Czech wife. Gorby caves on fearful symmetry.
Faced with this rush of headlines, ABC Radio News declared overload and led with the Oscar nominations. News junkies who rely on knee-jerk reactions find their patellas numbed. 
To program our weltanschauung so it can absorb this saturation of sensation, we must first decide for whom to root. As the stories develop, this mindset will enable us to hiss our designated villains and side with our heroes, thereby minimizing cognitive dissonance. 1. Tyson vs. Douglas. The first reaction is to hail the victorious older underdog, Buster Douglas, who knocked out the swaggering champ. But the rematch will test the mettle of the ex-champ in making a comeback.
Mike Tyson, of the long fur coat and glitzy life style, deserved comeuppance. At first a sore loser, he has cast aside petulance. If he does make it back, he should turn out to be more Clay than Liston; we can do with men tempered but not humbled by defeat, such as Ted Kennedy, Richard Nixon and George Bush. Root for: Tyson. 2. Smug Wall Street vs. the shattered House That Mike Built. The Schadenfreudian slips are showing throughout the securities industry: Establishment types, sucked into the vortex of leveraged takeover by the originality of Michael Milken, can hardly conceal their glee at the demise of Drexel Burnham, which ignobly ran out on him to save its skin but lost anyway.
Now the Feds will try to add insider trading to injury. Mr. Milken, his back to the wall, wants to fight the all-out Government campaign against him against all friendly advice to cop a plea. On the basis of contrarianism and the unpredictability of juries, root for: Milken. 3. De Klerk vs. Mandela. Here's Nelson Mandela being lionized and all but canonized after 27 years of suffering in jail, but falling short of the eloquence of nonviolent Martin Luther King Jr.; and here's Frederik de Klerk, dragging his countrymen into the path of righteousness at great personal and political peril, getting the ''but what have you done for me lately'' treatment in the U.S.
Mr. Mandela needs to be talked out of outmoded, stultifying Socialism while Mr. de Klerk should be encouraged to fold blacks into a democratic, free-market society that needs them. Root for: both, and not one over the other, because if one wins, both lose. 4. Gorbachev vs. the radicals vs. the nomenklatura. In this three-way struggle, the old apparat is the loser: not even changing its name will save the party. But apparatchiks evidently can restrain Gorby from turning to capitalism and salvation; instead, he is making himself the new Napoleon. The radicals, without Sakharov, seem stuck with the populist Yeltsin, but the reformist to watch is Yuri Afanasyev, who wants free markets and free people.
Gorby stays in the saddle miraculously, but his economic horse goes nowhere, and it's distasteful to cheer his grab for one-man power. But the swinging Yeltsin is a transition to trouble, and the rigid Ryzhkov and Ligachev would preside over the sure ruin of Russia; root for Afanasyev, the radical long shot. 5. The local leaders of the intifada vs. the Tunis-based leaders of the P.L.O. Likudniks in Israel see Faisal Husseini as a local P.L.O. front, and he is regularly arrested and harassed. But this Palestinian promptly condemned the slaughter of Israeli tourists in Egypt, while Yasir Arafat's deputy, Salah Khalaf, boasted of ''similar operations'' to come, in effect condoning the murders until Egyptian pressure forced a grudging disavowal. Root for: Mr. Husseini and the intifada against the Tunis terrorcrats. 6. Donald vs. Ivana. In what was dubbed ''the Trump scuttle,'' the New York Daily News gossip columnist Liz Smith revealed that the nation's most celebrated deal artist is working a leveraged throwout of his wife, who betrayed his trust by turning 40.
The issue is not the validity of a pre-nuptial contract (a deal's a deal) but the talent of the battle's publicity titans. Howard Rubenstein, maker of mayors and touter of tycoons, is Donald's media handler, pitted against John Scanlon, who turned Frank Lorenzo into a lovable pussycat and is now brushing the media's teeth with Ivana. Root for: Liz Smith.
In a worldwind of headlines, only a consistent worldview will bring peace of mind. Tolerance, Dignity, Civility. Root for: ''Driving Miss Daisy.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 7, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1477 words

HEADLINE: LAW;
Progress Spawns Question: Who Owns the Law?

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Filling shelf after shelf in any law library, the bound volumes of state statutes appear sedate and inert, part of the law's archives rather than its current battles.
But a dispute over public access to state law has transformed those serene bookshelves into a legal battleground. Fueled by new technology and big economic stakes, the debate is being conducted in the arcane, highly specialized language of copyright law. But at its heart is a question so fundamental as to be almost startling: Who owns the law?
One phase of the debate ended last month when the Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal filed by the State of Texas in an unsuccessful lawsuit against the West Publishing Company, for nearly 50 years the publisher of the state's statutes. While evidently of no interest to the Justices, the case was closely watched by copyright lawyers, legal publishers and officials of other states where versions of the same dispute are simmering. 
West, a privately held company based in St. Paul, Minn., is the country's premier publisher of judicial opinions and other legal material. As it does in some two dozen states, West publishes a multi-volume, annotated edition of the laws passed by the Texas Legislature. Each volume of Vernon's Annotated Texas Statutes, named for the publisher that began the project in 1914, carries West's copyright.
 
Computers Change Everything
For decades, no one had any reason to consider what West's copyright claim actually encompassed. But computers changed all that in the mid-1980's, as West and a new competitor, Mead Data Central Inc., began to offer computerized access to judicial opinions. In a legal research market with annual revenue in the hundreds of millions of dollars, copyright questions suddenly mattered a great deal. (A Mead Data Central subsidiary, the Michie Company, is the chief publisher of legal material in 21 states. Several other states do their own publishing.) West publishes the decisions of all Federal courts and nearly all state appellate courts. Its judicial volumes long ago acquired official status throughout the legal world, with most courts requiring citation to West volumes.
Mead Data sought to include the West page numbers in its Lexis computerized data base, making it possible for customers to cite the West volumes without having to buy them. Judicial opinions themselves may not be copyrighted, but West obtained an injunction on the ground that it had a valid copyright in its ''arrangement'' of the opinions. In 1988, after the Supreme Court refused to hear Mead Data's appeal, the two companies settled their dispute, with Mead agreeing to pay a fee for its use of the West page numbers.
The battle over judicial opinions inevitably spilled over to the area of state statutes. In 1985, West and the Bancroft-Whitney Company, a legal publisher based in San Francisco, sued each other over the validity of West's copyright in the Vernon's Texas volumes. The case remains undecided in Federal District Court in Minnesota. Meanwhile, the dispute caught the attention of the Texas Attorney General, Jim Mattox, who brought a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Austin seeking a declaration that West's copyright was invalid. Who Does the Updating? The suit had a limited focus. Texas conceded that West was entitled to a copyright in the annotations and interpretive material that West staff members produced and included in the volumes. For its part, West disclaimed copyright in the actual words of the Texas Legislature. The dispute was over West's claim to copyright in the way it had arranged, numbered and titled the Texas laws.
In many states, legislative officials are responsible for integrating the new laws passed in each legislative session into the existing state code. But Texas, along with Illinois, Pennsylvania and some others, has left this task to private publishers. The resulting products are amalgams that do not fit neatly within any legal precedent.
For example, the Texas Legislature completed its last statutory revision in 1925. Not surprisingly, the 1925 statutes failed to anticipate many features of the modern regulatory state, and it was West that supplied the framework for the legislative output of the ensuing decades. Statutory chapter headings that covered a paragraph in the 1925 edition grew in some instances to cover entire volumes of hundreds of pages, with new sections and numbers added by West.
In its lawsuit, Texas maintained that the headings and numbers supplied by West were, like the statutes themselves, in the public domain and not subject to private ownership. The state argued that the numbers and titles had become such an intrinsic part of the state code that the public law would be ''completely inaccessible'' without them, in effect giving West control of the statutes themselves. If there is a copyright, the state said, it belongs not to West but to the people of Texas.
 
Suit's Rationale Explained
''This is a significant public policy issue,'' Allene D. Evans, head of the state's antitrust division, said in an interview explaining why the state brought its suit. ''The fact that West Publishing does a good job conceals the real issue, which is who controls access to public law. Can a private company be allowed to be the gatekeeper?''
West's view was that copyright law entitled it to protect the fruits of its labor. ''The organic law passed by the Legislature ought to be open to all, and of course it is,'' Vance K. Opperman, a Minneapolis lawyer who is West's main outside counsel, said in an interview. ''But that which we've created and paid for over the years, we're entitled to.''
Whatever the lawsuit's merits, no court reached them. Federal District Judge Walter S. Smith Jr. dismissed the suit in a decision affirmed by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judge Smith said that because West ''has not done or threatened to do anything'' that would harm the interests of Texas, the state's concern was too hypothetical to create the ''actual controversy'' needed to invoke the jurisdiction of the Federal courts. The Supreme Court denied the state's appeal without comment.
As a result, the law in this area remains unsettled. ''It's a wonderful issue,'' said Peter A. Jaszi, a copyright specialist at the Washington College of Law at American University here. ''It goes to the tension at the heart of copyright law between dissemination and restriction.''
 
'Just the Beginning'
Professor Jaszi said the legal doctrine of ''compilation copyright'' supported West's position. As an example, he said someone who published a collection of poems that were in the public domain would nonetheless have a valid copyright in the arrangement of the poems into categories like ''17th century lyrics'' or ''Victorian pastorals.''
''But to say that West may have a valid compilation copyright is just the beginning of the analysis,'' Professor Jaszi continued. ''It's probably a mistake to resolve cases like this by doctrine alone. It's really a political question.''
In Illinois, where West publishes the Illinois Revised Statutes, the dispute has taken a different form. In both 1987 and 1988, in an effort to defeat West's copyright claim, the Legislature passed a bill declaring that West's statutory numbers and headings were in the public domain. Fearing a lawsuit from West, Gov. James R. Thompson vetoed the bill both times. Last year, the Legislature and Governor agreed on a bill requiring the state's Legislative Reference Bureau to produce a plan for recodifying the state's entire body of law, a project that will take years.
Three years ago, the American Bar Association became sufficiently concerned about the issue to create a special Subcommittee on Claims to Copyright in Statutory Names, Numbers and Arrangements. The bar association's section dealing with copyright law unanimously adopted the subcommittee's resolution opposing copyright protection for statutory names and numbers at the annual meeting last summer.
James Dabney, a New York copyright lawyer who heads the subcommittee, said in an interview that the names and numbers are ''fundamental bits of information'' essential to insuring public access to the law. He said the argument that competing publishers should be barred from using an original publisher's names and numbers is ''the equivalent of saying that although English is the language spoken here, if you want to compete you have to invent an entirely new language.''
Mr. Dabney said the statutes of 31 states were theoretically subject to competing copyright claims. He noted that some states, newly aware of a profit potential, were now claiming the copyright themselves and charging fees to private companies that want to publish their statutes. The subcommittee also opposes that step, he said.

SECTION: Section C; Page 33, Column 1; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 988 words

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Lives of New Yorkers, Uptown and Down

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

The Colorist
By Susan Daitch
242 pages. Paperback. Vintage Contemporaries. $8.95.
 
Leap Year
By Peter Cameron
245 pages. Harper & Row. $18.95.
The New Yorkers in these two new novels are young, hip, disoriented and self-involved. The ones in ''The Colorist'' live on the Lower East Side in grungy studios and lofts, wear colored streaks in their hair and wonder how they'll pay the rent. The ones in ''Leap Year'' live in appliance-laden apartments in SoHo and on the Upper West Side, shop at Barneys for their clothes and spend a lot of time talking about happiness and self-fulfillment. Though the characters in both novels are pretty casual about sex -a woman in ''The Colorist'' takes up prostitution as a way of earning pocket money; a man in ''Leap Year'' shuttles back and forth between the beds of his ex-wife and his male lover - no one seems to worry about AIDS. 
Julie, the narrator of ''The Colorist,'' Susan Daitch's second novel, works at a comic book company, coloring in the panels of a strip called ''Electra'' - a space-age fantasy about a warrior girl, who's constantly getting into trouble. ''Two fates, happy marriage and death, could be approached but must never actually be met,'' writes Ms. Daitch. ''For anyone or anything in space to fall, even superficially, in love with Electra was useless. Love for Electra was doomed, and death a subject of close brushes, but never the big end.''
When the strip is discontinued, Julie loses her job and she begins making up her own version of ''Electra'' at home, a version in which Electra falls to earth, becomes a homeless person and feels lost and confused -a state of mind that mirrors Julie's own.
In fact Julie's entire existence seems aimless and random. After a frightening encounter with a would-be mugger, she moves in with a man she barely knows - a photographer named Eamonn, whose work oddly complements her own cartoons. Eamonn disappears for long periods of time - he seems to be on some sort of secret mission in Ireland - and Julie passes some of that time dating Martin, a former office colleague, who may or may not have a mysterious half-brother. She desultorily looks for a new job, postpones a date with the unemployment office and ends up helping a friend who has borrowed a call girl's little black book.
Although Ms. Daitch's narrative tends to be as unstructured and improvisatory as Julie's messy life -the novel suffers from an all-inclusiveness that causes the reader's attention to wander - she demonstrates an observant eye and a gift for capturing the hectic rhythms of the trendy downtown Manhattan of Susan Seidelman's movie ''Desperately Seeking Susan.'' Her vision of New York is one of a cartoon city, where anything is possible, where real-life adventures resemble the antic happenings of a comic strip, where nothing is permanent and nothing is too far-fetched.
The events in Peter Cameron's ''Leap Year'' tend to be even more frantic and implausible - a reflection, perhaps, of the pressures of writing serial fiction on deadline (the novel originally appeared in serial form in the weekly magazine 7 Days). The novel's hero, David, is so upset by his ex-wife's announcement that she is thinking of moving to California with her new boyfriend that he sticks his finger in a candle flame, contracts a serious infection in his hand and ends up in the hospital.
His daughter, Kate, meanwhile, has been abducted in a case of mistaken identity, and his ex-wife, Loren, soon winds up in the hospital as well, after a close encounter with a plate-glass window. Their friends, too, are having their share of traumas. Lillian, who has just gone to a local sperm bank for artificial insemination, suspects that her sperm donor is David's new lover, Heath; and Heath has meanwhile discovered that he's the chief suspect in the murder of a wealthy gallery owner.
Mr. Cameron makes no attempt to conceal the jerry-built structure of his novel. In fact, he seems to relish the use of coincidence and cheap jump-cuts (from one group of people watching a television show to another group watching the same program, etc.) as a way to point up the absurdities of contemporary life.
Relentlessly self-absorbed, Mr. Cameron's characters speak in zippy little sentences peppered with buzz words and psycho-babble phrases (''my biological clock is ticking away''; ''there is a capacity inside each of us to change'') and their 20- or 30-something lives seem defined by brand-name products and preoccupations. They watch ''Jeopardy'' and ''L.A. Law,'' read People and Art News, and drink Evian.
We get to know them in the way we get to know characters in a soap opera: they are defined less by their personalities, than by the situations they find themselves in - situations, like those in ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' (another novel originally written in serial form), that seem fresh off the front pages of the papers. Kate is kidnapped by a man who has been unable to win custody of his own daughter. Lillian goes to a sperm bank because she has despaired of finding an eligible man. Heath is ''discovered'' by a SoHo gallery that specializes in marketing young artists. Loren worries about nefarious doings at her daughter's day-care center.
Such events are not particularly well integrated into the overall narrative of ''Leap Year,'' and they give the reader the impression that the author is constantly straining for topicality and relevance. Although ''Leap Year'' attests to Mr. Cameron's blossoming satiric gifts and his instinctive feeling for the confusions of a generation that came of age in the 1980's, the novel lacks the skill and intelligence demonstrated by his recent collection of short stories (''One Way or Another''). Given his talents, the reader only hopes that he will take a little more time and care with his next book. News Corporationd(Harper & Row)Advance Publicationsd(Vintage)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 842 words

HEADLINE: Profits Fall At Ford And G.M.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The nation's two biggest auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, posted significant declines in earnings for the fourth quarter and the year, reflecting the softness in auto sales and their costly incentive programs for buyers. Ford's results also reflect the sale of the company's Rouge Steel subsidiary in the fourth quarter.
For the quarter, profits fell 49.9 percent at General Motors and 72.9 percent at Ford, the companies reported today.
For the year, profits fell 13.2 percent at G.M. and 27.5 percent at Ford. For the first time since 1985, General Motors' annual earnings outpaced those of Ford. 
Weak profits are likely to continue through the current quarter, as auto makers continue to offer hefty rebates on their products in order to sell them. But the picture has brightened somewhat through early February as retail sales for the first 10 days of the month perked up.
Analysts said Ford and General Motors lost money on North American operations in the fourth quarter. ''Once we get beyond the first quarter we can look forward to better results,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an auto analyst for Merrill Lynch.
 
Stock Prices Rise
The stock of both companies rose yesterday. G.M.'s common stock rose $1, to $44, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Ford stock was up 62.5 cents, to $45.25. Some analysts said the earnings were in line with expectations.
G.M.'s fourth-quarter profit dropped to $700 million, or $1.01 a share, from $1.4 billion, or $2.12 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. Revenue fell 3.1 percent to $31.4 billion from $32.4 billion.
For the year General Motors' income declined to $4.22 billion, or $6.33 a share, from $4.86 billion, or $7.17 a share. Revenue was $126.9 billion, the company's third-best year, up 2.7 percent from $123.6 billion in 1988.
At Ford, fourth-quarter income dropped to $314 million, or 68 cents a share, from $1.16 billion, or $2.42 a share, in the fourth quarter a year earlier. Revenue edged up to $24.1 billion, from $23.9 billion a year earlier. The results include a one-time charge of $424.3 million, or 91 cents a share, to account for the previously announced sale of Ford's Rouge Steel subsidiary.
For the year, Ford's income dipped to $3.84 billion, or $8.22 a share, from $5.3 billion, or $10.96 a share, in 1988. Revenue rose 4 percent, to $96.1 billion, from $92.4 billion in 1988.
G.M.'s worldwide fourth-quarter vehicle production, on which revenue and profit are based, was off 7.5 percent; domestic vehicle production in the quarter fell 19.7 percent.
Roger B. Smith, the chairman of General Motors, said that in 1989 ''although profitability of G.M's North American automotive operations declined due to lower volume and higher selling expense, they made significant progress in terms of both product competitiveness and improved operating efficiencies.''
General Motors declined to specify its profit in North America. But a spokesman said, ''We're not satisfied with the number.'' However, 1989 profit-sharing payments to hourly workers, which are based on North American performance, will be $22.1 million, or only $50 to each of 443,000 eligible United States workers.
Reacting to the G.M. earnings report, an United Automobile Workers vice president, Stephen P. Yokich, said the workers ''are not responsible for G.M.'s costly blunders, including its repeated failures to understand and target a rapidly changing market.''
General Motors' overseas operations posted a net profit of $2.7 billion, up about $100 million from 1988 and constituting about 64 percent of the company's total profit. G.M.'s Eletronic Data Systems and GM Delco Hughes units also posted significant profits on Wednesday, although the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the finance subsidiary, posted a 2.4 percent decline in profits.
 
Ford Motor
At Ford, the financial services group, which includes the Ford Motor Credit Company, posted profits of $660.3 million, down 4.5 percent from $691.4 million in 1988.
David McCammon, Ford's treasurer, said the decline resulted mainly from a narrowing of the margin between short-term interest rates and interest paid on auto and other loans.
Mr. McCammon said Ford had been able to avoid large reductions in white-collar employment and plant closings, which have taken place at General Motors and the Chrysler Corporation. General Motors and Chrysler have been hurt by costs associated with unused capacity.
But Ford continues to look for ways to economize, he said, by examining outlays for travel, consulting and other discretionary costs, as well as productivity and material cost improvements in manufacturing.
Profit-sharing payments to Ford workers in 1989 will be down more than 38 percent from the $2,800 paid to each worker last year, Mr. McCammon said. The specific amount will be announced to Ford workers Friday.
The Chrysler Corporation reported Wednesday that it had a loss of $664 million in the fourth quarter and that profits fell 65.8 percent for the year.

HEADLINE: The Economic Ripples Of a German Union

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prospect of a rapid economic union of West and East Germany is sending jitters through European and other bond markets, pushing interest rates higher.
But the effects of the economic union of the two Germanys, even if all goes relatively smoothly, will be felt far beyond higher rates. West Germany's turn to the East could upset the delicate balance of trade in Europe, experts say. Investment once headed for countries like Spain and Portugal could shift to East Germany and other Eastern European nations. 
The rising interest rates in Europe have already spread to the United States and will mean slower growth in this country, economists say. And the fact that the crucial economic decisions involved in a German reunification will be closely tied to politics should continue to unsettle the markets.
West Germany's position as having the strongest economy in Europe means that higher interest rates - or just the fear of higher ones - reverberate quickly across the Continent and the English Channel.
For now, economists say, the uncertainty of the situation and the fear of inflation are mostly responsible for sending West German bond prices down sharply and causing interest rates on the 10-year bond to rise on Monday above American rates for the first time in more than a decade. Yesterday, at 8.50 percent, the West German 10-year bond was still above the United States yield of 8.41 percent.
Other European bond markets reacted similarly in the last week, and stock markets, including West Germany's, fell. The West German mark, which had been consistently gaining strength, also fell against the dollar.
''Economic union will have a wide-ranging impact on many countries,'' said Hung Q. Tran, director of global fixed-income research at Deutsche Bank in New York. Although he does not think the impact will be dangerously disruptive, he added that it should reach the United States in the form of slower economic growth.
 
The Earthquake Nightmare
David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, is more worried. ''This could be the slow-motion version of the Tokyo earthquake,'' he said, referring to the bond market's nightmare scenario. In it, Tokyo is devastated by an earthquake and Japanese money invested in the United States is sucked back home to rebuild the country, forcing interest rates up sharply in this country.
The billions of dollars needed to rebuild East Germany and other countries in the Eastern bloc will put strains on world credit for years, economists say. Interest rates will rise as countries, especially those with trade deficits, like Britain, France and the United States, compete to attract investment. ''This puts a floor under interest rates everywhere,'' Mr. Tran said, even if it does not push them much higher.
Also, the West German central bank, the Bundesbank, is expected to work to contain the inflation that could explode from such a union. The bank would most likely push interest rates higher in Germany to slow economic growth. That in turn would force higher rates in Europe or a major currency realignment, which West Germany's European neighbors have been resisting.
The diversion of capital could also result in less investment for countries like Britain and the United States. And together with a rise in interest rates - or at least a much smaller decline than might have been expected just a few months ago - this means slower economic growth.
Norbert Walter, senior economist for Deutsche Bank A. G. in Frankfurt, said there will be a shift in economic growth prospects in the 1990's, with Europe growing faster than in the 1980's and the United States growing more slowly.
 
Effect on Southern Europe
The reunification could also have an impact on countries in Southern Europe, like Portugal, which have been thought of as sites for future West German and other European plants because workers' wages are lower there than in the rest of Europe. East Germany could now offer such a low-wage attraction, and these important investments could be diverted.
Mr. Hale said the ''cost of reunification will be a major shock to European financial stability.'' The key to this stability for the last several years has been that the West German surplus has helped finance the trade deficits in other countries, like France. These deficits, he said, would become more difficult to finance as the West German surplus shrank with its diversion to East Germany.
Two key variables are being watched by the markets - and disturbing them: the exchange rate that will be set for the conversion of East German marks into West German marks, and the potential cost to rebuild the economies of East Germany and the rest of Eastern Europe.
If the exchange rate is close to one to one, it will cause a sharp rise in inflation by increasing purchasing power in East Germany. The expected spurt in spending would push prices higher.
 
Big Cut in Savings
But if the rate is too far from one to one, it will mean a major cut in the savings of East Germans, the value of their pensions and their standard of living. Even at three to one, Deutsche Bank says, the average monthly pension for 2.2 million East Germans over the age of 65 would be 123 West German marks, or $73.50, compared with an average of 1,100 marks, or $657.30, in West Germany. The bank estimates it would cost 13 billion marks annually, or $7.77 billion, to bring the pension levels to 500 marks, or $298.78, in East Germany, a subsidy the West Germans would have to help the East German Government pay.
The cost of rebuilding East Germany's economy is hard to estimate. In the next 10 to 20 years, Morgan Stanley & Company in London says, the rebuilding of Eastern Europe could divert as much as 5 percent of Europe's national income. Other estimates, including those by Deutsche Bank, put the cost at 500 billion to 800 billion marks over 10 to 20 years.
 
Bond Market Overreaction
Mr. Walter said he felt that the bond markets in Germany and other European countries had overreacted to these two uncertainties. He said the assumption that most of the money to rebuild East Germany would have to come from the West Germans was wrong. Portions will come from other countries wanting to take advantage of the expected Eastern European boom. And the East German Government, by selling state-owned industries, will also contribute.
In addition, he argued that the burst of inflation in East Germany should not be permanent. While the price of bread and rents will go up for East Germans, he said, the price of cars and appliances should go down because cheaper and better Western versions would become available.
But Ronald I. McKinnon, a professor of economics at Stanford University, said he was worried about inflation and the loss of control. In the rush to reunification, politics, not economics, is determining the decisions. This means monetary union could come too far in advance of the needed economic reforms in East Germany.
''Suppose they are forced to choose a two to one exchange rate and work out the details later,'' he said, referring to a combined Germany. ''Then there is a real chance of the loss of monetary control.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
High Hopes And Deep Fears

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS this a time for economic euphoria, depression or a bland, boring and sluggish condition between those extremes?
Generating euphoria is the collapse of Communism and the end of the cold war. This week brought agreements between the Soviet Union and the West on a framework for negotiating the reunification of the two Germanys and cutbacks in conventional forces in Europe, with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, so eager to get a deal to rescue his nation's failing economy that he is willing to accept bigger cuts than President Bush.
Some analysts are hailing these events as the triumph of capitalism; they hold forth the promise of a continuing decline in military spending that sooner or later will enable the United States to wipe out its budget deficit, raise its savings rate, eliminate its trade deficit and regain its world leadership. Euphoria is also fed by hopes that the opening up of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union may provide a vast new area for capitalist development that would rekindle the postwar boom. 
But fears of depression feed on the mountain of debt and the danger that it could collapse and wreck the economic structure. It would be an irony beyond belief if, in the hour of capitalism's triumph, when the Communist states are seeking a model, capitalism should collapse under the weight of its speculative excesses. Such fears were heightened this week by the failure of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the mother of the ''junk bond'' revolution, now in disintegration.
''Drexel illustrates the overall problem of too much debt - Government debt, consumer debt, corporate debt,'' said William N. Griggs, managing partner of the investment advisory firm Griggs & Santow. ''A disaster is brewing,'' he added. James J. O'Leary, economic consultant to the United States Trust Company of New York, agrees. ''We have already seen the serious consequences of this overhang in rising delinquencies and foreclosures of commercial and home mortgages which have occurred during the strong business expansion,'' he said. ''The very heavy overhang of debt seems bound to pose much greater dangers in an economic slowdown or a possible recession.''
But when will the disaster arrive - and must it come? The stock market this week shrugged off the Drexel debacle, which it had expected. Some on Wall Street even felt that the fall of Drexel was a good and necessary corrective to a decade of excess and hazardous debt.
Most economists, including Mr. Griggs and Mr. O'Leary, still expect continuing slow growth and also see it as part of the remedy for past excesses. The consensus forecast of the 50 economists and economic forecasting groups surveyed this month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators calls for the American economy to grow at the sluggish rate of 1.6 percent in 1990, with a moderate pickup to 2.4 percent in 1991.
The Bush Administration is somewhat more optimistic, but its forecast is just within the upper limit of the private economists' range; it foresees 2.4 percent real economic growth in 1990 and 3.2 percent growth in 1991. The Congressional Budget Office is closer to the midpoint of the private economists' range, forecasting 1.7 percent growth this year and 2.4 percent in 1991. No euphoria, no depression, not even a recession.
What is the logic behind the nearly unanimous forecast of continuing but sluggish growth? Roger Kubarych, manager of Henry Kaufman & Company, speaks for most economists in stressing the sustaining role of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Kubarych, a former Fed economist, contends that with the economy slowing the Fed has ''latitude to bring down interest rates and ignore the dollar.'' Indeed, a decline in the dollar would spur United States exports and help stave off recession. The Fed has husbanded its resources and can afford to feed more reserves to the banking system, which is facing heavy risks at home and abroad.
Gently but firmly, the Administration is also leaning on the Fed to keep the economy growing. In its annual Economic Report, the President's Council of Economic Advisers plainly states, ''The Administration's primary economic policy goal is to promote further growth.'' It contends that monetary policy can deliver on that growth objective, consistent with its aim of holding down inflation. In fact, that is why it expects no recession now: It says that when inflation becomes intolerable, politically or economically, there is ''little choice but to tighten monetary policy, which typically brings on a recession,'' but it sees no such need now.
The immediate issue is whether the Fed is easing enough to head off a recession, which could turn into something far worse if it brought the debt structure crashing down. That would worsen pressures for trade protectionism, aggravate strained relations with Japan, exacerbate the third world debt problem and that of some major American banks. It would hurt those Communist nations now striving for political and economic freedom and links to world markets. A depression and climbing unemployment would be the worst possible advertisement for capitalism.
For the longer run, the issue is whether the Administration is doing enough, through its own fiscal policies, to solve the Federal deficit problem, which has so hampered the United States' ability to tackle the country's domestic social problems or provide international leadership.

HEADLINE: Big Jump In Starts Of Housing

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Housing starts jumped a record 29.6 percent last month as builders took advantage of the warmest January on record, the Government reported today, but analysts said the industry could not sustain the pace.
''Levels like the ones we're seeing here would indicate a housing boom, and there is just simply no fundamental reason to believe that is going on,'' said Thomas Holloway, senior economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association.
Housing starts tumbled to 1.37 million last year, the lowest level since the 1982 recession, and many analysts do not expect much improvement in 1990 because of a weak economy and high interest rates. 
 
Rebound From a Slump
The Commerce Department said new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.63 million units last month after slumping a revised 6.9 percent in December, when the weather was bitterly cold.
The January increase was the highest since housing starts first were recorded in 1959, the department said. It broke the previous record gain of 29.3 percent set in July 1982.
David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, said that ''if you average the December-January numbers, you come up with 1.02 million starts'' at an annual rate. And that, he added, ''is probably just about right.''
The Commerce Department said that unusually warm weather contributed to the January increase. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said January temperatures were the warmest for that month since the Government began keeping records 96 years ago.
Mr. Berson said the weather particularly affected single-family housing, where starts rose 24.8 percent, to 1.14 million units, the biggest gain since a 26 percent rise in March 1979.
John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, said the January figures ''must be looked at in terms of the big picture, which shows housing starts holding steady.''
 
Big Gain in Apartments
Apartment construction jumped 42.3 percent, to an annual rate of 488,000 units, after a revised 1.8 percent gain in December. January's gain was the sharpest since a 56 percent advance in January 1985.
Applications for building permits, a measure of future housing activity, jumped 26.7 percent, the highest gain since a 30 percent increase in June 1980. Applications had risen 2.5 percent in December.
Applications for multifamily permits leaped 82.5 percent. Housing analysts said builders were trying to get started on projects before new regulations take effect requiring that apartments be more accessible to handicapped people. Mr. Perlman said the new rules would add between $2,300 and $4,600 to the costs of apartment complexes.
The Midwest recorded the steepest jump in overall starts, up 42.6 percent. Starts were up 38.6 percent in the Northeast, 24.6 percent in the South and 23.1 percent in the West.

HEADLINE: Canada's Banks Increase Rates

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Canada's largest banks raised their prime lending rate three-quarters of a percentage point today, to 14.25 percent, the highest level since 1982.
Analysts expressed concern that the move could push the weakening economy into a recession by reducing spending. 
The rise from 13.5 percent followed an increase in the banks' cost of borrowing money. Canada's central bank raised its key rate, similar to the United States discount rate, to 13.34 percent from 12.79 percent last week.
The Royal Bank of Canada was the first to announce the increase in its prime rate, charged to its best corporate customers, and was quickly followed by its competitors. The prime rate had sat at 13.5 percent since March.
The central bank has pushed up interest rates in recent days to attract foreign investment and support the Canadian dollar, which has fallen more than 3 American cents in the last month.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Shifts in Travel Group At American Express

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The American Express Company announced yesterday that R. Craig Hoenshell had been appointed the new president of its Traveler's Cheque Group USA.
Mr. Hoenshell, 45 years old, replaces Ronald K. Glover, who resigned earlier this month to become head of the business credit services division of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.
American Express also announced other appointments in its Travel Related Services division, which accounted for 70 percent of its pretax income last year. 
Phillip J. Riese, 40, was named executive vice president of the personal card division, which handles the green American Express card. Mr. Riese, who was executive vice president of the establishment services division, which deals with airlines, hotels, merchants and other retailers who accept the company's cards, led the team that successfully introduced the Optima card, American Express's revolving-credit card.
Named to replace Mr. Riese as executive vice president of establishment services was Gerald Luterman, 46, former chief financial officer for the company's Travel Related Services-North America division. Louis J. Lombardo, 46, senior vice president of card operations, was named to the newly created position of executive vice president of card operations.
Mr. Hoenshell enters a sluggish business. Last year, sales of traveler's checks grew only 2.3 percent, to $24.1 billion, mainly because of a weak economy and slow growth in travel. Asked about ways he might improve business, Mr. Hoenshell said American Express was considering a new check for everyday use by people who are not traveling.
The new version might be similar to the gift checks that American Express successfully promoted during the Christmas season, Mr. Hoenshell said. Those checks were on gold paper with a different typeface and style from regular traveler's checks.
''We aren't completely synonymous yet with safe money that you carry around all the time,'' Mr. Hoenshell said.
While there are no details yet for the new check, one thing is clear: like traveler's checks, users would be charged a fee and the checks would be refundable if lost or stolen.
Mr. Hoenshell, a grocer's son and former salesman with the International Business Machines Corporation, has spent much of his career in data processing and accounting. A graduate of the University of Nebraska, he majored in accounting because his college counselor said it was the most difficult of business majors. ''It was a macho thing to do,'' he said.
At American Express, Mr. Hoenshell was most recently executive vice president of consumer lending, where he oversaw credit lines associated with the green card and the premium gold and platinum cards.
He helped revitalize American Express's sign and travel feature, whose use was low and profitabilty weak. The feature allowed members to pay for airline tickets over 3, 6, 12 or 24 months instead of all at once, but was not used extensively. Now, payment is automatically divided over 36 months.
''We converted it from an installment loan, which people are not familiar with in a charge card, to a revolving-credit loan, which people are familiar with,'' Mr. Hoenshell said.

HEADLINE: Approval of Extra Money For Savings Rescue Is Near

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The agency that oversees the bailout of the savings and loan industry is close to approving a plan that will permit the additional borrowing of more than $40 billion from the Treasury Department this year. The new money is needed to cover the interim costs of taking over and selling off insolvent institutions.
Officials of the Resolution Trust Corporation Oversight Board said today that the added borrowings would total $11 billion for the first quarter of 1990, and could eventually total $44 billion by the end of 1990. 
Those funds would be in addition to the $50 billion the savings and loan bailout legislation has already designated to cover losses at hundreds of ailing savings and loan associations the Government plans to take over and sell off by August 1992.
But unlike the $50 billion, regulators say the interim financing will eventually be paid off when the Government liquidates the real estate and other troubled assets it inherits from the sick savings institutions.
 
Plan Set Forth on Capitol Hill
The plan was described to Capitol Hill staff members today by top officials of both the Resolution Trust Corporation and its Oversight Board. The Oversight Board sets broad policies for the bailout, while the trust corporation manages the bailout on a day-to-day basis and is the agency dealing with interested investors.
These officials said that the plan had been carefully circulated among the members of the Oversight Board - its chairman, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development - and that they anticipated no major changes.
The issue of interim financing has been controversial because some members of Congress see it as giving regulators access to unlimited sources of funds that could eventually be lost, adding to the borrowing of the Federal Government and increasing the Federal budget deficit.
But the request by the agency for new funds comes as no surprise, since from the beginning of the debate on the bailout legislation, regulators have warned that the need for large sums of money to finance the takeovers and sale of assets would exceed the $50 billion in anticipated losses.
 
Debate on How to Raise the Funds
The bailout legislation, however, was vague on how the Government would raise the cash, leaving that to the Treasury Department. Since the legislation was passed, debate has centered on how to raise the money without disrupting the budget-balancing discipline and without paying excessive interest rates.
The plan outlined by William Taylor, the president of the Oversight Board, and David C. Cooke, president of the trust corporation, calls for the borrowings to be done through the Federal Financing Bank, the arm of the Treasury that acts as a conduit for lending money to Federal agencies. Under the agreement, the trust corporation will pay a premium equal to one-eighth of a percentage point above 90-day Treasury bills.
A crucial point that neither Mr. Taylor nor Mr. Cooke addressed was the budgetary treatment of the new borrowings, and particularly the extent to which they will increase the deficit as measured by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act.
One Congressional aide, who asked not to be identified, said that for the first nine months of this year, the borrowings will indeed add to the deficit but will not prompt larger spending cuts under Gramm-Rudman.
But borrowings for the 1991 fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 could raise the deficit, precipitating deeper cuts than expected in both domestic programs and military spending.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Consolidation Of Paper Makers

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
DESPITE the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation's decision to auction itself to the highest bidder, analysts and industry experts predict that the giant paper producer will most likely be acquired by its unwanted suitor, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation.
And they are already turning their attention to the likely impact of that merger. Such a deal, they say, would quicken the consolidation of the paper industry by forcing other large paper companies to try to strengthen their competitive positions by acquiring smaller players with specialty niches.
Several analysts said the most likely targets would be smaller paper companies with particular strengths in one or two grades of paper. They mentioned the Union Camp Corporation, a Wayne, N.J., producer of linerboard used in making cardboard boxes; the Potlatch Corporation, a San Francisco producer of white paper and paperboard, and the Mead Corporation, a major lumber concern that is based in Dayton, Ohio. 
The big paper companies that are expected to go shopping include the Champion International Corporation, the Weyerhaeuser Company and the International Paper Company, which has already been on an acquisition binge.
A number of forces will lead to consolidation, the analysts say. Growing capacity will outstrip demand within the next year and paper prices will tumble in the next two years, making paper companies less expensive to buy, they say.
These experts predict that in an industry where few companies have more than a 15 to 20 percent market share in any product, a weakening of the market will compel producers to seek economies of scale through acquisition.
''You have to have economy of scale,'' said Hartwig Geginat, chief executive of Feldmuhle A.G., the large West German paper producer, and president of the European Paper Association. ''And as the capital involved in modernizing becomes more important, companies find that you can increase productivity and profitability by consolidating. I think there is no question about the fact that there will be more consolidation in the paper industry around the world.''
To be sure, the deal that is expected to provide impetus for the industry's consolidation is a long way from being done. Georgia-Pacific's $3.6 billion bid for Great Northern, first made in October, has turned into the most bitter takeover battle in the American paper industry. A string of lawsuits has been filed challenging Great Northern's anti-takeover provisions and asserting that the combination would violate antitrust laws. Georgia-Pacific has won several rounds in recent days.
To avoid some antitrust objections, Georgia-Pacific said this week that it would sell its safety paper business, which makes paper for checks and stock certificates, to a privately held company in Seattle. Great Northern is active in that niche.
Great Northern's decision on Tuesday to place itself up for sale has pushed its share price above the $63 offer price, a sign that some investors anticipate a bidding war to ensue. But even the analysts who expect Georgia-Pacific to succeed say the result will cause some problems. For one, its debt would soar, they say, from the current debt-to-capital ratio of 42 percent to 70 percent.
T. Marshall Hahn, Georgia-Pacific's chairman, acknowledges that the acquisition would take the ratio ''higher than 65 percent, but in the 60's.'' He said that paying off the debt would not be a major problem. ''In 1988, we invested $2 billion: $800 million in acquisitions, $700 in capital expenditures and $400 in the repurchase of our stock,'' he said. ''At the end of 1988, we had actually dropped the debt-to-capital ratio.''
Asset sales will not be necessary or desirable, he said, adding, ''Even with a downturn in prices and a significant capital-spending program, we will be able to work down that debt level to the low 40's within five years.''
Still, some analysts think that the sale of some parts of the merged company would be unavoidable. Sherman Chao, a paper analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc., said a likely candidate for sale would be Great Northern's paper distribution business, which last year had about $1.3 billion in sales. The distribution business, one of the largest in the United States, will be a strategic asset for a non-American paper company seeking to get a foothold for its products in the United States.
Mr. Hahn said that as heated as the current battle was, he was preparing to run a merged Georgia-Pacific and Great Northern. ''In the future of the industry, you will see larger, more efficient plants, more emphasis on quality and you will see the world as the marketplace for each mill, no matter where it's located,'' he said. ''I'm just preparing to compete in that environment.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Endure a Day of Bad News

BYLINE: By H.J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were battered yesterday by an array of developments that began occurring the moment the New York market opened.
The tone of the fixed-income market was set early when prices of Treasury bonds weakened in Tokyo, reflecting fears there that West Germany would raise basic interest rates yesterday. The West German authorities took no such action.
Dealers said the market in the United States was somewhat edgy, as it often is before a shortened trading session and a long weekend. Most government securities houses will close today at 2 P.M., Eastern standard time, for an early start to an extended weekend that includes the Washington's Birthday holiday on Monday. 
 
More Drexel Holdings
The market yesterday also faced more offerings of Treasury issues from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent company filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday. Many traders and investors had thought that Drexel's Treasury holdings had already been distributed and absorbed by the market.
The market was also unsettled by the report of an unexpectedly sharp rise in housing construction in January and, more important, a big jump in building permits. Any sign of a stronger economy tends to be bearish for fixed-income securities because it raises inflation fears and the prospect that forthcoming debt issues will offer higher yields than outstanding ones.
One analyst said the market had perhaps misread the housing data. ''While the fixed-income market factored in January's much improved weather, we don't think many realized that the new Federal regulations requiring builders to install special facilities for the physically handicapped were partly responsible for the increase,'' said Philip Braverman, chief economist at DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the big Japanese financial organization. ''Many builders rushed to either start or file for permits to beat the deadline.''
 
Bailout Agency Acts
Later in the session, the Treasury debt market was ruffled by news that the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency that is trying to bail out the savings and loan industry, planned to announce borrowings of at least $40 billion through the issuance of short-term debt this year.
The trust corporation plans to borrow the money from the Federal Financing Bank, the arm of the Treasury that acts as a conduit for lending money to Federal agencies.
Next Wednesday, the Treasury plans to auction $10 billion of two-year notes, which traded on a when-issued basis yesterday to yield 8.31 percent, up from 8.27 percent on Wednesday. On Thursday next week, the Treasury plans to auction $8 billion of five-year notes. Their yield on a when-issued basis rose to 8.33 percent, from 8.29 percent.
Other reports circulated later yesterday that the Federal Reserve had effected ''under the table'' sales of $1.8 billion of Treasury bills and other short-term instruments on behalf of a foreign central bank. In such operations, the Fed uses only a few dealers to distribute the securities. In its routine money market operations, the Fed uses most, if not all, the primary dealers.
The Federal funds rate rose yesterday to 8 3/8 percent, from 8 1/4 percent, but dealers said the Fed did not intervene in the market. Many credit market analysts believe the Fed wants a rate of 8 1/8 percent on the short-term loans that banks make to each other.
Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, said the reports of the Fed sales came out about the the same time as the reports of the Resolution Trust plan to raise cash. The two developments, he said, ''probably added a few basis points to bill rates and yields on the short notes.''
Discount rates on 90-day Treasury bills climbed 8 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.70 percent. The six-month bills gained 7 basis points, to 7.67 percent, and the one-year bills rose 7 basis points, to 7.54 percent.
As is often the case, the rise in short-term rates rippled out to the long end of Treasury maturities. The new bellwether Treasury long bonds, the 8 1/2 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered late in the day at 100 16/32, down 16/32, or $5 for each $1,000 of face value. The yield on the long bond rose 5 basis points, to 8.45 percent.
Among other Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the new long notes, the 8 1/2's of 2000, fell 8/32, to 100 19/32, for a yield of 8.41 percent; the 8 3/8's of 1993 lost 5/32, to 100 5/32, and now yield 8.31 percent, and the 8 1/4's of 1992 fell 4/32, to 99 21/ 32, and also yield 8.31 percent.
Mr. Ricchiuto does not expect a slow day today, even though the trading session is shortened. ''The fixed-income market will get the December merchandise trade deficit figures at the opening, along with the Government's January industrial production and factory capacity use for the month,'' he said. ''The Street expects the deficit to shrink by a billion dollars, to $9.5 billion, but the bond market's reaction will be determined by whether the reduction was caused by reduced imports or stronger exports.'' 'Junk Bond' Market In the high-yield market, prices of many junk bonds rose slightly yesterday, as corporations bought back these battered securities, said dealers.
Bonds of well-known companies like Colt Industries and Duracell Holdings were up one-quarter to one-half point, in what one trader said was modest trading. One RJR Nabisco bond was up three-fourths of a point.
But several issues were off sharply. Some bonds of Burlington Holdings plunged 8 points, or $80 for every $1,000 face amount, to about 90. The company reported lower-than-expected earnings. ''Even mildly disappointing news is going to be treated very negatively by bond holders due to market conditions,'' said Mariel Clemensen, the vice president of junk bond research at Citicorp Securities Markets Inc.
Bonds of the Ambase Corporationalso traded down 20 points, to about 63. The insurance company is one of the unsecured creditors of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
2d Round of Global Bonds Is Priced by the World Bank

 BODY:
The World Bank yesterday priced its second $1.5 billion issue of global bonds in nearly five months.
A 15-member syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company began offering the bonds simultaneously in the United States, Europe and, for the first time, in the Japanese markets.
Unlike the 10-year bonds sold in September 1989, these bonds have a seven-year maturity. Underwriters gave the new issue an 8 3/4 percent coupon and offered it at a price of 100, to yield about 33.4 basis points more than seven-year Treasury notes. 
The yield spread at pricing was near the low end of what had been expected. The expectations had ranged from 35 to 38 basis points over Treasuries with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The World Bank, owned by 151 Governments, including the United States and Japan, is the largest source of loans to third world countries. The proceeds from the sale will be used for these loans.
In the first sale in September, the bonds were not sold directly on the Japanese market but were traded among Japanese customers immediately afterward. This time, Japanese authorities allowed the bonds to be sold directly to the Japanese market.
According to traders, yesterday's bond offering was well received and oversubscribed, meaning there were requests to purchase more securities than were for sale. Up until pricing, traders said the seven-year bonds had been trading well, and were trading even with 10-year Treasury securities.
Last September, the bank sold $1.5 billion of 8 3/4 percent 10-year bonds at a price to yield 8.44 percent, or 37.5 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
The World Bank's outstanding debt is rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold and Platinum Weaken On Signs of Economic Vigor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of gold and platinum futures weakened yesterday amid new signs of economic strength, including a record-setting rise in housing starts and higher stock prices.
On other commodity markets, copper and petroleum futures gained, coffee futures slumped, grains and soybeans were mixed and pork bellies surged.
Gold futures fell by $4.30 to $5.10 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the contract for February delivery settling at $412.40 an ounce. Silver futures finished unchanged to three-tenths of a cent higher, with the March contract at $5.33 an ounce. 
 
Platinum Gives Up Gains
The platinum market gave up most of its gains from the previous session. Platinum futures settled $4 to $5 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with April delivery at $522.90 an ounce.
Precious-metals traders focused on a variety of positive factors, including a strong report by the Government on housing starts in January and expectations that a report to be released today will show a decline in the United States trade deficit for December.
Positive news about the economy generally depresses gold prices, because investors tend to buy gold as a hedge against an economic downturn.
The Commerce Department's report of a 29.6 percent increase in January housing starts, to a record seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.63 million units, helped to raise the dollar's value against other leading currencies. That typically prompts selling of precious metals. Analysts said the 25-point rise in the Dow Jones industrial average also quelled demand for gold.
 
Rumors on Drexel Moves
Analysts also cited profit taking in advance of a three-day holiday weekend, and rumors that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent company filed for bankruptcy protection this week, was liquidating its positions in the precious-metals markets to raise cash.
Despite the weakness, ''the platinum market is still very steady and the gold market also appears to be in a bullish trend,'' said Anne Orton, vice president of Deak International Inc. She added, ''They just didn't seem to have much strength today.''
The report on housing starts also lent support to copper futures on the Commodity Exchange. Copper wire and pipes are widely used in home construction.
Copper futures settled 0.95 cent to 1.7 cents higher, with the February contract at $1.085 an ounce.
 
Energy Futures Rise
Energy futures rose sharply on the New York Merc, partly reflecting fears that a new eruption of the Redoubt volcano in Alaska posed a threat to the oil industry there.
West Texas Intermediate crude settled 40 cents to 77 cents higher, with March at $22.84 a barrel. Heating oil was a half-cent to 1.01 cents higher, with March at 58.65 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline was 0.75 cent to 1.3 cents higher, with March at 60.64 cents a gallon.
Coffee futures retreated slightly on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on news that Brazilian shipping companies and dock workers had reached a wage agreement, averting a strike. Coffee settled 0.83 cent to 1.02 cents lower, with March at 84.98 cents a pound.
 
Soybeans Up Modestly
Soybean futures rose modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting strength in the European market for soybean meal, while wheat futures retreated and corn futures closed mixed.
Pork belly futures surged on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on news that the United States is exploring the possibility of subsidizing sales of American meat to the Soviet Union.
