HEADLINE: Many Hospitals Found to Ignore Rights of Patients in AIDS Testing

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Many hospitals fail to get patients' consent before performing AIDS tests, do not counsel them adequately about the results and lack proper safeguards to insure confidentiality, a national survey has found.
In 3 percent to 4 percent of the hospitals, the survey found, patients are never or only sometimes informed when they are found to be infected, so they may unwittingly infect others after leaving the hospital.
''The policies in place among hospitals in this national sample do not provide adequate protection of patients' rights,'' concluded the report, sponsored by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the University of California at Los Angeles. The authors suggested that every patient entering a hospital ask if he or she will be tested for AIDS infection and what will happen to the results. #560 Hospitals Surveyed The research, which covered 560 randomly selected non-government hospitals, is the first large study on hospitals' AIDS policies in the United States. Dr. Howard Freeman, a U.C.L.A. sociologist who was one of four authors, described the preliminary results on Thursday at a health policy meeting sponsored by the Johnson Foundation in Washington. 
Dr. Freeman said the results were troubling because they showed that many hospitals did not follow recommendations made three years ago by the Federal Centers for Disease Control. Guidelines of the Government and the American Hospital Association call for explaining the test to patients and getting their consent for it; counseling them before the test and again after it, if the result is positive, and making every effort to keep the results confidential. The Federal Government does not enforce the guidelines, but a number of states have their own laws and can prosecute hospitals that violate them.
Dr. Freeman said there were serious problems in all these areas. Forty percent of the hospitals never or only sometimes counsel patients before testing. Informed consent is not obtained from patients in many hospitals, and testing is conducted without the knowledge of patients in some hospitals, though Dr. Freeman would not say what percentage. In 25 percent of hospitals, those whose tests are negative for the virus are never told.
 
Patients Are Transferred
Two-thirds of the hospitals indicate AIDS infection on patients' charts despite the Federal Government's guidelines on confidentiality. Dr. Charles E. Lewis, another co-author of the study, wrote that one surgeon told other doctors at a meeting that his hospital had solved the problem of exposing staff members to the AIDS virus: It was testing all patients and marking their charts with stickers - green for those who did not have the virus, red for those who were infected or who refused to be tested.
Many hospitals routinely test for AIDS, partly to protect staff members from accidental infection and partly to help prevent the spread of the disease by informing patients who are infected.
Twenty percent of the hospitals in the survey reported at least one instance of a staff member's refusing to treat patients infected with the AIDS virus, and about 25 percent of the hospitals immediately transfer patients to another hospital if they are found to be infected.
Dr. Freeman said there are various motives for transferring patients, including getting the patients to hospitals with more experience in treating the disease. But he said that too often the motive is fear or the desire to relieve the hospital of an economic burden, since many people with AIDS have little or no medical insurance.
The preliminary data showed that while two-thirds of hospitals sampled test at least some patients for the AIDS virus, 17 percent have no policy governing such testing and a higher percentage have policies that do not comply with the established guidelines.
In the survey, four staff members were interviewed in person in each of the 560 hospitals, which randomly selected from the 5,191 nongovernment hospitals in the nation. The authors did not indicate a margin of sampling error. The paper is still under review for publication.
 
'Huge Job of Education'
The American Hospital Association refused to comment on the study, but said the association recommends that hospitals get consent for testing, notify patients of the results and counsel them once they are given the results.
Peter Staley, a spokesman for Act-Up, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, called the survey ''another example of the huge job of education we still have to do, when the medical establishment still harbors such prejudice on a national level.'' Failure to get informed consent for an AIDS test is illegal in many states, including New York, California, and Massachusetts, he said.
Dr. Dennis McShane of the Stanford University Medical Center said many hospitals have had relatively few patients with AIDS and have not come to grips with the issues created by testing, as larger centers have.
But Dr. Jerome Groopman, head of the AIDS program at the New England Deaconness Hospital in Boston, the largest AIDS center in New England, said: ''I think it's extremely disturbing that 10 years into the epidemic we still have this kind of thing. Despite AIDS' being on the front page and the evening news so long, there is still no structure established to deal with these questions. There is a fundamental lack of leadership from the Federal level, particularly from the executive branch.''
 
'A Long, Undistinguished History'
The finding that many hospitals routinely transfer infected patients is upsetting but not surprising, he said, adding, ''There is a good deal of jockeying going on to avoid the expense.''
Dr. Richard Chaisson, director of AIDS services at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, said the results should be viewed with caution, but added that the statistics were consistent with what he knew of attitudes toward people with AIDS and the economic burdens they could represent.
''This kind of data gives you some sense of general attitudes about patients, especially the transfer of infected patients,'' he said. ''There is a long, undistinguished history of hospitals' dumping what they consider undesirable patients.'' Johns Hopkins, a public hospital, receives many such patients.

HEADLINE: Would -Be Refugee Describes His Vietnamese Round Trip

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Le Van Kim, once a fisherman, sat in the house of a charitable friend and bemoaned his fate.
He was back in Vietnam, more than a year and a half after escaping by boat to Hong Kong. Instead of achieving a permanent haven, he was part of a planeload of refugees forced by the British authorities two months ago to return to Vietnam.
He has not been arrested, as some feared. But from what he says his life is fairly bleak. For the moment he is surviving on what amounts to charity, with little immediate hope of finding a new house or getting a new fishing boat. 
 
Initial Trip Is Smooth
As he tells it, his misadventure began five years ago, when he lost half his right arm and a few fingers of his left hand while fishing with dynamite. He continued to ply his family's traditional trade, but the fish did not run well for two seasons, and like so many Vietnamese before him he decided to leave by boat for Hong Kong.
With his wife, seven children and his mother, Mr. Kim, 37 years old, set sail the 500 miles east in his boat on June 10, 1988. It was an uneventful voyage, and he arrived on June 20, four days after a cutoff imposed by the British authorities in Hong Kong. He and his family became victims of a policy that made them part of the only group of Vietnamese forced to return.
For Mr. Kim life seems hopeless and dreary, and he is deeply ashamed of living on charity. ''Now we have no house and no means of living,'' he said. '' Before, we had a boat - it was all we had - but the Hong Kong Government destroyed it.'' His only hope, he said, is that the British will buy him another because the Vietnamese equivalent of $10,000 required for a new one is far beyond his means.
 
Happiness on Arrival
Before June 16, 1988, any Vietnamese arriving by boat in Hong Kong was automatically granted refugee status and eventual resettlement in a third country. After that date, all new arrivals were screened to see if they were fleeing political, racial or religious persecution and qualify as refugees.
If not, and they are judged economic migrants merely seeking a better life for themselves and their families, they are refused resettlement and pressed to return to Vietnam.
''When we arrived in Hong Kong, at the first moment, we were very, very happy, '' Mr. Kim said. ''We thought we had made it, through all the storms, the pirates and the dangers on the sea.''
He grew silent, and then finally said, ''But that was the only pleasant moment.''
The British administrators of Hong Kong insist on the right to send people like Mr. Kim home involuntarily. The United States argues that forcible repatriation to Vietnam, unlike to Mexico or Haiti, is intolerable, at least until more efforts are made to get economic migrants to agree to return. About 1,000 volunteers have already done so under the auspices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
 
Precedent Backfires
To set a precedent and in agreement with Vietnam, the British forced one planeload of boat people to return on Dec. 21, 1989. Mr. Kim and his family were among them.
But the publicity was sufficiently bad that Vietnam is hesitating to allow a second flight, which the British authorities want to arrange soon, before the good sailing weather comes again and more Vietnamese take to the sea in search of a haven. A British official, Francis Maude, arrives in Hanoi on Sunday to pursue such discussions with the Vietnamese Government, which says that it will accept people who do not volunteer to return but do not object to it, either.
''Forcible repatriation,'' Vietnamese officials say, is intolerable, a bit of semantics important for a country that badly desires better relations with the West and does not want to be accused of human rights violations.
The planeload that included Mr. Kim, said Vu Khoan, a Deputy Foreign Minister, was accepted on the principle that while the Vietnamese did not agree to return, they did not object to it, so no force was required to get them onto the plane.
 
A Nighttime Journey
Mr. Kim said British authorities woke them in the middle of the night and told them to board a bus for the airport, where a representative of Vietnam and of the United Nations High Commissioner would be waiting.
''But no one was there, and we were lied to,'' Mr. Kim said, an assertion that the British deny. Still, no one protested, he said, and everyone was silent on the plane because every Vietnamese was sandwiched between two Hong Kong policemen.
Since then, he said, the Vietnamese authorities have kept their promise and treated them with respect, with no punishment for having broken the law against illegal emigration.
Hoang Ngoc Tri, a Haiphong official in charge of caring for the returned boat people, said that, of course, Vietnam would keep its word. ''If they are treated badly by the people or the Government, they would leave again. So what would be the point of going through all this trouble to try to restabilize their lives?''
 
Intentions Seem Serious
The Vietnamese have a saying, ''we beat the ones who leave us but embrace the ones who return to us,'' Mr. Tri said, in a bit of approved homespun wisdom echoed by nearly every Vietnamese official interviewed.
But Hanoi seems to mean it, and with limited resources - per-capita income is a little over $200 - is trying to cope. The United Nations High Commissioner's office provides about $1,000, including airfare, for each volunteer, and the British provide airfare and $620 for each person who does not volunteer.
The Vietnamese have agreed to provide the equivalent of $30 a month in cash to each volunteer for a year, and $25 a month to each nonvolunteer, with the remaining money after welcoming and transit expenses, about $100 per person, being spent on special needs like medical care or housing. And in Haiphong, they are doing so, even though Mr. Tri complains that the port city has not yet received all the money due it from the national Government.
Haiphong, he says, with 640 boat people returning, is trying to deal with the extra burden and spending more than Vietnam gets from the United Nations or the British. But he is concerned about the future, because at least 5,000 more people from Haiphong are now in Hong Kong alone.
 
Budget Problems
Of the city's yearly budget of $14.4 million, 30 percent goes to the national Government in tax payments, Mr. Tri said. And the city is in ''a sharp discussion'' with the Hanoi authorities, trying to get that percentage reduced in order to cope with the returning boat people.
''Many of these people sold everything and must begin again,'' he said. And as for the city itself, it is ''almost true'' that it is out of fishing boats, and there are no used ones for sale. In the meantime, state enterprises must replace skilled workers. And yet given the enormous unemployment in Vietnam, when boat people return, ''we have to try to solve the problem of finding them jobs all over again.''
Mr. Tri's hope is that with the improvement in the economy since the Communist Party allowed private enterprise, Vietnamese will chose to stay home. The British hope so, too, but fear that the extra money in people's pockets will mean that more can afford the $250 to $350 required to buy an illegal passage to Hong Kong.
 
A Mother's Sadness
For his wife, Le Thai The, holding her 2-year-old, there are simply tears. ''I feel so sorry for myself and for my family,'' she said. ''My children are small; we don't have a house.
''I spent the three days of Tet crying,'' she said, referring to the lunar new year. ''We were in someone else's house, and we had nothing of our own.
''The children kept asking me, 'Mother, why don't we have a house? Why don't we have an altar?' I don't dare to even speak of the future.''
A Haiphong official, originally reluctant to allow an interview with the family, said later that the city was sincerely trying its best. ''But don't forget,'' she said, ''these people have done this to themselves.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Poland's Foreign Lenders Accept Unusual Extension of Payments

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The United States, West Germany and other major Polish creditors showed support for the Solidarity-led Government today by extending the payment deadlines for $9.4 billion of Poland's hard-currency debt on unusually lenient terms.
Polish officials rejoiced at the unprecedented relief granted by the Paris Club, a group of 17 creditor nations, which declared that easing Poland's hard-currency debt burden would help the country endure the strong and bitter economic medicine that it is taking to revive its prostrate economy.
''We're delighted the debt was rescheduled,'' Henryk Wozniakowski, a Government spokesman, said at a news conference tonight. ''It will be a great benefit to us.'' 
The agreement, signed in Paris today by Polish officials and the nation's government creditors, would stretch the payments of interest and principal over 14 years.
''It's the most extraordinary agreement we have ever had,'' said Jean-Claude Trichet, the chairman of the Paris Club and head of the French Treasury. ''It indicates the confidence that the governments have in Poland.''
The Paris Club has rescheduled the payment of debt for many nations, mostly in Africa, Asia and Latin America. But the Polish accord involves the largest amount of debt ever rescheduled by the club.
 
'An Exceptional Case'
Obviously aware of the reaction their generous decision might bring in other debt-troubled countries of Eastern Europe and South America, Poland's Western creditors said in a communique that they were ''convinced that Poland was an exceptional case'' and were impressed by its ''very courageous'' economic program.
Poland has leapt ahead of other Eastern European countries in seeking to transform its economy from Communism to capitalism and has taken painful steps like allowing layoffs and bankruptcies, lifting price controls and slashing subsidies to industry and consumers. [A watchdog group including Western nations has agreed to start relaxing controls on the export of sophisticated technology to Eastern Europe, but the United States has insisted that some concessions not yet apply to the Soviet Union, Western officials at the meeting said. Page 9.] All told, Poland has $40 billion in foreign hard-currency debt, with $27 billion of that owed to Western governments. West Germany is the largest creditor; the United States ranks behind Britain and France. Most of the rest of the $13 billion in foreign hard-currency debt is to private interests.
 
Terms of the Agreement
Under today's agreement, the payment of $3.4 billion overdue at the end of last year will be rescheduled, as will all the interest and principal repayments due until the end of March 1991. Polish officials said the agreement allows this $9.4 billion to be repaid over 14 years, with an eight-year grace period on the payment of principal.
One Polish official estimated that this would reduce Poland's annual debt repayments to about $1.1 billion. Poland's debt service has amounted to about $3 billion a year, but in recent years the country has fallen behind and paid only about half that amount annually.
Officials also said that under the agreement Poland would repay no money at all during the next 12 months.
 
A Plea to Bank Creditors
Mr. Trichet called on commercial banks that are also creditors of Poland to follow the lead of the Paris Club and offer similarly generous debt-relief measures. The club wants the commercial banks to postpone all interest payments that Poland owes them for an extended period.
Last week, Poland's Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, sent a letter to the heads of government of the creditor nations asking that all of Poland's debt repayments be postponed this year and that the creditors work to reduce Poland's debt through forgiveness or other means.
Poland's Vice Minister of Finance, Janusz Sawicki, said the agreement was a vote of confidence in Poland, but he said the problem of reducing Poland's debt remains.
At his news conference today in Paris, Mr. Trichet also said, ''We have already decided that we have a moral commitment not to leave Poland without a good new agreement after March 1991.''
Mr. Trichet said a task force was being formed to study means of debt reduction as well as future debt rescheduling.
The agreement announced today comes on the heels of other major Western assistance efforts for Poland. The International Monetary Fund has pledged $713 million in aid to Poland, while the World Bank has pledged $360 million this year as part of its $2.5 billion three-year aid package.
Mr. Sawicki, the Vice Finance Minister, said the agreement showed that creditors recognize that Poland's debt was inherited from a Communist regime that had mismanaged the economy and poorly invested the money it had borrowed.
The Paris Club's communique states that the creditors recognize the ''historic significance of the great transformations now under way in the Polish economy.''

HEADLINE: Cutting the Dropout Rate: High Goal but Low Hopes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
American educators are trying almost anything to keep children in school. They give pizza parties in Chicago, promise after-school and summer jobs in Philadelphia, hold drawings for used cars in Milwaukee and enroll American Indian youths in private schools in Minnesota, at state expense.
The challenge of reducing the dropout rate is something educators around the country have been struggling with for many years, with programs that are often experimental and, in any case, reach few of those at risk for leaving school. In his State of the Union Message, President Bush set a goal of graduating 90 percent of high school students by the year 2000. 
Over and over, school officials say they do not have the money to spend on much more than the basics, and certainly not enough to solve the larger problems of society like poor housing and drug abuse that contribute to the dropout rate. The nation's high schools now graduate about 71 percent of students who enter as freshmen, a figure that has remained about the same for two decades. Inspiration Stressed ''Is it realistic to build a school system that graduates 90 percent of its students?'' said Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. ''Yes, if we really mean it. Yes, if we're willing to put resources into it. Simply declaring it as a vision and not defining a program will leave us in 10 years about where we are now.''
But the Bush Administration says more inspiration than money is needed at this point.
''Per-pupil expenditures increased dramatically, by 29 percent over inflation, during the last decade, but reading scores and other results were essentially flat over that period,'' said Christopher T. Cross, the Assistant Secretary of Education for educational research and improvement. ''What the critics are missing is that we have to have a commitment to change values, to motivate students. Until we get that, throwing more money at the problem won't change it.''
 
'Great Leap' Not Achieved
Education experts could come up with no example of a school or school district that has succeeded in making what Dr. Boyer called ''that great leap,'' raising its graduation rate nearly 20 percentage points, as Mr. Bush wants for the whole nation. More commonly, a school with a low dropout rate never had a major problem retaining students in the first place.
Schools are increasingly encouraging teamwork with local businesses, which do have money to devote to dropout prevention programs, as an investment in a more qualified work force.
One of the oldest and most successful pairings of business and education is in Philadelphia. A 20-year-old program, offered at 14 of the city's 21 high schools, integrates academic courses with vocational training in auto mechanics, business and other careers.
The program, Philadelphia High School Academies, recruits eighth graders considered likely to drop out with guarantees of after-school and summer jobs, at $5.75 an hour. More than 93 percent of the students who enter the program graduate, as against 70 percent for the school district over all.
But the program now reaches only 1,750 of the city's 101,000 high school students, said Natalie S. Allen, president of the program. ''We hope to be able to serve 5,000 kids by 1995,'' she said, adding that a program that large would cost about $1.2 million a year.
Mrs. Allen said the money would have to come from businesses and foundations rather than the school district, which faces a $60 million deficit next year in its $1 billion budget. In the 1987-1988 school year local businesses contributed $400,000 to the program; last year they gave $830,000.
 
Pizza and Used Cars
In Milwaukee, where only 60 percent of the students graduate from high school, principals are enlisting local businesses to provide incentives for children who improve their attendance, grades and behavior, said David C. Begel, a spokesman for the district, which has 98,000 students.
Most companies give away small things like certificates for pizza, but two car dealerships give away used cars. Two schools let their most-improved students participate in a drawing for a car each year.
''Clearly, it's an incentive for some kids, but I don't know how you would quantify the impact,'' Mr. Begel said. The programs have been in effect for three years at one school and one year at another.
Chicago spends $3.8 billion a year on its public schools, including $1 million on programs to prevent pregnancy, a key reason for dropping out. Much of the money in that program is spent on pizza parties and party gifts to draw students to seminars.
''Counselors try to build their self-esteem and teach them about their bodies,'' said Dr. Grace G. Dawson, director of the district's Division of Dropout Prevention. ''We think we're reducing the pregnancy rate by as much as 50 percent.''
 
Programs Seen as Limited
But she said this program and several other dropout prevention programs reach fewer than half the 200,000 students considered at risk of dropping out. There are 410,000 students in the city's school system; Dr. Dawson said the dropout rate ranged from 20 percent in some schools to 70 percent in others.
In Los Angeles, a three-year effort to curb a 39 percent dropout rate has the money to serve only 144 of the district's 600 schools, said Peter Martinez, coordinator of the district's Dropout Prevention Office. The budget for his program is $5.6 million this year, out of a district budget of $3.2 billion.
One of the more novel ideas, which started in West Virginia two years ago and has already spread to Texas, Florida, Louisiana, Wisconsin and Ohio, is to revoke the driver's license of dropouts and truants.
''We're very pleased with the law,'' said Therese M. Wilson, acting director of the Office of Educational Support Services in West Virginia's Department of Education. So far, the state has revoked the licenses of 1,003 teen-agers, she said. As a result, 170 teen-agers have returned to school and 163 others have enrolled in high school equivalency programs.
''West Virginia is pretty rural, so if you don't have a license you really can't get around,'' she said.
 
Minnesota Leads the Nation
Minnesota is the only state that graduates more than 90 percent of its high school students. Six other states graduate slightly more than 85 percent of their students, according to a study of the high school class of 1987 conducted by the United States Department of Education. The states are Iowa, Montana, Nebraska, North Dakota, Wisconsin and Wyoming.
Florida ranked last, the department said, with 58 percent graduating, while Georgia, Louisiana, Michigan and New York had only slightly better rates. In the District of Columbia, the graduation rate is only 55.5 percent.
Schools in Minnesota have graduated 89 to 91 percent of their students since 1981, when data were first collected, said Robert J. Wedl, the state's Deputy Commissioner of Education. He conceded that the state had few minority students and less poverty than the national average; around the country, minority members and the poor are more likely to drop out. But he said it also helped that the state had long given education a top priority.
''We're graduating 91 percent of our kids, but that's not nearly enough,'' Mr. Wedl said. ''It's not O.K. to throw away 10 percent of our kids.''
 
A Flexible School System
With 720,000 students and a $3.8 billion budget, Minnesota ranks 17th in per-pupil spending. The state has developed a flexible school system, with a wide variety of specialty and year-round schools, and students can attend any school within commuting distance.
In 1988, when Minnesota could not keep one-third of its American Indian students from dropping out of high school, the Legislature passed a law permitting the State Department of Education to pay for private school for Indian children at risk of dropping out.
''You have to change the school to suit the child, rather than trying to change the child to suit the school,'' said Dr. David Beaulieu, the state director of Indian education.
He said school districts contracted with seven private schools, including three run by tribal governments, that graduate 90 percent of their students. The schools provide students with a great deal of individual instruction in an ambience and curriculum that reflect Indian society and culture, he said.

HEADLINE: Bush Gets Some Praise For Andean Drug Talks

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
President Bush told his Cabinet today that the regional drug conference in Colombia was an important start in international cooperation in fighting drug trafficking, an assessment shared by Administration critics.
Several academics, politicians and Administration officials also said the meeting could bring a shift in emphasis, with the United States acknowledging that it must be more aggressive in helping Andean countries economically, and those countries intensifying their law enforcement efforts against drug traffickers.
These analysts warned, however, that it could be years before it is known whether the oratory at Cartagena leads to concrete results. 
''There was a convergence of issues,'' said Raphael F. Perl, a specialist in international narcotics policy for the Congressional Research Service. ''We're beginning to recognize the economic and trade components, and the Latins are beginning to realize they need enhanced law enforcement.''
 
View of Meeting
The economic issues were emphasized by Mr. Bush at today's Cabinet meeting, where he and William J. Bennett, the drug policy director, encouraged department heads to seek new investment opportunities in the Andean region. Mr. Bush, Mr. Bennett and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d gave the Cabinet an overall view of the conference on Thursday, which focused more on issues like helping coca growers find substitute crops than on areas where there is less consensus, such as the role of the United States military in the fight against drugs.
In interviews today, several analysts and politicians said there were no fresh initiatives in a joint declaration by Presidents Bush, Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia, Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru. But they said it was far more important that a meeting took place involving President Bush and leaders of the three countries that produce or refine most of the cocaine consumed in the United States.
Even one of the Administration's sharpest critics on the drug issue, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, chairman of the House Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said the conference offered ''a valuable framework for future cooperative efforts.''
Yet Mr. Rangel and other Democrats said they were now waiting for the Administration to follow through on the words of cooperation from President Bush and the Andean leaders.
Although many past critics of the Administration's drug initiatives were laudatory today, some dismissed the meeting as a public relations gambit.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Meeting of Industrial Countries Declares Need for More Aid to Poland and Hungary

BYLINE: By PAUL MONTGOMERY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Officials of the major industrial nations meeting here today declared that their seven-month aid program for Poland and Hungary, already surpassing $2 billion in commitments, was well on its way but needed more initiatives for private investment, debt servicing, education exchanges and protection of the environment.
In their fourth meeting since the aid program began last July, the officials said the time of pious pronouncements in regard to Poland and Hungary was giving way to operational programs. From a boatload of herring sent from Iceland to Poland to billion-dollar loan funds assembled by bankers, the aid effort has represented the West's attempts to confirm the arrival of democracy and free markets in East Europe.
In a communique at the end of their daylong meeting, the officials said plans to include East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia in the packages were ''proceeding in the right direction.'' The aid program began at the Paris economic meeting in July, when only Poland and Hungary had created multi-party systems and had announced plans for free-market economies. 
The matter of broader participation will be taken up when the officials of the 24 countries involved meet again on May 22, followed by a meeting of their foreign ministers in Brussels in early June.
The aid effort of the so-called G-24 is coordinated by the European Commission, the executive body of the 12-nation European Community, and also includes the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Austria, Switzerland, Finland, Sweden, Iceland, Norway and Turkey.
 
Five Submit Applications
Last month the European Commission announced criteria including free elections, a rule of law and ''economic liberalization'' for other East European nations that wanted aid and invited applications from East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. Those countries submitted papers today, ranging from 2 pages by Romania to 32 by Czechoslovakia, detailing their needs and specifying their plans for liberalization.
The G-24 officials said that they would need more information and that they would send fact-finding missions to the countries soon. A formal decision on the applications can be made only by the foreign ministers of the 24.
In the meantime the European Commission gave a progress report on aid committed to Poland and Hungary. For Poland, the major contributions have been a $1 billion fund to stabilize the zloty and donations of food valued at $456 million.
Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland, who visited Brussels last month, has asked for 1.2 million more metric tons of bread-making wheat after the 562,500 metric tons already sent. The Commission said today that 788,000 tons of the additional 1.2 million had already been pledged, including 600,000 tons from the European Community, 150,000 from Japan and 38,000 from Austria.
 
Food Sold to Consumers
The food aid to Poland is donated by the G-24 but is sold to consumers. The resulting zloty funds, called counterpart funds, are to be used for investments in Poland that promote free enterprise. The Commission said today the counterpart funds so far totaled 180 billion zlotys and were soon expected to reach 400 billion zlotys.
The main initiative for Hungary is a proposed $1 billion bridge loan, to be repaid in a maximum of five years, that would help the country pay interest on its $20 billion in foreign debt. The loan is contingent on an International Monetary Fund program for the total debt. The European Community has already pledged $400 million toward the fund and is inviting other nations to join. Japan among other countries today raised questions whether it was necessary to have an overall fund rather than individual loans.
The group is also finishing proposals for modest environmental programs in the two countries, totaling $26.4 million for Poland and $32.4 million for Hungary. The projects concentrate on taking sulfur out of the emissions from coal burned for power and cleaning lakes and rivers. The projects are more in the nature of pilot studies than of actual attempts to reduce pollution.
The Commission also said today that its regulations to liberalize access to markets for goods from Poland and Hungary had taken effect on Jan. 1.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
17 Nations Plan to Relax Rules on Exports to East

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 16

 BODY:
A watchdog group including Western nations has agreed to begin relaxing controls on the export of advanced technology to Eastern Europe, but the United States has insisted that some of the concessions not yet apply to the Soviet Union, Western officials said today.
Since the 17-nation group known as Cocom makes its decisions by consensus, the officials said, Washington was also able to block proposals by Western European countries for greater flexibility towards the entire East bloc during a two-day meeting here.
Some Western European officials complained privately that Washington still views East-West trade through a cold war prism and ignores the needs of emerging Eastern European democracies for modern technology. They argued that a ''two speed'' approach limiting concessions to the Soviet Union would be impractical and bureaucratic. 
Although numerous Western European countries are already scrambling to take advantage of the new business opportunities opening up in the East, the United States seems determined not to be rushed.
Unable to agree on most specifics, the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls decided instead this week to set political guidelines for the future, including plans for a major review of the products subject to its export controls.
But Cocom, which is made up of 14 Western European countries, the United States, Japan and Australia, did reach these three basic agreements:
* To reduce from 12 weeks to 8 weeks the time that Cocom takes to review requests by Western companies for permits to export sensitive items to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
* To ease curbs on the sale of computers, precision machine tools and telecommunications equipment to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Such goods account for about half of the 1,500 or so items whose export is controlled and for about 80 percent of the license applications.
* To examine requests by Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia for preferential treatment in exchange for pledges and verification mechanisms to insure that technology with potential military applications does not reach the Soviet Union.
Western officials said that several Western European governments, notably West Germany and France, had argued in favor of a more ambitious across-the-board reduction of Cocom's list of sensitive items. France was also rebuffed in its bid to have controls relaxed on the export of civilian aircraft, they said.
''We reached agreement on a basic approach,'' one United States official said. ''This will enhance access to Western technology for legitimate civilian purposes for the regimes of Eastern Europe which have embarked on a democratic reform process.''
In Washington, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, told listeners today at the United States Chamber of Commerce that ''the Government understands Cocom has to adjust.''
But some industry spokesmen expressed disappointment that more was not achieved this week.
''It appears the net effect is we have the same restrictions that existed last Monday,'' said Willard A. Workman, Director of Foreign International Policy and Programs at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ''There is no change.''
''I think the United States defused a potentially explosive situation,'' said Debra L. Waggoner, manager of international trade policies at the American Electronics Association. ''But it is still moving too slowly and runs the risk of causing serious deterioration to Cocom.''
 
Awaiting Free Elections
The results of the review to be carried out by the United States are to be presented to Cocom here in June. By then several Eastern European countries theoretically will have held free elections, and efforts toward German reunification may have set the stage for a change in East Germany's status.
''At the moment, East Germany is still a a separate entity and a proscribed destination,'' a senior State Department official said in Washington. ''What it will be in three months, I don't know. I don't have the gift of clairvoyance.''
As in the past, secrecy characterized the Cocom meeting this week. Government delegations refused to say where the conference was being held, no public statement was issued on the results, and official briefers insisted that their names not be published.
But while Cocom has played a central role in the West's strategy towards the Soviet bloc over the past 41 years, political experts predicted that the organization would face growing pressure to change - not only from Eastern European governments, but from Western companies anxious for profit.
Among the major corporations already making bids or seeking opportunities in telecommunications, where Eastern European countries are dramatically behind, are American Telephone and Telegraph, Ericsson of Sweden, Siemens of West Germany and Alcatel of France.
Until now, the only significant relaxation of controls by Cocom involved exports to China since 1985, a move that was backed by the United States. The looser export policy has allowed many American companies to play an important and lucrative role in development of the Chinese economy.
Several Western European Governments are hoping that Eastern European countries will soon be given even more flexible treatment than enjoyed by China, officials said.

HEADLINE: 2 Public Relations Styles Clash in Battle of Trumps

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY

 BODY:
One is a mild-mannered man who once had a client bring a live elephant to the steps of City Hall, but who has since more often relied on his skills as a conciliator to build a large public relations firm and a reputation as a man you need to know in New York City.
The other is a bearded, burly opera-lover who is much more of a one-man show and known for stepping in in times of crisis, taking on tough and complicated causes and wrestling them to the ground.
These are the two public relations men representing Donald and Ivana Trump, men who behind the headlines are now locked in combat so bitter that it includes a threat from one to sue the other.
The two men, Howard J. Rubenstein, the conciliator, and John Scanlon, the crisis manager, have both been in the business a long time, moving from producing press releases and publicity stunts to becoming powerful middlemen guiding their often highly visible clients - ranging from the likes of Diana Ross and Covenant House to Philip Morris and the Gucci family -through the tangles of city government and the journalistic establishment. 
 
Art of a Deal
Yet each has his distinctive style. In Mr. Trump's corner is the smooth-talking Mr. Rubenstein, who now has more than 140 employees and 300 clients and has become known not only for image making but for deal making: For instance, he is widely credited with bringing two of his clients together - Rupert Murdoch and Peter Kalikow - and keeping them talking long enough to negotiate the sale of The New York Post.
In Mrs. Trump's corner is Mr. Scanlon, who is good friends with half the city's press corps, has only a handful of clients at anyone time and is usually called in when a client is already in deep trouble or unlikely to appear sympathetic.
Mr. Scanlon, who works for Daniel J. Edelman Inc., is probably best known for his dogged maneuvering on behalf of CBS News after Gen. William C. Westmoreland sued the network for libel over a documentary called ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception.''
 
'Back in the Game'
At stake, beyond the suit, was CBS's credibility as a news organization. George Crile, the producer of the program, credits Mr. Scanlon with persuading CBS management to speak up for itself. Mr. Scanlon also counseled Mr. Crile to go on the same television shows everytime the author of a book attacking the documentary appeared. And Mr. Scanlon was noted for appearing in court everyday to provide journalists with documents that supported the CBS position.
''After John, we had the opportunity to get in the arena,'' Mr. Crile said. ''We were back in the game.''
The case was eventually settled out of court with both sides claiming victory.
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, a man who has had plenty of dealings with both men, said that what you get when you hire Mr. Rubenstein ''is someone who opens doors for you.''
John Scanlon, Mr. Koch said, ''is the guy who comes in when you have a tough sell.''
Neither Mr. Scanlon nor Mr. Rubenstein said he was willing to discuss his strategy in the Trump case but others in their business say that some of the strategy is evident.
 
Scanlon Is More Aggressive
Mr. Scanlon, they say, has been more aggressive, trying to get news organizations to portray Mrs. Trump as an integral part of the Trump business empire, a tactic apparently intended to disrupt Mr. Trump's business dealings by creating uncertainty over who is in control.
If the divorce can be made to look like enough of a potential disruption to the organization, Mr. Trump may then move to settle with his wife quickly and more generously, regardless of any prenuptial agreement and its legal validity.
Public relations experts say Mr. Trump's camp has been reacting to this ploy by trying to discredit her business skills.
Such strategies are not what Mr. Rubenstein, 56 years old, made his name on.
He is most noted for his representation of the real-estate industry and for bringing real estate, business, union and government leaders together over a variety of enterprises.
He started his business by representing a Brooklyn nursing home. But his father, Samuel, a reporter for The New York Herald-Tribune, helped him get other clients, including young Democratic politicians from Brooklyn who would within a decade made their mark.
Among them was Abraham D. Beame, who when he became Mayor of New York, included Mr. Rubenstein among his closest advisors. Mr. Rubenstein's business boomed and he has retained influencial political friendships. At a 30th anniversary party for his business in 1984, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo referred to Mr. Rubenstein's ''enormous power and influence.''
Mr. Rubenstein declined to discuss his fees. Others in the industry said they ranged from about $2,000 to $10,000 a month.
Mr. Scanlon, 54, had several false starts before settling in as a public relations man. The son of a transit worker, Mr. Scanlon taught in a parochial school, was a textbook salesman and a book editor. He became involved in politics in the 1960's, working for Eugene McCarthy and then becoming a deputy commissioner in the Economic Development Administration under Mayor John V. Lindsay. Later, he briefly served as a press secretary for Felix G. Rohatyn, before senting up his own public relations firm in 1976.
After a heart attack, Mr. Scanlon went to work for Daniel J. Edelman where he now charges clients $300 an hour, he said.
Whether Mr. Scanlon or Mr. Rubenstein will be the most successful is unclear. Some see small victories for Mr. Scanlon already in the way the story has developed. Although Liz Smith, the gossip columnist for The Daily News, said she did not need Mr. Scanlon to tell her what to say when she was the first to announce that the Trumps were divorcing, her story did include a description of Mrs. Trump as her husband's full-time business partner.
And, other journalists have referred to a collection of excerpts and television clips showing Mr. Trump praising his wife for her management skills, which Mr. Scanlon made available.
Almost since the beginning the Donald Trump publicity camp has been reacting to events. In fact, when the story first broke, a Rubenstein spokesman denied the couple was separating, refusing to comment on ''idle gossip.''
Within a day quotes attributed to a spokesman for Mr. Trump appeared in many newspaper articles saying that Mrs. Trump had no decision-making abilities. Also quoted anonymously were sources comparing Mrs. Trump with Leona Helmsley, someone who has a reputation for being imperious and difficult.
It is the comparison to Mrs. Helmsley that triggered the threat of a lawsuit from Mr. Scanlon, who denounced it as libelous.
 
'The Greatest Carrier of Water'
He has also been quick to point out that Mrs. Helmsley is a client of Mr. Rubenstein's.
''Howard is the greatest carrier of water on both shoulders since Rebecca at the well,'' said Mr. Scanlon, who has a penchant for literary and Biblical allusions.
For his part, Mr. Rubenstein maintains that no one in his organization ever went so far as to compare Mrs. Trump to Mrs. Helmsley.
In keeping with his reputation as a conciliator, Mr. Rubenstein said he hoped that the press coverage of the Trumps' marital woes would quiet down and that the Trumps ''could work things out.''
But some in the public relations field are skeptical of that assertion, pointing out that Mr. Trump has repeatedly been available for interviews and has consistently downplayed his wife's role in his business.
From an image-making point of view, some public relations experts said such attacks on Mrs. Trump have left Mr. Trump, who for years praised his wife's abilities, looking like a liar.
''The Rubenstein strategy has a real flaw - it's inconsistent,'' said Alan Metrick, a partner in the public relations firm of David M. Grant & Partners. ''People are going to be saying: Well, Donny, which is it? Were you telling the truth then or now? That's never a good position to be putting a client in.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 The trade deficit narrowed sharply in December to $7.2 billion, the smallest gap in five years. The deficit for all of 1989 was $108.6 billion, a reduction of $9.9 billion from the 1988 total. This improvement, however, was far less than the $33.6 billion reduction achieved in the preceding year. [Page 35.] Industrial production had its steepest drop in nearly four years last month, falling 1.2 percent. Much of the decline was attributed to temporary factors. The operating rate for factories, mines and utilities fell 1.2 percentage points, to 81.9 percent of capacity. [41.] 
 
 
 
Companies
 Regulators took control of Franklin Savings Association, a large institution based in Ottawa, Kan., with close ties to Wall Street. It is now the largest savings unit in Government hands. [35.] The F.D.I.C. sued Drexel Burnham Lambert; Shearson Lehman Hutton and two former executives of a Texas savings institution, accusing them of a complex fraud scheme. [36.] Northrop was ordered to stop showing some commercials in Los Angeles by the Federal judge in a fraud trial involving Northrop. The judge said the commercials could influence prospective jurors. An appeals court has suspended the order. [35.] Securities fraud charges were filed against Bolar Pharmaceutical and its former president. The S.E.C. said the maker of generic drugs failed to promptly inform investors that it was suspending delivery of more than 70 products. [35.] Mack Trucks said it had a record loss last year and had reached financing agreements to avoid running out of cash. [35.] Drexel has been having trouble settling some sales of assets it has undertaken since its bankruptcy filing. While Drexel officials met with bankers about resolving the snags, more than 3,000 Drexel employees spent their last day in the office. [36.] Southwestern Bell is ending its test of an electronic information system in Houston. The company said it was evaluating the results, but analysts said they thought it had been a disappointment. [37.] A bid to buy control of The St. Petersburg Times was rejected by the institution that holds the controlling stake. [37.] G.M.'s pension fund reportedly plans to buy ''junk bonds'' because they are now viewed as investment bargains. [39.] Lockheed was fined $1 million for pollution violations by a Southern California air-quality agency. [10.] The Vuitton family plans to buy 95 percent of Lanvin, the Paris fashion house and perfume company. [37.]
 
International
 Poland's creditors agreed to a rescheduling of $9.4 billion of its debt on generous terms, in a move intended to show support for the Solidarity Government. [1.] Controls on exporting high technology to Eastern Europe will be relaxed, Western officials said, but the U.S. is balking on concessions to the Soviet Union. [9.]
 
 
 
Markets
 The dollar tumbled against major currencies despite the encouraging report on the United States trade deficit. [44.] Copper futures prices soared on signs of dwindling supplies. [44.] Late program selling depressed blue-chip stocks in slow trading. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 13.96 points, to 2,635.59. For the week the Dow dropped 12.61 points. [38.] Prices of Treasury securities were little changed. [38.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 A bill to close a loophole in biotechnology patent law has a provision that could reverse recent court victories by an American company and its Japanese pharmaceutical partner. Patents. [36.] Medical insurance that supplements Medicare for the elderly is worth the expense, one expert says. A long-term illness can deplete the assets of two generations, he points out. Your Money. HEADLINE: Mack Trucks Has a Record Loss

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Mack Trucks Inc., the company that once so dominated the heavy truck industry that its name became synonymous with 18-wheelers, announced yesterday that it had record losses in 1989 and had reached two financing agreements to keep from running out of cash.
The company's losses and debt financing announcements were a further indication of the deepening slump in the nation's $9 billion heavy-truck market, analysts said. The company lost $185.4 million last year, compared with a profit of $31.8 million, or $1.07 a share for 1988. Revenues fell 16.7 percent, to $1.75 billion, from $2.1 billion. Mack's medium- and heavy-truck deliveries tumbled 20 percent last year while parts and service sales fell 5.5 percent. 
 
Agreements on Bank Debt
 Mack, which is based in Allentown, Pa., said it had reached agreements in principle to reschedule its bank debt and sell $50 million worth of convertible bonds to Renault Vehicules Industriels. If exchanged for stock, the bonds would raise the French truck maker's stake in Mack to about 55 percent, from 44.6 percent.
Mack also announced yesterday that its employees and board had ratified an agreement with the United Automobile Workers that would immediately raise hourly wages by up to a third at the company's giant new plant in South Carolina. Mack built the plant in Winnsboro to try to reduce the proportion of its work force represented by the U.A.W., but lost a union organizing vote last April, a year and a half after the factory opened.
The troubles at Mack are partly a reflection of the truck building business's broader difficulties, industry analysts said. Slower economic growth and reduced spending on capital goods have left orders at barely half the level of a year ago.
The American Trucking Associations, a trade group based in Alexandria, Va., said the nation's general freight carriers hauled 5.1 percent less tonnage last year than in 1988.
In the last two months even Paccar Inc., the maker of the Kenworth and Peterbilt lines and the industry leader in size and profitability, has cut production by 20 percent and laid off hundreds of salaried and hourly employees.
And on Thursday, the Navistar International Corporation, another big truck maker, announced that it lost $18 million in the three months ending Jan. 31, compared with a $37 million gain for the same period a year ago. For its fiscal year, which ends on Oct. 31, Navistar predicted that sales of the heavy truck industry as a whole would sink 19 percent from the preceding 12 months.
Mack lost $79.5 million in the fourth quarter last year, compared with a profit of $13.8 million, or 47 cents a share, in 1988. Sales fell 33.8 percent, to $370.8 million from $554.7 million.
At Mack, corporate officers declined yesterday to discuss the company's announcements. Ralph E. Reins, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that Mack had cut costs and predicted that it would lose less money this year.
Most of Mack's problems have been self-inflicted, said Frank J. Prezelski, a truck industry analyst at the Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation. ''They've done just about everything wrong they could have done in the last couple years,'' he said. He added that new management led by Mr. Reins had improved operations since taking over last fall.
Mack spent $60 million and five years developing a new long-haul truck, the CH600, but introduced it last spring before all the bugs had been worked out, Mr. Prezelski said. The truck's engine did not become available until September and proved expensive to produce.
Mack stepped up production instead of stretching out delivery times last winter, when the industry's orders peaked at 23,000 in January, and then had to pay expensive benefits to U.A.W. workers laid off after orders for the industry plummeted to a low of 6,300 a month last August, Mr. Prezelski said. Monthly orders have since risen to about 10,000.
The South Carolina labor agreement ended a bitter five-year battle with the auto workers to open a nonunion plant in the South. Under a new agreement ratified by workers late Wednesday night, average wages at the Winnsboro plant will increase to $13.09 an hour, from $10, retroactive to Jan. 1, said Karl W. Mantyla, a union spokesman.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seizes Franklin Savings Association

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Federal regulators today took control of the Franklin Savings Association, a large and unorthodox savings institution based in Ottawa, Kan., with $11.4 billion in assets and close ties to Wall Street. It is now the largest savings unit in Government hands.
The Office of Thrift Supervision said that Franklin's net worth will fall to a negative $44.3 million after examiners today forced the institution to make several accounting changes. One involved recording $119 million in losses from futures trading that the savings unit had planned to write off over seven years. 
The savings institution, which reported $359.9 million in capital at the end of 1989, is also likely to lose another $185 million on zero-coupon bonds that it issued in 1984, the Government said.
The institution, which lost money from operations in four of the last five quarters, has been unable to raise fresh capital and had little prospect for recovery, said Marc Adams, a spokesman for the supervisory agency in Washington.
In its years of rapid growth, Franklin relied heavily on techniques designed to reduce the risk of loss from interest-rate fluctuations. It changed course after suffering losses in 1981 and 1982, when high interest rates hurt many savings institutions that made loans primarily to home buyers. Few of Franklin's current assets include home mortgages.
The analysis that led Franklin to adopt the interest-rate hedging techniques was developed by the institution with Wayne Angell, now a Federal Reserve governor in Washington. Dr. Angell was an economics professor in Kansas at Ottawa University during the period he was a consultant at Franklin.
Ernest M. Fleischer, an unassuming, analytical executive who built Franklin into the nation's 25th-largest savings institution, was removed from the chairman's post at Franklin as part of the Government action today.
Many on Wall Street had considered Mr. Fleischer a visionary in designing financial instruments to reduce risks from interest-rate swings. The primary market for his techniques was mortgage-backed securities. But as his success with the techniques in the mid-1980's were widely copied, profits for all players in that growing market, including Mr. Fleischer, became more elusive.
Mr. Fleischer attempted to expand Franklin's activities in search of new profits by acquiring brokerage firms. Franklin's parent acquired the Wall Street firm L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. in 1988. Earlier, it bought a large Houston-based brokerage, Underwood Neuhaus & Company.
Both efforts failed. Underwood Neuhaus was acquired by a unit of the Kemper Financial Group last November. And L. F. Rothschild's operations are essentially moribund after the firm filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in June. Mr. Fleischer did not respond to telephone messages placed to Franklin's offices in Kansas.
 
How Course Was Altered
 Franklin had less than $400 million in assets when Mr. Fleischer altered its course from home lending to a wide range of investments.Franklin invested mainly in mortgage-backed securities, which are mortgages packaged as certificates such as those issued by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and the Government National Mortgage Association. By the end of 1988, $7.3 billion, or more than half Franklin's total assets were in this market. It also began trading in the financial futures market and dealing in interest-rate swaps.
Among the many Wall Street executives Mr. Fleischer recruited to Franklin was John A. Scowcroft, a former head of mortgage-securities trading at Merrill Lynch. Mr. Scowcroft directed research at Franklin Savings and was its vice chairman. Mr. Scowcroft also did not respond to a request late this afternoon for an interview.
Mr. Fleischer, a Harvard-trained lawyer who practiced tax law for several years in Kansas City, Mo., controlled the majority of Franklin's stock, which was thinly traded in the over-the-counter market. His stake was worth approximately $200 million at the height of Franklin's success in 1988.
The stock rose 12.5 cents today in over-the-counter trading, closing at $2.50 a share, after having plunged $2.625 on Wednesday, when Franklin disclosed that it was undergoing a routine Federal examination.
 
Operations Worsened
 Mr. Adams of the Office of Thrift Supervision said Franklin's operations worsened over the last 18 months because the institution was unable to generate sufficient profit from securities trades or interest income to cover the high interest rates it had to pay to attract brokered deposits, which are those acquired through brokerage firms.
Franklin has nine retail branches in Kansas, but 71 percent of its deposits at the end of 1989 had been gathered either through telephone marketing programs or brokerage firms.
Mr. Adams said Franklin profitably sold big portions of its mortgage-backed securities in recent months, but the proceeds were inadequate to cover the high interest rates paid on the deposits. ''What is left is a lot of low-yielding assets,'' he said. ''There was no reasonable prospect that they would be able to recover.''
In an interview two years ago, Mr. Fleischer said more savings institutions should follow Franklin's methods. ''I do not believe many thrift executives seek to destroy their own financial institutions,'' he said. ''It's simply a result of not understanding or knowing what to do, or what can be done.''

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Reaches 5-Year Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit narrowed sharply in December to $7.2 billion, the smallest gap in five years, the Commerce Department reported today.
The latest figures brought the full-year deficit to $108.6 billion, a reduction of $9.9 billion from the 1988 total. This improvement, however, was far less than the $33.6 billion reduction achieved in the preceding year.
And while the December performance was considerably better than expected, most private analysts said that the deficit would likely widen again in coming months unless the economy sinks unexpectedly into recession. 
 
Trend for '90
 ''I think the trend is for little, if any, improvement'' for 1990, said Gary E. Schlossberg, an economist and trade specialist at Wells Fargo Bank.
Just over three-quarters of the December narrowing was the result of lower imports, a phenomenon that is mostly welcomed but that also implies a weakening domestic economy. This was quite consistent with the department's report last month that gross national product in the fourth quarter grew by a skimpy five-tenths of 1 percent.
The remainder of the December improvement reflected higher exports, but these were largely the result of a rebound in aircraft sales after the 48-day strike at the Boeing Company was settled Nov. 21.
 
Export Momentum Slows
 ''Export momentum continues to decline'' after helping to pace economic expansion for much of the past three years, said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, .
Currency traders focused on the sluggishness suggested by the decline in imports and the dollar fell against most major currencies. [Page 44.] The report had little impact on the credit or stock markets. [Page 38.] A number of analysts, however, took some heart from the December trade figures. The $3.1 billion drop from November's $10.3 billion deficit was significant, said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, precisely because - not in spite of - the drop in imports.
''For the first time there are clear indications that in the face of slowing domestic demand, imports of manufactured goods are declining,'' he said. ''The drop in imports of capital equipment at a time when exports of capital goods and machine tools are rising was particularly noteworthy.''
Mr. Jasinowski said he disagreed with those who are predicting little further improvement in trade this year. In addition to the gains made by American producers competing with imports, he cited a ''massive boom'' in European demand for American goods and a declining dollar that he expected would bring sustained increases in exports.
Michael R. Darby, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, called the report ''quite encouraging'' while cautioning that trade figures are subject to especially large short-run gyrations that make it hard to spot emerging trends.
 
Deficit With Japan
 The latest figures show, for example, a second straight sizable decline, to $3.5 billion, in the American deficit with Japan, but analysts remained wary of concluding that this represents fundamental improvement. They noted that the declines of 12 percent in December and 18 percent in November were preceded by a 19 percent jump in October. Imports of Japanese cars rose in December to $1.9 billion, from $1.6 billion in November, the report showed.
For the year, the United States deficit with Japan totaled $49 billion, down 11.6 percent from the 1988 total of $55.4 billion.
The trade balance with Western Europe swung in December to a $550 million surplus, from a $750 million deficit, with $100 million of the improvement accounted for by a smaller trading imbalance with West Germany.
There was some further shrinkage in the American deficit with the newly industrialized countries of the Far East - Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore. The combined deficit was $1.4 billion in December, down from $2.1 billion in November and $2.8 billion in October. Lower imports accounted for somewhat more than half the December improvement.
 
Bill for Oil
 The nation's bill for imported oil eased $300 million, to $4.1 billion, in December, as a 27-million-barrel reduction in volume more than offset a 64-cent price increase. This occurred despite record December cold, suggesting that refiners drew down inventories during the month. Analysts expect a huge January increase in the oil bill, which during December represented 56.9 percent of the total trade deficit.
For the year, oil imports surged 27.2 percent, to $48.94 billion - the highest amount since 1984, when the bill for oil was $52.4 billion.
December's exports rose 2.4 percent, to $31.1 billion, while imports fell 5.9 percent, to $38.3 billion, the report showed. The $7.2 billion deficit was the lowest since the $6.8 billion posted in December 1984.
November's deficit, initially reported at $10.5 billion, was revised to $10.3 billion but remained the worst deficit of 1989.
Capital goods accounted for the biggest changes on both sides of the equation for December - a $1 billion increase in exports, three-quarters of it aircraft, and a $1.1 billion decline in imports.
Without seasonal adjustment, the deficit dropped even more - to $6.4 billion from $10.6 billion, the report also showed. The three-month seasonally adjusted moving average now stands at $9.2 billion, down from $9.7 billion in November and from $10.2 billion in December 1988.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Advice for Elderly On Health Policies

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
Older taxpayers may be taken aback when they start to fill out their 1989 income tax forms. Many thought they had won a major victory in December when Congress repealed the surtax for catastrophic medical care that could have run as high as $800 per person or $1,600 per couple. But there it is on the forms, line 54 of the Form 1040 and line 23 of the 1040A.
''Ignore it,'' said Hal M. Cohen of Deloitte & Touche. ''Don't use it. The forms had already been printed when the surtax was repealed.'' Those who included that liability when making estimated tax payments last year ''will get it back as a refund,'' he added. 
Mr. Cohen, who is based in Morristown, N.J., is a member of the accounting firm's executive financial planning group. So he has a suggestion for how to use the funds that would have paid the surtax: buy supplemental medical insurance.
''The emotional and financial expenses of a long-term illness can deplete the assets and income of two generations,'' he said, if a family must pay for the uninsured portion of doctor and hospital bills or for custodial or nursing-home care not covered under Medicare that can cost $20,000 a year or more.
Consequently, Mr. Cohen is advising all his older clients, as well as those who may be responsible for elderly parents, to be sure they have adequate health-care insurance ''in order to avoid financial disaster or substandard medical care.''
Once a person reaches age 65, he or she is eligible for Medicare. It becomes the primary carrier for those who are retired, and supplemental ''medigap'' insurance is available through private carriers. Medicare pays 80 percent of allowable charges, but medical costs often exceed Medicare's allowable limits.
Medicare and the medigap policies will pay for nursing-home stays in approved facilities with medical staffs after hospitalization. Unlike Medicaid, which is the medical-welfare program for the indigent, Medicare will not pay for long-term custodial care for people who have not been hospitalized, like those suffering from Alzheimer's disease. So middle-class people are likely to need private insurance for this.
''Shop around,'' Mr. Cohen said. ''There can be tremendous differences among policies,'' both in terms of the cost and of the coverage provided. He suggested starting with the American Association of Retired Persons, which markets a Prudential medigap plan, or by consulting an independent insurance agent.
Insurance is regulated by state insurance commissions, so what is available in one state may not be available in another.
Tamara G. Telesko, vice president of Chase U.S. Private Banking, part of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said that with the frequent need for custodial care among the elderly, more people are becoming aware of the need for private insurance to supplement Medicare. However, she cautioned, this is a relatively new product, and actuarial data are still being developed. With rising health-care costs, premiums may rise.
Deloitte & Touche has advised its clients to look for policies that provide a waiver of premium in the event of disability, a maximum benefit period for one nursing-home stay of at least four years and a daily nursing-home benefit of about $80, with inflation protection written into the policy. Inflation protection can increase the premium cost by as much as one-third.
It is also important to make sure that the company issuing the policy is financially sound. One way to do this is to check the rating issued by A.M. Best & Company. Ratings range from A+ (superior) to C (poor).
Among the features Deloitte & Touche recommends in considering policies are these:
* Guaranteed Renewability. The policy should be guaranteed renewable for life, except for nonpayment of premium, so that the insurer cannot cancel the policy when the individual is making use of its coverage.
* Deductible Period. This is the period, generally 21 to 365 days, that must pass before the insurer begins to pay benefits. Although the shorter period is preferable, the longer period may reduce the premium.
* Grace Period. This is the time, generally seven to 31 days, after the premium due date, before which the insurer may cancel the policy. It gives the policyholder some protection, should he or she forget to pay the premium on time.
* Care Coverage. The policy should say clearly whether it covers skilled, intermediate and custodial care without a pre-hospitalization requirement. Also, some policies provide long-term home care only as a rider for an extra charge.
Alzheimer's disease is generally described in policy language as ''organically based mental conditions,'' and if such coverage is not specifically mentioned, Alzheimer's is probably not included.
In deciding on coverage, people need to do a cash-flow analysis to help determine how long they are able and willing to pay for their own medical costs before they would need insurance. And they need to determine whether they have any retiree health-care benefits.
Two groups are more likely than most to have these benefits, Mr. Cohen said - executives whose compensation package included them and union members.

HEADLINE: Bankers Hesitant on Drexel Sales

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Senior executives with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street firm that collapsed earlier this week, held high-level meetings yesterday with a number of banking officials who have been balking at settling sales of securities by Drexel in the last few days, people who were briefed on the talks said.
The discussions at the firm's international headquarters in downtown Manhattan came as more than 3,000 Drexel employees received termination notices and began moving their belongings out of their offices.
The discussions with the bankers came after several days of efforts to sell off billions of dollars in securities that were held by the firm, which collapsed after its parent filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
 
Concern Over Losses
 According to people present at the talks, a number of banks have been expressing concern about settling the Drexel trades, because they fear that they might be increasing their exposure to losses. In the settlement process, cash is transferred for securities, and the obligation is assumed by the bank for a short time after the cash is moved. 
While the banks hold securities from Drexel as collateral for the settlement, these sources said that some were concerned about the value of the assets.
''A bunch of individual banks feel that they have good collateral, while others don't,'' a person who was briefed on the situation said, adding that there had been discussions about pooling the collateral among the banks to make sure the transactions clear.
People at the firm said that the problem, while potentially significant, had not slowed the liquidation of the firm's assets.
In Drexel offices in New York and California yesterday, thousands of employees packed their belongings.
More than 3,000 workers at the firm that had once been a Wall Street giant were dismissed; some of the 2,000 or so remaining employees said they expected to be told to leave soon.
The employees were still shaken by the sudden collapse of the firm, which came after Drexel's parent filed late Tuesday for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
''It just hasn't hit me yet,'' said June Schultz, the conference coordinator for the firm's corporate finance department. ''Even now, nobody believes it's real. Tuesday morning, it's going to hit me when I get up and don't have a job to go to,'' said Ms. Shultz, who was on vacation in Florida, when she learned of the bankruptcy filing from her secretary.
Drexel allowed many employees to buy at bargain prices the computers and other electronic equipment they had used. Some employees paid as little as $350 for personal computers, for example, and by the end of the day streams of former employees were filing from the headquarters loaded with electronic equipment.
Inside Drexel's international headquarters, there were signs of bitter feelings. Employees, laden with files and equipment, argued with security guards at the exits about what belonged to them and what belonged to the firm.
Some frustrated employees kicked the inside of the doors of the elevators, leaving small dents and scuff marks on the shiny metal. Upstairs, employees quietly packed, with many of them breaking into tears and holding each other for support.
''There's been a lot of sadness here today,'' one executive said. ''Nobody knows quite what to do.''
Debbie Finn, a supervisor analyst in the firm's research department, who, while loading her parents' car in front of the firm, found that the car battery had died. She approached other drivers for aid. ''Please help me,'' she said, falling to her knees on the street. ''I'm unemployed.''
At Drexel's high-yield junk bond division in Beverly Hills, Calif., which has never walked to Wall Street's stride, the mood was different. The executives, many of whom had been made rich by Drexel, were losing their jobs, but they decided to have a party.
Traders with the firm said that on Thursday night they went to an inexpensive Jamaican restaurant called the Sugar Shack, which is near the firm's offices. ''They called it their last blast,'' said Evelyn Agbayani, the bookkeeper of the bar and restaurant.
''They all just went crazy,'' Ms. Agbayani said. ''They said that 50 people were going to come, and there were 250 people there. No wonder they went out of business. They can't count.''
 
Bidding for Milken Desk
 During the course of the party, according to David Feinman, a trader with Drexel, someone bid $1,000 for the famous black X-shaped desk where Michael R. Milken, the former head of Drexel's junk bond division, once sat. From that desk, Mr. Milken made decisions that had significant impact on corporations throughout America. ''I said I'd pay five grand for it,'' Mr. Feinman said. For now, the desk remains in its place.
A skeleton crew of about 10 people will remain in Drexel's California junk bond office to help wind down the firm's business.
Executives who remained at work in New York and California continued their efforts to sell Drexel's holdings of securities.
The firm reached an agreement with Goldman, Sachs & Company yesterday to sell billions of dollars of its obligations on mortgage-backed securities, people at Drexel said.
This week Drexel has sold more than $200 billion of its junk bond portfolio, which totaled a little less than $1 billion at the beginning of the week.
Drexel said yesterday that it was working to resolve difficulties it had in transferring funds and securities for its commodities futures customers, primarily because of the enormous amount of requests for transfers.
