HEADLINE: Greeks Feel the Pinch as Two U.S. Bases Close

BYLINE: By PAUL ANASTASI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, Feb. 17

 BODY:
A popular Greek cartoon shows American G.I.'s, a look of indifference on their faces, carrying out crates of personal belongings as they abandon their military bases in Greece. Taken away with the belongings is a Greek protester clutching a ''Yankee go home'' sign, a look of bewilderment betraying his confusion at being left without a cause.
For years the presence of American bases in Greece has led to huge rallies, riots and terrorist acts. American soldiers were advised to limit off-base activity for fear of public incidents. Now, in a paradoxical reversal of the public mood, that anti-American campaign has given way to last-minute efforts to hang onto the millions of dollars that will leave an already feeble economy when the United States shuts down two bases this year. One political joke making the rounds even has pro-Moscow Communists imploring the United States not to remove the bases, opposition to which has won them much of their electoral strength. 
Both the Hellenikon air base in Athens and the nearby naval communications base at Nea Makri will be dismantled. This leaves two bases on Crete and a number of smaller installations throughout Greece.
The American Embassy says the closing of the Hellenikon base alone means a loss of $66 million in revenue for Greece, about two-thirds of the $94 million estimated to have been the total economic effect in 1988 for all four bases. This includes Greek staff salaries, construction and other local contracts, base expenditures and off-base spending by military personnel and their dependents.
Washington has also indicated it will reduce military and economic aid to countries where it is cutting its military presence. But Greece has announced it will take ''every necessary measure'' to maintain the $350 million in military sales credits it receives annually from the United States.
Greek base employees, once strongly influenced by anti-American leftist parties, are now more concerned about their propects of unemployment. According to Greek statistics, there are 125 Greeks working at Nea Makri and 865 at Hellenikon. The payroll for Greeks at Hellenikon alone is slightly more than $6.6 million a year.
The Greek employees' two unions are mobilizing to protect their interests. Stavroula Stavropoulou, president of the politically mainstream Panhellenic Movement of American Base Employees, says her union is demanding that the Greek Ministry of Defense arrange for jobs and social welfare protection for base employees. ''Otherwise,'' she says, ''we should be given jobs by the Americans in the embassy or in other U.S. services.''
George Alexandrou, president of the Association of Employees of U.S. Bases, which under his leadership had developed into a leftist-controlled anti-American organization, says he now wants the Americans ''to pay what they owe us and negotiate with the Greek Government the rest of our social insurance and severance dues.''
 
Huge U.S. Debt Reported
Mr. Alexandrou asserts that the Americans owe $3.5 million in pay claims, severance pay and social security benefits. The American military contests those figures and says the responsibility for the employees lies with the Greek Defense Ministry.
Also concerned about the financial implications are local shopkeepers, landlords, restaurant owners and other entrepreneurs who rely heavily on American business.
''When the Americans go, someone like me could lose about 40 percent of their business,'' says a British hairdresser, Sandra Salway-Morris, who works near the Hellenikon base.
While many Greek businessmen agree with this assessment, others doubt that removal of the bases will have a significantly adverse effect. A real estate agent, George Niaros, said the American directives ordering personnel to limit their off-base activities and the development of shopping and entertainment on the bases kept outside spending to a minimum.
But the Mayor of Nea Makri, Vasilis Tzilavis, predicted that the town would suffer considerably from the departure of the naval communications base.

HEADLINE: New York's Census Is a Campaign: Stand Up and Don't Be Undercounted

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
On a recent Sunday morning, before Mass had ended, the pastor of St. Catherine of Genoa church in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn announced a visitor. Parishioners stirred in their pews as the guest approached the front of the altar, then turned to face the congregation, made up mostly of immigrants from Haiti and other Caribbean lands.
''You know that if I'm given an opportunity to speak to you, it's very, very important,'' the guest, City Councilwoman Susan D. Alter, began. ''How many of you have heard of the census?''
In New York City, where the word census has meant lost money and lost political power, community leaders and city officials like Ms. Alter are gearing up for the 1990 population count with the energy and grass-roots involvement usually reserved for a political campaign. 
Calls to fill out census questionnaires by the April 1 deadline are being made through any available outlet, from churches to produce markets. Efforts to have people counted are also well under way throughout the state and in Connecticut and New Jersey as well as across the country.
 
Promotional Resources Pooled
In New York, state and city government officials and business and labor leaders have pooled promotional resources under a project begun by Assembly Speaker Mel Miller dubbed ''New York Counts.'' In New Jersey, radio listeners will soon hear a rap song that state officials borrowed from their South Carolina counterparts.
The chorus: ''Count them, count them, count them all/Gonna count the people/Gonna have a ball.''
But behind the hoopla lies the fear of a significant undercount that would lead to losses in congressional representation and Federal aid. State and local government officials in New York are worried that logistical problems that plagued the count 10 years ago are surfacing again. Many of them say they have little doubt that a historical pattern of disproportional undercounting of minorities will continue this year no matter how much they reach out to those groups, and they fear that major cities like New York, where minority populations are concentrated, will suffer the most because of it.
''The basic problem we face is that the Census Bureau is still counting people as if everyone lived in Salina, Kan.,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn. ''Their view is that people are government-friendly, and very easy to pick out and locate, where in our large cities neither is the truth.''
 
A Costly Undercount
The 1980 decennial census missed an estimated 450,000 New York City residents, about 6 percent of the city's population, for an undercount rate more than four times the national average, city officials said. It cost the city one seat in the House of Representatives, one seat in the State Senate and three-and-a-half state Assembly seats.
The city also lost up to $675 million by some estimates in Federal aid allocated to states according to population. The 1980 census showed a final tally of 7,071,639 people in New York City, 823,223 fewer than in the 1970 census.
The best chance for accuracy, officials here and in other major cities said, is a statistical adjustment to correct any undercount. Under a court order that emerged from a lawsuit by New York City and several other cities and states, the Department of Commerce, the Census Bureau's parent agency, while not promising an adjustment, agreed to conduct a post-census survey to measure the undercount ''in a manner calculated to insure the possibility'' of an adjustment.
But lawyers for New York City are considering going back to court, contending that the Commerce Department's proposed guidelines for determining whether an adjustment is needed are so stringent that an adjustment is all but precluded.
 
Guidelines Could Change
''We're giving very serious thought right now to going back to court again and saying to the judge 'We want it enforced. They're not living up to their obligation,'' said Peter L. Zimroth, former Corporation Counsel for New York City who has stayed on the case as special counsel.
Robert Ellert, the Commerce Department's chief counsel for economic affairs, said the guidelines were not final and could change. He said final guidelines would be published on March 10.
New York City officials said the undercount of blacks was about 12 percent in 1980 and that of Hispanic people about 11 percent, and they expect the numbers to be worse in 1990 because although the minority population has grown - from 48 percent of the population in 1980 - the reasons it is undercounted have not changed.
Undercounts in New York City have been most severe in neighborhoods that are poor or whose residents cannot speak or understand English well. Those who move frequently were also undercounted in 1980, a Department of City Planning study found, as were homeless people and young singles who live alone and who are often away from home. For the first time this year, the Census Bureau will try to get an idea of how many homeless people there are by conducting a limited census in shelters, subway stations, parks and other sites on March 20 and 21.
 
Fear of Deportation
Many people are simply unwilling to be counted. They include undocumented immigrants afraid of deportation and public-housing tenants who double up in units and, apparently unaware of the Census Bureau's policy of confidentiality or not trusting it, fear eviction if they tell the Government who and where they are. There are about 100,000 of the latter, city officials estimate.
''It's going to be extremely hard,'' said Moises Perez, executive director of Alianza Dominicana, a community organization in Washington Heights that has joined the effort, ''We have a large number of people who are undocumented and are fearful of providing information. We're telling people that it is extremely important because it determines the extent of Federal assistance that we get and how the political map gets drawn.''
The city has used 1980 census data and recent data on immigration, public-assistance recipients and births to identify 70 neighborhoods where concentrated efforts will be made to reach the hard-to-count. The message may come through an employer, a welfare center or a parole office.
At the same time, Mayor David N. Dinkins's office is focusing on enlisting neighbors to persuade other neighbors to be counted, to follow up on people who do not mail back their forms and to staff ''census assistance centers'' at post-office branches, schools and other neighborhood sites.
Both state and local efforts complement the Census Bureau's own outreach. New York City needs 10,000 to 20,000 people to do the actual door-to-door counting. Because of the job's high turnover, at least 100,000 applicants are needed, said Sheila H. Grimm, bureau director for the region that encompasses New York City, Long Island, Westchester, Rockland and Orange Counties and Puerto Rico. The job pays $8 an hour.
About 23,000 people have already applied and taken the required reading and writing test, Bureau officials said. The bureau also needs volunteers to staff the 600 to 700 assistance centers.
A labor shortage is one of the potential setbacks that worries city officials. Another problem is inaccuracies in the Bureau's address lists.
A pre-census city review of numbers of addresses per block on the lists found whole apartment buildings missing, with the omission or mislocation of a half-million New Yorkers. Charles D. Jones, the census's assistant director, said the corrections have been made and city officials will have another chance to review the lists after the census. Such local reviews are a first, he said.
 
Translations in 32 Languages
There is also concern in New York City that census forms are available only in English and Spanish, and that the Spanish forms will be mailed only on request. For city residents who speak dozens of other languages, census-takers will carry translations of census questions in 32 languages.
In Connecticut, the statewide campaign is focusing on communities with lower incomes and large minority concentrations such as Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport, said Terry Schnure, of the Connecticut Office of Policy and Management. In New Jersey, such communities include Newark, Camden, and Jersey City.
Connecticut kept its six-member congressional delegation after the 1980 census, but New Jersey's representation shrunk by one, to the current 14, said Connie O. Hughes, assistant director for occupational and demographic research in the New Jersey Department of Labor. She said that although the state's undercount was about the national average in 1990, its population growth has not kept pace with the rest of the nation.
At St. Catherine of Genoa in Brooklyn that Sunday, Ms. Alter's hope was that parishioners would take her message back to fearful friends and relatives. Marjorie Patron, a church member, said some undocumented immigrants would not cooperate despite the prodding, but many others would.
''If they hear that they can get help based on numbers, they'd like to be counted,'' she said.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 8, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1079 words

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
The Art of Turning Ethnicity Into Entertainment

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff

 BODY:
''Ethnic Dance'' is the usual label affixed to any troupe that looks foreign and whose offerings are not in the realm of modern dance or ballet. The latest entrants would seem to be the Don Cossacks from the Soviet Union and the Jose Greco Company of Spanish Dancers, Singers and Musicians - two groups that are stirring up enthusiastic audiences this month.
Both draw their music and dancing from a national culture, and each (interesting in the case of the Cossacks because it is not true of all Russian ensembles) incorporates a great deal of foot stamping in the choreography. In both instances, the dancers are highly trained professionals, not amateurs plucked from villages along the Don river or from the caves of Granada. 
Like Mr. Greco, in fact, you can be raised in Brooklyn and become America's most famous Spanish dancer. What you need as an ethnic dancer is to master the idiom in question. This does not necessarily make you a folk dancer, and it is somewhat misleading to regard virtuosic theatricalized troupes like the Don Cossacks as folk ensembles simply because their material comes from traditional sources.
As for Spanish dance, the debate goes on. Is it a folk form? Its roots are certainly with ''the people'' - the gypsies of Andalusia who grow up dancing flamenco and the inhabitants throughout Spain who identify with diverse regional dances. Or is Spanish dance an art form? Certainly, flamenco performers such as Vicente Escudero and Carmen Amaya in the past were regarded only as what they were - great artists.
Terms like ''ethnic'' and ''folk'' have validity, but they are often misused or used superficially. This does not mean that dance can no longer be of genuine ethnological interest. Dances that still preserve ritual significance in daily life remain the anthropologist's preserve. Incidentally, it should be noted that a different kind of Soviet folk dancer and musician has increasingly been seen in the United States - usually under the auspices of the Smithsonian Institution or the World Music Institute: An ensemble of village elders from Russia (one such ''authentic'' group from Arkhangelsk may appear at Jacob's Pillow in Becket, Mass., this summer) is very different from the Don Cossacks, the State Academic Ensemble of Rostov, U.S.S.R. The truth is that the Don Cossacks and the Jose Greco Company are primarily entertainers. Their capacity to communicate with an audience is their open secret for success.
Mr. Greco himself is 71 years old. Now a bit stout, sometimes quaint looking, he can still burst into a blazing display of dynamic heel work. He never loses his star luster. Not for nothing was he the great popularizer of Spanish dance in this country in the 1950's and 60's.
In this comeback phase (the company closes at the Joyce Theater with a 2 P.M. matinee today) he presents a capsule introduction to Spanish dance. There is a tribute to Argentinita, the famous concert dancer who took him on as a partner in his youth. In ''La Castellana,'' Argentinita boiled down the essence of a Castilian folk dance with humor and economy. Mr. Greco flirts slyly with two charming doll-like dancers, Carmen Ortega and Pepa Romano, wrapped up in multicolored shawls and leggings.
In ''Los Picaneros,'' the opening flamenco number, Mr. Greco exercises a symbolic droit du seigneur, going off with Alba de Rio, whose proud carriage and sinuous arms weave rococco shapes in the air.
The company (with Luis Montero performing with integrity as a guest in an understated ''Alegrias'' and in the bolero-style ''Intermezzo'' from ''Goyescas'' with the gracious Pilar Serrano) is centered around Mr. Greco (who has had three wives) and four of his grown children. Carmela Greco, a statuesque performer who lacks the concentration to delve deep into herself as a flamenco dancer, does best as a choreographer. Alessandra Greco has a strong stage presence, personifying the moon who abducts a child in a vignette inspired by one of Francisco Garcia Lorca's ''Ballads.'' Jose Luis Greco is his father's music director.
The company's virtuoso is another son, Jose Greco II, who takes various stylistic liberties with his flamenco solos and gets away with it. A favorite device is his execution of ballet's double air-turns to the knee, a sequence usually repeated on the spot with staccato precision.
The first number introduces the style he shows later to full effect in the program's ''Farruca.'' His power is directed less to his strong heel work than to his corkscrew twists and turns. Occasionally, he dances on the outside of a foot like an Argentine gaucho.
Backed up by an excellent group of guitarists and singers, the company has two other fine male dancers. Juan Olarte can seduce with his glare and open-legged heel work; Jose Luis Romay, his slim body pulled up, is refined and forceful in his foot stamping. He is the purist.
This is a company that knows how to please. It does not, however, know how to move us the way truly great Spanish dancers always do.
The Don Cossacks, in contrast, offer considerable depth. The emotional resonance of the music, often sung separately by the men's and the women's choirs, is self-evident.
The dances, all professionally choreographed, speak more clearly of a population that grew out of Russians who settled the steppes as free men, not serfs. Cattle breeders and superb horsemen, the Cossacks often lived under self-imposed military administration; their regiments served the czars.
Yet, to see Cossacks solely as soldiers is inaccurate. Although most were poor, many became rich farmers. These aspects of Cossack history are expressed fleetingly in the dance imagery. The delightful surprise of this company, directed by Anatoly Kvasov, was its individualistic stamp (the troupe performs today at the Tilles Center in Greenvale, L.I.; Tuesday and Wednesday at the Trenton War Memorial Theater, and Thursday at the Palace in Stamford, Conn.) Even within a familiar outline, the pieces - by several choreographers - have originality. The basic steps and patterns may be found in other Russian folk ensembles. The difference is the accent placed on specific motifs. Horsemen are astride their steeds through a fluent combination of mime and dance; the mustachioed Cossack regiments are grouped to recall famous paintings. Even the foot-stamping never looks alike. The motto here is variety within specialization - carried off smoothly by an unusual company.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alessandra Greco, Jose Greco and Carmen Ortega in ''Rincon Flamenco''-A company that knows how to please. (Beatriz Schiller)

HEADLINE: FILM;
Partnerships Make a Movie

BYLINE: By ALJEAN HARMETZ

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
Joanne Woodward has a toothache. Paul Newman would prefer to be home in bed. ''This is certainly an endurance record,'' said James Ivory, the director of ''Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' the movie in which the Newmans are starring.
Almost nobody feels good during the last week of shooting a long movie on location . All the things that didn't get done are pushed and tugged and swept together into 18-hour days that have crazy rhythms and nonsensical juxtapositions.
''I can't believe we're doing this at this hour of the night,'' said Ms. Woodward, staring into a makeup mirror at midnight. 
Of the four major participants in ''Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' only the eternally optimistic producer, Ismail Merchant, has not been worn down by 11 weeks in Kansas City. Blythe Danner, who plays Mrs. Bridge's troubled friend, Grace, calls Mr. Merchant ''the happy, inexhaustible Buddha.'' Mr. Newman calls him ''the glue that holds us together.'' Layered in sweaters and jackets that give his rotund figure a Buddha shape, Mr. Merchant shrugs off the cold, dark night of shooting that will last until 3 A.M.
It is an oddity of ''Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' - which is based on two novels by Evan S. Connell that are disguised accounts of the marriage of his parents - that the stars have been married for 32 years and the director and producer have been making movies together for 27 years. Hollywood relationships rarely last a decade. It is too easy to blame one's husband or wife, producer or director, for bad reviews or bad box office.
But these two personal and professional partnerships have survived. James Ivory and Ismail Merchant made their first film in 1963, had their first success with ''Shakespeare Wallah'' in 1965 and became known for tasteful, literary examinations of the collision of cultures in such pictures as ''The Europeans'' (1979) and ''The Bostonians'' (1984), both based on Henry James novels.
After 22 movies, they hit the jackpot in 1986 with ''A Room With a View.'' Based on the novel by E.
* M. Forster, the romantic comedy about an Englishwoman abroad was a commercial success and was nominated for eight Academy Awards, including best picture. It won for costumes, art direction and the screenplay by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, who has been a partner in Merchant Ivory Productions since the beginning. The three of them live in the same apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and share a weekend house on 40 acres in Columbia County in the Hudson River valley.
The Newmans can barely remember all the movies in which they have performed together, starting with ''The Long Hot Summer'' in 1958. Sitting in Ms. Woodward's trailer at 1 A.M., they argue over whether they played husband and wife in two or three of the eight films. They were a young suburban couple in ''Rally 'Round the Flag, Boys!'' in 1958 and an heiress and the stockbroker who walks out on her in ''From the Terrace'' (1960). Ms. Woodward thinks ''The Drowning Pool'' (1975) should count, because she played her husband's ex-wife.
What their own marriage brings to the marriage in this movie ''is almost unconscious because you choose it so quickly,'' said Mr. Newman. ''I'm very vulnerable to Joanne. She does things that shatter me.''
''We have been married longer than Walter and India Bridge,'' said Ms. Woodward, marveling. ''I feel like a very old lady.''
In ''Mrs. Bridge'' (1959) and ''Mr. Bridge'' (1969), Evan Connell defined lives that were relentlessly shallow because they were lived so rigorously according to the conventions of the country club upper middle class of Kansas City. He wrote of Mrs. Bridge: ''She brought up her children very much as she herself had been brought up, and she hoped that when they were spoken of it would be in connection with their nice manners, their pleasant disposition and their cleanliness, for those were qualities she valued above all others.'' The choice of the Newmans for the roles, said Mr. Merchant, is intended to make Mr. Bridge less arid and give to the portrait of Mrs. Bridge a comical and bittersweet sadness.
The movie grew out of a dinner a few years ago at which Mr. Ivory met the Newmans for the first time. Ms. Woodward had been trying to mount a television production of ''Mrs. Bridge'' with no success. She had read and loved the book in 1960, but it had never occurred to her then that she might play the role. ''Mrs. Bridge was very much me, but I wasn't the right age,'' she said.
''The world of Mr. and Mrs. Bridge is the world I grew up in,'' said the 62-year-old Mr. Ivory, who grew up in Klamath Falls, Ore., and majored in architecture at the University of Oregon. ''It's the only film I've ever made that was about my own childhood and adolescence. When we talked about it, that seemed true of Paul and Joanne, too. We talked a lot about manners, about the way things used to be done. Paul said, 'If I like the script, I'll play Mr. Bridge.' Once Paul said he was going to do the film, he attracted the money.''
The budget for ''Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' is $7.5 million, of which $500,000 is a mirage, since it was spent immediately in interest payments on the borrowed money. Mr. Merchant and Mr. Ivory are used to low budgets, the price of their freedom to make the movies they want. The opulent ''Room With a View'' cost $3 million. The higher budget on ''Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' does not provide luxury. Some of the increase is due to inflation; most is the cost of doing business with the Newmans, although, said Mr. Merchant, ''If Paul and Joanne were to take their usual salaries, the budget would be $12 million.''
Throughout their careers, the Newmans have often spurned big-budget commercial movies in favor of small-budget oddities, including four pictures in which Mr. Newman directed his wife: ''Rachel, Rachel'' (1968), ''The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds'' (1972), ''The Shadow Box'' on television in 1980 and ''The Glass Menagerie'' (1987.) But old bones find Merchant Ivory film making difficult. ''This film is very tough,'' said Ms. Woodward, who is 59. ''You're not shooting the film. You're shooting the schedule and the budget.''
There are no comfortable soundproof stages. Real houses, auditoriums and office buildings are turned into sets for the week or the day. Because it is cheaper to film all the scenes in one location at the same time, little is shot in sequence. The previous morning, Mr. Newman leapfrogged half a decade in every scene. Furniture, makeup and clothes had to be changed every hour at the office of Walter Bridge, Kansas City lawyer in the spring of 1932, the fall of 1938, the winter of 1945, the summer of 1938.
''I've never had so many manicures in my life,'' said Ms. Woodward at midnight as her fingernails were painted sandalwood beige for a party at the home of a modern-art-loving psychoanalyst - faintly disreputable because of both his taste and his profession - in 1939. In this jumble of years and seasons, Ms. Woodward has often had two manicures a day, her fingernails shaped and reshaped, painted and repainted, decorated with white ends or half moons.
Politeness is the bedrock of Ms. Woodward's personality, and she admires Mrs. Bridge's emphasis on manners. ''Being from the South, nice manners are very high on my list,'' she said. ''They imply noblesse oblige, kindness and thoughtfulness for the other person, qualities that seem lacking today.'' But last night, politeness was swept away by exhaustion. At a party given by Mr. Merchant, the 65-year-old Mr. Newman - sleek in tight blue jeans and a leather jacket and opening every cupboard in search of peanuts - smiled and charmed. Ms. Woodward stayed home. ''After I had been on the set 14 hours, cried many buckets of tears and been photographed with 200 extras, I got into the tub with a glass of sherry and two Advils,'' she said.
In any case, the gregarious Mr. Merchant will give another party tomorrow or the next night.
Merchant. Ivory. The names could be symbols for the men who wear them.
Pale, quiet, his hair a brilliant white, James Ivory is so self-effacing that he often seems a wallflower on his own set. Even in the center of a room, he appears to be standing in a corner. Mr. Merchant is the salesman, raconteur and gourmet cook who charms and seduces with basmati rice and dilkhush shorba.
''Let me cook for you,'' he says - to his stars, his crew, the Kansas City aristocracy who have loaned him the antique furniture and porcelain that dress Mr. Ivory's sets, the store owner who lent him $25,000 worth of Oriental rugs for last night's party.
''The only thing low-budget about this film is our salaries,'' said the cinematographer Tony Pierce-Roberts, who was nominated for an Academy Award for ''A Room With a View.'' ''It would make Ismail happiest if we'd pay to work with him. We have incredibly rich set dressings, but a lot is begged, borrowed and stolen. On another film, the art director would just go rent things.''
Brunschwig & Fils has donated $100,000 worth of fabrics and wallpaper. A law firm in Kansas City has loaned a dozen Tiffany lamps and paintings by Kansas City artists of the 30's. Mr. Merchant has borrowed a desk used by the founder of Hallmark greeting cards from his son, the current head of the company, and bridge tables from a local society woman. Benjamin Moore has given 100 gallons of paint. Glen Raven Mills of North Carolina has donated period awning material. The London tailors Gieves & Hawkes made the entire wardrobe for the male characters in return for a screen credit. Marble bookends that used to belong to Evan Connell's father now sit in the office of Walter Bridge.
The house in which the Bridges live is filled with the personal belongings of the Connell family. ''We cleaned Evan's sister, Barbara Zimmermann, out of every porcelain object, her whole collection of silver, her Christmas tree ornaments and her coffee urn,'' said David Gropman, the production designer. ''The lamp Evan Connell made as a boy is in the bedroom of the Bridges' son Douglas.''
Added Sandy Hamilton, the prop man, in amazement: ''Ismail can talk museums into lending us things no one in his right mind should lend to a movie company.''
But getting things free is paid for in time and energy. There are phone calls to be made, flowers to be sent, dinners to be cooked, visitors to be invited to the set. Carol Ramsey, the costume designer, has borrowed $4,000 worth of sashes, merit badges, handcarved neckerchief slides and Boy Scout pins from 1938 for a ceremony in which Douglas Bridge, played by Robert Sean Leonard (the boy who commits suicide in ''Dead Poets Society''), becomes an Eagle Scout.
''Because we got them free, it takes enormous time,'' said Ms. Ramsey, who also did the costumes for Merchant Ivory's last movie, the critically savaged ''Slaves of New York.'' Each separate pin and badge has had to be described, sketched and logged onto its own page in a looseleaf notebook.
None of this bothers Mr. Merchant, who would rather cook dinner for 100 people than hand over an extra thousand dollars. Mr. Gropman, the production designer, was going to spend $500 to have period mattresses made for a scene in the county jail. ''Ismail was livid,'' said Mr. Gropman. ''He told me to call the President Hotel, which is closed down, and ask if they had mattresses. They did, but the mattresses weren't the right size. Ismail said, 'Cut them!' There was no way I was going to cut mattresses, so I took blankets and folded them to mattress size.''
But if Mr. Ivory quietly says he wants something, he usually gets it. The day of the party Mr. Merchant allowed him an expensive crane shot for use during a Boy Scout ceremony that required 220 extras and for which every boy's hair was cut by one of two 60-year-old Kansas City barbers.
Born in Bombay, the only son of a textile merchant, the 52-year-old Mr. Merchant speaks Urdu, English, Hindi, Gujarati, Marathi and Persian. At 5 P.M. he was chopping 20 heads of garlic, slicing ginger, chilies and oxtails into boiling oil and sweeping the floor between phone calls. At 6:35 he hit the market. In less than 11 minutes, he had spent $136.38 on spinach, cucumbers, 20 pounds of ground meat, six loaves of sourdough bread, five pounds of frozen blueberries, gallons of yogurt and peach ice cream. The party was due to start at 9 P.M.; his Indian spices, chutney and Masoor lentils were with Blythe Danner on a plane from New York that was an hour late; the Boy Scout scenes might not even be finished by 9 and the $25,000 worth of rugs had been delivered to the wrong house. Mr. Merchant, who has a touch of Eastern fatalism, seemed serene.
Later - barefoot, wearing a cream-colored 150-year-old kurta and a shawl that he described as ''hair from the throat of a goat and three times as soft as cashmere'' - Mr. Merchant flattered and hugged his guests. Rumpled in dark gray cords and a cardigan sweater, Mr. Ivory stood to the side.
They have never come close to breaking up, said Mr. Ivory, not even during a string of films in the 1970's that were disliked by the critics and made no money. The success of ''A Room With a View'' has made everything easier.
''After 'Room,' the studios offered all sorts of films with big stars but not with the freedom I have,'' said Mr. Ivory. ''As long as I keep within the budget, I have absolute creative control.''
Because of 'Room,' Mr. Merchant is now able to get all the money from one place: Cineplex Odeon Films financed ''Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' and then sold American theatrical rights to Miramax - instead of using a combination of limited partnerships, local distributors and their personal salaries. Because they were almost never able to get studio backing for the films they wanted to make, Merchant Ivory owns the negatives to more than 20 movies at a time when television across the world is hungry for product. Mr. Merchant expects the company to net $2.5 million from its library during the 1990's.
Mr. Merchant went to bed at 4 A.M. He was up at 9 to cook breakfast.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Awaiting the Results in Japan

 BODY:
Foreign-exchange traders around the world will be keeping an eye out Sunday for the first results from the Japanese elections for the lower house of Parliament. The Liberal Democratic Party, which has been plagued by scandals and lost the upper house last year, is fighting to keep control of the Government. A loss for the Liberal Democrats could further weaken the yen, at least temporarily. But whichever way the election goes, the Bank of Japan is expected to move to strengthen the yen by raising its key interest rate. Meanwhile, the dollar rallied a little last week against the German mark but lost its gains on Friday, when the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production had declined 1.2 percent in December.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Rocky Times for Trump's Bonds By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump's marriage is not the only one of his important relationships that is not working out these days. His rapport with the ''junk bond'' market - whose contribution to his success arguably approaches that of his estranged wife, Ivana - has become equally rocky.
The prices of several of Mr. Trump's mortgage-bond issues have fallen so far in the past several months that Salomon Brothers, the Wall Street bond house, recently advised its institutional clients to sell the bonds issued for Trump's Castle casino in Atlantic City.
Those unrated bonds were trading at 92 cents on the dollar at the end of January, when Salomon said ''sell.'' The issues promptly tumbled to 82 percent of par, a price that would offer a yield to maturity of roughly 20 percent. Are the bonds now a bargain? Not according to Salomon Brothers. 
''In the next couple of months, the downside risk of these bonds is greater than the upside,'' one analyst said. ''There won't be any news in the next few months to provide any reason for these bonds to go up.''
The tabloids may debate the roots of the Trumps' marital discord, but there is little doubt about why bondholders have grown so chilly toward Mr. Trump's mortgage issues.
The coupon-clipping crowd is worried about three things: debt levels, real estate values and the casino industry. The Trump bonds, of course, are debt issues sold to finance heavily leveraged real estate ventures in the casino industry.
The largest group of securities examined by Salomon Brothers are $226.8 million worth of bonds known as the ''Trump's Castle Funding 13.75s of 1997.'' Translated, that simply identifies them as mortgage bonds issued to finance the Trump's Castle casino, paying a stated interest rate of 13.75 percent and maturing in 1997.
A tandem $125 million issue, the ''Trump's Castle Funding 7s of 1999,'' are bonds with a stated interest rate, or coupon, of 7 percent; they mature in 1999. The Trump's Castle 7s, with their artificially low coupon, were designed to sell considerably below par, with investors reaping the difference between the purchase price and the value at maturity.
That was not the case with the Trump's Castle 13.75 bonds, however. They were issued at par and the price at which they trade is influenced chiefly by the ambient interest rates and the perceived likelihood that the issuer will continue making payments until the bonds mature.
Obviously, investors are not avoiding these bonds because better interest rates are offered elsewhere. To be sure, other casino bond issues also have dropped in price since September, but their decline was not as steep as that of the Castle bonds. Could it be that the bond market is growing worried about the prospects of some of Mr. Trump's enterprises? It certainly could be, said James Grant, the publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a credit-market newsletter.
''It is the certainty of the tabloid press and the electronic media that Mr. Trump is worth approximately the gross national product, that he has more money than the Federal Reserve,'' said Mr. Grant, who has been following Mr. Trump's use of leverage for several years. ''Maybe he does. But knowing Mr. Trump to be a real estate operator, and therefore a leveraged one, and knowing him to be a casino operator in a city in which casino revenues are weak, I would find it unusual for him to be untouched by recent realities. So this is a fascinating study in public opinion about leverage.''
The Salomon Brothers report on the Trump's Castle issues notes that the amount of income available to service the marina-based casino's outstanding debt is shrinking, as the Atlantic City gaming industry weathers a weak season.
For Trump's Castle, ironically, the hard times could be exacerbated by the April opening of the Trump Taj Mahal, a Boardwalk establishment of record-setting size and Ivana-inspired opulence.
The completion of the Taj Mahal, originally begun by Resorts International, was financed with yet another Trump-related bond issue, the ''Taj Mahal Funding 14s of 1998,'' which carry a coupon of 14 percent and mature in 1998. Those bonds, for the record, are trading at less than 75 percent of their face value these days.
The Taj Mahal's grand opening ''will add substantial capacity to the Atlantic City casino industry and cause the Trump Organizaton to divert personnel and clientele away from its other casinos,'' the Salomon report pointed out.
''We believe that Trump's Castle will also be negatively impacted due to its location off of the Boardwalk, where all of the excitement associated with the opening of the Taj Mahal will be taking place.''
It presumably will not worry Mr. Trump if high rollers choose the Taj Mahal over Trump's Castle; it's all the same pocket to him. But the Taj Mahal bondholders and the Castle bondholders might view it differently, since the revenues raked in at one casino are not automatically available to pay the debt service owed by the other.
Mr. Trump is the controlling officer of both establishments, however, and he presumably could move the available capital around as necessary. But the bond market may be remembering that an earlier group of investors - those who bought bonds issued by Resorts International -did not fare very well by relying on the loyalty and largess of Mr. Trump, who took over Resorts in 1987.
Within two years, Mr. Trump had sold the company - lock, stock and bond obligations - to entertainer Merv Griffin, and had simultaneously arranged to buy the unfinished Taj Mahal from Resorts with other bondholders' money. Soon after, Resorts had filed for bankruptcy-court protection, leaving the Resorts investors with a fraction of their original investment.
 
THE WELL OF GOOD LUCK AT SOURCE PERRIER
The shares of Source Perrier, the publicly traded French water bottler, fell sharply after the company announced on Feb. 9 that North Carolina health officials had found traces of benzene in local Perrier samples. A worldwide recall is underway.
Given the circumstances, the stock's tumble would hardly be noteworthy except for two other developments. First was the stock's unexpected (and, to many analysts, inexplicable) rebound on Thursday, despite news that the source of the benzene may have been the Source itself - Perrier's spring.
The second was an odd blip on the regulatory radar. Before the Feb. 9 contamination announcement, there was heavy trading in Perrier ''put'' options, contracts which permit the option-holders to sell Perrier shares in the future at a specific price - in this case, a price considerably higher than the one that obtained after the bad news hit. Two days earlier, the volume in Perrier common stock also bounced well above recent levels.
French regulators checked it out; unlike the North Carolina scientists, they could find nothing worth reporting.

LENGTH: 699 words

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Volatility in South Africa's Markets

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Humphrey Borkum, a director of South Africa's largest brokerage house, wasn't surprised by what Nelson Mandela said when he was released last week from prison after more than 27 years. But other players in the South African stock market apparently were.
After Mr. Mandela restated his support for the African National Congress's long-held policy of nationalization of some key industries, like gold mines, the Johannesburg Stock Exchange Overall Index plummeted 7.5 percent in just three days. It recovered a bit at the end of the week, but still finished 6 percent down. ''I didn't expect him to come out after 27 years and say, 'I changed my mind,' '' said Mr. Borkum of Davis Borkum Hare. ''Everyone here thinks he is doing no more than staking out his position from where he will negotiate.'' 
But that didn't deter the selling, which was accelerated by a concomitant sharp decline in the financial rand, the special investment currency foreigners must use to buy South African stocks. Kloof Gold, a gold-mining company, fell from 42.75 rand on Feb. 9 to 37.75 at its low on Wednesday; and the drop of the financial rand increased the loss when translated into other currencies.
The fall was just as scary for Americans who invest dollars in gold funds concentrated in South African shares. International Investors Inc. is the largest gold fund and has 56 percent of its investment in South Africa. It fell from $18.18 on Feb. 9 to $15.75 Wednesday, a 13.4 percent decline, compared with a 11.6 percent decline in the South African gold index. A sister fund, Gold Resources, which does not invest in South Africa, was down only several pennies, to $5.42 on Wednesday.
Mr. Borkum and Niall Brown of Simpson McKie, another big South African brokerage firm, attributed the sell-off to speculative foreign investors who had already pushed the the market up 3.2 percent after South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, promised two weeks ago that Mr. Mandela's release was imminent. ''It is a case where people are behaving more on sentiment than fact,'' Mr. Brown said about both the run-up and the fall.
David Poole, chief economist at International Investors Inc., said a correction was due anyway because of the large rise in gold-share prices. The fund has risen 73.6 percent since last May; the South African gold index has risen 44.7 percent.
Most Americans who invest in South Africa do so through funds, like International Investors, that buy gold stocks in South Africa, the United States, Canada and Australia. But opposition to apartheid has deterred many investors. According to Davis Borkum Hare, Americans held only 3.9 percent of the South African gold shares that are traded in American Depository Receipts in the United States at the end of last year, down from 13.8 percent at the end of 1987.
Last week's decline in the South African market means investors will have more volatility to contend with. It is likely that every hiccup in talks between the A.N.C. and Pretoria could move the market quickly in one direction or another. And as in the case of the plunge last week, these moves may not seem logical.
There is, of course, a risk that talks won't get off the ground. But Mr. Mandela's release and Mr. de Klerk's willingness to negotiate are real reason for optimism. And they give investors, for the first time in years, several positive factors with which to balance South Africa's risks.
One is that South African gold stocks are already some of the most attractive in the world and would be more so with a new government. In the last year, they are up 72 percent in dollar terms compared with 27 percent for gold shares in the United States.
And investors can look forward to the lifting of sanctions, which is now a real possibility and would bring in floods of new money.
But after all this, there is still one other variable to contend with: the price of gold, which colors the atmosphere on the exchange. Warren Myers, vice president of Merril Lynch Capital Markets in New York, predicts a continued rise, which should push up the price of gold shares. But Mr. Brown thinks gold will not rise much this year, ''so gold shares are not too exciting.''

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1529 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: February 11-16

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Drexel: Driven From the Market It Created
 
Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday amid ironies heaped as high as its clients' - and now its own -debts. The brokerage house has been driven from a ''junk bond'' market it created. A firm whose executives insisted they were investing in America, not just making quick profits, failed in part because they put too little money in the business and took too much out for themselves, bankruptcy filings indicate. Banks that invested in highly leveraged deals refused to extend further credit to the firm that organized many of those deals. Michael Milken, the King of Junk Bonds himself, is now on the receiving end of a debt gone bad. And, for those given to proclaiming the significance of new decades, it all conveniently happened in just the second month of 1990.
 
Profits According to Iacocca
 
Lee Iacocca is having trouble selling cars as well as he sells books. The chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation declared himself ''not in the least bit disappointed'' last Tuesday with a $664 million fourth-quarter loss reflecting the costs of layoffs and plant closings. But analysts took a darker view, especially since Chrysler lost $87 million even before the expenses of cutting back. Mr. Iacocca kicks off a tour this week to try to convince the press, the analysts and the public that they are wrong about his cars and his company. 
 
Back and Forth With Japan
 
More bad news for Chrysler: Honda and Toyota threaten to move ahead in United States auto sales. Both of them bested the Chrysler Corporation's 9.3 percent share of car sales in December, when the Honda Motor Company had 9.5 percent and the Toyota Motor Corporation 10.4 percent. Analysts say Chrysler will out-sell the Japanese companies this year, but inevitably slip behind. ''It is something that will happen eventually,'' said Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch. Chrysler sells enough minivans and trucks to stay third in the American market overall. But at least for cars, it makes more sense to speak of the Big Five than the Big Three.
 
Comebacks at Gulfstream
 
Allen E. Paulson is back as owner of the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, and Theodore J. Forstmann is back as a buyout artist. They teamed up to acquire the company from Chrysler last Tuesday for $825 million. Both are men with something to prove. At age 67, Mr. Paulson still, every few years, takes a Gulfstream corporate jet out for a record-setting whiz around the world. Mr. Forstmann, 50, dubbed the junk-bond Jeremiah, brags to anyone who will listen that his investment firm does deals without that sort of debt.
 
Auto Woes Elsewhere
 
Slow auto sales and costly incentives also hurt fourth-quarter earnings at the United States' two largest auto makers. Profits at the General Motors Corporation were down 49.9 percent to $700 million, at the Ford Motor Company down 72.9 percent to $314 million.
 
New on the Toy Front
 
The American International Toy Fair bustled into New York last week with Entertech's Spit Ball water gun, Milton Bradley's Gorbachev board game (''acquire the luxuries that every Russian desires'') and Hasbro's Baby Uh-Oh, a doll that dirties its diapers in two realistic colors. Toy industry analysts say kids will stick with Barbie and Nintendo.
 
The TV Pie and How It Slices
 
It was Tisch vs. Turner, network vs. cable. First, on Tuesday, the Association of National Advertisers heard from Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS Inc. He said that the networks' slide had about halted, safely above 60 percent of the prime time audience: ''As we enter a new decade, somehow things have settled down.'' Unlike the other two networks, CBS sees no need to hedge by investing in cable, he said. The next day came Ted Turner, chairman and chief executive of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., to compare network television to other declining enterprises. ''I love when they say our shares are going to bottom out at 60 percent or 50 percent or 40 percent,'' he said. ''How the hell do you know? How do you know where G.M.'s share is going to bottom out, or Drexel Burnham's?''
 
Time Warner Takes It on the Chin
 
The major bottom-line result so far of the 1989 merger that created Time Warner Inc.has been a fourth-quarter loss of $222 million. The loss, reported last Monday, reflected interest expenses and merger costs in creating the world's largest media company. For all of 1989, Time Warner lost $256 million, compared with a profit of $288 million in 1988. Wall Street responded by pushing the stock down toward $100, far less than Paramount offered for Time Inc. last year.
 
Bolar Faces the S.E.C.
 
The Securities and Exchange Commission filed charges of securities fraud on Friday against the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company and Robert Shulman, its former president. The S.E.C. said Bolar ''made false and misleading disclosures and omitted disclosing material information'' when the company agreed with the Food and Drug Administration on Feb. 2 to temporarily suspend shipments of its products. Bolar, which produces generic drugs, confirmed on Friday that Mr. Shulman had resigned as president. He has been replaced by Lawrence S. Raisfield, who founded the company with Mr. Shulman and remains a major stockholder.

 
THE ECONOMY
 
Will Trade Improvement Last?
 
The merchandise trade deficit for December fell to its lowest level in five years. On Friday, the Commerce Department reported a 30.3 percent improvement to $7.17 billion. The annual trade deficit, $108.6 billion, was the lowest since 1984. But economists doubt the improvements will last. They said that exports rose because the Boeing Company's shipments picked up after its 45-day strike ended in late November. Imports slackened as the nation's economy slowed last year and many businesses reduced their inventories. ''The odds are we're really running at about a $9 billion trade deficit per month rather than the $7 billion for December,'' said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at First Boston.
 
The Sense of the Markets
 
By week's end, many traders and analysts were agreeing that the stock market's strength and junk bonds' recovery made perfect sense. And everyone had a good, sensible reason. Some said stocks and junk bonds had already been discounted to reflect Drexel's weakness. Others said it was a quiet week sandwiched between holidays. A few cited program trading, a few the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe. And some said that everybody on Wall Street had been ignoring 200-day moving averages and index arbitrage strategies to devote their attention to Donald and Ivana Trump and their pending divorce.
 
Slowdown, Not Recession
 
January's retail sales gain of 1.6 percent - the strongest in a year - gave economists more confidence that the nation can hold off a recession. They saw a 1.2 percent drop in industrial production in January - the steepest plunge in nearly four years - as evidence of slow growth rather than economic decline. The Federal Reserve said on Friday that the production slowdown was due to a 10.7 percent drop in utility output during an unusually cold January.
 
Foreign Oil Dependence Grows
 
The nation depended on imports for 54 percent of its oil in January, the highest monthly figure ever. A cold December was responsible for some of last month's rise, but industry experts said that declining production would continue to increase the need for foreign oil.
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
The Downside of Unification
 
German unification advances by the minute. The Allies and East and West Germany agreed Tuesday to speed unification talks. The next day, Bonn approved $4.1 million for East German aid. But the high costs of unification are becoming apparent. The anticipated expense of rebuilding East Germany has already raised West German interest rates, depressing bond markets around the world. Investment in East Germany and elsewhere in Eastern Europe could drain capital from other nations, including the United States. Deutsche Bank A.G. of West Germany estimates the cost of development in Eastern Europe at $300 billion to $500 billion over the next 10 to 20 years.
 
In Brief
 
Food fight: Members of the Petrossian family are battling in a Paris court for control of their caviar and restaurant business.
 
*
 
The Soviet Union announced a contest Wednesday for the best plan to make the ruble convertible into hard currencies. No conversion problem with the reward: $25,000. In dollars.
 
Perrier Recalled Worldwide
 
The Perrier drought entered Week II as the company withdrew every bottle of its sparkling water throughout the world. Source Perrier said on Wednesday that traces of benzene, a toxic chemical, had been found in bottles in Denmark and the Netherlands as they had the week before in the United States. Perrier shares have declined sharply on the Paris stock exchange. The Bourse's Commission of Operations said it would investigate possible insider trading before the company's initial announcement.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Don't Forget Baseball's Young Fans

BYLINE: By CHARLES B. SCHUDSON: Charles B. Schudson is a Wisconsin Circuit Court judge in Milwaukee County. He has served on the faculties of the National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges and the National Judicial College. He is a loyal Milwaukee Brewers fan.

 BODY:
Why should I care about Major League baseball? After eight years as a judge in criminal and juvenile court, why would I have special concerns about the 1990 season and the disputes between the players and owners?
Baseball in America is much more than sport, much more than business. Symbolically, it has provided catalytic power for cultural, social and political change. Most significantly, it provides children with the ''field of dreams'' on which they and society test values and learn lessons. 
If I seem to make too much of this, at least I'm in good company. For many years, great writers and serious scholars have examined the impact of baseball on American life. Consider the following, recent comments.
Roslyn A. Mazer, a lawyer: ''Girls didn't collect baseball cards in the 50's, yet I cede to no one in my enthusiasm, indeed my passion, for the national pastime. I would contend that our nation can be guided to greatness, depending on whether our children are baseball fans.'' Dan Rea, a television newsman: ''I learned sociology in a shoe box. Baseball cards taught me how to read, do math, learn geography and understand life. Baseball games on back-porch radio at night with those old cards would lead me through the lives of players, time and again showing me that nothing - in life or in baseball - is accomplished without hard work and, sometimes, great disappointment.''
Unfortunately, the potential for lifelong lessons seems forgotten in the current disputes between owners and players. Every day I read news of the offers, the negotiations, the dollars. Sure, occasionally someone mentions that the fans might also be a factor. However, all seem to accept that the decisions will be business decisions; the love and loyalty of fans are romantic - and irrelevant.
No one mentions children. No one suggests that these business decisions will be important to kids and the lessons they will learn. No one seems to consider that these business decisions can assume national significance at a time when, finally, Americans seem to be shaking off some excesses of the ''me generation.''
For the last 20 years, kids have learned some cynical lessons from baseball's ''me generation.'' Heroes seem hollow; owners, obese. Cy Young winner Denny McClain becomes a racketeer; Pete Rose, a gambler. And George Steinbrenner - well, George Steinbrenner. Again and again, superstars play where dollars dictate, and teams move where television contracts demand. Children change their cheers or stop cheering, while their parents try to explain insatiable greed.
While such lessons of cruel reality are important, they must not eclipse equally real lessons of virtue. A generation ago, I was fortunate. Growing up in the 50's, when I was forced to confront cruel reality through baseball, I learned of an extraordinary owner who fostered Jackie Robinson's fight against racism, of Roy Campanella's courage from a wheel chair. Later, I learned of Roberto Clemente's death as he helped earthquake victims.
As a judge, I have seen the disastrous results that come when individuals and government ignore the interests of children. Now, in the business of baseball, I see children ignored again. I believe the kids should be a critical concern for owners and players as they make decisions that will teach children about the business of life and the values most important in human relationships.
So perhaps that helps explain why, for me, there is not a terribly great distance between county stadiums and the county courthouse. For those who take the time to care, there is a link between the interests of abused and delinquent children in America's courts, and the generations of children who seem to be peering through a knothole in the center field fence watching, wondering and waiting for Major League Baseball.
Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, recently told students at a college commencement, ''If the only principle our society adheres to is economist Adam Smith's invisible hand, it leaves little or no room for the hand of man, or woman, or of God. There is then a hollowness left at the core of socity whose members share no mutual goals or joint vision - nothing to believe in except self-aggrandizement.'' Children retain goals and vision, dignity and virtue until adults fail to hear their voices.
Baseball, America's most public private enterprise, better start listening.

LENGTH: 1524 words

HEADLINE: All About/Avionics;
American Electronics Companies Still Rule the Cockpit

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
In 1929, Jimmy Doolittle flew blind - covering the cockpit of his biplane with a hood - to prove that a pilot could rely on flight instruments alone. Since then, cockpit electronics have become sophisticated enough to all but take the place of the pilot.
Today's cockpit resembles a flying video arcade: computers and video displays are fast replacing the jumble of gauges, dials and switches that for decades distinguished the modern jetliner. The new gadgets can warn a pilot of sudden wind gusts or an impending collision. With the push of a few buttons, autopilots can guide a plane from New York to Los Angeles while the real pilot sits back.
An airline might load a million dollars' worth of computers and electronics - or avionics - into a cockpit, accounting for as much as 10 percent of the plane's price. Riding a record wave of commercial airplane orders, the avionics industry has grown about 20 percent annually for the past three years. Today, the electronics market for just commercial jets is $2 billion a year, and industry analysts expect revenues to grow 7 percent to 10 percent annually this decade. 
As the electronics grow more prominent, so do the firms that make them. Rather than merely supplying black boxes to be plugged into the cockpit, the companies now design entire cockpit layouts, working on new airplane models from the outset.
With tens of millions of dollars needed to earn Government approval for a new set of avionics, the industry is all but closed to brash upstarts. The industry is dominated by three American companies: Bendix/King, a division of the Allied Signal Aerospace Company; Collins Avionics, a division of the Rockwell International Corporation, and Honeywell Inc. All three are enjoying record growth. Collins's revenues rose last year by 22 percent, Bendix/King's by 12 percent, and Honeywell's by 10 percent. Honeywell, which bought Sperry for $1 billion in 1986, has the largest share of the commercial market, with about $1.2 billion in sales last year.
The major foreign challenge to America's dominance is coming from France. Thomson CSF has recently joined with other French manufacturers to furnish cockpit electronics for Airbus Industrie, the European commercial jetliner company. The amount of American electronics on Airbus jets is shrinking.
Though Japanese electronics may fill American households, they are nearly absent from airline cockpits. Japanese companies supply only the semiconductor chips and other components. Aviation analysts say the Japanese have stayed out of the industry for two reasons: The market is relatively small, and it takes years to earn United States Government approval for a new piece of equipment. ''It's a vertical wall to climb,'' said Paul Gralnick, the president of Bendix/King. ''But if we get sloppy in this country, they'll climb it.'' The Japanese might be tempted by after-tax profit margins as high as 20 percent, considerably higher than for the airplane makers and airlines. But with only three or four potential customers for many avionics products, competition is fierce and each new airplane design critical. ''If you don't get on board a new aircraft you're locked out for 30 or 40 years,'' said D. Larry Moore, president of Honeywell Space and Aviation Systems.
There are few trade secrets in the avionics business. Most of the technology is developed in the military and quickly enters the public domain. A product's shelf life is shrinking, as companies play technological leapfrog.
With most of their sales dependent on the booming commercial airplane business, the avionics makers have become less vulnerable to defense cuts. ''These companies can be like chameleons, shifting from defense to commercial products,'' said Paul Nisbet, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Inc.

 
The New Tools
 
Pilots Worry That Skills Will Atrophy
 The industry's most dramatic advance came in the late 1970's with the advent of the computerized ''glass'' cockpit. Computer equipment became small and light enough to carry aloft. Engineers consolidated dozens of instruments onto six computer-backed cathode-ray tubes. Pilots could check altitude, speed and direction on video displays rather than the more temperamental mechanical gauges. For communications, radios that failed every 2,500 hours, on average, have been replaced with models that last 12,000 hours.
The biggest advantage of the glass cockpit is that the black boxes can talk to one another. The on-board computers can calculate an altitude for the greatest fuel efficiency and the autopilot can guide the plane there.
Most pilots like the new technology, with some reservations. If something goes wrong, the problem may be hard to detect. ''Troubleshooting is a more delicate art than before,'' said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with UBS Securities. And a three-year National Aeronautics and Space Administration study of 200 Boeing 757 pilots found that they were concerned about spending too much time staring at computer screens and not enough looking out the windows. They also worried that their basic flying skills would atrophy as they spent more time punching keypads. ''I was somewhat concerned with the 'I can't fly but I can type 80 words per minute syndrome,' '' said one pilot. Still, about 90 percent of the pilots saw the glass cockpit as a big step forward.

 
Stricter Safety Standards
 
Rules Guarantee More Sales for the Industry
 The Federal Aviation Administration's latest airline safety standards are as reassuring to avionics companies as to passengers. The rules will require more than a billion dollars' worth of electronic gear over the decade.
By 1993 the airlines must install cockpit devices that warn pilots of wind shear - a sudden shift in wind direction and speed that has proved deadly. Only Honeywell and the Sundstrand Corporation make the warning systems; Honeywell has about 70 percent of the market.
By 1993 the airlines must also carry devices to warn of impending collisions. Without relying on ground-based radar, the equipment can suggest evasive action - a climb or descent. Eventually, it may allow closer spacing on North Atlantic routes, where radar coverage is limited. At about $100,000 each, the collision avoidance systems represent a $700 million market worldwide, more than half of it controlled by Bendix/King.
 
 
Flying in the Future
 
Will Computers Supplant Co-pilots?
 Avionics companies say they have only begun to demonstrate the advantages of electronics. In the next few years, pilots might finally solve the problem of cockpit clutter by storing the hundreds of maps they need on optical disks to be read by computers and displayed on video screens.
Another new technology might give them a way to see their instruments even as they look out the windshield. Heads-up displays - already in some military jets - are mounted on the windshield so pilots do not need to fix their gaze inside the cockpit. And a new flat video display is being developed that is thinner and lighter than current screens, which are as bulky as small television tubes.
Airborne navigation and communications are entering a new age as well, with satellites playing a larger role. The airlines have installed satellite communications equipment - standard in the latest Boeing 747's - even though a satellite network probably won't be deployed until the mid-1990's. Honeywell is working with the Racal Corporation, a British company, to develop satellite communications equipment. Pilots and passengers will be able to communicate by telephone and radio anywhere in the world. Eventually, satellite navigation could replace today's system, which is based on earth-bound radio and radar.
Another project sounds like it could all but replace the co-pilot. The Air Force boldly calls it the ''pilot associate.'' More than a mere autopilot, the associate devices use artificial intelligence to help fly the plane, plan missions and deploy weapons. The project is in such an early stage that it will take several years to find its way into jet fighters and, eventually, commercial planes.
 
 
HELPING PILOTS AND CONTROLLERS COMMUNICATE
Before an Avianca Airlines Boeing 707 crashed last month, controllers on Long Island kept it circling for nearly 90 minutes after the crew had reported that fuel was dwindling. Government researchers are working on new technology to help clear up the garbled messages and misunderstandings that can lead to such disasters. Called datalink, the system would let controllers and pilots exchange electronic messages that could be viewed on video displays. The system would complement, not replace, the radio.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is already testing datalink on a Boeing 737. Some airlines now use a form of it, but only for messages about maintenance, gates and other routine matters.
Government officials hope that controllers and pilots will be able to communicate through datalink beginning in 1992. The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered airlines to install new transponders capable of receiving the data.

HEADLINE: Conable's World Bank: Finding Fault (and Praise)

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
One of the first things Barber B. Conable Jr. did when he became president of the World Bank nearly four years ago was to adorn his office with non-American objets d'art: a Waterford globe from Ireland, Cantonware serving plates from China, rugs from Mauritania and Morocco.
On Capitol Hill, where he had served on the Ways and Means Committee for 18 years as a Congressman from upstate New York, he had been known for a collection of tomahawks, bead works, masks and other artifacts of Indian tribes from the Finger Lakes region of his birth. That collection didn't make it to the bank's headquarters here. ''I'm suspected of being an American anyway,'' he said, grinning. ''Why do I need the trappings of an American environment?'' The trappings may be gone, but with a little more than a year left in his five-year term, Mr. Conable's nationality is still very much an issue, cited both by detractors and supporters.
Though the bank presidency traditionally has been filled by an American, some of the organization's 152 member nations say that Mr. Conable has been far more willing than his predecessors to pursue an American agenda. They cite a cutoff of loans to Nicaragua, an increase in lending to Mexico and the continuing emphasis on free markets. 
Meanwhile, others find fault with Mr. Conable as an administrator, contending that he has not taken firm control of the bank, the biggest source of aid to developing countries.
''He has learned and improved, but it has never been Barber Conable's bank,'' said a director of one of Washington's prestigious think tanks, who asked not to be more closely identified. ''He's still more the politician, telling people what they want to hear.''
But even his critics credit Mr. Conable, the seventh president since the bank was created out of the ashes of World War II, with dramatically strengthening the institution's role in global development. And that, some observers of the bank say, is at least in part a direct result of the adroit ways in which Mr. Conable has used his nationality and political roots to advantage.
Thanks to his lobbying powers, particularly with former colleagues in Congress, a reluctant United States has gone along with other members and agreed to nearly double the amount of capital - to an impressive $171 billion - that supports the bank's loans.
Moreover, Mr. Conable is credited with shifting the institution in new directions, developing programs to help women and address environmental concerns. (See box.) ''He's a very open and practical man, and has done as good a job as can be done in a tough situation,'' said David R. Obey, a Democrat from Wisconsin who as chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations has watched the Conable performance closely.
Against the mixed reviews, it may not be surprising that Mr. Conable has yet to say whether he will try to stay on when his term expires on June 30, 1991, although some associates believe he will not. Asked in an interview what he intended to do, Mr. Conable, who is 67, replied with a broad smile:
''I'll decide that later. I've had three and one-half years here. They have been a rich, full three and one-half years. People ask me whether I'm having a good time. No, I'm not having a good time, but I'm having a very challenging time, and I do believe that the challenge of being useful on this scale is a unique opportunity that very few people get.''
Indeed, whether based on an American or a global agenda, the bank's policies are commanding increasing attention. Last year, commitments to about 80 developing countries totaled $22.9 billion, more than a third larger than the aid budgets of either Japan or the United States, and the loans are growing at a rate of 10 percent a year. Among other things, the credits are helping to build roads in Pakistan, strengthen commercial banking in Gambia, fight AIDS in Zaire and improve water supplies in Haiti and Mexico.
In the poorest countries, the bank charges no interest and gives the borrowers up to 45 years to repay. The so-called middle-income countries pay interest based on the bank's own cost of money and have 15 to 17 years to repay.
Although the bank is an economic institution, the lines between economics and politics are often blurred, particularly when it comes to Washington. And, say some foreign officials, Mr. Conable is simply too closely linked with American policy interests.
An Indian official, for example, noted that in Delhi the view is that the United States is using the bank in large measure to solve problems of Latin America - a reference to a key financing role the bank plays in the Bush Administration's strategy to help highly indebted countries.
''Abroad there is a view that the bank has become unusually responsive to American opinion,'' said Richard E. Feinberg, vice president of the Overseas Development Council, a Washington-based research group.
American domination of the bank is one factor behind a French initiative last month to establish a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development committed to helping East European countries revamp their economies. The United States would play only a modest role in that body, which would include the Soviet Union among its members. Moscow is not a member of the World Bank.
For his part, Mr. Conable, a hearty man with a stentorian voice, bridles at suggestions that he pushes America at the expense of other countries' interests at the bank.
Mr. Conable thinks it is important for the bank to have good relations with Washington, its biggest contributor. His success in lobbying on behalf of the bank in part reflects his personal friendship with President Bush, with whom he served for four years on the Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Conable is also close to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who as Treasury Secretary in the Reagan Administration, picked Mr. Conable for the job.
The current harmony between the Bush Administration and the bank is in sharp contrast to the cold war that existed under Mr. Conable's predecessor, A. W. Clausen, the former head of the Bank of America.
The Reagan Administration's first Treasury Secretary, Donald T. Regan, and his Under Secretary for Monetary Affairs, Beryl W. Sprinkel, had little sympathy either for Mr. Clausen or the World Bank and at one time even considered pulling the United States out of the organization.
The Clausen period resulted in relatively little growth for the bank, a situation that Mr. Conable has sought to rectify.
While acknowledging - and saying he refuses to apologize for - the ''constructive'' influence of Washington on that growth, Mr. Conable insisted that the bank is a collegial institution not dominated by any one country.
On cutting off loans to Nicaragua, for example, he stressed that this was a decision forced by bank rules, not American policy mandates. The Sandinista Government defaulted on its debts to the bank, he said. Six other countries are in the same category. But even if there had been an American agenda at the bank, Mr. Conable insisted that it has become the ''global agenda.''
''If I were to characterize the past decade,'' he observed, ''the most remarkable thing was the generation of a global consensus that market forces and economic efficiency were the best way to achieve the kind of growth which is the best antidote to poverty. We now have Eastern Europe participating in this agenda.''
Given all the tumultuous changes of the past year in Europe, he said, the bank is ''a paradigm for the post-cold war world.''
''People are sold on what they are doing here,'' Mr. Conable added. ''They're quite cheerful about continuing to do what they do well and be responsive to their perception of need. Somebody has to look at the world and ask are we meeting that need. We are meeting that need.''
 
TWO ROADS TOWARD CHANGE
Besides nearly doubling the World Bank's lending resources, Barber Conable has pressed new initiatives involving women and the environment.
The new women in development division, which employs about a dozen specialists, designs projects to improve women's productivity and earnings.
''We basically practice guerrilla warfare, trying to persuade our colleagues in the bank and in developing country governments that it makes sense to invest in women,'' said Barbara Herz, the former Yale economist whom Mr. Conable put in charge of the division.
Though the initiative has won support from many women's groups, the pace of activity has not kept up with rhetoric, some groups say. ''The bank has yet to fully implement what he's been saying, showing how slowly bureaucracies change,'' said Mayra Buvinic, director of the International Center for Research on Women in Washington. ''The bureaucrats still think this is a fad, related to affirmative action, rather than a central issue of development.''
Mr. Conable has also opened a new department for environmental issues and staffed it with more than 50 specialists.
In previous years, the World Bank was strongly criticized by environmental groups for pushing projects with little regard for their ecological implications.
While conceding that ''the bank is doing better,'' one of its sharpest critics, Senator Bob Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, said that change has been slow and that the environmental issue still represents an ''Achilles heel'' for the institution.
Senator Kasten has been particularly critical of a second loan now being weighed by the bank for the Poloroneste region of northwestern Brazil. Among other things, Mr. Kasten told Mr. Conable in a recent letter, ''it is unclear that the forestry and agricultural programs supported by this loan will be environmentally or economically sustainable.''
The Agency for International Development, a part of the State Department, issues a list every six months of loans of environmental concern being weighed by international institutions. Of 35 projects on the list in December, 24 were World Bank projects.
