HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Digging Out After Drexel

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
When the crisis at Drexel Burnham Lambert hit the news last Monday, Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, geared up for Tuesday's flood of telephone calls.
It prepared its telephone sales representatives for the expected onslaught of calls from investors wanting to unload shares in ''junk bond'' mutual funds. And junk-bond portfolio managers worked late into the night developing strategies to deal with the anticipated outflow of cash from the funds. It never happened. ''We had very little activity'' on Tuesday, said Neil Litvack, a vice president of marketing for Fidelity. Shareholders in Fidelity's junk-bond funds who did call asked questions about how the Drexel crisis might affect their investment, but didn't sell their shares. Redemptions were ''at pace with a typical February day,'' Mr. Litvack said. 
At the Vanguard Group, in Valley Forge, Pa., there was ''very little in terms of net cash outflow'' from junk-bond funds, said Brian S. Mattes, vice president. At T. Rowe Price Associates, in Baltimore, there has been no surge in redemptions and few telephone calls.
''We're not seeing the kind of panic reaction and heavy selling that we saw in the past,'' when other bad news about the junk bond market was reported, said Steven N. Norwitz, a vice president at T. Rowe Price. ''Investors seem to be taking it more in stride,'' he said.
Why did shareholders act so differently - so complacently - this time?
Thin-skinned investors, for the most part, have already bolted, fund managers say, leaving a smaller pool of investors who are more savvy and who have a greater tolerance for risk. ''We're left with the people who have evaluated the risks of the fund and want to stick around for the long term,'' said Fidelity's Mr. Litvak.
''We're down to true buy-and-hold investors who are ready to ride it through even if share prices move a nickel or a dime on a given day,'' Vanguard's Mr. Mattes said.
And it may well prove to be a bumpy ride. Fund managers expect a rough-and-tumble market for the next few weeks, as the questions about Drexel - especially how its portfolio will be parceled out - are resolved. But after that, they say, it's back to normal. The market is ''accepting the Drexel news and preparing to go about its business,'' said Carl C. Ericson, manager of the Income Plus Fund for the Boston-based Colonial Group.
Other fund managers point out that during the 18 months that Drexel's problems have been building, Drexel has taken a diminishing role in making the secondary market for junk-bond issues. As it lost its dominant position, other firms took up the slack, meaning that although Drexel was the leading underwriter last year, most of its deals were supported and traded by others.
Some managers are trying to take advantage of the market disruptions, buying what they say they consider good deals at rock-bottom prices. Ken Urbaszewski, manager of the Kemper High-Yield Fund for Kemper Financial Services, in Boston, bought several issues from Drexel early last week. The fund experienced no unusual redemptions, says Mr. Urbaszewski, who thinks the Drexel news ''could be the last shoe to fall before the junk-bond market stabilizes'' in the next few months.
Martin Wiskemann, manager of the Age High-Income Fund, part of Franklin Resources Inc. in San Mateo, Calif., is also buying.
''Bad news is bad for prices, but a couple of months ahead, things will improve when people realize that the cash flows and asset values of these companies are better than the market gives them credit for,'' he said.
For many investors, however, any improvement would be too little, too late. Investors who bet on junk-bond funds last year got a real lesson in the true meaning of ''investment risk.'' When the market began its long slide, yields that reached 15 percent or more were offset by steep drops in the prices of the bonds, producing a dismal overall performance. Each time the market took another hit - the bankrupcty of Resorts International, the downgrade of RJR Nabisco, the Campeau Corporation default - investors fled the market in droves.
At the beginning of the year, the funds held $34 billion of assets, according to the Investment Company Institute, a trade group. The hemorrhaging started in July and was most pronounced in October, when the junk funds lost $1.24 billion. By the end of the year, assets were down 19 percent, to $28 billion. During the year, the assets of virtually all other fund categories were up, in some cases sharply.
Investors who had put their money into safe, United States Government bond funds last year would have earned 12.9 percent. But in the same period, the 88 junk-bond funds lost an average of 0.88 percent, with the biggest loser, the Dean Witter High Yield Fund, dropping almost 14 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., which tracks mutual fund performance.
 
POOLED MONEY
Investors tend to be paid more for tying up their money longer.
 Every five years or so, the yield curve flips and the opposite is true, and that's what market watchers had been expecting for 1989. But it didn't happen.
Experts had thought that the economy would be sour and that that would push scared investors into shorter-term investments. To be sure, an inverted yield curve did develop for a few months at the beginning of 1989, but it righted itself for the year as a whole, mainly because the economy stayed strong.
Although the markets expect inverted yield curves on a regular basis, they don't really occur as often as predicted. The last one was in 1981.
This year, there should be no flip-flopping of the yield curve, market watchers say. But there are, as always, the contrarians in the crowd, and so far they are saying it may just be too early to tell.

HEADLINE: The Anti-Dumping Laws Do Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As administrator of the United States anti-dumping statute at the Commerce Department, I wish to note that in ''No Justice in Anti-Dumping'' James Bovard misstated department practice in several places (Forum, Jan. 28).
Most troubling was his assertion that the department has disclosed confidential information from foreign businesses to their American competitors. This is untrue. There are stringent rules to protect proprietary data, and sanctions to insure compliance. The integrity of this process lets us collect proprietary information and base dumping calculations on company-specific data.
And the criticism of the department's administrative review process is unfounded. Rather than inflate margins, it is designed to insure that dumping margins reflect up-to-date pricing practices. Once an order is issued, the department does not keep foreign firms ''under economic house arrest for the next 15 years.'' If no dumping margins are found three years in a row, anti-dumping orders can be lifted; more than 80 have been since 1980.
The article contains no recognition that anti-dumping regimes have their foundation in the GATT and are designed to deal with unfairly traded imports that injure a domestic industry. Other governments administer similar regimes, some with considerably less due process. The United States is addressing that problem in the current Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations.
The dumping law is an effective, internationally accepted way to handle unfair trade. It is complex and not perfect. But for American businesses there is justice in knowing that effective relief from unfairly traded goods is available.
 
ERIC I. GARFINKEL
Assistant Secretary
for Import Administration,
Department of Commerce
Washington, Feb. 1

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Selling of Western Water Rights

BYLINE: By SANDRA POSTEL; Sandra Postel is vice president for research at the Worldwatch Institute in Washington.

 BODY:
Last September, the City Council of Aurora, Colo., approved a $1.25 million purchase of agricultural water rights in the South Platte river basin. Eager to secure more water for its rapidly growing population, this municipality east of Denver joined numerous others throughout the West by turning to what it sees as the only vast pool remaining: irrigation water.
Historically, the solution to looming water shortages has been to build additional dams, reservoirs and diversion canals, or more and deeper groundwater wells. Withdrawals from the nation's rivers, lakes and aquifers rose tenfold between 1900 and 1985. 
But with the best water development sites already taken, the cost of new sources is climbing. Mounting concern about the loss of free-flowing rivers, the destruction of freshwater fisheries and damage to wildlife habitats is making new water projects increasingly unacceptable. With water tables falling pervasively and roughly half the West's rivers already overused, new sources of water are simply getting harder to find.
Recognizing that water scarcity will constrain future growth, cities are looking to farmers - and the marketplace - for help. Agriculture has claim to the lion's share of the West's water supplies, accounting for 80 percent to 90 percent of consumption in most states. Cities are effectively bidding supplies away from farms through a process of marketing - the transfer of water or water rights between willing buyers and sellers for an agreed-upon price.
Sale prices have varied greatly, with perpetual water rights having been sold for less than $200 per acre-foot in the Salt Lake City area, but for as high as $3,000 to $6,000 per acre-foot in the rapidly urbanizing Colorado Front Range. (An acre-foot equals 325,850 gallons -enough to supply a typical four-person American household for about two years.) Clearly, if a farmer can earn more by selling water to a nearby city than by using it for growing crops, shifting that water from farm to city use is economically beneficial. If it prevents the city from damming another river to increase supplies, the transfer can also benefit the environment.
Many large trades of this kind, however, could jeopardize crop production. Without protective measures, they will certainly sap the prospects of rural economies where large areas are converted to less lucrative, rain-fed farming, or abandoned to revert to desert.
In Arizona, state law makes it difficult to buy rights to water independent of the land. So Tucson, Phoenix and other rapidly expanding cities have taken to ''water ranching'' - buying up land to get the associated water rights. Already more than 575,000 acres of agricultural land have been purchased as water farms. Some of it will stay in production until the cities actually need the water, but presumably all of it will be removed from farming eventually. In Pima County, where Tucson is located, irrigated agriculture is expected to disappear by 2020.
Fortunately, not all farm-to-city water transfers require that rights be permanently taken out of agriculture. A good example involves a trade between the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, a wholesaler for roughly half the state's 28 million residents, and the neighboring Imperial Water District. The Metropolitan Water District has agreed to finance conservation projects in exchange for the estimated 100,000 acre-feet of water per year those investments will save. The annual cost per acre-foot conserved is estimated at $128, far lower than the district's best alternative. No cropland is being taken out of production, and no irrigation water rights are actually being sold.
Since agriculture uses such an enormous quantity of water, conserving even a small portion of it can meet a large share of new urban needs.
Raising water prices to reflect the true cost of deliveries is a critical step toward this end. The Federal Bureau of Reclamation supplies water to a quarter of the West's irrigated land under long-term contracts at greatly subsidized prices. Farmers benefiting from one huge California project, for example, have reapaid only about 5 percent of the costs over the last 40 years. Hundreds of Federal contracts are coming up for renewal. If the bureau seizes this opportunity to set prices that prompt farmers to conserve, water stresses in the West could ease measurably.
Cities can turn to conservation within their own boundaries as a largely untapped alternative to reaching out for new supplies. Studies have shown that residential use could easily be cut by a third through known water-saving methods.
While increased efficiency - on farms and in homes and industries - can buy much-needed time, in the long view it is but a stopgap. The thirst for water will grow inexorably as long as human numbers and needs continue to expand.

HEADLINE: Tax Credits for Health Insurance Won't Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Coming to Terms on Health Care,'' Stuart M. Butler touts a Heritage Foundation idea to do away with employer-funded health insurance (Forum, Jan 28). He suggests replacing it with a system of tax credits and individually purchased policies. 
There is a fundamental flaw in his proposal: it is inconsistent with how insurance works.
Any potential cost savings from the tax-credit incentive - encouraging employees to buy their own policies - would be more than consumed by increased administrative expenses. Individual policies are more expensive to administer than group policies. But this pitfall is minor compared with the high administrative cost of assessing the health risks of each individual to set premiums and tax credits. The advantage of group policies is that such assessments aren't necessary because the variance in risk can be averaged over a large number of people.
 
CIARAN PHIBBS
Assistant Professor of Health
Economics, Columbia University
School of Public Health
New York, Jan. 31

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Peace Dividend: A Dream for Every Dollar

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
No one knows how much the peace dividend will be or when it will be on the books, but the debate over how to use it may dominate American politics for years to come.
In Congress and city halls, in lobbying circles and academic towers, the politicians and the people who try to influence them are salivating over the prospect that the electrifying changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will permit the United States to spend much less money on the military and create a windfall that can be used elsewhere.
Only in the White House is sand being thrown on the fires of anticipation. President Bush maintains that the peace dividend is a mirage and that talk about it leads to false expectations. 
Asked at a news conference last Monday whether his military budget was not ''out of sync'' and whether he was not ''tone deaf as to what's been happening,'' Mr. Bush responded: ''I think the American people want a cautious approach on this. I don't think any of us think we can see with clairvoyance what's going to happen the day after tomorrow.''
But the news last week served only to fan the flames. The day after the President's news conference, the Soviet Union surprisingly agreed to a Bush proposal to reduce its military forces in Eastern Europe to a level that will allow the United States to withdraw 80,000 troops from Europe, reducing troop strength there by almost a third. Preliminary estimates are that this will save $7 billion to $8 billion a year, a saving that was not fully counted when the President sent his budget to Congress late last month.
In that budget, the President proposed that Pentagon spending rise from $287 billion in the current fiscal year to $292 billion next year and to $305 billion in 1995. While that would be a gradual increase in actual dollars spent, it would be about 2 percent less each year than what would be needed to keep pace with inflation.
By the Administration's own figuring, this would mean spending about $40 billion less in 1995, after taking inflation into account, than is now being spent.
The prevailing view in Congress, among many Republicans as well as Democrats, is that Mr. Bush is shortsighted. For 45 years, United States military policy has been based on defense against a Soviet invasion of Western Europe that could turn into a nuclear holocaust. With each passing week, as the threat from the Soviet Union lessens and as Communism crumbles in the countries along the invasion route to the West - East Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary -that focus seems more anachronistic.
Congress is thus likely to approve much deeper reductions in military spending than the President wants. The lawmakers have paid close attention to some recognized military experts, including former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and William W. Kaufmann, a national security specialist at the Brookings Institution, who believe the Pengaton budget could safely be cut in half by the turn of the century.
That anticipates an average cut of 5 percent a year below this year's level, adjusted for inflation. If that path is followed, an additional $75 billion would be available in 1995 and $150 billion by the end of the decade in 1990 dollars.
There are basically three alternative uses for the windfall: cut taxes, spend the money or use the revenue to reduce the budget deficit and, eventually, the $3 trillion national debt.
Many conservatives favor a tax cut. Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, argues that ''the American people paid for the superiority of our system to emerge'' and should now be rewarded in kind. ''I don't think the benefits from winning the cold war should go to the Government,'' he declared.
The Heritage Foundation, the conservative research institute, published a paper last week listing 11 different ways to cut taxes.
And not only conservatives take this approach. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, argues that a peace dividend could make up most of the revenue that would be lost from his proposal to cut Social Security taxes.
Many others in Washington and around the country maintain that the United States now has a golden opportunity to meet problems that were overlooked in the tightfisted Reagan years.
Lobbyists for social causes envision using the money for education, housing, drug control and welfare. The General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress, has prepared a list of ''unavoidable costs'' facing the Government, from repairing deficient bridges and highways to modernizing the air traffic control system to cleaning and modernizing troubled nuclear weapons plants. The United States Conference of Mayors last month called for spending the money on urban aid. Two conservatives, Phyllis Schlafly and Paul Weyrich, pleaded with President Bush recently to devote the funds to programs to strengthen the American family.
Economists for the most part would neither cut taxes nor spend the money but would use it to lower the Federal budget deficit and to begin paying off the national debt. Such a policy, says Charles L. Schultze, director of the economic studies program at the Brookings Institution, would lead to lower interest rates, more national savings, greater investment and productivity and, as a result, a much higher living standard for all Americans.
There is little doubt where the American public stands. A New York Times/CBS News poll last month found that 62 percent of Americans, representing a large majority of every demographic and geographic group, would spend the money ''to fight problems such as drugs and homelessness.'' Twenty-one percent would reduce the deficit, 10 percent would cut taxes and the rest had some other answer or no answer at all. But the public may be disappointed. Much of the Pengaton's money for the next several years has already been obligated. Some long-term savings like closing military bases, ending weapons contracts and relocating troops from abroad may actually require additional outlays at first. Lawmakers who want to cut the military budget in the abstract may find it difficult to do so when bases and factories in their states and districts are threatened.
Moreover, history has shown that peace dividends do not stretch as far as might be thought. From 1968, at the height of spending on the Vietnam War, to 1976, the military budget fell, in 1990 dollars, from $302 billion to $195 billion. Without a plan or much public debate, most of the money went to increased Social Security and Medicare payments, and the public hardly noticed it.
Because the economy has grown so much in the ensuing years, the peace dividend this time will be a much smaller fraction of the gross national product than it was after Vietnam.
Isabel V. Sawhill, a scholar at the Urban Institute, does not agree with President Bush that a peace dividend may not materialize, but she cautions against over-enthusiasm.
''Real defense spending is almost surely on a downward path,'' she said, ''but it's unlikely to solve most of our problems.''

GRAPHIC: Drawing; graph of military budget projections before and after the outbreak of peace in late 1989, 1991-95 (Source: Congressional Budget Office)

LENGTH: 503 words

HEADLINE: More Hype Than HOPE

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's new housing initiative, announced with great ballyhoo by the President and Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, certainly has a ring to it. HOPE, it's called, the last word in inspirational acronyms: Homeownership and Opportunity for People Everywhere, a package filled with promising programs.
But hype aside, the numbers don't add up to much. Except for a new focus on converting public housing to tenant ownership and a small but genuine effort to address the homeless problem, HOPE is mainly a menu of familiar strategies. Like the rest of the President's domestic program, HOPE is long on talk and short on money. 
The most troubling aspect of this housing strategy is what H.U.D. has not proposed: a national housing policy concentrating on those who most need help. Nearly 11 million low-income households that receive no public housing assistance need help. The proposed $23.7 billion H.U.D. budget will not go very far toward helping them.
There's no funding at all for new public housing, no substantial effort to encourage private industry to build low-income housing. HOPE's centerpiece is a plan to help people already in publicly assisted housing buy their apartments.
H.U.D. officials acknowledge they'll have to use even this program judiciously. Tenants in public housing who buy their homes and apartments will at some point lose the Federal subsidies that now allow them to pay only 30 percent of their incomes for rent. There's another problem with tenant ownership. Successful public housing projects include a mix of people, ranging from very poor and troubled people to stable families. Once Government moves out, the new tenant owners are understandably likely to keep out ''undesirables'' - often precisely the most troubled and most needy.
The HOPE conversion proposal is a welcome tool to help save some troubled housing projects. But tenant ownership is no substitute for a real housing policy. The programs aren't there, and neither is the money.
Consider total H.U.D. spending. It includes $7.7 billion in existing subsidies that are expiring and have to be renewed. If that's taken into account, along with inflation, H.U.D.'s request for the next fiscal year is actually down a bit from 1990. It cuts several programs and proposes that 82,000 new households get public housing assistance, compared with the 109,000 requested last year.
HOPE itself carries very little new funding, despite H.U.D. news releases. It borrows from other programs, one reason for the cuts. If America is to have a true housing policy, there are three approaches:
The Federal Government can build public housing the way it used to, unpopular but still generally successful. It can provide more vouchers and certificates to poorer people to help them afford rents where vacant housing is available. And it can provide long-term, high-rate incentives to encourage banks to underwrite housing development.
The pretty, mostly empty package called HOPE provides none of the above.

HEADLINE: Painless Way to Cut Social Security Deductions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Congressional reactions to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security tax have centered on how to replenish the payroll tax revenue being counted toward deficit reductions under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act. Neither raising other taxes (income or gasoline) nor cutting spending (defense or nondefense) is acceptable to many, as evidenced in your report on the Senate Finance Committee confrontation between Senator Moynihan and Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director (news article, Feb. 9).
There is another option, but it depends on a willingness to see the relationship of the Treasury to Social Security reserves as it really is, not in a distorted view as dishonesty or fraud. Reserves in the Social Security trust funds are by law required to be invested in United States Government bonds. So the Treasury quite legitimately is using the funds thus borrowed to defray expenses and is paying interest on these bonds. This is neither thievery nor embezzlement. What may make it appear so is that annual additions to the Social Security reserves count toward deficit reductions, thereby making the budget deficit look smaller than it is. 
The real problem with the Treasury's borrowing from Social Security is that it is borrowing from, in a manner of speaking, the wrong people -bluntly put, it forces low- and middle-income wage earners, including the working poor, to lend to the Government. This interpretation inspires the following suggestion.
Instead of raising additional income taxes, the Government could issue interest-bearing bonds to people who would otherwise have to pay more income tax if Congress chose that option. This would force the right people to lend to the Government. Let's call them ''income-tax bonds,'' carrying maturities of five to seven years, which would be staggered to avoid bunching repayment. The interest rate would be the average of United States Government securities, the same rate paid on the Government bonds in which the Social Security trust funds invest. This could be an acceptable alternative.
 
YUNG-PING CHEN
 Boston, Feb. 14, 1990
 
The writer holds the Frank J. Manning chair in gerontology at the University of Massachusetts.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 527 words

HEADLINE: Painless Way to Cut Social Security Deductions;
Saving the System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
My friends Henry J. Aaron and Charles L. Schultze, senior fellows at the Brookings Institution, correctly reject Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to suspend the Social Security increase in payroll taxes (Op-Ed, Jan. 18). They do so because repeal would add to the overall deficit when increased saving and investment are needed for economic growth. They propose that the repeal be matched by an increase in other taxes. This would reduce reliance on the regressive payroll tax without adding to the deficit. It would also stop the phony use of Social Security surplus to camouflage the budget deficit. 
True enough, but as they note, their plan would also move Social Security fully toward pay as you go. As I see it, this would threaten its future as a contributory plan, which the 1983 reform, of which Senator Moynihan was a sponsor, was designed to avoid. It was realized then that, because of an aging population, future benefits would exceed contributions, requiring a sharp increase in payroll taxes later.
Such a pay-as-you-go approach would be unfair and politically untenable, undermining the stability of the system. A set of earlier and more modest tax increases was scheduled, permitting buildup of a reserve. The reserve was to be invested in outstanding United States securities, reducing the volume of debt held by the public. But instead, the Social Security account surplus is used as an excuse not to reduce the deficit in the regular budget, permitting the Budget Limitation Act to be met painlessly.
This is a sham. But the remedy is not to scuttle the 1983 reform. Social Security as a contributory system is sound, and the payroll tax, though regressive, should not be viewed in isolation. The benefit side of the system must also be considered, and its net effect is to favor lower incomes.
Instead, the following three steps should be taken:
(1) The Social Security surplus should be separated entirely from Government debt and invested in capital assets, whether fee-yielding public investments in infrastructure or by providing capital to the private sector.
(2) The Social Security system should truly be taken out of the budget, so that it can no longer be used to camouflage the deficit.
(3) Steps should be taken to balance the regular budget. Pending the emergence of a peace dividend, this may be done by raising the first-bracket rate of income tax to 16 percent and the top bracket to 33 percent.
This package will preserve Social Security, while stopping abuse of its surplus. By adding to revenue, it will also permit reversal of the misguided easy fiscal-tight money policy that has plagued us for years. Threatening reduction in the payroll tax to prevent reinstatement of the capital-gains preference might be a clever political move; but if both were enacted, damage to the Social Security system would be compounded by dropping a key component of the 1986 tax reform.
 
RICHARD A. MUSGRAVE
 Santa Cruz, Calif., Jan. 26, 1990
 
The writer, H. H. Burbank Professor of Political Economy emeritus at Harvard University, is a University of California adjunct professor.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
China Gulag Inc.

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Here is some important legal and business information for Americans importing goods from China or investing in Chinese factories or mines:
The chances are high that you are breaking the law of the United States.
Specifically, Chapter 19, Section 1307 of the United States Code. It is entitled ''Convict Made Goods; Importation Prohibited'' and reads as follows:
''All goods, wares, articles and merchandise mined, produced or manufactured wholly or in part in any foreign country by convict labor or/and forced labor or/and indentured labor under penal sanctions shall not be entitled to entry at any of the ports of the United States, and the importation thereof is hereby prohibited.''
The Chinese Government is not only the largest user of forced labor in world history, but its Communist economy is heavily dependent on it. Thousands of camps scattered around the country, millions of forced laborers, perhaps more than 20 million at this moment. 
Many labor camps are specifically set up and organized to manufacture goods for export. Specialists on Chinese commerce have no doubt that slave-labor products and raw material reach the United States market.
So far the United States has chosen to ignore the import ban. But here is another business note for Americans in the China trade: The Congress of the United States is likely to try to change that this year.
The full Congressional spotlight will focus on the Chinese gulag for the first time - a Government report due about May 1, hearings, investigations, legislative action.
Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, is organizing the Congressional battle to expose the convict labor system that underlies so much of the Chinese Communist economy. He will be joined by other Republicans and Democrats, conservative and liberal, in what will be another bipartisan effort to fight the Bush Administration's policy of appeasing Beijing.
In the Senate and then in the House of Representatives, legislation will be introduced to enforce the law and impose real penalties - fines, seizure of goods and treble damages.
The plan also is to give organizations like labor unions and business associations the legal right to sue against forced-labor imports. Currently that right is limited to companies damaged by the import of forced-labor merchandise. There will be a legislative effort to write regulations against American investment in enterprises using forced labor. Forced labor has been essential to the Chinese Communist economy for 40 years, although the world carefully looked away. The regime has said so openly in the law of the land: ''Production from reform-through-labor shall become a part of the overall plan for the reconstruction of the nation's production capabilities.''
The same law also states: ''Plans for the distribution and coordination of the labor of criminals will be based on the number of criminals in each area and on the needs of production and the reconstruction of the nation.''
The Chinese millions being ''reformed'' by being forced to work unpaid for the profit of the Communist system include those deemed ordinary criminals.
In China, conviction is a formality after arraignment. Not-guilty pleas are an insult to the state.
Political prisoners are also used in forced labor. Now, once again, that can be anybody the Government wants to put away. Other millions are ordered into ''job placement camps'' when spot needs develop - large-scale impressment gangs.
The factories are not merely ancillary to the camps. The contrary. Around China, prisons are established in or near factories specifically designed economically and physically to depend on forced labor.
The slave-labor factories and mines produce textiles, chemicals, iron, coal, tools, machinery, consumer goods and other Chinese exports.
The Bush Administration is expected to try to block legislative action, veto it or cripple it by demanding power for the President to waive enforcement.
And some American businesses that trade in the sweat of slave labor will lobby against the ban, arguing that the Chinese people will be hurt.
That argument could be countered easily: banning imports from slave-labor plants and dollar exports to them would open jobs in the non-prison economy.
But do we really have to debate? Even arguing the point seems like pandering to hard-core hypocrisy. The ban is American law. It remains only to enforce it - sorrowfully past time.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

PUB-DATE: February 18, 1990

SECTION: Section 5; Page 19, Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2603 words

HEADLINE: China After Tiananmen Square

BYLINE: By CAROL KRAMER; CAROL KRAMER is an editor of 7 Days, a New York weekly.

 BODY:
WHO would be the first to mention Tiananmen Square, I wondered as I embarked on a 12-day tour of China in December with 33 other Americans - one of the first large tourist groups back in China since the events of last June 4. The speculation was incredibly naive.
One can barely get through customs before a Chinese guide or hotel clerk says something about what is variously referred to as ''the incident,'' the ''events'' or ''the turmoil'' that caused American tourism to drop 80 percent almost immediately.
The American tourist is a prized commodity in China today, lured by lower prices (my tour with Orient Flexi-Pax, for instance, cost about half what it would have pre-Tiananmen Square), red-carpet treatment, sumptuous hotel rooms and everywhere and always, empassioned entreaties to end the tourist embargo.
The pleas can be ironic: ''You see, the situation is much better here than in Romania,'' one guide joked. Or they can be heartbreaking: Toward the end of a cruise down the Li River to see the striking stone forest landscape created by rock formations around Guilin, I sat down at a table where a young Chinese woman was humming an American tune. She didn't know what it was. ''It's 'Edelweiss' from 'The Sound of Music,' '' I told her. It was the strain that goes, ''Bless my homeland forever.'' 
She asked me why so many Americans were staying away from China. I explained that they were afraid. She understood that. Then I tried to explain that many Americans also feel that visiting China might be politically incorrect, construed as acceptance of what happened in June. That was a concept she couldn't understand at all. ''Yes, but not coming will only hurt the people. You will tell people it's all right to come, yes?'' she said, tears in her eyes.
Touring China today is like riding a roller coaster. There are breathless highs and stomach-wrenching lows. One minute you're listening in shock to your guide's description of the monthlong ''re-education'' he went through last summer because his brother was one of the student radicals. The next moment you're laughing at a Jimmy Hoffa joke another guide is cracking in flawless American idiom. You enjoy a couple of glasses of wine at your hotel one night, only to learn the next day that they cost you the equivalent of one month's salary in China.
This is not to say that traveling in China is uncomfortable - for the psyche or anything else. Except for a few guards at Tiananmen Square, the soldiers have been off the streets for two months. We were there just before martial law was lifted but saw no signs of it - with one possible exception. Friends tell me that before, you couldn't walk down the street without people trying to practice their English on you. On three walks - in Guilin, Beijing and Shanghai - I encountered very few Chinese wanting to chat.
Still, my group - which included teen-agers, teachers, businessmen, a radiologist from South Africa now living in Houston, a dentist from Minsk now living in New Jersey and a plumber from Brookline, Mass., who managed to carry a carton of Budweiser along with him to the Great Wall - agreed that it was the best tour they had ever taken. Even this travel snob, on her first group tour, had few complaints.
The China International Travel Service (CITS) supervised our visit to the top tourist cities - Beijing, Shanghai, Guilin and Xian - with military precision. We were like guests at a Chinese banquet, sampling a little of this, a little of that. The Great Wall, then a Friendship Store for souvenirs. A visit to a township (formerly commune) sandwiched between the Reed Flute Cave and the oldest banyan tree in Guilin. Superficial, yes, but this was not a trip for China scholars. It was calculated to give maximum photography and shopping opportunities. My chief complaint: the obligatory stops at factories and outlet stores. But our group, said Wendy, the national guide who accompanied us everywhere, bought more stuff than any other group she had ever escorted - and she appreciated what we had done for the economy.
Since my return, these are the questions everyone has asked:
 
What about Tiananmen Square?
Before June, Tiananmen Square was just one more stop in a dizzying schedule. Today, it's the No. 1 tourist site in China, according to Flexi-Pax. And so it was with us, the place we kept thinking about throughout the tour, and finally, on New Year's Eve, we saw it.
Wendy had told us on the first day of the trip that we could walk freely anyplace in China, except for the square. When we arrived there, at dusk, only four armed guards were stationed in the 100-acre square. Silently, Chinese biked along the street, staring at the group of Americans frantically taking pictures. Wendy had to talk the guards into letting us into the square, and they did so only after looking at some passports, even though she had previously obtained official permission to bring us there. It was the only time we felt frightened in China - and the first time we had felt ashamed. It was like walking on someone's grave. For once, Wendy had no trouble shepherding us back to the bus.
 
What did the Chinese say?
A lot, surprisingly. The guides are obviously trained to skirt difficult questions. When someone asked Wendy whether democracy would ever come to China, she quickly said, ''To me, democracy is too abstract to discuss.'' But the guides were forthcoming about most subjects. A quick-witted English literature major who loves Thomas Hardy and Jane Austen, Wendy could describe economic reforms, the Cultural Revolution and Chiang Kai-shek's theft of treasures from the Forbidden City competently and reasonably. As the tour went on and the group bonded, the guides became more open.
Soon after the news of the Ceausescu execution, a guide said, ''The big fishes here are worried. But we'd never shoot Deng. We appreciate what he did for the economy.'' And in Beijing, when the group made what seemed to me the 72d stop at a Friendship Store, a guide pulled me aside and pointed out the overpass ''where the students tried to stop the tanks,'' a few blocks away. I walked over, but there was nothing left but memories from the nightly news.
A young man we encountered said democracy would come ''when all the old men are gone,'' and one of our guides expressed the same thought. When we drove by a huge billboard in Beijing and asked what it said, our guide said with great sarcasm, ''Oh, it says only the socialists can save China.''
 
What did you see?
In Guilin, the scenery; in Shanghai, remnants of the colonial past; in Xian, the phenomenal 2,000-year-old terra-cotta warriors guarding the tomb of Emperor Qin Shi Huang Di, and in Beijing, just what you'd expect - the Forbidden City and other familiar sights scattered around a generic big city that could be plopped down anywhere in the world. However, in China, the expected, like the Great Wall, always turns out to be unexpected.
And of course, we saw a good portion of China's millions of bikes (six million in Beijing alone) and one billion people - some driving water-buffalo-powered tractors, some shopping for hair dryers, radios, televisions and Christian Dior cosmetics.
Some of the stops seemed too well orchestrated - for instance, the visit to what is supposedly a typical farmer's home in Guilin. Dirty underwear was left on a chair in the living room, and the bottles on the sink were so dusty the place looked as though no one had occupied it for years. And if someone did live there, where were they and what on earth were we doing snooping around?
What was most noticeable, perhaps, in Guilin and Shanghai was the cold. Beijing, it seems, has decreed that it doesn't get cold south of the Yangtze River, so even when the thermometer reaches, say, 35 degrees, no heat is provided. Some children in the school we visited were playing the violin with coats on. And the Chuanshan township we visited was bone-chilling, especially the clinic, where a husky nurse gave us mini-back rubs to encourage us to buy a bottle of Zhanjian medicinal oil. She swore it would prevent us from catching cold in China.
 
How was the food?
What was the most memorable moment of the tour, I asked the group on our last night in China, at a banquet at the Hui Feng Tan restaurant in Beijing, where we were eating a gelatinous stew of pigs' feet and mushrooms; stir-fried, shredded pig's stomach, and other delicacies before they brought on the Peking duck. ''Breakfast at the Shanghai Hilton,'' responded Carolyn, a Southerner. She was only half joking. Breakfast in Shanghai typified the kind of luxury the Chinese are willing to stake tourists to in 1990.
To get to the Hilton's coffee shop, we'd had to cross a moat in the huge marble lobby. Students from the Shanghai Conservatory were playing Mozart on a balcony, and as in every hotel we visited, the staff seemed to outnumber the guests. (At the Hilton, probably Shanghai's grandest hotel, occupancy has gone from 85 percent to 20 percent since June.) There were pancakes, waffles with blueberries, eggs Benedict, quiche, bacon, sausage, mountains of pastries and muffins and a vast array of fresh fruits, including kumquats and litchis.
All our breakfasts in China were Western style, and usually consisted of an enormous buffet. The Chinese meals ranged from execrable in the country - where we might encounter lard-saturated stir-fries served on chipped, dirty plates - to quite sophisticated fare in Beijing and Shanghai.
Most meals started with cold appetizers, which we would select from a Lazy Susan. Ham, pickled cabbage, peanuts, pickles and hard-boiled eggs were the usual choices. Then the kitchen would send out hot platters of food - stir-fries with pork and chicken; pieces of roast chicken, duck or turkey; bean curd in hot sauce, and always plates of stir-fried greens, usually bok choy. Also accompanying most meals were a dish of scrambled eggs and tomatoes, and french fries - probably a concession to Western tastes. And most ended with a steamed fish, usually carp, and hot soup. Rice, to the annoyance of many, usually appeared at the end of the meal, and according to one hotel official, it wasn't of the same high quality you get in Hong Kong: ''The first-grade rice is exported.''
With every meal came vast quantities of the local beer and orange soda. The beer was good but got monotonous, as did the food by the end of the trip. Some people ordered Cokes or mineral water, and some of us tried the Western-inspired wines of China. Named Great Wall, Dynasty and Calvin, they are medium-dry and taste like a good California chenin blanc (if California made a good chenin blanc).
 
How were the hotels?
A few years ago, we were told, natives weren't allowed in the tourist hotels. Today, if they have the money they are, though we rarely encountered any in the marble-and-crystal palaces where we stayed.
The Hilton is in the area that was the French concession in the 1930's, and except for the laundry hanging out of every window, the area looks like it was airlifted out of Lyons. With nine kitchens, including a chocolate kitchen and a charcuterie, the Hilton is an enclave of affluence. All bathroom fixtures are marble, rooms are big enough to hold a ball in and the service is almost disturbingly obsequious. A hotel executive explained it was because ''we're able to fire.'' At most hotels in China, employers are not allowed to fire or promote, making it difficult to persuade staff to encourage people to buy a souvenir or have another cup of coffee.
The Shangri-La in Beijing is another example of near decorating overkill. The Holiday Inn in Guilin and the Golden Flower in Xian were less ornate but well equipped and comfortable.
 
How was the flight?
Ever since the Chinese went into tourism in a big way, opening Western-style hotels and training first-rate English-speaking guides, visiting China has not had the sort of Indiana Jones air of adventure it used to have. And so, I think, someone decided to maintain the pioneer spirit with the service on Air China.
The airport in Guilin looks like it stepped out of a 1935 Warner Brothers movie. The temporary domestic terminal in Shanghai looks even older and more decrepit, with hand-lettered signs announcing that smokers will be arrested. Our planes, except for one very dilapidated Boeing 737, were Russian Tupalovs. When you sat down, your seat slid out from under you, which was only a problem if you were in one of the few seats with working seat belts. Overhead compartments were wide open; on one flight the toilet burst, and the contents had spread to the middle of the plane by the time we landed.
Were we scared? Only when we were told we might be delayed going into and out of Xian because of the fog and discovered that there was no radar. The morning we left, the fog kept us on the ground for four hours. Fortunately, the waiting room had seats - a luxury in China - and four of us played bridge while the Chinese around us kibitzed.
All our flights, though, were smooth, uneventful (except for the lavatory explosion) and pleasant. The stewardesses served tea and box lunches of filled buns, a piece of cold chicken and chocolate bars.
 
What are the people like?
Since our stay was brief and most of our contact with the Chinese was pro forma, it would be foolish to pontificate on what people in China are like or what they think.
Peddlers, who descend on tourist groups like swarms of locusts, constituted most of our contacts with the populace. But it was clear that our guides - all city people - were disdainful of these hard-working entrepreneurs who would cheat us out of a dollar or two whenever they could. ''Don't pay more than 20 yuan for a large jacket,'' we were warned as we got off the bus in Xian. ''And get the merchandise in your hand before you pay.'' Okay, so I didn't and someone sold me a quilt with embroidery on just one side. I admired her spirit.
And so what if our visit to a Shanghai children's palace (an after-school activity group for gifted children) was shamefully manipulative, guaranteed to trick Americans, a cynic might say, into feelings of universal friendship. It worked.
The children assigned to greet us spoke perfect English. If they had been directed to hold our hands and sit on our laps, then they did it well. We went from classroom to classroom where children were waiting to perform. In one room an accordion band played the ''Clarinet Polka,'' and even now this former accordion player gets teary-eyed remembering. In other rooms, they played ''Yankee Doodle Dandy'' on the violin and sang ''It's a Small World'' in Chinese. As we left the building, a little boy ran up to one of the women and said, ''Please give my love to your children in America.'' Wendy and the local guide poured a bunch of emotionally exhausted tourists onto the bus for the trip back to the Hilton.
Our last night in China was similarly wrenching. Wendy gave a speech thanking us for our visit and beseeching us to ''tell everybody China is a beautiful country and if they don't come I'll lose my job.'' Her boss at CITS also spoke, thanking us for coming ''after the June 4 incident.'' Somehow, I was drafted to give the group's farewell speech, and fortified by a few glasses of Great Wall, I did. But I don't remember a word of it.
 
Orient Flexi-Pax (630 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017, telephone 212-692-9550 or 800-545-5540) offers 10- to 21-day all-inclusive tours of China, some with Hong Kong segments, costing from $1,499 to $3,499.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Orlando

BYLINE: By TODD WOODY; TODD WOODY is a reporter for The Palm Beach Post.

 BODY:
If Orlando had not existed before Walt Disney World, those who built the central Florida entertainment empire would probably have had to invent the city. With 32,000 workers and more than 23 million annual visitors, Disney World relies on Orlando and surrounding communities to house its employees and administer the airport that is the gateway to its three theme parks: the Magic Kingdom, Epcot Center and Disney-MGM Studios.
Although only 19 years have passed since the opening of Disney World, few recall life before Mickey Mouse. In effect, the Mouse (or other evocations of Walt Disney) is everywhere - on road signs, at information booths at Orlando International Airport, on advertisements for the official Disney airline, the official Disney cruise line and the official Disney car rental company.
There is more to come: a fourth Disney theme park; the 1,500-room Dolphin Hotel, which will be Florida's largest hotel; 29 more attractions at the three existing theme parks and doubling the size of the movie theme park. 
While it is possible to spend one's entire vacation in Disney World, many other attractions beckon, from Sea World and the Kennedy Space Center to Orlando's quiet and leafy downtown.
 
What's New
The most talked-about attraction is the Star Tours ride at Disney-MGM Studios. Based on the ''Star Wars'' trilogy, Star Tours takes visitors on a journey to the Moon of Endor. The trip begins with a visit to the Village of the Ewoks, populated by overgrown teddy bear-like creatures. Robots R2-D2 and C-3PO are on hand before visitors enter a 40-passenger flight simulator designed as a Star Speeder spaceship.
While passengers watch a large screen, the Star Speeder rocks and rolls as it maneuvers through an asteroid shower. After a dogfight with the Empire's fighter ships, passengers survive a showdown with Darth Vader's Death Star.
Visitors can take a journey through inner space at Epcot's Wonders of Life pavilion. In Body Wars, visitors board a flight simulator and take a trip through the human bloodstream. When their human host becomes ill, the ship goes on a rescue mission. On the way to the brain, the ship is buffeted by the beating heart and endures gale-force winds in the lungs.
Disney has tried to lure young adults by adding the Pleasure Island complex of seven nightclubs, six restaurants and a 10-screen movie theater.
A one-day, one-park ticket is $31, $25 for ages 3 to 9. Children under 3 free. A four-day pass is $100, $80 for children 3 to 9. A five-day pass is $117, $95 for children 3 to 9.
 
A Rival Park
In a community dominated by Disney and where the opening of a new entertainment complex ranks as a major civic event, the opening this coming May of Universal Studios Florida has been a major topic of conversation in Orlando.
Built to rival the Disney-MGM Studios Theme Park, Universal's $600 million, 444-acre park will have movie and TV production facilities surrounded by attractions. Universal has retained Steven Spielberg as a creative consultant (Disney has George Lucas) and has based some of the attractions on ''E.T.'' and other Spielberg movies.
Universal will try to out-Disney Disney with rides like King Kong Kongfrontation and Earthquake - the Big One. In Kong, visitors will ride a tram through a set as life-size helicopters buzz a 30-foot-tall ape. When King Kong takes a swipe at the tram, the cars (connected to cables) fall 20 feet.
Universal calls its Florida studios the largest movie and TV complex outside of Hollywood and promises visitors a look at the movie-making process. In the ''Murder, She Wrote'' Post-Production Theater, visitors become executive producers and choose the guest star, plot and special effects for an episode of the TV series.
Like Disney, Universal's park will also have roving cartoon characters, souvenir shops and restaurants.
Universal Studios Florida (407-363-8000) is 10 miles southwest of Orlando (about 30 minutes from the airport) at the intersection of Interstate 4 and Florida's Turnpike. A one-day ticket will be $29, $23 for children 3 to 11. Free for children under 3. A two-day pass will be $49, $39 for children.
 
Coming Events
Performers from the Royal Danish Ballet and the Southern Ballet Theater will present an ''International Evening of Dance'' next Friday and Saturday at the Bob Carr Performing Arts Center (407-849-2020) at 401 West Livingston Street, Orlando. Tickets: $10 to $24.
The three-day Kissimmee Blue Grass Festival begins March 2 at the Silver Spurs Rodeo Arena (407-896-6641) on U.S. 192, about six miles east of Kissimmee. Admission is $25 for a three-day pass, $15 for Friday only, $12 for Saturday only and $12 for Sunday only.
From March 16 to 18 the annual Winter Park Arts Festival (407-644-8281) will be held from 9 A.M. to dusk in Central Park between New York and Park avenues in Orlando. The festival attracts artists from across the Southeast United States.
''Footsteps,'' an exhibit from the Israeli Museum of the Diaspora, will make its American debut on April 2 and continue to June 2 at the Historical Museum of Orange County (407-898-8320) at 812 Rollins Street, Orlando. The exhibit on Jewish immigration from 1640 to 1870 focuses on several American communities, including Savannah, Ga. The entry fee is $2, $1 for children.
Arts in April is a month-long festival held throughout the Orlando area. On April 1 at 3 P.M., the soprano Faith Esham will offer a program of classical and semiclassical works at the Bob Carr Performing Arts Center. Tickets: $10, $20 and $25. A list of Arts in April events is available by calling 407-420-2150 after March 20 or the Orlando Mayor's Office (407-849-2221) before then.
 
What to See
Sea World (407-351-3600) at Interstate 4 and the Beeline Highway offers whales, dolphins, sharks and other marine animals in a variety of shows and exhibits. Open every day from 9 A.M. to 8 P.M.; entry fee: $25.40, $21.15 for children 3 to 9. Children under 3 free.
About 40 miles from Orlando, Space Port U.S.A. (407-452-2121) offers a two-hour bus tour of the Kennedy Space Center and Cape Canaveral Air Force Station on Merritt Island. Beginning at Spaceport U.S.A., the tour stops at the space shuttle and moon launch site and the 525-foot-high Vehicle Assembly Building. Open 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. First bus tour leaves at 9:45 A.M., the last one at 3:30 P.M. Entry fee: $4, $1.75 for ages 3 to 12. Take the Beeline Highway in Orlando east to Kennedy Space Center.
For a break from the manufactured fun of Disney World, downtown Orlando offers an oasis of lakes and tree-shaded avenues. Visitors can stroll around Lake Eola Park or peddle across the lake in swan-shaped paddle boats ($5.30 for 30 minutes).
The Leu Botanical Gardens (407-849-2620) at 1730 North Forest Avenue contains 40 acres of camellias, ancient oaks and subtropical and tropical plants and flowers on the former estate of the industrialist Harry P. Leu. Open every day from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $3.
Once the winter home of wealthy Northeasterners, the town of Winter Park has retained a small-town atmosphere. A few miles north of Orlando off I-4, Winter Park is known for graceful estates along Lake Virginia. Park Avenue, a four-block shopping district lined with palm trees, has boutiques, specialty stores and cafes across from Central Park.
The Morse Museum of American Art (407-644-3686) at 133 East Welbourne Avenue, Winter Park, has one of the country's largest collections of Tiffany stained glass. The museum is open from 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M., Tuesday to Saturday and 1 to 4 P.M. on Sunday. Admission: $2.50, $1 for children and students.
 
Where to Stay
For visitors planning to spend most of their time at Disney World, there are several hotels in the complex.
The Swan, a 758-room luxury hotel designed by Michael Graves, offers rooms for two ranging from $185 to $285. Opened in January, the Swan is in the new Epcot Resort Area and is connected to Epcot Center by tram and a boardwalk. A boat ferries guests to Disney-MGM Studios.
The Contemporary Resort near the Magic Kingdom has rooms for two at $160 to $230. The budget-priced Caribbean Beach Resort is connected by bus to Epcot Center and Disney-MGM Studios. Rooms for two: $69 to $99. (Call 407-934-7639 for reservations at all Disney World hotels.) Outside the Disney complex, the luxury Hyatt Grand Cypress (800-228-9000) at 1 Cypress Boulevard, Orlando, charges $160 to $225 for two.
Budget choice: Travelodge (800-225-3050), where rates for two start at $41 and range up to $78, depending on proximity to Disney World, the day of the week and the month.
 
Where to Eat
Victoria and Albert's in Disney World's Grand Floridian hotel (407-824-2383) offers a fixed-price dinner of Continental cuisine and seafood for $65 a person, not including wine or drinks. The dinner includes a choice of three appetizers, two soups and salads, an entree and after-dinner cheeses and ports. The restaurant specializes in souffle desserts.
There are two or three sittings in the dining room, which has a hand-painted domed ceiling and a harpist. Reservations required.
Another popular Disney restaurant is the Louis XV-style Empress Room (407-828-3900) on the Empress Lilly river boat in Disney Village Market Place. Chilled avocado soup, mushroom salad and Dover sole are featured. Dinner for two with wine: about $130. Reservations required.
The Epcot Center World Showcase offers more economical dining with entrees starting at $10 at half a dozen restaurants. Each offers a different cuisine, including Italian, Chinese, British and Indian.
Outside Disney World, Montezinos (407-841-6668) at 800 North Magnolia Avenue in Orlando is a local favorite. The restaurant serves Italian and Continental cuisine in two dining rooms. Dinner for two with wine in the Gourmet Room: about $90; in the regular dining room, $70. The menu features grilled salmon with caviar champagne sauce and other seafood specialties. Reservations recommended.
The Park Plaza Gardens Restaurant (407-645-2475) at 319 South Park Avenue in Winter Park offers fresh seafood and Continental cuisine. Dinner for two with wine: about $60. Budget choice: Pebbles (407-827-1111) at 12551 State Road 535 in the Crossroads Shopping Village in Lake Buena Vista, known for its thumb bits, an appetizer of broiled beef marinated in a garlic sauce. Other specialties: breast of duck, seafood and pasta. Dinner for two with wine: about $25.

HEADLINE: On Language;
If You Will

BYLINE: BY WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
The National - our first all-sports daily newspaper distributed nationwide - was launched last month by the ace sportswriter Frank Deford. It appears to be a literate publication; one headline in its first issue over a story about the New York Knicks basketball center Patrick Ewing was ''The Center Is Holding,'' an allusion to William Butler Yeats's poem ''The Center Cannot Hold.''
William Henry 3d, a classy writer who runs the section proudly labeled ''Press'' in Time magazine (others lump the print and electronic media together under media, but who ever heard of a ''full court media''?) posed this question in his coverage of the launch: Will the public support an all-sports daily? Time concluded that ''the National is hard to assess because it is unprecedented - one might say, a whole new ball game.''
Now we're into a whole nother problem: parrhesia, accent on the reezh, the Greek word for ''speaking boldly of something obnoxious,'' which can be stretched into a a second sense of ''excuse the joke.'' 
This preemptive apology, one might say, is a rhetorical balk. It says to the reader: ''Look, I'm going to do something egregiously pun-related, or outrageously metaphor-extending or simile-provoking, and you mustn't hold it against me - but for God's sake, notice it.''
Some speakers self-conscious about humor, or worried that their audience will miss their hard-earned easy wit, use the internal flag at the conclusion of the thigh-scratcher, like the Fred Allen Senator who would add ''That's a joke, son.''
The most familiar I-was-being-funny phrase is so to speak. This Britishism, originally meaning ''in the vernacular'' or indigenous dialect, was an aristocrat's apology for stooping to colorful downstairs language. In the United. States, it remains a staple of academics who get a kick out of pitching their lectures to classy listeners, so to speak. Another form of this elitist elocution, sometimes used self-mockingly, is as they say, ''they'' being the less refined types.
Politicians are parrhesiacs, too: Forgive me, but was Ronald Reagan's favorite way of sugar-coating some seemingly outrageous pill. This is a variation of you will permit me, or if you will forgive the pun, often shortened to if you will and put at the end. Some writers are shy not only about making a funny, but also about appearing to be too literate or la-te-da in their apology aforethought. These cringing comedians pretend to be speaking in their writing, and use a transcribed articulated schwa - er or uh - as in ''Some football commentators use language that, er, really came to play.'' Show off or shut up. Make your joke, or dazzle us with your double meaning, or skip rope on a trope without shyness or deprecation; spare us that twisting of the toe in the dirt that whispers ''I know this is awful,'' or digs us in the ribs and asks ''Get it?''
Wordplay is not foreplay; it may cause a groan or two, but won't provoke a passionate response. Man the ramparts of repartee with stout heart, perservere in your persiflage without shame - it's all good badinage, as it were.
Budget Brightness
''Just toss them a metaphor and cycical journalists go weak-kneed,'' wrote Michael Kinsley in The Washington Post. He was complaining about the attention given to the ordinarily stupefying ''Budget of the United States Government'' because Director Richard Darman enlivened the hefty tome with a personal introduction comparing the general perception of the Budget to the Cookie Monster on Public Television's ''Sesame Street.''
I enjoy bright writing in unexpected places and salute Mr. Darman for slipping some wake-up prose into the torpid, tumid, turgid world of governmentese.
The last time this happened at O.M.B. was in Cap Weinberger's day, when the Budget Director suggested that Nixonian economic projections could become a ''self-fulfilling prophecy.'' When he sent the draft out for comment to a score of departments and agencies, every single one returned the document with that line crossed out: the turn of phrase generated universal horror. Cap the Knife pretended to accept the deletion, sent out eight more re-drafts with the original thought excised, and then slipped it back in just before the budget went to the printer. He knew bureaucratic infighting better than most.
However, Mr. Darman - having dared to be colorful - invites close inspection of prose as well as numbers. Here are a few potshots:
''As all monsters are, Cookie Monster is initially intimidating.'' This is so grammatically correct as to be hopelessly stilted. What's the matter with the natural Like all monsters,? Mr. Darman knows how to do it; later in the document, he writes ''Like education, drug abuse is a problem.'' That's, like, the way, man - no graceful writer would try ''As education is, drug abuse is. . . .''
''The true cost of the previously planned and Congressionally approved defense program is. . . .'' In this explanation of the absense of a peace dividend, Mr. Darman tries to have it both ways on hyphenation. When an adverb ending in ly modifies an adjective before a noun, no hyphen is called for. Previously planned is correct; Congressionally-approved is a mistake.
''Federal investments in the future will only achieve their objectives if they are effectively managed.'' Because this comes in the context of improved returns on investment, I think he means ''In the future, Federal investments will.'' (He could be talking of ''investments in the future'' but that is usually placed in the section under Education.) Worse, the man charged with keeping track of more than $1.3 trillion has misplaced his modifier; he does not mean ''will only achieve,'' because achievement is not to be sneezed at. He means ''will achieve their objectives only if.''
A metaphor (in the case of the Cookie Monster, an analogy) is attention-getting. But in the future, Federal budget messages will achieve their objectives only if they are effectively copy-edited.
Ro, Ro, Ro Your Boat
You think powerful institutions are incapable of drastic change? You think the people are powerless to bring about fundamental reform in entrenched bureaucracies?
Consider this Editors' Note in The New York Times, reprinted here in its entirety:
''The Times today adopts the country name Romania, spelled with an o, in place of Rumania. The o form is preferred by many Romanians as a reflection of their Roman origins and has been favored in recent years by most English-language publications.
''Until now, in using the u, The Times has been guided by its main geographic reference, the Columbia Lippencott Gazetteer of the World. The gazetteer editors apparently believed that u, better than o, conveyed the Romanian pronunciation of the name.
''The gazetteer was revised most recently in 1961, and its publishers have no current plans for a new edition. The Times is shifting now because Romania has become more familiar to Americans than Rumania.''

HEADLINE: About Men;
The Case For Grad School

BYLINE: BY MARK McGURL: Mark McGurl is on the staff of The Times Magazine.

 BODY:
AT LAST IT HAPPENED. Four years of college, one more for good measure - all told a half-decade of great books and gregarious nights and green lawns and girls - and then one day some malignant force somewhere, some vile conspiracy of time and teachers and empty-pocketed parents had the nerve to hand me a diploma. I barely had the chance to read the thing, let alone get it framed, before that very same malignant force picked me up and hurled me, howling, through the air toward life.
I landed in New York City. I bought a few ties, found a cruddy apartment, got a job as a fledgling journalist, and started to pay taxes.
I felt pretty noble, all things considered. I was no longer freeloading, and I got up at a perfectly reasonable hour. I contributed to the gross national product, in a roundabout sort of way. But then I had the misfortune, on successive days, of bumping into two former girlfriends of mine, from whom I learned that getting out of bed in the morning isn't enough. 
Kristin works with the homeless. Every morning, just when my alarm clock is gearing up to give me the bad news, she can already be found on the train into town from a vastly less-expensive outer borough. She spends the day on the phone badgering politicians, or public housing officials, then heads down to street level with her ladle. For her efforts, she makes slightly more money than her clients, and slightly less than I do.
We decide to meet somewhere after work and discuss old times, because this is what ex-boyfriends and ex-girlfriends do. Before you know it we've found ourselves gabbing over coffee, served in suitably humble environs, about our chosen lives. As it turns out, we studiously avoid the past, though of course it's hovering there anyway. I was the one who initiated the breakup. I had handled the whole thing like an idiot. True to form, I'm being an idiot, though a different kind of idiot, right now.
''Kristin, this is just great, what you're doing. I really admire it. I wish I would do something like that.'' ''So why don't you?'' There are certain kinds of social workers who, fighting in the trenches all day, feel no need to apologize for riding the moral high horse. If they have to embarrass you to get you thinking, then so be it (especially if that embarrassment can simultaneously be put to the purposes of a little amorous revenge). Unbeknownst to me, Kristin had become one of these. I squirm, and my tongue stumbles.
''Well, I dunno. . . . I mean, I just never. . . .''
She lets me hang. But then some glimmer, some sliver of compassion for the privileged kicks in, and she takes me down off the rack. She changes the subject.
''How do you like working at that magazine?'' she asks, benignly enough, though I swear I hear a sneering edge to that last word.
''Oh, it's fine, I guess. I'm a nobody. I spend a lot of time at the Xerox machine.'' I'm losing. Losing what I'm not sure, but losing. ''Actually I just did some research on the homeless,'' I say, feebly, clawing at my tie, which suddenly seems absurdly, decadently silky, though I got it on sale. ''That's nice,'' she says. ''My God, I can't believe what I saw today. This guy on the subway was wearing ski boots, these big white plastic ski boots with normal clothes. I guess they were the best he could do for footwear, crazy city, just crazy, jeez. . . .''
She doesn't respond. I can suddenly tell she's sick of me, and every buffoon like me. She's wondering how she could have ever been interested in such a buffoon. In another mood she might be angry. Now she just seems bored. She has to catch her train. I put some money down on the table, ample funds for two coffees, and she quietly pushes half of it back at me, replacing it with her own. We say the usual things about seeing each other again, but this hardly seems likely.
Sheila, on the other hand, works on Wall Street. I have never figured out exactly what it is she does, but she has purchased a pair of wire-rimmed glasses with noncorrective lenses, so she will be taken seriously while she does it. She makes more money than Kristin and I and a few homeless people put together make. We make our date over the phone. She wants to meet at a place called Bice. ''What's that?'' ''Bice. Bee-chay. You know, it's spelled like BISE. It's a restaurant.'' ''Oh. Sure. When?'' There are delays on the subway, and by the time I get there she's already seated in the corner. She has brought her new boyfriend. This friend is a year ahead of her at the same investment bank, though he works in a different division. He is very handsome, and his suit fits him conspicuously well. As I approach the table he is telling her how to get herself involved in the interesting deals. I sit down and eventually the conversation politely turns to me. ''So what do you do?'' asks the friend. I tell him. I leave out the stuff about the Xerox machine.
''Right now I'm doing some research on homelessness for one of our editors,'' I say. ''I do a lot of things like that. It's pretty cool.'' ''Cool,'' he says, flicking something from the lapel of his suit. ''The people I work with are unbelievably smart,'' I say, hoping that this implies that I, too, could be described this way, and that this excuses the strip of slime I have tied around my neck, which I had previously thought was a fairly decent tie. ''Do you make enough to live on?'' asks Sheila, admirably direct. ''I dunno, I guess I do O.K. I mean, it all depends what you consider living.''
Sheila dishes out a smile, at once maternal and bankerly. She's looking exquisite - much, much better than when we were involved. The friend reaches for her hand, squeezes it, then orders me a drink. I am not consoled.
It turns out they're going to Berlin together tomorrow to check out all the revolutionary activity, which is covered with insufficient energy, or so they seem to be suggesting, by magazines like the one I work for. When Sheila and I went out, before that relationship, too, fell by the wayside, we used to watch movies.
When I get back from the bathroom they already have their coats on. I glance at the table and realize that they have paid the check. A voice inside me barks in outrage. I quickly slip my wallet from my pocket and remove a large, imposing bill. I stuff it into the friend's palm with a gesture that brooks no argument. He stares at it as though it were a used Kleenex. ''Please,'' I say. A few minutes later, when I am alone, I hear another voice inside me, of higher pitch this time, let out a long, plaintive yelp. This is the spokesman for my bank account. Humility would have been much cheaper. On the way home from the subway station I used my privacy to quietly bewail my fate to the jagged bits of sky visible between the tops of tall buildings. I felt poor, and grossly overstuffed, all at once. If I had been honest I would have admitted to myself that I had felt similar, contradictory things, even in the idyll of college. But at the time it was easier to blame all the confusion on ''real'' life, as opposed to the collegiate version, and leave it at that.
This interior symphony of whining and moaning was interrupted, just then, by a haggard man stepping from the shadows. He was by no means the first homeless person who had approached me that day; in fact he was probably the 12th, and I quickened my pace a bit to remove myself as quickly as possible from his sphere of need.
''Hey, my man, could you lend me $5,000? My Porsche needs a new transmission.''
This stopped me in my tracks. I turned to him and smiled. ''Yeah, I hate it when that happens.''
I gave him a few dollars, which certainly didn't help him with his Porsche, and probably didn't get him any closer to having a roof over his head, but which he didn't mind taking, and I didn't mind giving, it being late and the real world confusing.
