HEADLINE: MATRONS WITH STICKY FINGERS

BYLINE: By JACK KATZ; Jack Katz, a professor of sociology at the University of California, Los Angeles, is the author of ''Seductions of Crime.''

 BODY:

WHEN LADIES GO A-THIEVING
Middle-Class Shoplifters in the Victorian Department Store.
By Elaine S. Abelson.
Illustrated. 292 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $29.95.
In the late 19th century, the large department store emerged as a new urban spectacle. Macy's in New York, Marshall Field in Chicago and Wanamaker's in Philadelphia displayed clothes against walls and carpets in never-before-seen colors, created miniature electrified theaters in windows, decorated doll-like rooms from top to bottom, occasionally brought in live music and even zoo animals and assembled an unprecedented diversity of goods around wondrous inventions like the escalator. Part of the spectacle was a new social problem: ''ladies'' were frequently caught shoplifting. Journalists went wild when, the day before Christmas in 1870, Macy's arrested five eminently respectable women, including Elizabeth B. Phelps, a rich philanthropist and vice president of the National Woman's Suffrage Association, who was charged with stealing a small package of candy. 
Shoplifting ladies in late-19th-century America posed three interpretive challenges, writes Elaine S. Abelson in ''When Ladies Go A-Thieving,'' which she addresses after research into store archives, 19th-century journalism and academic journals. First, how would scientific opinion of the times understand the shoplifter's motivation? Ms. Abelson, who teaches at the New School for Social Research, documents how metaphors from medicine - shaped by beliefs in uniquely female sources of character weakness - dominated the intellectual discovery of ''kleptomania.'' Middle-class shoplifters could still be ''ladies'' if their deviance could be attributed to puberty and the menstrual cycle, if ''their physiology . . . betrayed them.'' When Freudian thought became popular, scientific explanations were given a psychological turn, and they still show up occasionally in criminology as the suggestion that menopause induces crime. Feminist scholarship now presses us all to wonder why the theorists did not note that the customers as well as the shoplifters were primarily female.
Second, how did store management attack the problem? While only Lord & Taylor completely denied that its customers shoplifted (''a detective's time would be wasted utterly in our store,'' a spokesman told the press in 1883), department store managers, even those who prosecuted offenders, were extremely uncomfortable acknowledging publicly that there was a problem. Ms. Abelson suggests that there was a close connection between management's posture toward middle-class women shoplifters and toward employees. ''There was a poorly veiled assumption that neither group could be trusted.'' Today, stores ubiquitously post promises to prosecute shoplifters; Ms. Abelson's readers may suspect that, although the management posture is now tough, the most significant target is still employee theft.
On a third question - contemporary understanding of shoplifters' motives - Ms. Abelson struggles with limited materials. Today we have sources, from Ladies' Home Journal articles to research monographs, in which female shoplifters vividly recount how, with trembling hands, they inserted forbidden objects into magically alive purses, achieving pleasures they characterize as orgasmic. We also have reports from young shoplifters, male and female, in which they treat the event as an exciting game with tricky maneuvers and passes, time outs to revise strategies in dressing rooms, thrilling runs to the exit and little victory dances after the score. In interviews, amateur shoplifters outline vandals' attraction to defiling public places through attacking rather than acquiring property; often abandoning their booty, they seem less concerned with what they get than with getting away with it.
Ms. Abelson lacks such firsthand data on the process of deviance and imputes to her sneaky ladies the owners' narrowly materialistic focus on the value of merchandise. She opines that middle-class shoplifting emerged from a clash between an aggressive commercialism that stimulated impulse buying and the economic constraints experienced by women who were hard-pressed to demonstrate their family's social status with consumer goods. This does not account for society shoplifters, who knew no such constraints.
Middle-class women in the late 19th century were accustomed to other forms of retail buying. Society women were skilled at eliciting personal recognition and in demanding elaborately deferential personal service at small shops. Women with origins in working-class neighborhoods had frequently bargained over price and quality, employing their street smarts to seize bargains and to avoid being taken in by fraud. Both rich and poor women had been accustomed to emerge from shopping trips not only with things but with tales that spoke of their economic shrewdness and sensitive manipulation of social interaction.
The department store became a retail setting where prices were fixed, service was uniform, money alone counted and the customer, delighting in an elegant, ''modern'' environment, played a relatively passive role. For some customers, shoplifting exploited the act of acquisition for material proofs of personal superiority; it diffusely called upon one's emotions and intellect to beat a system that paradoxically enriched the display of goods while impoverishing the customer's contribution to shopping.

HEADLINE: LEARNING TO BE ITALIAN

BYLINE: By FREDERIKA RANDALL; Frederika Randall is a freelance journalist who lives in Milan, Italy.

 BODY:

WHERE IT ALL BEGAN
Italy 1954.
By Ann Cornelisen.
281 pp. New York:
A William Abrahams Book/E. P. Dutton. $18.95.
Its opening pages seem to suggest that this, Ann Cornelisen's sixth book, will be autobiographical - part of the life story of the person who, in the course of an intense 35-year relationship with Italy, has written such inspired accounts as ''Torregreca: Life, Death, Miracles'' and ''Women of the Shadows.'' But Ms. Cornelisen's easy style and vein of personal reminiscence should not really be mistaken for autobiography or, even more remote, confession. She is a natural storyteller, and the same interest in the lives and circumstances of others, the same economy of emotion that governed her earlier works also provide the structure here. An important (but not the most important) character in ''Where It All Began,'' Ms. Cornelisen is the outsider who measures against her own milder experience the destruction of war, as well as the misery and comic opera of village life in a remote town of the Abruzzi in the mid-1950's. 
When it comes to the personal, ''never apologize, never explain'' might be Ms. Cornelisen's motto. A firm net of discretion (and pride, no doubt) keeps us neatly away from any private satisfactions, any hardships, doubts or second thoughts she may have had while adjusting her American ways to Mediterranean peasant life. Better, she seems to say, to observe the great commedia of everyday life as you find it than indulge in questioning how comfortably you fit into it. Perhaps this is one way in which Ms. Cornelisen is, or has become, more Italian than American.
The place is the town of Ortona, on a bluff along the Adriatic coast of south-central Italy; the year is 1954. The author (age 27, newly divorced, at ease in the middle-class female freedoms of her comfortable Chicago upbringing and her Vassar education) has arrived in Florence with a trunk full of evening dresses and some very good introductions. In Rome, where she is to begin studying archeology, she accepts an invitation to visit Giovanna Guzzeloni Thompson, a young woman who is working for the British Save the Children Fund in the eastern Abruzzi. There Ms. Cornelisen finds an almost medieval society that is still reeling from a traumatic head-on collision with modern civilization.
Apart from enduring the Fascists' rule, which doesn't seem to have had a great impact, the town of Ortona had been the scene of a pitched battle between the retreating Germans and the Allied Eighth Army at the end of 1943. Reduced to open muddy pits and piles of rubble, Ortona was still a bomb site nine years after the end of the war. Driving into town, Ms. Cornelisen sees people leading their lives in two- and three-story houses with the facades blown off, eating and sleeping inside three walls as if on stage. Somewhat later, when she has begun to work for the fund herself, she visits a group of children who live in an abandoned mill at the edge of town. She finds herself ''staring through wide gaps in the floor boards, watching another woman with a broom or a child or an old man waving his arms in the room below. They were slatted scenes - a knife hacking at bread, a baby kicked away from its mother's skirt. Lean slightly forward and I saw a woman's face contorted in rage. Lean slightly back and through another gap I saw the man whose hands held the knife. He hacked at the bread, ignoring the woman.''
But what strikes Ms. Cornelisen more than poverty is the ingenious and sometimes corrupt ways that people trained in hardship manage to survive. There are men who deploy themselves in the town square, hoping to get hit by a passing car to collect damages. There is also the mother superior who runs a mountain convent where orphan refugees are being exploited in a cottage industry while the storeroom is bulging with international relief supplies to be sold on the black market. And then there is the carabiniere who leads tours past the house where Ms. Cornelisen and Giovanna are staying so that the villagers can peer through the windows and observe the Anglo-Saxon way of life, tea trays and all. And there is Giovanna herself, a young widow raised in Milan and later, during Fascism, in England, whose northern education and sense of responsibility for the south become a model for the newly arrived American.
And though she doesn't say so, it is clear that this first year in Italy was Ann Cornelisen's education, when she learned the restraint and discipline (serieta in Italian) that enabled her to be effective in a world whose codes were very different from her own. Her willingness to adapt (not an easy thing for a single woman in a society where only a dowry and children guaranteed a woman her ''rights'') made it possible for her to go on living and working for many years in Basilicata and Calabria, and to write books that rival those of Ignazio Silone and Carlo Levi in their enduring portraits of a peasant society that has now all but vanished.
Today the Abruzzi coast would no longer be called the south, that loosely defined realm that begins somewhere south of Rome, where local enterprise does not flourish and civil society is still struggling to take root. Abruzzi towns like Ortona are thriving with small industries, and the children don't suffer from hunger and disease but, if anything, from modern ills like drugs. A postscript to the book tells of a recent visit to Ortona. The author wonders where the prosperity has come from, and an old friend says, ''Nobody knows, but people always find a way to steal.''
Ms. Cornelisen leaves it at that, but she shouldn't. That too-cynical piece of village wisdom reflects a world that really has disappeared throughout much of Italy, except that the Italians haven't quite absorbed the changes yet. And in this too Ms. Cornelisen proves herself to be thoroughly Italian.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24, Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: U.S. VERSUS JAPAN: A PROBLEM OF ATTITUDES

BYLINE: By CLYDE V. PRESTOWITZ; Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a former United States trade negotiator, is the author of ''Trading Places: How We Are Giving Our Future to Japan and How to Reclaim It.''

 BODY:

THE END OF THE AMERICAN CENTURY
By Steven Schlossstein.
537 pp. New York:
Congdon & Weed. $22.95.
Does America have to be No. 1? This is a question frequently asked in the current debate on the economic decline of the United States. In ''The End of the American Century,'' Steven Schlossstein minces no words in answering. The United States must reinvigorate the Pax Americana, he emphasizes, because the alternatives are either chaos or a Pax Nipponica that is likely to be very unattractive to the United States and the rest of the world. 
In explaining why, Mr. Schlossstein argues that Japanese dominance will be dangerous because many Japanese assert values that are diametrically opposed to those of most Americans. While we advocate freedom, equal rights and justice, the Japanese are governed by hierarchy, loyalty, conformity, duty and obedience. Moreover, he argues, the Japanese are obsessed with their own homogeneity, and as an example he cites former Prime Minister Yoshiro Nakasone's comments that Japanese education is superior to America's because Japan is not troubled with minorities. The combination of this emphasis on ethnic purity and other Japanese values, Mr. Schlossstein asserts, leads to totalitarianism and is dangerously close to racism. This is why none of Japan's Asian neighbors want it to gain hegemony and why, the author concludes, it is imperative that the United States not let it happen.
Before reaching this conclusion, Mr. Schlossstein takes the reader on an elaborate tour of Asia and explains in great detail the causes of American decline by contrasting the failure of our methods in key business areas with the success of Asian approaches. Japan and its clones - the so-called four tigers (South Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore) - pursue strategic economies instead of free markets and free trade. Here Mr. Schlossstein, the author of ''Trade War'' and other books, makes a telling point when he notes the futility of our devaluation of the dollar in the face of economic decision-making that is largely unrelated to prices.
Several chapters on education and the family also add some new elements to the debate. The author compares the success of Japanese education, which is based on peer pressure, teacher authority and strong parental involvement, with the stifling centralization of an American system choking on bureaucracy and dedicated to turning out cogs for an industrial machine that no longer exists.
Even more critical than the demise of our educational system, Mr. Schlossstein argues, is the disintegration of the family. He attributes this partly to American tax, welfare and parental-leave policies that penalize families. At the risk of rousing feminist ire, he also points to the clearly defined male and female roles in Asian families and the strong influence of the mother in educating children, and he contrasts this negatively with the disappearance of role differentiation in the American family.
Readers may find Mr. Schlossstein's habit of recounting the type of tea served during each interview he conducted, as well as his somewhat novelistic descriptions of the people he talked to, a bit irritating. More important, his prescription for re-energizing America is not as strong as his analysis of our ills, and one wonders about its curative powers. It may be that the decentralization of United States education is a good idea, but Japanese students seem to thrive in the world's most centralized system. Indeed, Asian-Americans seem to do very well in the United States system that Mr. Schlossstein decries as structurally hopeless. No doubt more child-care centers, more liberal parental-leave policies and higher tax exemptions for dependent children would be useful. But one wonders if they would really reverse divorce rates and lead to stable families dedicated to posterity rather than to the instant gratification that Mr. Schlossstein correctly identifies as a major problem.
Japan's former consul general in New York, Hidetoshi Ukawa, may be closer to the mark when he tells the author that the problem is one of attitudes. Indeed, Mr. Schlossstein demonstrates vividly that if Americans are to achieve a competitive attitude, they will have to reaffirm traditional values. This important book defines the nature of our competition with Japan more bluntly and directly than any other.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: END OF TEH AMERICAN CENTURY, THE (BOOK)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1090 words

HEADLINE: TALKING: Insider Deals;
A Guide To Co-op Bargaining

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AS hundreds of residential buildings in the New York City area were converted from rental to co-op status in the last decade, the tenants, regarded as insiders, were offered their apartments at prices as much as 40 percent below those posted for outside buyers.
Tempting as those offers were, many tenants turned them down because their regulated rents were so low they were reluctant to take on the higher costs of ownership. Others, like Corrine Schmidt of Jackson Heights, Queens, an airline technician, could not afford to buy. But now those tenants are being offered a second chance to buy, and at sweetened prices as much as 60 percent off current market value. Before accepting, they should examine their options carefully, and they also should investigate whether the sponsor is having difficulty meeting his obligations to the co-op. Sponsor defaults are forcing some co-ops to raise maintenance payments. 
In the last few months, many rental tenants have been offered ''a second bite of the apple,'' as conversion professionals have dubbed the new wave of discount purchase deals. For example, Aaron Ziegelman, a converter who still owns some 3,000 occupied apartments, said he recently completed new proposals for 20 of his buildings.
Secondary offerings have occasionally been made in the past, but the big difference now is that the current owner - most likely either the sponsor or an outside investor who bought occupied units in bulk from the sponsor - has probably been caught in the downward spiral that has been reducing the value and marketability of such units.
A result is that the owner may no longer view the long wait until the protected tenant moves out as an opportunity to hold onto an appreciating asset. Or the owner's cash position may have deteriorated to the point where selling to an insider may be one of the only ways left to unlock sorely needed liquidity, especially as apartments are not selling as briskly as they formerly did even when they become vacant.
In others, the sponsor may have found that the cost of renovating a vacant apartment before offering it for sale has increased to a point where it makes economic sense to woo insiders more ardently, a conclusion reached recently, for example, by Bill Felder, a sponsor in Kew Gardens, Queens.
''The financial problems that sponsors are facing are about to create a windfall for insiders,'' said Alan J. Pomerantz, a real estate finance lawyer who represents lenders and is seeing firsthand how much financial pressure certain sponsors are under. Miss Schmidt of Jackson Heights, for example, ended up buying her unit for $40,700, nearly 60 percent under the $90,000 outside price.
For these reasons tenants who are not being solicited with such overtures from sponsors might want to initiate the idea. A second chance could be especially relevant to anyone whose rent has gone up sharply since the first offering. If such an offer is received, or if tenant wants to seek a discounted offer, what is the best way to negotiate terms?
The first move should not be to go directly to the sponsor but instead to find out how many other tenants are interested, said John Dandola, a New York City lawyer involved in dozens of conversions. ''The more potential sales you can offer that sponsor, the more clout you will have,'' he said.
Sponsors agree. ''If a person can bring in 10 people or more we will offer a greater discount,'' said Mr. Ziegelman.
When the group has been defined it might well be worth hiring a lawyer to handle the negotiations, as price should not be the only objective. ''You should also be looking for a new basket of goodies,'' said Alvin I. Apfelberg, a New York City lawyer who has negotiated many deals on behalf of tenants.
CONCESSIONS that increase value and the quality of life in a building include getting an increase in the sponsor's contribution to the reserve fund, negotiating the right to control the board of directors, selecting a mangaging agent of the resident's choice, rather than the sponsor's, and setting sales and sublet policies if that has not been done already.
Mr. Apfelberg recommends getting a new and independent engineering report, too, if the cost can be spread widely enough not to cause hardship. Also, he said, it is often wise to ask the sponsor to bring in new sales staff and lawyers to handle these secondary deals since there may have been ''resentments and animosities'' left over from the original offering.
This most often occurs, he said, when a sponsor intentionally bypassed the insiders the first time around because he did not want to make concessions and could get enough sales without them.
Anyone negotiating individually should be as comprehensive as possible in the sort of concessions being sought. There could be pleasant surprises. For instance, a tenant living in a spacious two-bedroom unit owned by Mr. Ziegelman on the Upper West Side - who preferred not to have his name used - was able to work out a deal whereby his purchase of the unit at $280,000 was contingent upon Mr. Ziegeleman's finding an outside buyer for it at around $600,000, its appraised vacant market value. A buyer is now being sought.
Similarly, Arthur Beckerman, a partner in Coronet Properties Company, another major converter, has begun offering purchasing tenants a $200 discount off monthly maintenance payments for the first two years. Mr. Beckerman is also one of a growing number of sponsors providing discount financing on the cost of the shares. For example, he does not charge points or an application fee and also provides insiders with 100 percent financing.
If the apartment is owned by an outside investor an even sweeter deal can probably be negotiated because the investor does not have to worry about alienating residents who might have paid more for their units two or three years ago, or even having to make the same bargain deal throughout the building. Michael Porter, president of the Harris Group, which sells sponsor-owned apartments to investors, said he recently heard about one tenant who, after discovering the apartment had been bought by an outside investor for only 30 percent of vacant market value, offered that investor about 15 percent more - and clinched a deal.
But Mr. Dandola warns tenants not to overreach in their bargaining.
''Don't wait too long or it may be too late,'' He said. ''As soon as those sponsors feel the pressure is off they will go back to holding on as long as they can to get as much appreciation as possible.''

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Elkton, Md.;
Maryland Wins A Site Battle

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD

 BODY:
MORE than a year of competition between Maryland and Delware has ended with this state's capturing a major research and development center proposed by Himont, an international chemical company based in Wilmington, Del.
Himont, the world's largest manufacturer of polypropylene and a major producer of polymer-based specialty composites and alloys, considered and rejected 12 sites in New Castle County, Del., before deciding on a 196-acre parcel in Cecil County, Md., just over the Delaware state line. The center, just north of I-95 at the juncture of Routes 277 and 316, will anchor Himont's United States research. 
Officials in Cecil County, which is far more rural than neighboring New Castle County in Delaware, say Himont will not only add to the tax and employment base, but also help attract similar industries. Himont has its headquarters in Hockessin, a few miles west of Wilmington, and employs about 650 people in Delaware, including those in its headquarters.
One of the requirements was that the property be close to Delaware, where most of the company's employees live. The campus-like Maryland research park, for which no builder has been selected and no details are yet available, will be minutes from Newark, Del., home of the University of Delaware, and a 20-minute drive from Himont's headquarters.
Himont needed a minimum of 100 acres already zoned and immediately available. A building boom in the last eight years in Delaware made large parcels scarce and those already zoned for commerce or industry almost nonexistent.
J. Randall Evans, secretary of Maryland's Department of Economic and Employment Development, said the research center ''promises to provide opportunities for Maryland's universities to participate in emerging technology.'' To land the center, state and county economic development offices worked closely with Himont on a package of incentives, including a $2.27 million, low-interest loan to help pay for infrastructure improvements and land acquisition and a state job-training program.
Himont was formed in 1983 as a joint venture between Hercules of Wilmington and Montedison of Milan, Italy. In 1987, Hercules sold its share to Montedison, which in January completed its acquisition of all publicly held shares. Himont has research and development centers in Italy, England, West Germany, Canada and Hong Kong.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: West Side Landmark;
Rebuilding a Stable

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
The Claremont Riding Academy, a fixture on the Upper West Side for nearly a century - it stables 100 horses and serves almost 50,000 riders a year - has been rescued from the knacker and will undergo an extensive rehabilitation with the help of the city's Industrial Development Agency.
The horses will remain in the five-story building for the duration of the $2.6 million project, which is expected to be completed by the end of the year. 
Designed by Frank A. Rooke and put up in 1892, the building at 175 West 89th Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, is the oldest functioning stable in Manhattan. It was condemned in 1962 as part of the West Side urban renewal program. But it continued on a month-to-month basis and two years ago it was awarded landmark status by New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission.
''No work has been done on the building for well over 20 years because we didn't know how long we could survive, so the renovation effort will be extensive,'' said Paul Novograd, who oversees the operation of the stables that his family has owned for over 60 years. Mr. Novograd said $1.8 million of the costs will come from low-interest bonds floated by the I.D.A., which spurs business development and the creation of jobs in New York.

HEADLINE: Strategies for the Softer Resale Market

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
JEREMIAH COLE sold his Chelsea co-op in a week by trimming his price and offering brokers 8 percent instead of the normal 6 percent commission.
Bruce and Rene Young reduced their price and are heavily advertising their two-bedroom co-op in the Riverdale section of the Bronx in Chinese-, Russian- and Korean-language papers and on bulletin boards in local hospitals, synagogues and churches.
John and Meredith Forsberg found a buyer for their house in Rockville Centre, L.I., by cutting the price, running their own selling campaign and giving up their weekends to hold open houses for prospective buyers.
David and Melissa Boyce sold their six-room Upper East Side co-op by cutting the price and by repainting some rooms and clearing away clutter to make the apartment more attractive.
The stories of these sellers in what all acknowledge to be a tough resale market illustrate some hard truths. The prime one is that almost every home that sells these days is going for less than the owners hoped for. Buyuers are looking for price breaks and few of them are willing to bite unless the hook is baited with what looks like a bargain. 
The other side of that coin is that sellers who refuse to take less than their inflated hopes, based on the boom prices of the mid-80's, are wasting their time. Moreover, ordinary houses and apartment that were snapped up in the buying frenzy of the mid-80's are, in some places, not moving at any price.
Figures of the National Association of Realtors show the steady decline in sales throughout New York State in the last three years. In 1987, 223,900 single family houses, cooperatives and condominiums were sold in the state. The following year, the number dropped to 213,400 and last year there was a further drop, to 187,400.
In that kind of climate, there is no question that homeowners who want to sell have to take a much more activist role in the search for buyuers. The good news is that most motivated sellers do eventually find buyers, although for some it takes a long time to find the silver lining behind the dark clouds hanging over the market. Here are the slow-market strategies adopted by some New York City area home sellers, some successful, some not.
WHEN Mr. Cole was looking for ways to sell his apartment in the Chelsea section of Mahattan quickly last summer, he focused on attracting the attention of brokers rather than buyers.
''I knew what I was asking for the apartment was very competitive to start,'' said Mr. Cole, a former health-care executive who now lives in Cambridge, Mass. He had put a $265,000 asking price on his two-bedroom co-op.
''Brokers carry around in their heads lists of apartments they want to show,'' he said. ''I knew I needed something that would make the apartment stand out for them. They decide what buyers see. If your apartment is not worth their time, they just won't show it.''
Mr. Cole, who is embarking on a new career as a freelance writer, was in a rush to move before the start of the school year. He notified neighborhood brokers last Aug. 1 that he would pay an 8 percent commission on a sale made within 30 days. As the former owner of homes in Los Angeles, Washington and San Francisco, he knew that was an optimistic timetable even in a thriving market.
''I had made up my mind that if I could not have the apartment sold and be in Boston by Labor Day,'' said Mr. Cole, who wanted his teen-aged son to start school on time, ''then we would probably stay in New York. So I guess it was an all-or-nothing proposition.''
Mr. Cole believes the bonus had more of a psychological than monetary impact. ''It really got the attention of brokers,'' he said. ''The response was much better than I expected, since not that much money was involved.
''In the case of my apartment, the extra money would have been about $5,000, half of which would have gone to the brokerage company.''
As it turned out, Mr. Cole, who sold his apartment for about $259,000, did not have to pay the premium even though a contract was signed long before his deadline. His buyer's final offer was a little lower than what Mr. Cole thought he could get for the apartment. In order not to lose the sale, the broker gave up the bonus in a compromise that satisfied all concerned. Mr. Cole said his goal was achieved, but at a cost. ''Even though I sold for slightly higher than I bought,'' he said, ''when the cost of selling was factored in, there was a slight loss. If there had been more time I think I could have done a little better.''
WITHOUT a doubt, say the Forsbergs, they broke the first rule of trading up in a soft market - to sell before buying. Nevertheless, the Rockville Centre couple seem to have have landed on their feet anyway.
After putting money down in December on a six-bedroom home four blocks from the house they wanted to sell, the Forsbergs, who have two children, put their four-bedroom Dutch colonial on the market in mid-January. They had a contract for sale by the end of the month.
''It was risky,'' said Mrs. Forsberg. ''But even with the market so soft, we felt we would lose this house if we waited until we had a buyer.''
When they turned to the task of selling their home, the Forsbergs, not wanting to see any profit eaten up by a broker's fee, decided to try a do-it-yourself sales campaign before listing their house with brokers. Their strategy was to write and place their own advertisements and hold weekend open houses rather than schedule appointments for house hunters.
''I think some people would be reluctant to do what we did,'' said Mrs. Forsberg, of their decision to include their address in the advertisement for the open houses. ''But we figured that by listing our address, we would save time by attracting only serious buyers. Anyone who was not interested in our house or living on our street just would not come in.''
Because their home is on a fairly busy street and the yard is small, the Forsbergs aimed their advertising campaign at couples with no children. They believed their house would be most attractive to empty-nesters from their community looking to trade down to a smaller residence or to a young couple in the market for a starter home.
''The ads for the older people stressed things like low taxes,'' said Mr. Forsberg, an executive with a Long Island bank. ''We put them in the Long Island papers.
''But the ads that we placed New York City papers, which we wrote with the yuppies in mind, talked about the easy commutation to the city.''
The Forsbergs, who say their home was in top shape to start with, employed a few time-tested house-showing devices that Mrs. Forsberg calls her ''broker's tricks,'' before opening their doors to the buying public on the second Sunday in January.
''We had a fire going in the fireplace,'' said Mrs. Forsberg. ''We scented the rooms, we had easy listening music on the radio.'' Had it not been for the stack of fact sheets and snapshots of their home left by the door, their open houses could have been mistaken for parties.
The Forsbergs said the bid they accepted was just below their asking price of $229,000, but they had no commission to pay and their advertising bills came to only $600. The couple buying their home are relocating from Manhattan to be closer to jobs on Long Island.
THE BOYCES were in the two-bedroom apartment they bought in the East 90's only two years before they had outgrown it. With one young son and another child on the way, the Boyces were forced back into the co-op market last year.
''We could not have picked a worse time to be trying to sell,'' said Mrs. Boyce, whose husband is a researcher with the Hitachi Chemical Company.
''We bought our apartment when prices peaked. They seemed to start falling as soon as we decided to sell.''
The first bids for their prewar apartment, which they sold last spring, were not close to their $570,000 asking price. Even after they dropped the price, they found that acceptable bids did not start coming in until after they spruced up their prewar apartment.
''You get used to your apartment looking a certain way,'' said Mrs. Boyce, ''Its not that there are major flaws, but just small things that your eyes have adjusted to but the buyers notice.''
The couple started their fix-up project by repainting some rooms. Next, toys and other odds and ends were relegated to the basement of their apartment building. Then extra pieces of furniture that did not quite fit were transported to the couple's second home in Virginia.
The idea was to make the rooms look more spacious and to give the whole apartment a more attractive look.
The strategy seemed to help because interest picked up, and six weeks later, the Boyces got a bid for about $525,000 that was close enough to what they wanted and they accepted it. They then bought a three-bedroom apartment on the same block. ''I don't think that painting and rearranging furniture is going to help you sell an apartment if the price is too high,'' said Mrs. Boyce. ''But these days you have make an effort to sell.''
A FEW years ago, the Youngs moved into their two-bedroom Riverdale apartment with their golden retriever. Then their daughter, Emily, was born and they hired a live-in housekeeper. While they are under no financial pressure to move, they feel squeezed and want to relocate to a suburban house.
The Youngs decided to seek sellers as broadly as possible. That is why they are using foreign-language weekly newspapers to reach the increasingly ethnically diverse population of their neighborhood. Mrs. Young who is a public relations executive, also put notices on bulletin boards in local institutions.
They hoped their low $110,000 asking price would be particularly enticing to first-time buyers.
Traffic through their home has increased in the last few weeks. But the Youngs admit to being frustrated and they are puzzled by what seems to be contradictory responses from potential buyers.
''It's not just that people say they like our apartment,'' said Mr. Young, who is an attorney. ''Everybody who is looking tells sellers they have a nice place.''
''But when buyers are not interested,'' he went on, ''they are usually in and out in a few minutes. The people who have come to see our apartment in the past few weeks really seem to be interested. They spend a long time looking around and asking questions. They make favorable comments about the building, the indoor parking garage and things like that. But we usually don't hear from them again.''
The couple theorize that some buyers today may be paralyzed by the wealth of choices.
''A lot of people are trying to sell right now,'' Mr. Young said. ''Buyers have a lot to choose from. Even when they find something they can afford and like, they resist making an offer because they are worried that there might be something else to see that they will like a little bit better.''
But Mr. Young, who is not only looking for more room but also wants to take advantage of the lower prices in the suburbs, is optimistic.
''When buyers realize that sellers can come down only so far,'' he said, ''maybe things will start moving.''
RICHARD WEATHERS is under the gun. A few months ago, he bought another home when he thought he had a buyer for his 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bathroom, stone-and-frame ranch-style home in Armonk. But that deal evaporated days before a sales contract was to be signed when the buyer changed his mind.
''We lost two very valuable months with that buyer,'' he said. ''And prices dropped during that time.''
To remain competitive, Mr. Weathers cut his price when he put his home back on the market.
''SACRIFICE SALE - Original Price $429,500. Reduced Price $375,000,'' read the classified ad Mr. Weathers ran for several weeks. His was far from the only one written to appeal to bargain-hungry buyers. His advertisements were surrounded by scores of others reflecting the current flexibility - even desperation - of other sellers.
In an effort to improve his odds, Mr. Weathers is now sharing the marketing chores with the brokers who have the listing on his home. He has placed his own advertisements and is showing on his own as well.
The agreement he has with the brokers is that if one of them sells the house he pays a 5 percent commission; if he sells it, no broker's fee is owed.
But Mr. Weathers attributes his lack of success so far in selling the house, which is set on a wooded lot of more than an acre, to a home-sale gridlock rather than a price that is too steep for the market.
''There is log jam where homes sales are concerned,'' he said. ''People are looking for good deals but I do not think that at this point pricing is our main problem.
''Plenty of people are interested,'' he continued. ''Our living room is filled every weekend with young couples trying to trade up. But for a lot of them lower prices aren't helping much. ''Even those who can afford my house are sometimes stuck with smaller homes or condos that they can't sell.''

LENGTH: 636 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
An American Sendup Of the British Royals

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
IN ''Rumors in the Palace,'' Enid Rudd's two-character sendup of royal tradition, British style, the oversexed future king (Arthur) and his frigid teen-age princess (Vivian, or Vi) play, teasingly, with plastic water guns. Before long, their fun and games are aimed toward kinky sex. Years later, in a hot tub, where the prince is playing with his little boat, they have a spat over mutual infidelities, and Vi tosses fried chicken nuggets at Artie. By the time they are enthroned, this king and queen of England have been diminished to blathering buffoons.
Miss Rudd, an American playwright, clearly has a message in mind beyond the sort of tacky sex comedy that runs for ages in London and closes in a flash on Broadway. Indeed, the message, about the pomposity and preposterousness of the royals, couldn't be clearer. Anachronistic, empty-headed endangered relics they are, and Miss Rudd telegraphs that throughout, mistaking restatement for development and thinly disguised topical celebrity baiting for satire. 
She also confuses double-entendres with metaphors. Apart from obvious name associations to the monarchy of the moment, one is reminded that the royal couple's favorite verbal game is Trivial Pursuit and that Vi is the champion. And Vi's ability to reach an orgasm occurs at the play's climactic moment, the coronation scene, thus literalizing the aphrodisiacal properties of power.
In roles that require a subtle command of constancy and change, Michael Lasswell and Deirdre Madigan work valiantly, but come off too adorably at first. Their English accents are basically dreadful, and periodically mercifully forgotten.
Whether he's feeling ''awfully badly'' about the homeless and otherwise victimized, or acknowledging his own ''bloody good luck,'' or going on about the formation of a think tank to deal with the troubles of inner cities, Mr. Lasswell has a disarmingly dopey air.
Whining about drafty castles and not caring ''a fig about ritual,'' Vi soon is advocating mandatory classes in etiquette and the importance of the curtsy. Miss Madigan adapts neatly to her role, which calls for varying degrees of petulance, with a bit of haughtiness thrown in. On video, Sarah Saltus and Joel Stedman play sparring newscasters with rather more style than those silly young royals.
Steve Karp's generally toneless direction is obediently farcical when it needs to be, but how is one to pursue a play that doesn't transcend its own triviality?
This production of ''Rumors in the Palace'' is its premiere, and Mr. Karp, who is also the artistic director of Stamford Theater Works, is holding to his objective of offering new plays to local audiences at least once a season.
This is the fourth full production for Stamford's new professional theater company, where plays have had two-week runs. Miss Rudd's work evolved from a staged reading at the Theater Artists Workshop in Westport.
Mr. Karp expected to extend the engagement of ''Rumors in the Palace'' through next Sunday. (It opened on Feb. 8.) But after last Saturday's matinee performance he learned that a grant from a local corporation had not come through. ''With it, we would have extended the run for sure, but we don't have the resources to gamble on another week,'' Mr. Karp said.
In addition to the play's operating expenses, the company would have been required to purchase the hot tub for $2,500. It is being rented for a nominal fee, only through today. The artistic purposes of playwrights are all too often compromised by economic realities. Perhaps the most pressing question raised by Miss Rudd's play is, is that hot tub really necessary?
''Rumors in the Palace'' will have its final performance at 2 P.M. today at the Sacred Heart Academy Center for the Arts, 200 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford. 359-4414.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Our Greatest Asset: Educated Workers

BYLINE: By Ivan Frisch; Ivan Frisch is director of the Center for Advanced Technology in Telecommunications at Polytechnic University.

 BODY:
WE hear much of the economic decline of Long Island. The key to recovery is the creation of jobs in the service industries and the computer and communications technologies they depend upon.
In 1969 two of my colleagues and I left the faculty of the University of California at Berkeley to start a company in Glen Cove called Network Analysis Corporation. We had a number of good reasons for starting on Long Island, as well as some others that occurred to us later. It is worth examining those reasons because they give us clues about the directions that industry and university must take. 
Our field was computer and communication systems. Early on we had a key role in developing the world's first ''packet switching network,'' with the technology now being used in all modern computer networks. In today's terminology, we would call our field information systems. In this field, New York City was, and continues to be, the major center in the United States, with its concentration in publishing, banking, brokerage and insurance.
Part of the Island is a bedroom community for New York. However, we found that people who commute would gladly switch to appropriate jobs on the Island. We also learned that we could attract people who live in Queens and Brooklyn, or even Manhattan and New Jersey, because of the easy reverse commute, while considering the longer-term possibility of moving to Long Island.
The salaries we offered had to be competitive with New York City. On the other hand, the cost of office space is less than New York. When we started our company we rented an entire mansion, one of the old Pratt estates. The atmosphere was exotic, with the master bedroom serving as the president's office. When we outgrew the mansion we moved to more conventional, but still reasonably priced, facilities in Great Neck.
Long Island's labor force is affluent, educated and knowledgeable about information systems and other fields essential for business. As our company grew we were able to recruit, from the local community, superb financial, marketing, sales and administrative people as well as the technical people who were the heart of our business. We have been called a service economy in a post-industrial society. Rather than fight the designation we found it profitable to be part of it. Rather than business going to Texas or Tokyo, we were able to bring some of it to Long Island.
University education is the major factor in attracting and keeping industry on Long Island. The New York metropolitan area is one of a handful of centers in America with dozens of two-year and four- year colleges and universities, including some of the finest in the nation.
We obtained most of our new young hires, in the areas of computer science and electrical engineering, from the eastern section of this galaxy, particularly New York University, Columbia University, the City University of New York, including Queens College; the State University of New York at Stony Brook, and Polytechnic University, both in Brooklyn and in Farmingdale.
We asked faculty members we knew to recommend their best students. We built a team consisting of the best students, a highly motivated, dedicated group. We also taught as adjunct faculty at all the schools named above and once again made offers to the best students we saw. Even as we grew and needed far more employees, the technique was still effective. With creativity we can attract and keep our graduates on Long Island.
The university is also critical in attracting the less affluent and enabling them to join the community. It may appear that the high technology industries exclude these very people. The only real entry barrier is the willingness to exercise one's intellect. For example, Polytechnic University draws almost all its students from the New York area, with many students being the first generation in their families to attend college.
About 71 percent remain in the metropolitan area after graduation and if more jobs were available even more of them would stay. Among those who work in industry as co-op students while undergraduates, 83 percent are placed locally.
Of course, the university's impact does not stop with undergraduate education. In any technologically centered company, and particularly in information systems, professionals must be prepared to learn. However, many people must change their technical fields several times in a career. For lasting and deep knowledge, fundamentals must be presented in a coherent graduate program.
Our company was acquired in 1980, and I have now returned to teaching at Polytechnic University, where I continue to implement the tenets I preach. One program we offer is in telecommunications management and the other in information systems engineering. Some of the people who enroll in these programs are working on information systems but never were formally educated in either computers or in communications or both. The people who have graduated from the program compete and excel in two of the areas critical to the welfare of Long Island.
I do not minimize the magnitude of our problems. One does not overcome problems of tax burdens, job displacement, aging industries and international competition by penning a few words. But one can set objectives. Our future lies in our ability to capitalize our college-educated work force to stay at the forefront of information technology and attract business to Long Island.

PUB-DATE: February 18, 1990

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1, Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1465 words

HEADLINE: >Fund Offers Aid To Children With Severe Illnesses

BYLINE: By SANDRA FRIEDLAND

DATELINE: WARREN

 BODY:
FOUR-YEAR-OLD Ryan Damrau was born with a hole in his heart and enough other medical problems to fill a pediatric textbook.
He is deaf and suffers from a chronic eye ailment. His body temperature fluctuates; he has no muscle coordination, and he lacks the sucking and swallowing reflexes needed to eat and drink. Four times a day, his parents must thread a tube through his nose and into his stomach to feed him.
''It's like having an infant in the house all the time,'' said his father, the Rev. Robert Damrau, pastor of the Mount Bethel Baptist Church here. He said he and his wife, Ulla, and their two older children communicate with Ryan mainly through touch. 
The boy's care has cost thousands of dollars a year beyond the amount covered by the Damraus' insurance. Lately, the family has been struggling to make the $453 monthly payments on a van to transport Ryan, whose high-backed wheelchair does not fit into a car.
 
$13,000 State Grant for Van
But now, thanks to a $13,000 grant from a new state fund, the van will soon be paid for, and the Damraus are breathing a little easier.
The fund, New Jersey's Catastrophic Illness in Children Relief Fund, is the only one of its kind in the nation, state officials say. It is intended to protect families from financial ruin when the care of a severely ill or disabled child generates staggering expenses that are not paid by insurance or other government programs. The fund covers children 17 years old or younger afflicted with either physical or mental disorders.
''This fills the gaps where other programs don't come into play,'' said Dr. Leah Ziskin, the Acting State Commissioner of Health. ''It will help those people who make too much money to qualify for Medicaid but have no health insurance, or who have insurance that doesn't cover such items as doctor visits, home care, prostheses or medical supplies.''
Financed through a $1 assessment on employers for every worker subject to the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Law, the fund has nearly $5 million a year to dispense. It is administered by a nine-member commission, which is now accepting applications for help with expenses incurred in 1988 and 1989. The Damraus got one of the first three grants, which were announced last December.
 
Next Round of Awards
The commission will meet March 20 to consider the next round of awards.
Applications for aid are made through the Special Child Health Services program in each of the state's 21 counties. Families must have lived in New Jersey for at least six months before applying, although migrant workers who can prove they have worked in the state may also qualify.
Families earning up to $100,000 a year can qualify for aid if their child's unreimbursed medical expenses exceed 30 percent of their income. Families earning more than $100,000 a year can apply if their unreimbursed expenses account for more than 40 percent of their income. The fund will pay that portion of a family's eligible expenses that exceeds the 30 percent or 40 percent threshold.
The maximum award is $25,000, but the commission can grant additional aid to families with other hardships. Special consideration will also be given to families with more than one child with a catastrophic illness. The commission can also pay insurance premiums for a child.
Richard Ahlfeld, a commissioner of the fund, said the program was designed to be accessible and ''user friendly.'' But he stressed the need for applicants to have good documentation.
''Even if all the family has is a shoebox full of receipts, there has to be documentation,'' said Mr. Ahlfeld, who also is president of Children's Specialized Hospital in Mountainside. He said that case managers in the Special Child Services unit of each county had been trained to help families complete their applications.
 
Expenses Bring Hardships
''There are families whose lives are totally wiped out by their children's medical expenses,'' said Dr. Leta Bagden, director of the Child Development Center of Children's Hospital of New Jersey in Newark and a commissioner of the fund. She pointed out, for example, that bills for the care of a critically ill newborn ''can approach $100,000 in a very short time and throw the family into total chaos.''
In 1988, Gina and Michael DeFeo of the Camden County community of Clementon received a bill for $80,000 after their 11-day-old daughter Michelle, died of kidney failure in a Philadelphia hospital. She had been transferred there for special care after her premature birth in a New Jersey hospital. Her twin sister, Maria, did not need to be transferred, and she survived.
''As long as Michelle was in New Jersey, her bills were covered under an arrangement we had with the New Jersey hospital's clinic,'' Mrs. DeFeo recalled. ''But once she was taken out of the state, she wasn't covered. We were still mourning her death when that bill arrived. There was no way we could pay it. It was devastating.''
Mrs. DeFeo and her husband, who earned about $17,000 in 1988, were ineligible for public assistance and could not negotiate a settlement with the hospital. They lost their credit rating and faced deepening financial troubles.
 
'Christmas Present From God'
Then, last year, a county caseworker who had been helping them manage Maria's health care needs told them about the catastrophic illness fund. The commission agreed to pay $35,000 to the Philadelphia hospital.
''The news was like a Christmas present from God,'' Mrs. DeFeo said recently. ''We are talking to the hospital and hope they'll accept the money as full payment or at least for most of it.''
Dr. Ziskin of the Health Department said it had been extremely gratifying to make the first awards from the fund. ''This has been a public health professional's dream: to get money directly to families who feel abandoned and discriminated against by the system,'' she said.
State Senator Donald T. DiFrancesco, Republican of Westfield, introduced the legislation in 1986 that eventually led to the establishment of the fund. He was inspired, he said, by the experiences of two local families whose children had been involved in crippling accidents.
''I realize that we needed a program to take care of people who could go bankrupt from an illness or accident,'' he said in a recent interview. ''I focused on children because they are not in a position to decide what kind of insurance they must have or whether to buy it at all. They can't take care of themselves.''
 
Families May Reapply
Although he had first envisioned a program for children with physical problems, Mr. DiFrancesco said it was expanded to include the retarded and children with mental illnesses as well. Under the rules of the fund, families may apply for aid every year if they continue to meet the requirements.
Mary Ann Whiteman, executive director of the fund, pointed out that families with a chronically ill child may have little hope of increasing their income.
''Their income level often does not rise,'' Ms. Whiteman said, ''either because one parent must stay at home to care for the child or because the family needs insurance so badly that the wage earner cannot risk changing jobs for a promotion for fear of losing coverage. But long-term prospects are poor for these families ever paying all their bills.''
Cheryl and Alexander Holdosi of Dover have been told that their son will outgrow the severe kidney problems that almost killed him 1988. Alexander Jr., now 3 1/2, was hospitalized repeatedly and has required continual monitoring. The family's insurance paid for the hospital charges but not for the doctors' bills or the boy's outpatient laboratory tests or medications.
''We couldn't afford to pay, and we were denied Medicaid coverage,'' said Mrs. Holdosi, adding that she and her husband earned about $21,000 in 1988. ''Collection agencies were after us.''
Last December, the Holdosis learned that the catastrophic illness fund would pay $1,600 of the family's medical expenses.
''We still have bills left,'' Mrs. Holdosi said. ''But this has taken off a lot of the pressure. It really felt great.''
 
HOW TO APPLY
Families interested in applying for aid from New Jersey's Catastrophic Illness in Children Relief Fund should follow these steps, says Mary Ann Whiteman, the executive director of the fund:
Obtain an application by calling the fund headquarters in Trenton, (609)292-0600, or the Special Child Services unit of their county.
Isolate medical expenses relating to the child's care, dividing them by year and identifying the paid and unpaid bills.
Take the application and financial records to the appropriate county Special Child Services unit, where a case manager will help complete the application process.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
An American Sendup Of the British Royals

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
IN ''Rumors in the Palace,'' Enid Rudd's two-character sendup of royal tradition, British style, the oversexed future king (Arthur) and his frigid teen-age princess (Vivian, or Vi) play, teasingly, with plastic water guns. Before long, their fun and games are aimed toward kinky sex. Years later, in a hot tub, where the prince is playing with his little boat, they have a spat over mutual infidelities, and Vi tosses fried chicken nuggets at Artie. By the time they are enthroned, this king and queen of England have been diminished to blathering buffoons.
Miss Rudd, an American playwright, clearly has a message in mind beyond the sort of tacky sex comedy that runs for ages in London and closes in a flash on Broadway. Indeed, the message, about the pomposity and preposterousness of the royals, couldn't be clearer. Anachronistic, empty-headed endangered relics they are, and Miss Rudd telegraphs that throughout, mistaking restatement for development and thinly disguised topical celebrity-baiting for satire. 
She also confuses double-entendres with metaphors. Apart from obvious name associations to the monarchy of the moment, one is reminded that the royal couple's favorite verbal game is Trivial Pursuit and that Vi is the champion. And Vi's ability to reach an orgasm occurs at the play's climactic moment, the coronation scene, thus literalizing the aphrodisiacal properties of power.
In roles that require a subtle command of constancy and change, Michael Lasswell and Deirdre Madigan work valiantly, but come off too adorably at first. Their English accents are basically dreadful, and periodically are mercifully forgotten.
Whether he's feeling ''awfully badly'' about the homeless and otherwise victimized, or acknowledging his own ''bloody good luck,'' or going on about the formation of a think tank to deal with the troubles of inner cities, Mr. Lasswell has a disarmingly dopey air.
Whining about drafty castles and not caring ''a fig about ritual,'' Vi soon is advocating mandatory classes in etiquette and the importance of the curtsy. Miss Madigan adapts neatly to her role, which calls for varying degrees of petulance, with a bit of haughtiness thrown in. On video, Sarah Saltus and Joel Stedman play sparring newscasters with rather more style than those silly young royals.
Steve Karp's generally toneless direction is obediently farcical when it needs to be, but how is one to pursue a play that doesn't transcend its own triviality?
This production of ''Rumors in the Palace'' is its premiere, and Mr. Karp, who is also the artistic director of Stamford Theater Works, is holding to his objective of offering new plays to local audiences at least once a season.
This is the fourth full production for Stamford's new professional theater company, where plays have had two-week runs. Miss Rudd's work evolved from a staged reading at the Theater Artists Workshop in Westport.
Mr. Karp expected to extend the engagement of ''Rumors in the Palace'' through next Sunday. (It opened on Feb. 8.) But after last Saturday's matinee performance he learned that a grant from a local corporation had not come through. ''With it, we would have extended the run for sure, but we don't have the resources to gamble on another week,'' Mr. Karp said.
In addition to the play's operating expenses, the company would have been required to purchase the hot tub for $2,500. It is being rented for a nominal fee, only through today. The artistic purposes of playwrights are all too often compromised by economic realities. Perhaps the most pressing question raised by Miss Rudd's play is, is that hot tub really necessary?
''Rumors in the Palace'' will have its final performance at 2 P.M. today at the Sacred Heart Academy Center for the Arts, 200 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford. (203) 359-4414.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

 BODY:

 
A BIT OF HISTORY
An open house celebrating George Washington's birthday will be held from 2 to 4 P.M. today at the recently restored Jacob Purdy House in White Plains. It is the first of a series of events planned ''to acquaint people with a bit of history in their midst that is largely unrecognized,'' said John W. Harrington, president of the White Plains Historical Society, which acquired the building in the late 1960's.
''We have documentation that General Washington spent seven days in the house in 1776, before and during the Battle of White Plains, and six weeks in the summer of 1778,'' he said. Purdy was a captain in the militia and his 123-acre farm was a convenient meeting place and rallying point for the military.
The house, on two acres at 60 Park Avenue, was built in 1794 and remained in the Purdy family until 1963. ''The city moved it for us from a nearby urban-renewal area to its present site in 1973, saving it from demolition and restoring the exterior with H.U.D. funds,'' Mr. Harrington said. 
Restoration of the interior was completed by the historical society last fall at a cost of $85,000. International Business Machines contributed $25,000, the rest was raised from private donations. All the original wide-plank flooring and most of the wainscoting was preserved, along with the mantel in the main parlor, where Washington held his conferences. Funds must now be raised for appropriate antique furnishings. ''The house was empty and badly vandalized when we got it,'' Mr. Harrington said. ''It had been a rooming house and for a time, a brothel.''
Stephen Holden Jr., a local lawyer, will portray General Washington and act as host, while a number of costumed hostesses will serve gingerbread made from Martha Washington's recipe and a selection of teas and coffees. Five costumed militiamen will fire a musket volley for the raising of the American flag and the Washington Headquarters flag - a solid blue field with 13 white stars.
A special feature of the afternoon will be a harpsichord performance by Robert Canfield. The all-Early American program includes the Federal Overture by Benjamin Carr, written in 1794; Washington's March; the Marseilles Hymn; Carmagnole; Ca Ira; and Yankee Doodle.
To reach the house, proceed up Church Street opposite Macy's and turn left on Park Avenue to the red farmhouse. Everything is free, including refreshments.
 
ENSOR SELF-PORTRAIT
An exhibition called ''James Ensor: Self-Portrait in Prints'' opens today at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at in Purchase, running through April 15. Devised by a student, Carrie Brewster, as her senior project in art, the show contains two lithographs and 14 etchings, all in black and white and all modest in size - up to about 20 inches - and all self-portraits.
One is called ''The Entry of Christ Into Brussels in 1889'' and is indicative of the Belgian artist's perception of himself as persecuted by the critics. ''Demons Tormenting Me'' has a tombstone in the background with his name on it, illustrating his preoccupation with his own death. He died in 1949 at the age of 80.
Museum hours are 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays, and 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. weekends. Admission is free but a donation of $2 is asked.
 
ENVIRONMENTAL LAW
A moot-court competition and series of environmental-litigation workshops will be held at the Pace University School of Law in White Plains from 2 to 9 P.M. Thursday, from 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. Friday and from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Saturday.
Among the issues to be discussed are local and municipal recycling programs; protection of United States wetlands; the environmental role of the United States and the Soviet Union among developing nations; President Bush's proposal to amend the Clean Air Act; criminal environmental-law enforcement; regulation of petroleum transport; alternatives for energy management, and groundwater pollution.
A forum from 7 to 9:30 P.M. Friday titled ''Attack on the Venus Sky Traps: Strategy and Tactics to Abate the Roots of Global Warming'' will feature Richard L. Ottinger, a former Representative from Westchester who is now a member of Governor Mario M. Cuomo's Environmental Advisory Board, and a panel of government, academic and private-sector representatives.
Among the workshop speakers are John Meagher, director of the wetlands strategies and state programs division of the United States Environmental Protection Agency; Andrew Praschal, senior environmental counsel for BASF Chemicals; Judy LaBelle, deputy director and counsel of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation; Lieut. Mike Kearney, assistant port safety officer for the United States Coast Guard; Victor Rocque, vice president and general counsel for Orange and Rockland Utility.
Dr. Michael H. Robinson, director of the National Zoo at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, will address an awards banquet for competition winners from 52 teams representing 37 law schools in the United States and Canada, scheduled from 6 to 9 P.M. Saturday at the White Plains Hotel.
All aspects of the program are open to the public. Registration, from noon to 2 P.M. Thursday, is $50, or $25 for any law student and $10 for other students, in the Glass Lounge on the campus, at 78 North Broadway. Tickets for the banquet are $25. Call 422-4360 for more information.
 
A SILENT WILDE
The rarest of the films to be shown in a series beginning this week at Westchester Community College in Valhalla is ''Lady Windermere's Fan.'' Made in 1925 from an Oscar Wilde play, it was filmed as a silent feature starring Ronald Colman. Although not a word of Wilde's witty dialogue can be heard, Ernst Lubitsch's direction was credited with making the movie a hit. At the screening on March 3d the silence will be breached with a live and original piano score composed and performed by Lee Erwin, a specialist in the field.
''Pelle the Conqueror,'' the 1988 Danish film with Max von Sydow opens the series this Friday, followed on successive Fridays at 8 P.M. by ''Murmur of the Heart,'' France, 1971; ''Wuthering Heights,'' United States, 1939; ''Made for Each Other,'' United States, 1971; ''The Navigator,'' New Zealand, 1988; ''Lady Windermere's Fan''; ''Wings of Desire,'' West Germany, 1988, and ''Queen of Hearts,'' Britain, 1988.
A performance of the 1989 British film ''My Left Foot'' will end the season June 1 as a benefit for the college's Arts Fund. Subscriptions for the rest of the series cost $27, or $20 for the elderly. Single tickets are $4, or $3 for the elderly. Benefit tickets are $10. Each film is preceded by a reception at 7:15 P.M. Call 285-6700 to subscribe or obtain more information.
 
THE AIDS TRAGEDY
''AIDS: The Science and Ethics of a Social Tragedy'' will be discussed by Dr. Robert C. Gallo, co-discoverer of the AIDS virus at noon Wednesday at the Performing Arts Theater of Lehman College in the Bronx.
Dr. Gallo, who is chief of the Tumor Cell Biology Laboratory at the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health in Washington, also heads the institute team that developed a blood test used to detect the AIDS virus and is at work on developing a vaccine.
Dr. Gallo is a member of the National Academy of Sciences and has been awarded honorary degrees from several universities in the United States, Italy, Israel and Belgium. Admission is free. For more information, call (212) 960-8441. $90ELEANOR CHARLES

AND BEAR IN MIND
 (Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)
 A LAW UNTO INSELF: Power, Politics and the IRS, by David Burnham. (Random House, $22.50.) An absorbing, critical, well-argued inquiry into our tax agency, by a former Times reporter.
 THE KNIGHT, DEATH AND THE DEVIL, by Ella Leffland. (Morrow, $22.95) This vigorous novel about Hermann Goring, Hitler's baroque enigmatic No. 2 Nazi, gives a credible sense of why Nazism succeeded in inflaming so many generatons.
 A TENURED PROFESSOR, by John Kenneht Galbraith. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A liberal economist learns to quantify investor irrationality and makes millions until conservatives cut him down in Mr. Galbraith's rollicking spoof of free-market ideology.
 ME AND MY BABY VIEW THE ECLIPSE, by Lee Smith. (Putnam, $18.95.) Powerful short sotires of small-town life and the passage of time in the American South, full of striving, jealously and pettiness but also of transcendent generosity and devotion.
 PASSING ON, by Penolope Lively (Grove Weldenfeld, $17.95) Tough and shrewd, precise and understated, Ms. Lively's eighth novel renders a family's painful efforts to sort out and overcome the emotional legacy of a truly awful mother.
 WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION: A Political Life in the Reagan Era, by Peggy Noonan. (Random House, $19.95.) Ronald Reagan's speechwriter, an articulate true believer in her President's greatness, is also a wide-awake observer of comings and goings in the Administration, rendering what she saw and heard into fine, sometimes brusque and rough-cut social comedy.
MARY REILLY, by Valerie Martin. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Stevenson's story of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde from the unexpected viewpoint of a housemaid, a woman fierce with love, loyalty, and the will to figure out what's going on between good and evil.
