SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1432 words

HEADLINE: Tight Budgets Force Towns To Cut Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
ON Lincoln's Birthday last week, for the first time in years, there was no one at the New Haven Public Works Department to answer the phone in an emergency. This weekend, the street-sweeping trucks are not out as usual, as the city cuts overtime hours to save money.
''If it's a real emergency, people can get in touch with the Police Department on a holiday,'' said the acting public works director, Brian W. Funk. ''And for two days a week, the litter will have to accumulate.''
Those are some of the first visible effects of New Haven's money problems. The city is running a budget deficit this year estimated at nearly $12 million. 
In Bridgeport city officials are planning to come to grips with their problem this week. On Tuesday, Mayor Mary C. Moran will meet with union representatives to discuss an anticipated $28.6 million shortfall for the budget year beginning July 1, and the new chief financial officer, Richard V. Robinson, will announce his recommendations for cuts.
New Haven and Bridgeport are the most visible examples, but towns across the state are struggling with fiscal problems in increasing numbers, according to audits filtering into state offices.
Municipalities are faced with tax revenue that is lower than expected, largely because of the sluggish real-estate market. Anticipated money from building permits, real-estate transfer taxes and property taxes on new structures has not materialized. Leading many towns' unexpected costs are the arbitration awards won by municipal employee unions, especially those representing teachers.
Mr. Robinson said the possibility of layoffs in Bridgeport, ''is very real.'' He said the city pared its services to a minimum in an effort to pull itself out of a serious fiscal crunch in the mid-1980s.
''The easy cuts, they've all been made,'' Mr. Robinson said. ''Now we're looking at making cuts that will definitely have an impact on programs and services.''
Luca Cardozo, an administrative aide to Ms. Moran, said that when the Mayor took office in January, the deficit for the 1990-91 fiscal year was projected at $15 million. Last week, the city announced that the actual figure would be closer to $30 million.
''When you come in with one figure in your mind, and you start figuring out how to deal with it, but then that figure suddenly doubles, it takes you a little off guard,'' Mr. Cardozo said. ''It's not a matter of pointing fingers at anyone and laying the blame. We've got a serious job ahead of us, and we've got to get to work.''
Van Sullivan, a staff member of the State Municipal Finance Advisory Commission, said that in the 1988 fiscal year, seven towns reported a deficit in municipal fund balances.
This year, 9 of the 154 towns that have reported so far have deficits, and as many as 3 or 4 of the last 15 whose reports are expected by early March could be in the red.
''By and large, the towns are well managed,'' Mr. Sullivan said. But they all face rapidly increasing costs of providing services, he said, while some find that revenues are falling short of expectations.
 
Painful Choices
Earlier this month, Gov. William A. O'Neill added to the bad news when he announced that towns would get millions of dollars less in state aid than they had anticipated.
The legislative services director for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, James J. Finley, said: ''Every dollar they don't get in state aid, towns are going to have to make a decision: 'Do I cut services? Do I raise taxes? Or do I do some combination of both?' '' .
Mr. Finley said his group's analysis of the Governor's budget showed only a 2.4 percent increase in state aid to towns this year, less than half of the rate of inflation and down even more from what local officials had expected and, in some cases, built into their budgets based on state promises.
''The hits are on the education side, mostly,'' Mr. Finley said. Towns expected an $87.7 million increase in education cost-sharing grants, as required by law. But Mr. O'Neill has proposed a $44.9 percent increase, about 5.4 percent. For special education, the statutes called for an increase of $38.7 million this year, but the Governor's budget allots the towns just $22.5 million more.
 
Some Bright Spots
''That special-education money is reimbursement for money towns already spent, money they thought they were guaranteed, and now they're not going to get it,'' Mr. Finley said.
Revenue sharing has been eliminated, a loss of $10 million, and non-education grants are down $5 million, or 1.2 percent, he said.
Some of the bright spots in an otherwise bleak budget, Mr. Finley said, are increases in money for drug treatment and enforcement, to $12.5 million from $3.5 million; infrastructure grants, up to $67.5 million from $66 million; recycling grants, up from to $6 million from $2 million, and payments in lieu of taxes for private colleges and hospitals, to 50 percent of the tax they would otherwise pay, up from 40 percent.
But the bad news could make an already difficult situation worse for municipalities. Mr. Sullivan said that in the 1989 fiscal year, when state spending was considerably more generous, nine towns posted a municipal fund deficit.
The towns must report to the Municipal Finance Advisory Commission under the 1979 law that established it in the wake of Waterbury's fiscal problems. Officials in that city, however, are buoyed this year by the news that Waterbury finished the 1989 fiscal year with a $5.4 million surplus.
 
Matter of Accounting
Mr. Sullivan said the deficits posted so far range from $8,700 in Canaan to $1.6 million in Stratford.
In New Britain, one of the cities on the 1989 deficit list, the finance director, John Jedrzekczyk, said the shortfall is really an accounting deficiency. New Britain counts money paid to teachers in July and August against the fiscal year in which it is paid, while the state counts the funds against the previous fiscal year, he said.
The difference would be significant only if the city ''went out of business,'' Mr. Jedrzekczyk said.
Mr. Sullivan said: ''Normally, you try to keep 4 to 5 percent of your annual budget in your fund balance. But there doesn't seem to be any town in a really serious situation. If a town ran negative fund balances four out of the last five years, you have to look a little closer.''
In a small town, he said, having an unanticipated special-education student can put it in the red for one year. And some larger Fairfield County towns have had their finances disrupted when corporations picked up and moved out.
 
Correction Plans
''The things we look at are whether the towns have had a lot of deficits and the size of those deficits,'' Mr. Sullivan said.
This year for the first time, the Municipal Finance Advisory Commission will have the authority to call in towns that have financial problems and get an explanation of what they are are doing to correct the situation. Mr. Sullivan said he expects the first towns to be called in later this year, after the regulations become final, although he declined to speculate which towns might be the first.
Among the likeliest contenders are New Haven and Bridgeport. When John C. Daniels won election as Mayor in New Haven last November, the incumbent Mayor, Biagio DiLieto, was projecting a $3.7 million shortfall in the city's $235 million deficit.
But last month, Mr. Daniels announced the actual gap would be about $11.7 million, in part because departments are expected to spend $8.4 million more than budgeted and because anticipated revenues were overly optimistic.
The Mayor has ordered an immediate halt to overtime in an attempt to get control over expenses.
 
Cutting Fire Service
New Haven's Fire Chief, John P. Reardon, said he will not be able to authorize overtime when the vacation season starts in April.
''People might not like it, but it might mean eventually taking companies out of service,'' he said.
''When you get down to a certain point, you have to bring people back on overtime no matter what it's going to cost,'' Chief Reardon said. The department's job over the next few weeks, he said, is to determine just how low staffing can go.
At the Public Works Department, Mr. Funk said officials are hoping that if snow has to fall, it arrives between 8:30 A.M. and 4:30 P.M., Monday to Friday.
''Any bad weather, obviously, and we have to go out and plow,'' Mr. Funk said. ''But we're more careful about the use of overtime. If it's a real emergency, that's one thing. But if it's not, we find some alternative.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SEATTLE;
A Condo Plan For Downtown

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

 BODY:
A $16 MILLION, 70-unit condominium project - the first major new condominium proposed since the early 1980's - is being planned for a downtown site by the Hammond-Pacific Development Company.
The plans call for a 26-story tower, called One Pacific Tower, at 2000 First Avenue and Virginia Street in the Denny Regrade area. The area, a little more than a square mile, was once hilly but was leveled for development around the turn of the century and named for David Denny, a city founder. Instead, it became a wasteland of bars and parking lots. 
Officials hope that the condominium attracts more residential complexes to the neighborhood, which abuts the downtown core. If that happened, people would be able to live, work, dine and attend cultural activities there. In the last two years, 753 rental apartments have been built downtown and, as the effects of radical changes in 1985 in the municipal code became increasingly manifest, 3,700 new units have either gone into construction or into the approval process.
Travis Hammond, president of Hammond-Pacific, announced the project a month ago and said he has reservations of interest for half the units even though prices have not been set. One-bedroom units will be 1,150 square feet, two-bedrooms 1,550 square feet and three-bedrooms 2,250 square feet, each with a den. There will be a health spa and ground-floor shops.
Condominiums have not fared well here. About 600 units were built in the late 60's and early 70's, but sales dragged and it took most of the 70's to sell them. Developers who built more units got squeezed financially when interest rates soared in the early 80's.
''We've tried to make it easier for residential developers,'' said Rebecca Herzfeld, manager of the city's code development and coordination. In 1985, the city revamped the municipal code to encourage housing and low-rise commercial construction and ban high-rise commercial building in the Denny Regrade. In return for building housing there, developers were granted higher commercial densities elsewhere in the city.
''People who had been holding onto land, hoping values would rise as sites for office towers, now are turning to housing instead,'' Ms. Herzfeld said.
The city also streamlined the permit process to lessen delays when several agencies were involved. One of the changes provided for a master-use permit, an umbrella permit for zoning, land use and environmental elements. Mr. Hammond has applied for one and hopes to begin construction this summer and be ready for occupancy by the fall of 1991.

HEADLINE: PANAMA: OUR DANGEROUS LIAISON

BYLINE: By THOMAS POWERS; Thomas Powers, the author of ''The Man Who Kept the Secrets: Richard Helms and the CIA,'' is completing a book on Germany's failure to develop atomic bombs during World War II.

 BODY:

DIVORCING THE DICTATOR
America's Bungled Affair With Noriega.
By Frederick Kempe.
480 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95.
 
OUR MAN IN PANAMA
How General Noriega Used the United States - and Made Millions in Drugs and Arms.
By John Dinges.
Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: Random House. $21.95.
Just about everything the journalists Frederick Kempe and John Dinges have dug up about Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's life so far was at one time an official secret in Washington, classified in the interest of American national security. It is not hard to see why. Just about everything he did for us as an intelligence czar and, later, as dictator of Panama is an embarrassment - sometimes painful to acknowledge - and a trifling fraction of what he allegedly did for himself led to his being brought in chains to a Florida prison. 
The arrest was long delayed and notoriously difficult. Nearly two years after General Noriega was indicted on drug-trafficking charges by two separate grand juries in Florida - years in which he ostentatiously thumbed his nose at the United States and tightened the screws on opponents at home - President Bush finally sent the Army after him. What followed was the largest American military operation in nearly 20 years, cost the lives of 23 United States soldiers and several hundred Panamanians and set the stage for another generation of Latin American resentment toward the colossus of the north. The long history - there'll be a pop quiz later - of how the Americans recruited, paid, lectured, excused, protected and finally overthrew General Noriega with a bulldozer's finesse is the heart of the instructive tale told by Mr. Kempe and Mr. Dinges in their new books, ''Divorcing the Dictator'' and ''Our Man in Panama.''
Both books were largely written before General Noriega's overthrow last December and show signs of haste to include some account of the invasion. Mr. Dinges has been content to tell that part of the story in a few pages; Mr. Kempe has a much longer and fuller account of General Noriega's fall from power. But the bulk of both books centers on the rise of General Noriega and his genius for making himself indispensable to Washington. Most of the action takes place in Panama, of course, but it is still very much a Washington story. Few of the characters, from President Bush on down, emerge with dignity intact.
When the secrets start to spill out in a Washington scandal, the first thing the ever-innocent citizen wants to know is how bad it's going to get. The worst of it - that is, the secrets the United States Government tried hardest to keep - looks like this: the Central Intelligence Agency recruited Mr. Noriega as an informer back in the 1950's while he was attending a Peruvian military academy. According to these accounts, the relationship grew as Mr. Noriega rose through the ranks of Panamanian military intelligence, especially after he helped Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera remain dictator of Panama in 1969.
What the C.I.A. got from Mr. Noriega, the authors say, was mainly information and logistical help; Panama served as the National Security Agency's principal listening post in Latin America. In the mid-1970's, the clever Mr. Noriega suborned a couple of United States Army sergeants who provided him with a menu of communications traffic that the National Security Agency intercepted, and he apparently passed it on to Fidel Castro, who was, of course, a principal N.S.A. target. When he found out about it, Gen. Lew Allen Jr., the head of the N.S.A. at the time, was furious and wanted to prosecute the sergeants, but George Bush, during his year as President Gerald Ford's Director of Central Intelligence in 1976, blocked the prosecution. He claimed that it was the Army that wanted to avoid prosecution, but the real reason seems to have been a desire to avoid the public embarrassment of a trial and to preserve Mr. Noriega's cooperation in other matters.
In the fall of 1976, the C.I.A. learned that Mr. Noriega had arranged some car bombings of United States targets in Panama. Torrijos hoped the bombings would persuade Washington to talk seriously about ownership of the Panama Canal. This seems to have sent a ripple of second thoughts through the intelligence community. It was no secret that Mr. Noriega was personally a nasty piece of work. The C.I.A. knew of several instances in which he had beaten up prostitutes, and in 1971 it received N.S.A. transcripts of Mr. Noriega joking over the radio that he'd learned never to throw a live man out of a helicopter - something he'd just done with a Roman Catholic priest who had offended a relative of Torrijos. No one said we had to like the guy. But handing over N.S.A. secrets to Fidel Castro and bombing American facilities in the Canal Zone was crossing the line.
In December 1976, Mr. Bush had lunch with Mr. Noriega in Washington, presumably to read him the riot act, according to Mr. Kempe and Mr. Dinges. But for reasons of expedience, Mr. Bush seems to have read it in a whisper. They met again in 1983, when Mr. Bush as Vice President was seeking Panama's support for the contras' back-country war in Nicaragua. Thereafter General Noriega referred to his friend the Vice President. Mr. Bush did not give his heart so easily. During the 1988 Presidential campaign, he denied ever having met General Noriega; after newsmen obtained a photograph of the two of them together, Mr. Bush conceded, well, maybe once or twice.
Trying to separate the white hats from the black hats is a hopeless task in the recent history of American diplomacy in Central America. In the case of General Noriega things began to get really sticky in the late 1970's when he sold arms to the Sandinistas and other leftist guerrilla groups in Central and South America. Typically, Mr. Noriega provided details of these shipments to C.I.A. friends, who used them to warn President Jimmy Carter of the leftist threat. Other friends of Mr. Noriega's in the State Department and Pentagon warned him that Florida authorities planned to arrest him for gun running. Mr. Kempe and Mr. Dinges say that Washington was grateful when Torrijos agreed to give the Shah of Iran a home for three months in early 1980, but at the same time United States officials were worried that Torrijos was turning leftward, growing closer to Fidel Castro. In July 1981, Torrijos was killed in a plane crash; rumors at the time held that General Noriega had murdered him. In September 1985, General Noriega arranged the brutal murder of Hugo Spadafora, a Panamanian who had publicly charged General Noriega with drug trafficking. Once again the National Security Agency overheard General Noriega discussing the crime. In 1987 one of his allies turned against him and claimed that not only had General Noriega murdered Torrijos but that the United States helped him do it.
Question, true or false (counts 10 points on your final grade): Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was an ''asset'' of the Central Intelligence Agency?
This is the sort of stuff that keeps Government classification officers busy in Washington. Think of it as background music. In the United States, the main charges against General Noriega are that he helped the Medellin cartel of Colombia sell cocaine here and launder the proceeds through Panamanian banks. A number of General Noriega's former friends and associates are prepared to testify against him. His lawyers say they'll need two years to prepare for trial. Doubtless several tons of classified Government documents will be required as well. If the odds-makers in Las Vegas have any sense, they'll stand pat on even money for a conviction.
But a trial there will be, and unless you quit reading the newspapers you're going to be presented with many a twist and turn in the Noriega case over the next few years. It would be hard to think of better guides through the undergrowth than either of these two books. Both authors are journalists by profession, Mr. Kempe for The Wall Street Journal and Mr. Dinges for National Public Radio. Both have burrowed deeply into the huge published record and have talked to numerous Panamanian and American officials (the latter mostly unnamed). Most of the stories the authors tell are identical, but some are different. The explanation seems to be temperament. Mr. Kempe is a bit breathless; he can't wait to tell you all the incredible stuff he has learned. Mr. Dinges is more scholarly, speaks frequently of the legend and hearsay that invest popular accounts of General Noriega and is on guard to exclude anything doubtful from his book. Mr. Kempe, for example, gives a full and fascinating account of the 1983 meeting in Havana where Fidel Castro made peace between General Noriega and the Medellin drug cartel. The story comes from Jose Blandon, a former Noriega ally. Mr. Dinges thinks there are too many chronological and other discrepancies in the story to take it at face value, and he is not about to give house room to scandalous tales about Mr. Castro unless the evidence is overwhelming. In other instances, Mr. Dinges is prepared to entertain evidence that is underwhelming. If you choose Mr. Kempe, you can be sure you will hear everything, including a few bits of gossip of unproven rigor. If you read Mr. Dinges, you will get the details straight. But the truth is these two books complement each other nicely.
What emerges from them both is a portrait of General Noriega as a thoroughly repellent little man - superstitious, often drunk, sexually confused, bitterly envious of the well-born, the tall and the fair-skinned. He sought expensive treatment in Switzerland for his pockmarked cheeks, wore boots with high heels and hats with tall peaks, wrote a windy book called ''Psychological Operations,'' admired Adolf Hitler, shrank from the wrath of his wife, took beautiful women from fellow officers, flaunted a macho heterosexuality while showing more than a passing interest in good-looking young men, and betrayed everyone with the exception of his homosexual brother, who died young. He ran Panama from 1981 until last December but does not seem to have spent 10 minutes thinking about any of the ordinary issues of government.
But within this blighted figure there are certain gifts. General Noriega is intelligent, a shrewd judge of men, conscientious in taking care of business, a skillful intriguer. He extracted a lot of illicit money, but, except for routine personal luxuries, he seems to have spent most of it buying the loyalty of the Panamanian Defense Force.
He appeared to enjoy the personal humiliation of rivals and was responsible for several quite savage murders clearly intended to cow other opponents. But General Noriega is no Caligula. What he likes is politics - taking risks for power, then using it to win more. Being utterly without principle or long-term political goals, he had something to offer everyone and an uncanny ability to convince everyone - from Fidel Castro and the Sandinistas to his C.I.A. cronies - that they were getting the best of the deal. He helped the Medellin cartel through some tight spots and, for his anti-drug efforts, was showered with letters of commendation and grateful thanks by the Drug Enforcement Agency in Washington. He'd probably still be getting them if it weren't for those Federal prosecutors in Florida, who received zero encouragement from Washington. Their indictments didn't reveal anything the Government didn't already know, but they spilled it in public. That tipped the balance.
Essay question (counts 20 points on your final grade): Compare and contrast Soviet control over Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski of Poland with American ditto General Noriega. Who got the most for their money as long as the relationships lasted?
General Noriega's career isn't over yet; other books will be written when the record is complete. But these lives of the dictator are everything we might ask for so close to the event. Winded by the effort to keep up with the story, both authors haven't much to add about what it all means (because of the invasion both books were rushed to into print several months early). They think it is shocking that we supported this man politically for as long as we did, and they seem troubled and saddened by the failure of Washington officials to handle the divorce with greater finesse. With a little clear thinking in 1988 and less worry about what General Noriega meant to Mr. Bush's Presidential prospects, these books suggest that the Panamanian strongman might have been forced into exile without the loss of lives, the wrecking of the Panamanian economy, the smoldering Latin American resentment of our intervention in the region to clean up a mess we ourselves made. I have got no quarrel with any of that.
But ''Divorcing the Dictator,'' which was excerpted in Newsweek last month, and ''Our Man in Panama'' also left me longing for the old-fashioned seriousness, civility and rectitude of American leaders like Henry L. Stimson, who served as Secretary of State from 1929 to 1933 and later as President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Secretary of War. When the highest officials in the land express themselves in Mr. Kempe's book in particular it is to dismiss something with an obscenity. When Stimson closed down the State Department's code breakers in the 1920's he made himself immortal with the simple claim, ''Gentlemen do not read each other's mail.'' Incredibly, that was then true.
It was not until World War II that the United States plunged into its romance with the clandestine. But the glory days of American intelligence during the cold war have long since faded, covert action is now frequently the instrument of first resort, and Washington's hunger for secret knowledge, secret allies and secret advantage has become an addiction. As the authors show, General Noriega told us secrets about Fidel Castro and the Sandinistas, and he let us set up high-tech gear to collect secrets of our own. During a secret tryst with Lieut. Col. Oliver North in London in 1986, he said he could set off bombs for us in Nicaragua, even offered to assassinate Sandinista leaders. Bombs were O.K.; from assassination we shrank. It pleases me to report this. In Washington they said that our dealings with General Noriega were all intended to promote democracy in Central America. Mr. Kempe and Mr. Dinges suggest not. Our affair with General Noriega had no romance in it; the encounter was more like an orgy no one wants to remember in the morning.
Question, true or false (counts 70 points on your final grade): The United States has learned its lesson in Panama?

GRAPHIC: Drawing: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega (Raul Colon) (pg. 1); photo: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, center, in the custody of Federal agents last month. (Pg. 26)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: YOU'RE ONLY AS OLD AS WE SAY YOU ARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT H. BINSTOCK; Robert H. Binstock is the Henry R. Luce Professor of Aging, Health and Society at Case Western Reserve University.

 BODY:

HOW OLD ARE YOU?
Age Consciousness in American Culture.
By Howard P. Chudacoff.
Illustrated. 232 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press. $19.95.
Throughout our lifetimes American society has been age conscious. But this has not always been the case. Until the mid-19th century, Americans showed little concern with age. The one-room schoolhouse was filled with students of varied ages, and children worked alongside adults. 
In ''How Old Are You?'' Howard P. Chudacoff, a professor of history at Brown University and the author of ''The Evolution of American Urban Society,'' suggests that age consciousness in the United States began in the late 19th century, when schools began to set age limits and pediatrics was established as a medical specialty. At the same time, old age began to be identified as a separate stage of life, marked by specific age boundaries. Older people were set apart from the rest of society, because it was assumed that they could not keep up with the demands of an increasingly scientific and economically rationalized world.
Mr. Chudacoff offers a lively picture of the development of age consciousness in urban middle-class culture. We learn that age norms were expressed in popular magazines and songs for the first time in the late 1800's, and that ''the rise of the birthday celebration as a commercial enterprise'' began around the turn of the century with the arrival of the first birthday cards. In the early decades of the 20th century age norms intensified, especially for the young, as child psychology, organized sports, age-peer organizations such as the Girl Scouts, street gangs and legislation regulating child labor and the age of sexual consent were established. Even though youth and old age were recognized as distinct life stages by the turn of the century, middle age was not ''discovered'' until after World War I. Mr. Chudacoff traces the evolution of age norms through the latter part of the 20th century briefly, but accurately. He focuses particularly on the changes that affected the elderly - the development of old-age peer groups and the enactment of Federal programs that use age as a criterion for regulating and distributing benefits. For instance, he notes that pensions for older people were instituted publicly through the Social Security Act of 1935, which designated age 65 as an eligibility requirement for retirement benefits.
Has the ascendance of age norms been good or bad? Mr. Chudacoff believes that there are certain advantages to living in an age-conscious society. Individuals can derive a sense of belonging and a sense of self from their age-based peer group. And policy makers are better able to identify ''problem groups'' - infants, teen-agers, middle-agers, the old and the ''old old'' - who need specific kinds of government help.
The major drawback of such a society is ageism - the attribution certain characteristics to all persons in an age category. Mr. Chudacoff notes the differences among age norms and the realities of age-group behavior, and he is sensitive to discrimination. ''Like gender and race,'' he writes, ''age cannot be changed. To disadvantage individuals merely because they possess a particular characteristic, one for which they cannot be held morally responsible, offends traditional American sensibilities of fairness.'' As a particularly apt example, Mr. Chudacoff points to the recent proposal, by the biomedical ethicist Daniel Callahan, that life-saving care be categorically and officially denied to old people, regardless of their clinical conditions.
Although Mr. Chudacoff notes that age consciousness may have already peaked, he does not analyze whether age norms have changed in recent years, or why Americans are beginning to ignore such norms in increasing numbers. As the social psychologist Bernice Neugarten has observed, we are now becoming an increasingly ''age irrelevant society.'' The ages at which we are marrying, giving birth, entering the labor force, holding political office and engaging in a variety of other activities and roles conform less and less with age norms. The implications of these changes for our culture and social structure may be profound. Perhaps we can look forward to Mr. Chudacoff's next book for an analysis of them.

HEADLINE: New York State's Budget Troubles Are Rising, Approaching a Crisis

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 18

 BODY:
After two years of bad news about revenues, New York's financial problems appear to be growing increasingly dire. Financial analysts and even politicians are warning that dramatic steps will be needed to arrest the state's slide toward fiscal crisis.
''This is a very serious situation for the state,'' said Maury Cooper, a senior vice president of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which issues a credit rating that is crucial to the state. ''They have a structural imbalance in the budget. We have met with the state, and we have expressed our concern.''
The bad news about the state's finances has trickled out slowly over the last two years, as a slumping economy sent tax revenues further and further short of projections. Last week Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced that the state's budget shortfall for the current fiscal year had grown by $300 million, to more than $1 billion. 
 
Less Service, More Taxes
Over the next few months, the most noticeable effect of the state's budget problem is likely to be cuts in state programs and increases in taxes for New Yorkers. But more subtly, the budget problems threaten to undermine the stability of the state government. They also pose tremendous political risks for the Governor and state legislators, especially in a year in which all are up for re-election.
It now appears that the state will end the current fiscal year, which closes on March 31, in record financial trouble.
To meet expenses through the end of the year, the state is expected to issue more than $600 million in deficit notes, more than ever before. At the same time, the state's long-term, or accumulated, deficit, which Governor Cuomo at one time took credit for restraining, is expected to grow to almost $5 billion, a record high.
 
Overly Optimistic Projections
The state's financial troubles, once considered a temporary aberration, now appear to be a long-range problem. On Thursday the Governor's budget office missed the legal deadline for releasing its five-year projections of the state's finances. But people familiar with the calculations say the forecast shows the state running deficits for the next several years.
The growing gap between state revenues and expenses is in part a result of an unexpectedly sharp downturn in the New York economy, and in part a result of overoptimistic projections by the Cuomo administration. Since Mr. Cuomo took office in 1983, state spending has been growing, on average, at a rate that well exceeds inflation. But during the mid-1980's New York's economy was so strong that for several years the state had a budget surplus, prompting the enactment of a four-year income tax cut in 1987.
''The softening of the economy was more severe than the consensus forecasters had anticipated,'' Ms. Cooper of Standard & Poor's said. ''In hindsight it's clear that the state should have been more conservative in its estimates.''
 
Handwriting on the Wall
Administration officials insist that their projections were not influenced by politics. But many financial analysts say that the administration's forecasts were so optimistic that they can only be explained as an effort to delay coming to terms with the magnitude of the problem.
''The handwriting has been on the wall for some time,'' said one government economist, who asked not to be identified.
Perhaps to avert panic, Governor Cuomo has tried to play down the significance of the budget problem, referring to it with a rueful smile as an opportunity and a challenge. But some politicians have already begun to call it a crisis.
''This is as big a crisis as the fiscal crisis of the 1970's,'' said the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat. ''I don't know if people are writing it that way, but it really is.''
 
Coming at the Worst Time
The risks to the state of falling further into debt are substantial. Standard & Poor's has put a ''negative outlook'' on the state's credit, and many budget analysts fear that the state's credit rating could soon be lowered. If that happens, the state's financial problems will be magnified; it will become more expensive for the state to borrow money and more difficult for it to sell bonds to finance projects like road building.
''I certainly think it is time to think about getting ahead of this problem,'' said Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. ''Because once you have trouble selling a bond issue, you don't argue your way out of it.''
The state's financial decline could hardly come at a worse time - the end of the state's four-year political cycle. This year is a re-election year for the Governor, the State Comptroller and all 211 legislators, and it is traditionally the time when the urge to avoid painful decisions and negative headlines is most irresistible.
But perhaps in a reflection of just how sobering the state's financial problems are, the colorful partisan attacks that usually enliven the budget season have been subdued this year.
 
'We Have to Start Dealing With It'
Republican members of the State Senate have issued a steady stream of press releases condemning the Governor for spending too much and decrying his efforts to cancel the next phase of the state's scheduled income tax cut. But unlike in previous years, the Senate majority has not tried to portray the state's fiscal trouble as a ploy by the Governor.
''I think we are truly in a mess,'' said one Republican Senate official, who asked not to be identified. ''There's red ink as far as the eye can see. We have to start dealing with it, because the longer you wait, the more it kind of festers.''
The state's budget problems have also had a moderating effect on the relationship between the Democratic Governor and the Republican State Comptroller, who have barely been on speaking terms during the last few years. Recently, the two men began to hold regular conversations about the state's finances.
Three weeks ago, the Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, warned that unless the budget for the upcoming year was based on ''demonstrably conservative'' revenue estimates, he would not approve it. Such a move would create fiscal chaos by blocking the state's access to credit.
 
Not an Opportunity for Ridicule
In other years Mr. Cuomo, who often belittles the Comptroller as failing to follow through on his threats, might have used Mr. Regan's warning as an opportunity for ridicule. But not now.
''The Comptroller has said he's going to be very tough, which makes him a player,'' said the Governor's chief of staff, Gerald C. Crotty. ''The Governor and the Comptroller have spoken quite a few times.''
There is tremendous temptation in Albany to patch over the state's fiscal problems until after the November election. But financial experts are warning that the state has already relied too heavily on ''one-shot'' revenues like reserve funds, and there appears to be a growing consensus in Albany that the experts are right.
What this means is that substantial new taxes and spending cuts are likely this year, despite the election-year taboos.
 
Millions in More Fees and Taxes
''You're in the worst possible situation,'' Mr. Miller said. ''You've got to cut and tax, and there's nothing more politically unpopular.''
Mr. Cuomo has already proposed significant tax increases in the $51 billion spending plan he presented to the Legislature last month. Not only did he recommend canceling the next phase of the state's scheduled income tax cut, but he also proposed almost $800 million in increased fees and taxes, including a new tax on long-distance telephone calls. He also proposed several hundred million dollars in spending cuts.
But the new taxes and spending cuts will not be enough. Last week, the Governor lowered his revenue estimates for the upcoming fiscal year by $250 million, leaving a gaping hole in his spending plan.
Additionally, many financial analysts have started to question whether the Governor's budget relies too heavily on reserve funds and refinancing deals that may turn out to be damaging to the state. If that is the case, then still more taxes or spending cuts will be needed to balance next year's budget, which is supposed to be in place by April 1.
While it is still too early to tell how the Legislature will react to the state's financial problems, some options are quietly being discussed that in other years would never have been mentioned, including an increase in the state gasoline tax and cuts in financing for drug treatment.
''The standard options have been played out,'' Mr. Regan said. ''I'm really concerned, and I think others are very nervous, too.''

HEADLINE: Many in Medicine See Rules Sapping Profession's Morale

SERIES: Doctors In Distress
Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
Even the most staid audience of doctors applauds with vigor when Dr. Arthur Caplan gets to the part about Gulliver and the Lilliputians.
In speeches around the country, Dr. Caplan compares Gulliver, the mythical traveler, to today's doctors, who have awoken to find themselves pinned to the ground by hundreds of 6-inch-tall Lilliputians.
In his modern parable the Lilliputians are not imaginary islanders but the growing number of official and unofficial regulators - insurance companies, government agencies, malpractice lawyers and employers - that make the doctor feel trapped.
 
Chained by 'Munchkins'
''They love that analogy,'' said Dr. Caplan, the director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota. ''They applaud. They resonate. They come up to me and say, 'That's exactly what it's like out there, we're chained down by munchkins.' '' 
This feeling of being shackled by rules and overseers is nearly universal among doctors today, experts inside and outside the profession say. Doctors say they are overwhelmed by paperwork, prohibited by insurance companies from doing procedures and subjected to scrutiny by group employers like health maintenance organizations that can even include scheduling of restroom breaks.
 
Taking a Toll on Morale
There is a seemingly endless debate over whether all the supervision is necessary, with regulators saying doctors refuse to police themselves and doctors saying the level of policing is extreme. But both sides agree that it is taking its toll on the morale of the medical profession.
A poll taken last year by the Gallup Organization for the American Medical Association found that nearly 40 percent of all doctors probably or definitely would not go to medical school if they were in college today. The most common reason was government or insurance regulations that ''interfere with doing my job'' and cause a ''lack of autonomy,'' which was cited by 27 percent of the respondents.
''I've become irrelevant,'' said Dr. Joseph J. Merigo, a Boston doctor who bought a laundromat and is looking for a small restaurant to buy so he can close his medical practice. The last straw, he said, was when he had to send a patient home without treatment for several days because a new state rule required tests before the treatment and the insurance company refused to pay for them without a second opinion.
''Medicine is not really the profession that it was,'' he said. ''The regulators make up a formula, and they don't include the doctor in that formula. We no longer make important clinical judgments.''
These feelings are causing some concern but little alarm among those who regulate and study the medical profession.
''Accountants leave, lawyers leave, businessmen walk away from their jobs,'' said Bruce C. Vladeck, the president of the United Hospital Fund, a philanthropic and research organization in New York City that specializes in health-care matters. ''The fact that a 50-year-old guy who's been doing well decides he doesn't want to buck the bureaucracy anymore, that's to be expected.''
Many observers believe that ''doctors brought this on themselves,'' in the words of Prof. Uwe Reinhardt of Princeton University, an expert in health-care economics. In 1965 when Medicare was formulated, he said, doctors refused to accept limits on the amount they could charge patients, so they ended up with limits on the clinical procedures for which they would be paid.
''The regulations that rain down on physicians are largely of their own doing,'' he said. ''If they had accepted a fee schedule their lives would be much easier.''
Medicine is, in fact, more regulated than ever before, a change that can be traced to 1965, when Medicare began. Since then, the yearly cost of health care in the United States has risen more than tenfold, to $550 billion or 11.1 percent of the gross national product in 1987, and nearly all the new rules have been aimed at controlling costs.
The autonomy of doctors eroded slowly for nearly two decades, but after 1983 the pace increased when the Government adopted a system that broke down all known diagnoses into 467 subgroups and set a price that Medicare would pay for each. The price for each type of care in these Diagnostic Related Groups is based on the expected average cost in the region for the care. Regardless of what the care really costs, that is all a doctor or a hospital will receive from Medicare.
In a poll conducted for the American Medical Association last year, 81 percent of the doctors surveyed said that D.R.G.'s had ''a significant impact on medical practice'' and two-thirds of those felt the impact was ''primarily negative.''
Soon private insurance companies were following the Government's lead. Most companies now require doctors to ask permission, in effect, for major, non-emergency hospitalization and procedures. If the company does not approve the care in advance, it will not pay. The extra paperwork is annoying, doctors say, but even worse, companies occasionally refuse to authorize treatment that a doctor thinks to be neccesary.
These changes, and others, have led to more sophisticated, and more public, ways to rate the performance of hospitals and individual doctors. In March 1986, the Federal Government for the first time released the mortality rates of Medicaid patients in hospitals nationwide. Last year, New York State began compiling statistics on the rates of Caesarean sections at hospitals and trying to reduce the number of the expensive and often unnecessary procedures at hospitals having high rates.
Although it may seem to some doctors that the rules were designed only to harass them, the real purpose is to allow payers to exert some control over sky-rocketing medical costs, at a time when state and Federal government budgets are hard pressed and the well-publicized abuses of some doctors add to those costs by doing unnecessary procedures.
''There are certainly doctors whose attitude is 'well, the insurance company is paying,' '' said Dr. Cary Sennett, who now works for an insurance company. ''We do have a responsibility to guard against that.''
Two years ago, Dr. Betty Halpern, an internist in Houston, volunteered to serve on the utilization review board of the The Travellers Companies, which reviews doctor bills that the insurance company considers excessive. She said she joined the group expecting to be outraged at the restrictive decisions of the insurance company.
Instead, she found, that while her group approved many of the disputed charges ''there were also physicians who would do things repetitively that were inappropriate. Certain specialties were worse than others,'' she said, ''and you could see who had taken a course on how to code their charges to be maximally reimbursed. I saw a need for some control.''
 
 
Who Decides?
 
Doctors Debating The Insurers
 Of all these external influences, those that second-guess the doctors' care seem to chafe the most. ''They don't allow you to make your own decisions, they expect you to follow theirs,'' said Dr. Michael Rosenthal, who specializes in internal medicine and gastroenterology in Branford, Conn, near New Haven. ''I was trained to practice medicine, not debate with insurance companies.''
Dr. Rosenthal is currently debating wth Medicare about $2,000 in care for a patient last spring. The elderly man was admitted to the hospital with a broken hip and then suffered numerous complications, including pneumonia and an instance of cardiac arrest.
The hospitalization lasted three months, and Dr. Rosenthal said he saw his patient every day. But Medicare payment was disallowed for a number of those days, after the Government said the patient did not need to be visited then. Recently Dr. Rosenthal spent several hours at the hospital reviewing the patient's chart and preparing a detailed memorandum to justify the visits that were questioned.
The Government and insurance companies frequently stipulate minimum requirements for certain operations: for example, in some states a patient's airway must be 80 percent obstructed to warrant a tonsillectomy. Surgeons must often obtain approval from insurance companies or Government agencies before starting a case.
Dr. Ralph Bard, a 42-year-old general surgeon in Tullahoma, Tenn., told the American Medical News, the newspaper of the American Medical Association, that medicine had been ''a big disappointment.'' In an interview, he said he performed emergency surgery last year on a young boy with heavy intestinal bleeding. Because he did not call before starting the operation, Medicaid payment of his fee was refused.
''The last thing on my mind as I prepared the child for surgery was calling Medicaid,'' he said. ''But now before I do any procedure, I phone my office manager and ask: Can I go ahead?'' Dr. Bard said he plans to leave medicine. ''I wouldn't do it over again, and I tell others not to,'' he said.
 
 
The H.M.O.'s
 
Controls Within the Profession
 While most of the wrath of today's doctors is directed at outside regulators from the Government and private insurers, they also complain of internal controls. Health maintenance organizations, which are groups of doctors who accept a yearly fee from an employer or individual in exchange for nearly unlimited health care, are becoming more numerous and more complicated. In 1970 there were 37 H.M.O.'s enrolling 3 million people. This January, there were 607 serving 32.5 million, or nearly 13 percent of the population.
H.M.O.'s regularly issue lists comparing their physicians for the time spent with patients and the amount of medications prescribed - with the clear message that those highest on the list are a financial drain on the group. All care beyond the flat fee paid for a patient is absorbed by the organization, while all unused fees are profit.
Dr. Halpern, the Houston internist who is now in private practice, left two H.M.O.'s in the last five years. ''They're trying to make rules for disease, which doesn't follow rules,'' she said.
Her decision to leave was due in part to the fact that one organization went so far as to schedule her restroom breaks. More important, she said, she was tired of the monthly lists showing how many lab tests, X-rays and consultations each doctor in the group had ordered and frustrated at being urged to spend as little time on each patient as possible.
''I would be confronted by my bosses on how long it would take me to do a physical,'' Dr. Halpern said. ''Why wasn't I more like Doctor X, who does it faster? The system doesn't reward people for being competent or good or up to date. It rewards them for being superficial.''
 
 
The Bureaucracy
 
The Paperwork Grows Rapidly
 Both a cause and a consequence of the growing number of players in the health industry is a growing number of administrators. An American Hospital Association booklet lists 200 health-care careers, and 52 of those are administrative. Similarly, a study by the Journal of Internal Medicine found that the numbers of health administrators increased nearly fourfold between 1970 and 1986, while the number of doctors increased by half.
Doctors tend to see these administrators as another obstacle to what needs to be done and another cap on their authority. Dr. Sally Faith Dorfman, is a New York gynecologist and now, as Commissioner of Health for Orange County, she is an administrator. She recalls the time she spent as the medical director of a clinic in the Bronx.
Dr. Dorfman still sees patients once a week ''to keep me from being an ivory-tower bureaucrat.'' And she speaks for many doctors when she questions the effectiveness of administrators who have never been doctors.
Some, but not all, administrators, she says ''are frustrated physicians, who, for whatever reason, family, finances, grades, didn't go to medical school, and these people now have the power to regulate doctors. Some might even admit say they always wanted to be a doctor. I think some may delight in being able to tell doctors what to do and not necessarily for the right reasons.''
The growing bureacracy also brings more paperwork, another source of frustration. Dr. Robert and Dr. Dennis Wagner are brothers and have been practicing in Shiner, Tex., with a population of 2,500 for nearly 30 years. They say they no longer enjoy it and spending 40 percent of their time on paperwork is one of the reasons why.
They recently bought a $75,000 computer system to handle their insurance forms. The computer ''doesn't eliminate the paperwork,'' Dr. Robert Wagner said. ''It just makes it neater.''
One Boston internist estimates he is 200 hours behind on his paperwork, and the thought of adding catch-up hours to his already overloaded schedule exhausts him. ''I'm afraid I'm going to burn out at the ripe old age of 35,'' he said. ''I know a lot of happy doctors, but none of them take care of patients. For $72,000 a year, this isn't worth it.''
 
 
The Consequences
 
Many Are Leaving In Frustration
 In fact, many doctors are leaving medicine entirely. Dr. Michael McCarthy, who works in an emergency room in Seattle, is trying to become a journalist, specializing in medical writing. ''I like the emotional side of medicine,'' he said. ''But this isn't about emotion anymore, it's a business. I'm not a businessman.''
Dr. Sennett graduated from Yale Medical School in 1983, worked as a doctor briefly, then joined Aetna Life and Casualty in Middletown, Conn., in July. ''I did my residency at a time when Medicare D.R.G.'s were being implemented,'' he said. ''I saw doctors under increasing obligation to justify their decisions to people who didn't understand and certainly were not interested in learning.''
He hopes that by ''working within the system,'' he can ''make the policy more rational,'' but says that ''a lot of doctors I meet at parties, and who know nothing about me, don't like me because I work for Aetna.''
Other frustrated doctors are staying, some because they cannot afford to leave. One 29-year-old New York-area obstetrician says she has soured on her profession because ''the Government and the malpractice lawyers are always looking over your shoulder.''
She has thought of such alternatives as starting her own medical-transcription service, pursuing a business degree or becoming a professional musician. But if she does any of these things she will have to pay about $78,000 for a ''malpractice tail'' to keep her covered until the statute of limitations runs out on claims over cases she has handled.
As New York State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod has been responsible for such policies as the regulations on resident hours, the publishing of statistics on Caesarean sections and the proposed universal health insurance for the state. He complains that doctors have failed to police themselves.
''Laissez-faire has not been successful,'' he said. ''The regulatory process has stepped into a void. Physicians are going to have to recognize that if there is to be less regulation there has to be a more effective level of peer review.''
Others have reached the same conclusion. In their book ''Quality Health Care,'' published last summer by the American College of Physicians, the editors Dr. Norbert Goldfield and Dr. David B. Nash warn that in the near future regulators will cross the line from monitoring performance to rewarding and punishing on the basis of that performance.
Already, they said an H.M.O. in Pennsylvania planned to pay physicians bonuses based partly on their performances in quality measurement scales. And the Health Care Financing Administration, which watches over Medicare, is proposing to rate individual physicians, as it does individual hospitals, and make the results public.
''Physicians have to take the lead and be responsible for themselves,'' Dr. Nash, an administrator at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, said in an interview. ''I would rather have other doctors doing this than someone more pernicious. It's inevitable.''
Said Dr. Axelrod: ''I suspect that in the future the pendulum will swing away from the extraordinarily high level of regulation. I think the medical community's begun to recognize that if there is to be less regulation there has to be a change in attitude.''
But if that change comes, it will be too late for some.
''So many of the people you most want to go into practice have already been driven out of it,'' said Dr. Sennett of Aetna. ''Many of my patients told me they were very sorry that I was leaving. I took that as very flattering. But I couldn't plan a career in private practice as I saw the world shaping up.''

HEADLINE: Chinese Students Remain a Human Rights Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The vote on the visa status of Chinese students studying in the United States came to be defined as a foreign policy issue, rather than a human rights issue or an immigration issue (front page, Jan. 26), yet technically it is not a foreign policy issue. Saying that the status of these students is a foreign policy issue and therefore should fall under the Presidential prerogative is to make their lives a pawn of diplomacy: if the Chinese leadership remains obstinate and uncooperative, we will punish it by stealing some of its intellectual capital (the part that wasn't massacred last June); if it behaves reasonably and cooperatively, however the President wishes to define those, we will be nice and give back its students to arrest and execute.
I am not saying that President Bush intends to do this. I am saying that by asserting that the visa status of Chinese students in the United States should be up to the President as a foreign policy issue, the Administration implicitly asserts that the President has the right to dispose of them as he wishes (as long as it is in ''the national interest,'' the ultimate justification for any foreign policy action and one Mr. Bush cited in lifting the ban on sensitive technology to China, through a sleight of hand that equates the economic interests of a few companies with the national interest). 
Congress obviously viewed the issue as foreign policy as well, for although the vote was eventually lost because it came to be perceived as attempted President-bashing by the Democrats, the original impetus behind the motion to override the veto was Congressional displeasure with Mr. Bush's China policy.
The President urged caution, or rather timidity, on this issue because he was afraid of offending his old friends in Beijing (Mr. Bush's choice of friends is suspect - Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega used to be counted among them), maintaining that the Chinese Government would retaliate if Congress passed this bill. But why should we always be worried about how Beijing will react? There are many more sanctions we could impose (or reimpose) in response to any retaliation, and they would be far more damaging to China than anything China could do to us. (Of course, this might cause some short-term losses to businesses with interests in China.) Why should we always be worried about offending China's leadership and bowing to its threats, while it feels free to do whatever it wants, knowing that we will not respond? If we are not confident in our ability to control China's policy over student exchanges, what makes us confident that we can control it on strategic military issues?
Mr. Bush fancies himself a China expert because he spent a year and a half there. However, in the two years I spent in China (which ought to make me more of an expert), I noticed that a lot of people who had spent some time in China still had no idea of what was going on. I find it hard to believe that Mr. Bush has a special insight into China that the rest of us do not. I find it easier to believe that he wants to do anything to avoid offending his old friends, who happen to be butchers and despots.
 
ROGER CLIFF
Princeton, N.J., Jan. 31, 1990
 
The writer is a doctoral candidate at the Woodrow Wilson School of Princeton University.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Castro's Last Stand

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
''Socialism or Death'' is now Fidel Castro's slogan, repeated at the opening and close of his speeches. He may be right, but it is not socialism that is ahead for Cuba.
After 30 years in power, Castro is this hemisphere's Ceausescu: more dictatorial than ever, refusing to save his nation from disaster ''even if we were left alone and were the last ones,'' he swears to defend a system that promised security but delivered tyranny.
From the start, he made his nation a dependency of the Soviet Union; the Castro economic system, which insures total control of the political system, guarantees permanent hard times for Cubans. 
This made for a kind of depressed stability as long as Moscow would pick up the bill. In 1988, that subsidy totaled nearly $7 billion in hard currency, and did not decline last year; in return, Castro sent an army of 50,000 men to serve Soviet interests in Africa.
The adventure in Angola helped Castro beyond the rental of his troops: it kept busy an officer corps likely to turn against him. Last year, he executed Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa and other potential coup leaders on trumped-up drug charges.
We may one day see, at the trial of the deposed strongman of Panama, how Mr. Castro's regime profited from that drug trade; we will also learn how Cuban fishermen used Panamania cutouts to evade the U.S. trade embargo.
But the reason for Castro's coming downfall is the economic crisis facing his Soviet sponsors. An academician's article in Muskovskie Novosti revealed that Moscow is spending proportionately six times as much as the U.S. on foreign aid, the largest portion of this unsustainable cost of empire going to Cuba.
That sort of Soviet article is now banned in Cuba. The Cuban dictator has said he banned such publications of perestroika as Moscow News ''without vacillation'' because they cast aspersions on Lenin and socialism itself.
This unfraternal act was caused by delays in delivery of Ukrainian wheat and the oil Moscow arranges for Venezuela to deliver. Bread prices have jumped a third in Havana, and rationing has begun in the countryside.
In another self-defeating response, Castro has delayed shipments of fruit and sugar to the Soviet Union, where those items are especially scarce. Cuba has become a satellite trying re-entry into this world without a heat shield.
Some evidence of mutual cooperation remains. Moscow has inexplicably begun delivery of MIG-29 jets, making Cuba more dangerous in the Caribbean. Moscow has also failed to accelerate the removal of the remaining Cuban mercenaries from Angola, where the continued presence of more than 20,000 of Castro's troops has encouraged the Communist Government to break the truce in a last-ditch effort to defeat Jonas Savimbi's Unita.
Secretary of State James Baker, in his finest hour before the Soviet parliamentarians, hammered away at the MIG shipments and the ''intolerable'' Soviet subsidy of Cuba. By recalling Arthur Koestler's ''Darkness at Noon,'' he nicely alluded to the confession of General Ochoa at his show trial.
The Soviets should know by now that they can expect great resistance to any U.S. economic cooperation while they subsidize Castro's regime with money and food the Soviet consumers desperately need.
Cuts in Moscow's subsidy are inexorable. That means more rationing and higher inflation on the way. Cuban troops now exiled to Angola are coming home, further separating the army from the party.
The other day, a nervous Central Committee in Havana promised a ''critical analysis'' of Cuba's ''lack of freshness.''
But in an oblique warning to the army, it circled Castro's wagons, pledging to ''perfect'' its grass-roots organization that controls the country - the Committees for the Defense of the Revolution.
If help from Moscow turns to hostility; if the dispute over Cuba's $6.8 billion debt means that no fresh loans are granted by other sources; and if the U.S. turns up the economic heat both directly and through Castro's longtime sponsor, then a great many Cubans are going to get both hungry and angry.
Where is the Cuban Sakharov, Havel, Walensa, Fang Lizhi? Dissidents exist, though few are publicized; but the notion of a docile, brainwashed Cuban populace devoid of heroes offends logic and conflicts with reality.
We need incite nobody, though the dictator rails at our broadcasts as ''imperialist ideological tele-aggression.'' The Cuban people will turn against repression sooner rather than later. Freedom's tide will touch the sands of Havana.

HEADLINE: William C.W. James, Lawyer, 70

 BODY:
William C. W. James, a former board chairman of the Salmagundi Club, the oldest professional artists' club in the United States, died Saturday in Fishguard, Wales, where he had retired in 1987 after working in New York. He was 70 years old. 
Born in Wales, Mr. James came to New York City with a British law degree after World War II. He earned additional degrees in accounting and economics from Columbia and New York Universities.
Mr. James was board chairman of the Salmagundi Club on lower Fifth Avenue from 1977 to 1987. He was a past director of the English-speaking Union and of the St. George and St. David Societies. He was made an Officer of the British Empire by Queen Elizabeth in 1977.
There are no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: Vero Beach: Dark Clouds Over Paradise

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16

 BODY:
This is not a town that stops everything to bow to royalty.
For one thing, a visit by the Prince of Wales, who arrived here Friday, is not a once-in-a-lifetime event; it is his second stop here this year.
For another, the town has other things on its mind these days: a lockout that has shut the Los Angeles Dodgers' spring-training camp to all but minor leaguers; a drought; layoffs in its citrus and aircraft manufacturing industries. 
Prince Charles came to town to play polo; the money raised by the two matches will benefit wildlife conservation in Africa, for the most part. But it seems to some people here that there are worthier causes closer to home.
 
'We Don't Want Him'
''We don't want him,'' said George Marchant, a 78-year-old former valve salesman from Boston. He said the Prince and his polo match do not change the poverty that persists amid the wealth, the million-dollar houses and the polo club.
''Some of them don't have enough to live on,'' said Mr. Marchant, waving an arm toward the poor neighborhoods to the northwest.
Off U.S. Highway 1, near the citrus fields and packing plants north of town, unemployed men sit under banyan trees, playing dominoes.
The Christmas freeze cut the harvesting season almost in half, and Piper Aircraft, one of Indian River County's biggest businesses, has laid off about 575 people. The year looks bleak for local workers.
''It'll be disastrous,'' said Dexter Francis, a 32-year-old outreach worker for the Economic Opportunity Council.
Even in hard times, people here could turn to the Dodgers, who have been training in Vero Beach since 1948 - it's not called Dodgertown for nothing. ''It's a big thing in this town, the Dodgers,'' said John Rolle, a 50-year-old construction worker. ''When they come here, it's just like they're playing the World Series.''
But while the Dodgers are likely to be back, if not this spring then another, other things the town has lost cannot be reclaimed.
Owners of citrus farms, their crops decimated every few winters by frosts like the one this past Christmas, have begun putting their properties on the market for development.
''They figure they can make more money by selling it off for development,'' said Maggy Bowman, an Indian River County Commissioner who is head of the Pelican Island Audubon Society.
At South Beach, Charlie Battles surveyed a parking lot full of cars with license plates from Canada and the Northeast.
''All this was woods and swamplands,'' said Mr. Battles, a city parks maintenance worker who grew up in Vero Beach in the 1940's. ''They puffed sand in and built it up. That was in the 50's, and they're still doing it.''
 
'It's Woken Up, I'm Afraid'
People who have lived here for years are beginning to wish that things had not gone so fast. The county's population has grown from 11,872 in 1950 to about 83,000 now, not counting winter visitors.
''We didn't have a mall, we didn't have a Pizza Hut, a K Mart, a Wal-Mart,'' said Shirley James, a front-desk clerk at the 90-room Driftwood Resort, one of a string of waterfront hotels lining Ocean Avenue on Orchid Island. ''The only shopping we had was downtown.''
Mrs. James, who spoke while attending to three people at the counter, moved to Vero Beach from Memphis almost two decades ago.
''That's why we came here, because it was a sleepy little town,'' she said. ''It's woken up, I'm afraid. People who've lived here a lot longer than I have are sad about it.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prince Charles with Jorie Kent, right, his hostess, Cathryn Hilker of the Cincinnati Zoo and a cheetah at a wildlife exhibition in Vero Beach, Fla., before a polo match to benefit the fight to protect wildlife in Africa. The cheetah is a threatened species and lives in the wild only in eastern and southern Africa. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: DOCTORS IN DISTRESS;
Some Point to Massachusetts as Extreme of Regulation

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
In 49 states, grumbling private doctors are consoled by the fact that the regulation could be worse: they could be practicing in Massachusetts. In the name of controlling costs and improving access to medical care, that state has led the nation in enacting strict laws to govern doctors' practices and limit their fees.
But many say the good intentions have backfired. The American Medical Association estimates that more than 10 percent of doctors in private practice have left the state since 1985; the figure may be as high as 30 percent in some specialties, although a special state commission says the figures are difficult to determine. 
Doctors say three laws make practice in Massachusetts financially difficult:
* Limits on doctors' bills. Doctors have to accept as payment whatever an insurer, including Medicare or a private insurance company, will pay and cannot bill patients for the rest.
* Forced Medicare participation. To be licensed, physicians have to accept all Medicare patients.
* Retroactive malpractice payments. The state's Joint Underwriting Association lost money through much of the 1970's and early 1980's, and doctors are paying extra premiums to make up for these losses. According to Medical Economics magazine, a urologist was charged $16,000 for 1989 insurance and $15,000 in retroactive premiums.
With doctors' incomes in Massachusetts running 15 percent below the national average, many doctors are leaving.
At Dr. Scott Fox's ear, nose and throat office in Falmouth on Cape Cod, one of the areas hardest hit, one doctor retired, another moved to New York and Dr. Fox is the only ear, nose and throat doctor at his hospital. Departures by doctors have left the hospital emergency room without a general surgeon to cover one night in five.
Last year Massachusetts convened a special Physician Supply Commission to study the problem. That was in part to respond to legislators' claims that constituents in some areas were having trouble finding doctors. and to claims by hospitals in some parts of the state that they could not fill their staffs, said Matthew Fishman, Massachusetts Assistant Secretary for Health and Welfare.
Because of data problems, the report the commission issued in July, reserved judgment about whether the number of doctors practicing in Massachusetts was dwindling but acknowledged that ''there was significant room for improvement'' in the supply of doctors, especially on Cape Cod and in the western part of the state, Mr. Fishman said.
Among the commission's recommendations were incentives to practice in areas with few doctors and a pilot project to allow some doctors' bills to exceed insurance payments. The report ''did a lot of consciousness-raising in the Legislature and let them know that doctors here were really angry,'' Mr. Fishman said.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 5, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 19 about regulation of doctors in Massachusetts misstated two provisions of state law.
One limits the fees that Massachusetts doctors can charge elderly patients to the amount permitted under the Medicare program, but the doctors are indeed permitted to bill patients - for 20 percent of the total.
Other provisions require that physicians who treat one Medicare patient must thereafter accept all Medicare patients and Medicare's fee schedule.
But the law does let doctors refuse to participate in Medicare entirely, by not seeing elderly patients.

HEADLINE: Maine's Rafters See New White-Water Battle

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUGUSTA, Me.

 BODY:
John Abbott used to spend summers leading rafting trips through the white-water rapids of the Kennebec River in Maine. Now he is a lawyer trying to rewrite state law, which he says gives long-established rafting outfitters like his former company an advantage over their fledgling competitors.
A bill written by Mr. Abbott and submitted by his local representative would revamp the way the state grants permission to conduct rafting trips on Maine's premier white-water rivers, the Kennebec and the Penobscot, by giving the same number of trips to every qualified outfitter.
Outfitters are now permitted trips according to a formula based on their experience, safety records, financial investment, quality of service and whether they completed most of the trips allowed in the previous year. 
The owners of several of the largest rafting companies in Maine say changing the formula would wreak havoc in a highly competitive industry.
 
Small Companies Complain
Owners of some smaller companies say the current restrictions are making it impossible to run a profitable business.
Priscilla Edwards, who operates a small rafting business with her husband, Brad, in Greenville, said, ''It has just become a system that protects the larger companies, their interests, their investment.''
From meager beginnings in the mid-1970's, commercial white-water rafting has grown into a $35 million-a-year industry in Maine, counting trips and other services. Last summer, 50,000 people signed up for the wet-and-wild rides in inflatable rafts - an experience that some compare to riding a particularly riled bronco through a rainstorm.
The congestion drove the state to limit commercial rafting on the two rivers in 1983 to preserve the environment and insure access for fishing and private rafting. The limits apply only on summer weekends, which are by far the most popular time for the trips.
Of the 27 outfitters licensed in Maine, 13 have all the prized weekend allocations.
There is no consensus among the states or Federal agencies on how to regulate river use. Some states do not impose any limits, while others use a lottery system. Still others restrict the number of outfitters, leaving almost no opportunity for new businesses.
 
'A Classic Problem'
''It's a classic problem in white-water rafting,'' said Tim King, a management analyst for the Colorado Parks Department. The agency is studying a system for the Arkansas River, one of the most popular white-water rivers in the nation. ''Once you get into a regulatory mode, you're going to step on somebody's toes.''
The trouble with Maine's current law, several Government officials said, is that it tried to encourage development of new businesses and protect existing businesses at the same time.
''You can't accomplish both,'' said Alan Clark, who oversees white-water rafting for the Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife.
Jay Schurman, owner of Unicorn Rafting Expeditions, the second-largest outfitter in Maine, acknowledged that the law protects long-established companies, but said he thought the companies had earned that protection.
''Is it fair to take away the business these businesses have built?'' Mr. Schurman asked. ''How are you going to have business stability without giving existing businesses an advantage?''
 
Concern Over New Proposal
He said Mr. Abbott's proposal would hinder planning by rafting concerns because outfitters would not know how many customers they would be allowed to carry from one year to the next. He said the law would also make it more difficult for companies to borrow money from banks because they could not guarantee a certain level of business every year.
But State Representative Judith Foss, who introduced Mr. Abbott's bill in the Maine House of Representatives, said: ''I keep hearing they've had capital investment, they've bought land, sporting camps. But my question is, Why doesn't any other business have that same concern? If a dairy builds a new building, does that mean they've earned protection from competitors?''
The outfitters, meanwhile, have introduced their own legislation, which would help smaller businesses by cutting five weeks from the period governed by the limits, now May 18 through Sept. 18. The proposal would also automatically allow an outfitter to offer the same number of trips in successive years if it met a certain minimum.
''Some of these people have become quite wealthy in a business regulated with laws that protect existing businesses,'' Mr. Abbott said. ''There's nothing inherently wrong with making money as long as you go out and slug it out in the free market.''
