HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
New Crops For Coca: A Harvest Is Unlikely

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Before he left Washington earlier this week for his summit conference on drugs with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, President Bush had some blunt words for the farmers who produce coca, the raw material from which cocaine is refined.
''Grow another crop,'' the President said before departing for Cartagena, Colombia. ''Grow one that has a useful purpose and not an immoral purpose in the world.''
Treating addicts, jailing traffickers, stopping shipments of narcotics - all those things would be less important to the war on drugs, of course, if less coca were grown. That was a central tenet of policy in the Reagan Administration, in which a fellow named George Bush was the designated hitter against drugs. Under a pilot program promoted as a considerable success, the United States has paid a few Bolivian farmers not to grow coca - a new twist on the old farm-subsidy system here at home. 
President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia, the host of the meeting, called for ''viable economic alternatives'' for those who grow coca plants. President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia said he sought ''coca reduction in exchange for development aid.'' And President Alan Garcia of Peru warned that ''massive economic resources are needed'' if crops are switched because coca ''is enormously important to our economy.''
After the conference Thursday, Mr. Bush agreed, in language vague even by the standards of communiques, ''to support the Andean parties' efforts to counteract the socioeconomic impact of an effective fight against illicit drugs'' and to take part in joint ''actions to bring about a net reduction in the illegal cultivation of coca.'' So far, so good. But a top White House adviser says that while Mr. Bush would like to convince Bolivian and Peruvian farmers to grow something else, he now sees stopping the flow - and not subsidies - as the key to success in the war on drugs. That explains, the adviser said, why the President is still working on ways to use American military resources to stop the flow of drugs despite calling off plans to send an aircraft carrier to patrol the Colombian coast when Colombia protested.
The adviser, who spoke on condition of anonymity, questioned whether it was moral to subsidize farmers for obeying the law by ceasing to grow an illegal crop.
But the big problem with subsidies is money. An effective crop-replacement plan would cost far more than Mr. Bush is prepared to commit.
It is not simply a question of getting farmers to grow something else; that might be feasible, given the relatively modest amounts of money they earn. Nor is it a question of lifting trade barriers against things they do grow, like coffee or cut flowers. The serious money goes to the middlemen, the people between those who grow coca and those who use cocaine, and they pour much of their ill-gotten gains into other businesses. Without narcotics, that spending would dry up, undermining already marginal economies.
Mr. Bush has promised $2.2 billion in military, economic and law-enforcement aid to the three countries over five years. One report says $30 million would be available to ease the farmers' shift from one crop to another. But Rensselaer W. Lee 3d, who wrote ''The White Labyrinth: Cocaine and Political Power,'' published last year by Transaction Books, said the amount of aid under discussion ''doesn't even begin to compensate'' for what those countries stand to lose.
It will have to do, though, at least for now. As in so many areas, Mr. Bush is hemmed in by a political calculation, that the American people will not stand for increased taxes, and by a strategic calculation that it would be dangerous to divert money from the military to fight drugs.
Responding in Cartagena to the calls for more spending on subsidies, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, used a phrase that has come to sound like the theme song of the Bush Administration.
''We don't have unlimited resources,'' he said.
True enough. No Administration has ever had bottomless pockets. But what the United States can afford to spend on any given program depends more than anything else on how high a priority it is given. And it is Mr. Bush, after all - the man who promised in his Inaugural Address to ''make the hard choices'' and who said of the drug epidemic, ''This scourge will stop'' - who sets national priorities these days.

HEADLINE: Overnight Mail Service To End in Some Areas

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Trading off speed for reliability, the Postal Service plans this summer to eliminate overnight delivery of first-class mail for millions of Americans.
When a letter is sent a short distance the Postal Service's goal is to deliver it overnight; that distance varies from place to place, but in many locations it includes mail within a city.
Starting this summer, the Postmaster General said in an interview, the boundaries of the areas in which mail is supposed to be delivered within one day will apply to 4 percent to 7 percent fewer letters. Express Mail, the service's premium overnight service, remains unchanged. 
At the same time, postal officials say, the service expects to raise its standard of reliability so that more mail will be delivered without the serious delays that have sometime occurred.
The changes would take place at a time when the Postal Service is seeking a 20 percent increase in the basic first-class postage rate, to 30 cents from 25 cents, to catch up with the rising cost of health-care benefits and other labor expenses that are expected to produce a record $1.6 billion deficit this year. Last year the service delivered 85.8 billion pieces of first-class mail.
Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said that he was not pleased about the size of the increase but that it was necessary to meet the statutory requirement that the Service be self-supporting.
''We are user-paid - to the penny,'' Mr. Frank said of the Postal Service, which was separated from the Government in 1971 and receives no tax support. Rate increases require approval of the Postal Rate Commission, a Federal agency.
 
Plans to Cut Costs
He pledged to reduce future cost increases to one or two percentage points a year less than the inflation rate, beginning in 1990. He said costs rose less than the rate of inflation in the first quarter of the current fiscal year.
Mr. Frank also played down the importance of what he called the pulling back of one-day deliveries, to begin June 30.
''It's not a degradation of service,'' the Postmaster General said. In exchange for slower delivery of some mail, he added, ''we've got to have better consistency.''
Mr. Frank said that last year the new standards, including reduction in one-day deliveries, were introduced in the New York metropolitan area as an experiment and that they had produced almost no complaints.
 
Service Change in New York
In the past, the overnight delivery area for New York City extended north to Poughkeepsie and Monticello, south to Red Bank and New Brunswick, N.J., and included all of Long Island and a small part of Connecticut to Stamford. Under the new standards, the boundaries will be restricted to the city's five boroughs, where one-day delivery will continue.
Because of the continuing experiment, there should be no noticeable effect in New York regional service when the changes begin, officials say. In 1989 the percentage of New York area first-class mail that was delivered in one day climbed to 93 percent from 89 percent.
Elsewhere the effect is expected to be modest, though some newspapers and other publications have strenuously opposed the change because it could mean a loss in timeliness for their subscribers.
These adjustments in standards, the first in 20 years, are a result, in part, of new roads and population growth and, in part, are a response to customer surveys. While customers appreciate fast delivery, the Postal Service found, ''for first-class mail to be considered excellent, it must meet specific delivery times with a high degree of consistency.''
New standards for second-day and third-day delivery areas are scheduled to be implemented effect Sept. 22.
The changes seek to provide ''highly consistent'' overnight delivery within the same city and in other areas where volume warrants. Two-day delivery would be to all other locations in the home state, in nearby states within ''reasonable'' reach by surface transportation, and in other areas where volume warrants and timely air routes are available. All other destinations would have three-day delivery.
A tiny proportion of first-class mail - perhaps two-tenths of 1 percent - is to be switched to next-day status from second-day, the Service said. Among the areas where service will be improved are the Albany-Poughkeepsie area in New York and the Oshkosh-Madison area in Wisconsin.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 20, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a planned reduction in postal service included in some copies an incorrect example of the effects of the cutback. Letters mailed within the same city will still be delivered the next day.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Czechoslovakia;
Havel, U.S. Bound, 'Going to Learn'

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Twenty-two years lie between Vaclav Havel's American visits, years of struggling for democracy and human rights under a repressive Government, years of persecution and prison.
His two decades as spokesman for the outlawed opposition and his leadership last fall of what he calls ''our velvet revolution,'' which peacefully overthrew Communist rule, conferred on the 53-year-old playwright such national backing that in December there was no other candidate when a new head of state was chosen.
So on Tuesday Mr. Havel will arrive on his second American visit, this time not to attend the premiere of one of his plays Off Broadway but as President of Czechoslovakia, to see President Bush. He is to travel to New York on Thursday, where a rock concert in his honor and a visit to the Museum of Modern Art are to be the highlights of his day. 
 
An Informal Way of Life
''We are not going to the United States to beg for big economic aid or loans or something similar,'' he said in an interview in his office in Prague Castle. ''We are going there to learn.
''We are going to learn from a democratic system like the one we enjoyed for only so brief a period, only 20 years, and lost. We can learn from American democracy. We can learn from a highly industrialized country, a highly developed education system and universities - from many spheres that can serve as examples to us.''
The President has not changed the informality of his writer's life; he has merely transferred its casualness to the august palace that was built for the Hapsburg emperors who ruled over Bohemia and then taken over by the democratic, Nazi and Communist leaders who followed them.
Mr. Havel puts on a suit and tie only for official foreign visitors of rank; he receives his other callers - his schedule is so full that much of it is in 15-minute segments - dressed as he would be in his apartment on the other side of the Vltava River, where only the secret police used to limit the number of callers. The President works in his intimidatingly sumptuous, high-ceilinged office in an open shirt and sweater.
To lessen the grandeur, Mr. Havel has moved from the immense hall in which his predecessor, Gustav Husak, a dogmatic Communist, worked to the smaller vastness that Mr. Husak used for his naps. To make himself feel more at home, the new tenant has surrounded himself with many modern paintings and sculptures.
 
A Home for Kitsch
''We thought we'd find a lot of Socialist Realist art, but it was worse,'' said Michael Zantovsky, the presidential spokesman. ''It was pure kitsch.''
The only examples of representational art that moved in with the new President are busts of Thomas G. Masaryk and Eduard Benes, the Presidents of the democratic prewar republic. The memory of both was consigned to oblivion under the Communists.
Mr. Havel has also brought with him many friends of his years as the country's leading and most frequently jailed dissident. His advisers and the specialists in karate who watch over his security form an inner circle of trusted men and women, around whom officials who did not stand aside from the old regime hold positions that may be of higher nominal rank.
One part of the job on which Mr. Havel seeks no advice is his public statements. He does all his own writing, asking help only in the search for exact quotations. He writes on weekends, at home or sometimes in the presidential manor in Lany, in the countryside near Prague.
The rest of the week Mr. Havel tends to be on the run - literally, for he trots even between the offices of the Castle - visiting as many places as he can and talking to the people. As his main duty until the elections tentatively planned for June, Mr. Havel sees the preservation of the respect that Czechoslovakia has gained for the orderly way in which it deposed a dictatorship.
 
'A Danger Almost of Chaos'
''There is a danger that rivalries and individual ambitions will emerge, negative human qualities,'' he said. ''People may throw the responsibility for all the incompetence of the past at one another's heads. There is a danger almost of chaos, I would say, unless some elements are introduced to prevent this. One is the spiritual - that is why I invited the Dalai Lama and the Pope.''
''This society has awakened, from the human and civic point of view,'' he said. ''But it has slept for so long and so deeply that on waking it still feels a little groggy, not yet in full command of its capacities. It is necessary somehow to watch over this awakening, to arouse the people to take charge of their spirit, to lead them back to a state of calm, mature, daytime vigilance.''
Rising, he added, ''I'll have more time to talk to you when I'm not President.'' Asked whether he would continue beyond the parliamentary elections, which he set as the limit of his presidency, he avoided an answer but said: ''I don't want to be President. I have a better profession.''
The President slipped into a black lumber jacket and ran off for a lunch engagement. On the back of the jacket, in green letters in English, it said, ''Awakenings.''

HEADLINE: Jackson Brings 'Message' From Mandela

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
Fresh from a trip to South Africa, the Rev. Jesse Jackson went to Harlem yesterday and asked black Americans to learn from the life of Nelson Mandela, who was released last week after almost three decades in prison.
''What is the message for New York?'' Mr. Jackson asked an overflowing crowd at Abyssinian Baptist Church at 138th Street between Lenox Avenue and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard. ''Nelson Mandela spent 27 years in jail because he defines freedom as the right to vote. And yet, there are almost 1.2 million African-Americans and Hispanics in this city who are not registered to vote.'' 
Earlier, Mr. Jackson spoke at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. When a high school student asked him what young people could do to help bring about change in South Africa, Mr. Jackson said, ''Be sober, be sane, be sensitive, be alert and register to vote.''
Mr. Jackson, a Presidential candidate in 1984 and 1988, returned Saturday from a trip that coincided with the release of Mr. Mandela and the legalization of the African National Congress.
 
Invitation to Mandela
Mr. Jackson, who appeared at the cathedral with Mayor David N. Dinkins, said that he had conveyed an invitation to Mr. Mandela from the Mayor to visit New York City and that Mr. Mandela had accepted. No date has been set, Mr. Jackson said.
At both his appearances in Manhattan yesterday, Mr. Jackson took issue with newspaper headlines around the world that announced, ''Mandela is Free.''
''That is not true,'' Mr. Jackson said. ''Mandela is not free. He is in front of the bars and not behind the bars, but the chains are still on his arms and legs.''
As long as the system of racial separation called apartheid is in force in South Africa, Mr. Jackson said, Mr. Mandela and other blacks will be imprisoned. He said Mr. Mandela emerged from prison ''with more credibility than the whole Government'' of South Africa, yet he is denied the right to vote, the right to live where he wants, the right to send his children to the school of his choice, the right to use a public restroom.
 
'Hope Is Beyond Apartheid'
Mr. Jackson repeatedly referred to these limitations against blacks as sanctions, and said that economic sanctions of other Governments, especially the United States, should not be lifted until the sanctions of apartheid are fully removed.
Mr. Mandela, he said, believes that President F. W. de Klerk, the South African leader, is a ''man of integrity'' who realizes that ''South Africa's brightest days and greatest hope is beyond apartheid.'' But, Mr. Jackson cautioned, ''time is working against both leaders,'' adding that ''the will to struggle within the country is very intense.''
''The expectations are well ahead of the negotiations,'' he said.
Mr. Jackson was received with a warm ovation when, midway through the service, he took a seat on the stage at Abyssinian and was embraced by the pastor, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d. Mr. Jackson rose and asked his daughter, Santita, a member of the church, to also rise from her seat in the congregation.
 
'Just a Suffering Servant'
Mr. Jackson urged the historic Harlem church, once led by the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., to ''adopt a sister church'' in South Africa. He said South African churches were in desperate need of financial and moral support because their pastors were often denied pensions and other benefits after they had spoken critically of apartheid.
Mr. Jackson called the triumph of Mr. Mandela ''a vindication for the principle of non-violence'' as practiced by the American civil rights leader, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., and the leader of Indian independence, Mohandas K. Gandhi.
''Mandela sat there without a bullet, without a missile, without a plane, without an army, without a bank account, without a political position, without a portfolio,'' he said.
''Just a suffering servant, who suffered his way into power.''
He concluded, ''My hope is that Mandela will be free, that all South Africa will be free.''

HEADLINE: Gotti: Dapper Celebrity Or Ruthless Mob Boss?

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
They came every day to see John Gotti and to shake his hand. For three weeks strangers queued up outside a Manhattan courtroom for a glimpse of the man the authorities call the nation's most powerful Mafia figure.
''Why not?'' explained Philip Weisler, a salesman from Fort Lee, N.J. ''Gotti is a celebrity, and this is a chance to see what he really looks like or even talk to him before they make a movie about him.''
Mr. Gotti's was acquitted Feb. 9 of charges of assault and conspiracy, his third acquittal in four years.
The cheering and fireworks displays after the acquittal disturbed law-enforcement authorities, who conceded that misplaced public sympathy for him is mounting. 
 
'People Are Hurt'
''Sure, I'm bothered,'' said the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Andrew J. Maloney. ''It's like the crowds that cheered Al Capone. People don't see the fruits of his labor, the violence he creates, how people are hurt and extorted through his various rackets.''
''With all this media coverage he's beginning to look like a folk hero,'' said Jules J. Bonavolonta, director of the F.B.I.'s organized-crime division in New York. ''What the public should realize is that he is the boss of the largest Cosa Nostra family, that he surrounds himself with ruthless killers and that he is flat out a criminal.''
Mr. Gotti declined to be interviewed, but his chief counsel, Bruce Cutler, insisted that his client has no ties to organized crime and that he is popular because of a growing distrust of government and because he ''is a champion for the little man.''
Dr. Charles Bahn, a consultant to law-enforcement agencies on criminal behavior, attributed the acclaim to vicarious envy. ''People, especially at the bottom of the economic ladder, don't see him as a threat,'' he said. ''They identify with him as a winner, as someone who fights City Hall.''
Mr. Gotti courted the attention he got at the trial. He smiled and waved at television cameras, and trial-watchers were quoted as fussing about how his bodyguards gave money to homeless men living in cardboard boxes outside the courthouse. He was particularly attentive to television reporters, discussing off camera with them the color combinations he favors for his clothes and the liqueurs he laces his coffee with.
But investigators who have tracked his rise maintain that his broad smile, opulent clothes and the Fourth of July street parties that he sponsors camouflage a substantial record of arrogance and violence.
Mr. Gotti grew up in the East New York-Brownsville section of Brooklyn, dropping out of high school at age 16. By the time he was 24, he had nine arrests and several brief jail sentences for street fighting, public intoxication, stealing cars, burglaries, bookmaking and gun possession.
In 1969, at 28, he was convicted of hijacking. In 1973, he was accused of posing as a detective to ''arrest'' a man in a Staten Island bar who was believed to have abducted and killed a nephew of Carlo Gambino, the founder of the crime family. When the man resisted, witnesses said, Mr. Gotti and a companion dragged him outside and shot him dead. He fled before being apprehended by the F.B.I in 1974.
Plea bargaining by his lawyer, Roy M. Cohn, reduced the charge to attempted manslaughter, and Mr. Gotti was jailed for four years.
Prosecutors say he was promoted from soldier to capo, or captain, in the Gambino family in the late 1970's and given charge of a crew.
Lieut. Remo Franceschini, the commander of the Queens District Attorney's detective squad, began watching Mr. Gotti at that time.
 
'A Short Fuse'
''He hasn't changed that much over the years,'' said Lieutenant Franceschini. ''He is very volatile, with a short fuse and he'll blow his top at any moment.''
On a tapped telephone in 1981, Mr. Gotti is heard warning one of his associates that he would blow up his home and kill him if he did not return calls promptly. ''I need an example,'' Mr. Gotti said angrily. ''Don't you be the [expletive] example, you understand me?''
As the associate pleads that he never got the messages, Mr. Gotti says: ''Listen, I called your [expletive] house five times yesterday; now if your wife thinks you are a [expletive] dunsky or if she's a [expletive] dunsky and you're gonna disregard my [expletive] phone calls, I'll blow you and that [expletive] house up.''
The man starts to say ''I never disregard anything you . . .''
Mr. Gotti says: ''Well, you call your [expletive] wife up and you tell her, or I'll get in the [expletive] car and I'll go over there and I'll [expletive] tell her.''
 
Disappeared or Murdered
Two men who have crossed Mr. Gotti's path have disappeared or been murdered.
Mr. Gotti's 12-year-old son, Frank, was killed in 1980 when his minibike swerved into the path of a car driven by a neighbor, John Favara, 51, near the Gotti home in Howard Beach, Queens. Mr. Favara, who knew the Gottis, apologized to them, but began getting anonymous death threats, investigators said, and made plans to leave the neighborhood. Four months later, while Mr. Gotti was in Florida, witnesses saw three men club Mr. Favara on the head and stuff him into a van in a Long Island parking lot. He is presumed by the police to have been slain.
In 1988, Wilfred (Willie Boy) Johnson, who Federal prosecutors said had been an informer for a decade while working for Mr. Gotti, was shot to death in Brooklyn.
Mr. Gotti, through Mr. Cutler, denies any knowledge about Mr. Favara's disappearance and Mr. Johnson's murder.
In 1984, when Mr. Gotti was not well known publicly, he was arrested in Queens, accused of punching a man who had honked his horn because Gotti's double-parked car had blocked his. The police said he also took the man's wallet, with more than $300. By the time the case came to trial in 1986, Mr. Gotti had been identified by the authorities as a major Mafia boss and the complainant said he was unable to recognize Mr. Gotti as his assailant. The charges were dismissed. F.B.I. agents and state investigators have contended in testimony that Mr. Gotti gained control of the Gambino family in 1986 after engineering the murder of the previous boss, Paul Castellano. #19,000 Conversations Taped From April 1985 to May 1986, the state's Organized Crime Task Force recorded 19,000 separate conversations consuming 750 hours from court-authorized electronic bugs planted at the Bergin Hunt & Fish Social Club in Ozone Park, Queens.
At Mr. Gotti's trial on state assault charges, the prosecution played 25 conversations that they asserted were snapshots of him progressing from capo to boss. Mr. Cutler dismissed them as conversations taken out of context or altered by overzealous investigators.
Investigators say Mr. Gotti's life style changed after he became the Gambino family head in 1986. He exchanged his slacks and Windbreaker-style jackets for custom-tailored silk suits. Instead of spending most of his time in Ozone Park, he appeared almost daily at Manhattan cafes and clubs.
He has infuriated law-enforcement officials by defying bans on fireworks at his Fourth of July street barbecues in Ozone Park and by having his lawyers openly assail prosecutors as ''persecutors'' engaged in ''vendettas'' against him.
F.B.I. agents and other investigators maintain that Mr. Gotti inherited a thriving criminal empire now grossing $300 million a year that Mr. Castellano had developed.
Mr. Bonavolonta of the F.B.I. said Mr. Gotti was known as an unsophisticated ''strong-armed thug'' when he took over the family but has since shown ''managerial experience,'' and has relied on older capos to maintain the family's income.
 
Prison Terms for Some
But in the last two years, reputed family leaders, including Mr. Gotti's brother, Gene, who was convicted of heroin trafficking, were sentenced to long prison terms.
Another brother, Vincent, was sentenced in 1986 to six years to life for selling cocaine.
Investigators say Mr. Gotti relies on two other brothers, Peter and Richard, for advice and relaying important orders. He is trying to insulate himself by holding abrupt meetings while walking in the street with other suspected mobsters, investigators say.
''He's just reaping the harvest,'' said Lieutenant Franceschini. ''As boss, he gets a percentage of everything without having to do anything except settle disputes.''
According to transcripts of tapes played at the trials of Mr. Gotti and other suspected Gambino mobsters, he was heard in 1986 describing himself as being ''a boss'' who can no longer ''socialize with these guys.''
He says: ''They can't have that liberty. In other words don't get me wrong, I'm not talking about close guys, I'm talking about, Ange, they have to go through a skipper, then go to an underboss.''
One month after the authorities said he became the head of the family, he was heard demanding ''respect'' from underlings and stressing the necessity of capos having to work on Sundays.
Mr. Gotti's ''importance has been blown all of out proportion by the media,'' said G. Robert Blakey, a professor of law at University of Notre Dame, who was the principal author of the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, known as RICO, used in prosecuting organized-crime figures.
''Gotti - or maybe we should call him Gaudy - is going down,'' Professor Blakey added. ''He's not untouchable. It's just a matter of time.''

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
A Commissioner For Consumers Has High Hopes

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Twenty years ago this month, New York City imposed its paradigmatic consumer protection law. Bess Myerson was consumer affairs commissioner then, followed briefly by Betty Furness. Those were the golden days of the consumer movement.
Tomorrow, though, may herald the resurgence of an agency with the rare ability to collect more money than it spends while also enhancing the reputations of its commissioner and the mayor. Mayor David N. Dinkins is to swear in Mark Green as the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner. 
For Mr. Dinkins, the appointment of Mr. Green represents an opportunity to convey the image of an administration vigorously protecting the salaries of the middle class and the dwindling resources of even more vulnerable New Yorkers - the young, the elderly, the poor and the disabled - when budget constraints are forcing the Mayor to curtail city services.
For the glib but cerebral Mr. Green, who sometimes speaks in slogans, the position offers public exposure and an opportunity, after 20 years as an independent consumer advocate, to put the city's money and legal might where his mouth is.
''While the department has been a competent licenser, it has been a relatively quiet advocate,'' Mr. Green said. ''There's a lot of room to raise the agency's voice and revenue.''
The job marks a major adjustment for the 44-year-old Mr. Green, an energetic Ralph Nader protege who has spent the last decade - with a detour in 1986 to run unsuccessfully against Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican United States Senator - lobbying for a liberal agenda through his nonprofit Democracy Project.
''This is the first job in which I haven't had to help raise money for my own salary,'' Mr. Green said of the $97,000-a-year commissionership.
''In fact, I may be the only commissioner whose salary went up when he joined city government. My sacrifice is not financial, but mobility.''
In 1979, Mr. Green rejected the job of consumer adviser to President Jimmy Carter -largely, he said, because of philosophical disagreements about energy deregulation and other issues.
After Mr. Dinkins was elected last November, Mr. Green stepped aside as co-chairman of a panel searching for a consumer affairs commissioner once he was persuaded that he need only look in a mirror to find the perfect candidate.
Mr. Green hopes to transform the Consumer Affairs Department from a monitor of weights and measures and collector of license fees and fines (it took in $11.9 million last year and spent $10.4 million) into a more vocal advocate and law-enforcement office. The fact that his most recent predecessors (identify one if you can) are not household names is a reflection of their styles, if not their records.
''Let's ask why Bess Myerson succeeded 20 years ago,'' Mr. Green said. ''Because Bess exploited a prior prominence, hired a great staff and had a supportive mayor. I'm no Miss America, but several of those elements exist for my tenure, too.''
Mr. Green seeks to elevates concerns of consumers, and, therefore, their champion, to a higher plane than ''housewife issues.''
''Tell it to a family of four earning $20,000 that is overpaying $1,000 for an old refrigerator sold as new,'' he said, cautioning that cumulative abuses erode not only the economic health of families on the margin but also their faith in government.
Might not aggressive consumer advocacy sometimes clash with Mayor Dinkins's eagerness to cast his administration as receptive to business?
''I will be resolutely anti-business-abuse, which is pro-business,'' Mr. Green declared. ''The scale of consumer justice is tilted against consumers - business has the resources, lawyers, contacts. My assignment and history are to lend my weight and voice to the consumer side of the scale so there will be a better balance.''
Will public office still his partisan voice? Mr. Green said he is satisfied for now that he has persuaded the Senate to investigate conflict-of-interest allegations against Mr. D'Amato. ''My private opinion of Al D'Amato has not altered, but I won't spend time prosecuting the case,'' Mr. Green said. Will he run again for the Senate in 1992? Less likely now than before his appointment, Mr. Green said. The only Sherman-like statement he would issue is a pledge to enforce the antitrust law of the same name.
''It is wrong to precondition appointive office on not seeking elective office,'' Mr. Green said, slyly recalling the appointed City Clerk who ran three times for Manhattan Borough President, David Dinkins.

HEADLINE: Mets Seek Workout, Find Frustration

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 18

 BODY:
The Mets in exile, who were locked out of their training camp Thursday because of the baseball labor dispute, reported for their informal morning workout at a Little League field here today and, to put it bluntly, were locked out.
The infield gate at the public park was chained and locked, and a sign said, ''Facility Closed, Keep Out.''
''Locked out again,'' muttered Bob Ojeda, the senior member of the Mets. ''We get no respect.'' 
Ojeda and three teammates hopped the wire fence and started tossing a baseball on the outfield grass. But a park supervisor drove up in his Jeep and told them to quit. There was nothing personal or strategic in this lockout, he said. It had nothing to do with economic warfare; it was just a case of cricket warfare.
''I'm sorry to do it,'' said the official, Harold Biller. ''But we've got to keep the field free. We've got chemicals on the grass to get rid of the crickets and we're trying to fertilize the rest of it.''
So, the four Mets kept improvising, as they have been doing since their spring training camp was closed by order of the club owners' Player Relations Committee, which is trying to negotiate a new basic agreement with the Players Association. The Mets crossed a gully and went to a grassy area about 100 yards away and once more tossed baseballs lightly before splitting for some basketball and fishing.
The training cadre was small today: Ojeda, Keith Miller, Terry Bross and Alejandro Pena, the pitcher acquired in a trade this winter from the Los Angeles Dodgers, who was making his debut with the Mets under the strange conditions that prevail. The Mets' modern two-year-old training complex with its six baseball fields and elegant locker room stood empty, three miles away, while the four Mets went through the motions outside a Little League field besieged by crickets.
 
Contrast With '76
The Mets conceded that their camp-in-exile was radically different from their regular training base. It was also radically different from the highly organized rump camps run by players during a similar lockout in 1976, when the training complexes were closed until March 17.
In those days, the main issue in the labor dispute was free agency, and the players conducted their camps with due regard for the high stakes. Tom Seaver, Bud Harrelson and Willie Stargell organized one of the biggest and best, a fairly formal workout class held every morning at Eckerd College in St. Petersburg, and they drew a couple of dozen players from the Mets, St. Louis Cardinals, Philadelphia Phillies and Pittsburgh Pirates.
But this year, the players' union vetoed such camps on the ground that they might lull the club owners into a sense of serenity in the labor talks.
''The owners see 20 guys out here working,'' Ojeda reasoned, ''and what's their incentive to settle? So, we keep it low-key. We don't do it for the owners; we do it for ourselves.
''But I'm ticked. You see what we do here: toss the ball, play basketball, go fishing. So, I'm here dinking around, and up the road they've got this beautiful new stadium that the people here raised their taxes to build. And now the people who sold them the bill of goods are telling them the stadium's closed.''
 
No Fantasy-Camp Lockout
The Mets' training stadium was filled with old Mets this weekend. They were in town to play a series of games against the paying customers at the fantasy camp operated at the Mets' minor-league base by Steve Zabriskie, the broadcaster, and Harrelson, a Met coach. And many of them were also alumni of the lockout camps of 1976.
''Tom Seaver and Buddy organized it with Stargell, and all the guys started showing up,'' Jerry Koosman remembered. ''We felt that we needed to stay in shape so we wouldn't hurt ourselves when the regular camps opened. We had calisthenics, live batting practice, throwing on the side, all the things you normally do in camp.''
He smiled faintly and said, ''I won 21 games that year.''
''We just got some bats and balls, and the guys brought their own stuff,'' Harrelson recalled. ''Stargell and Mike Easler came from the Pirates, and Ted Simmons from the Cardinals, and a bunch of us from the Mets and Phillies. It was fairly organized. Two hours a day. We got a lot of work done.''
Larry Bearnarth, once the premier relief pitcher for the Mets, was the pitching coach for the Montreal Expos when the camps were locked in 1976. He remembered that the Expos' coaches spent the time working with their minor leaguers at Daytona Beach.
''We had 24 players and 10 minor league coaches, the farm director, the manager and some other guys,'' he said. ''We almost had one coach for every player. But our varsity players meanwhile were holding their own training camp at an aeronautical college in West Palm Beach, and they were highly organized workouts.''
''We kept an eye on them,'' acknowledged Bearnarth, who is in his second stint as the Expos' pitching coach. ''More than we're allowed to do this time.''
He sighed and said, ''It was different then from now.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Fine-Tuning Panama's Bank Policy

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
As a senior banking executive for the Panamanian branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank many years ago, Ruben D. Carles received an unexpected visitor late one afternoon, the kind of person he says banks here seldom see anymore.
The man had a suitcase filled with more than $1 million in small bills and asked Mr. Carles to open an account. Told the bank was closed, the man asked to put the suitcase in the vault. Told the vault could not be unlocked until the next morning, the man asked if Mr. Carles would store the suitcase under a bank counter. 
Rebuffed a third time, the man left with his cash.
Although some American officials maintain that Panamanian banks did a brisk money-laundering business at least through December, Mr. Carles, the nation's new comptroller, says changes in the law and in the economic and political scene have dried up the large, suspicious cash deposits believed linked to the drug trade.
A former economics professor and longtime critic of the military Government that dominated life here for more than two decades, his position reflects the commonly held view in Panama City that narcotics profits no longer fill the nation's banks.
 
No Hot Issue
''It is an activity that has almost disappeared now,'' Mr. Carles said in a recent interview. ''It is no longer a hot issue.''
''We cannot change our banking laws just because somebody in the United States thinks they are not proper. They are important for other uses that are not drug-related.''
American officials were pleased by the changes made so far but want even more stringent rules to combat money laundering.
The banks in Panama, gleaming and pristine structures that shimmer in the tropical sun and form Panama City's skyline, dominate life in this nation of 2.4 million.
From the moment of stepping off the plane at the international airport near Panama City, their omnipresence is apparent. The airport terminal's walls are decorated with large billboards touting high-quality service and maximum confidentiality.
Almost all the senior officials from the president on down are or have been connected to one or more of the 110 international and local banks that are officially registered. Banking and related financial services represent 16 percent of the gross domestic product, providing 8,000 jobs directly and large amounts of business for local lawyers and accountants.
The country's banks include branches of American, Swiss, Japanese, Korean and German institutions. Officially, many exist to service the $4 billion a year in commerce that passes through the free trade zone in nearby Colon, the largest such zone in Latin America.
For two years, the banking industry has been hit hard by economic sanctions imposed by the United States. Deposits on hand have declined sharply, falling from more than $29 billion two years ago, to $7.8 billion when Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega surrendered to American troops in December. Before the banking laws were rewritten in 1970 to make the country a money haven, Panamanian banks reported deposits of $250 million.
Bankers say foreign investments are beginning to trickle in again. Panamanian officials are trying to walk a tightrope on banking policy, promising some modifications while at the same time trying to lure back some of the enormous amounts that fled to other jurisdictions.
''In the past, Panama has not been the most law-abiding nation,'' said Carlos F. Rodriguez, the new Ambassador to the United States and chairman of the Dadeland Bank in Miami. ''Panamanians have been the major victims of money laundering. It has led to abuses which cost Panama its democracy.''
 
Money-Laundering Cases
The two largest money-laundering cases prosecuted so far in the United States were against Panamanian banks and the current case against General Noriega also involves sweeping accusations of money laundering. A recent Senate report listed Panama as one of six nations most widely used to launder illegal profits. The others are Switzerland, Hong Kong, the Bahamas, Canada and Luxembourg.
In approving the first part of a $1 billion aid package, Congress has required the Bush Administration to prepare a report by April 15 that outlines what steps are being taken to modify Panama's strict bank and corporate secrecy laws.
In response to calls for such changes, Panamanian officials say they will soon require banks to begin keeping special records of deposits of more than $10,000 under a rule similar to one in the United States. But precisely what the requirement will do remains unclear.
In addition to the banking laws, the nation's corporate secrecy laws make it virtually impossible to determine the real owners of businesses used as fronts for illicit operations.
Lawyers here report business is as brisk as ever in forming secretly registered companies for anywhere between $300 and $1,000 a company, many little more than brass plates on a door. The actual founders and shareholders of such companies are never disclosed, and Panama receives no taxes so long as the business is offshore.
Asked about the corporate secrecy laws, Ambassador Rodriguez said, ''That is a different matter completely.'' Other officials said there would be no important changes in the corporate secrecy rules.
 
Role of American Banks
Jose Antonio de Gracia, economic analyst for the National Banking Commission, a regulatory body, says banks in the United States have a more important role in moving ill-gotten gains than Panamanian banks.
''The laundering and ironing is always done in other places - places like Miami, San Francisco and New York,'' Mr. de Gracia says. ''It's true that the final product is deposited here through wire transfers, but the responsibility for those improper deposits should rest with the banks in the United States.''
It is a widely shared view among the members of the commission, which regulates banks here and is dominated by Panamanian bankers.
To these bankers, the new administration presents opportunity. As long as the corporate and banking secrecy laws are maintained, Panama will remain a haven for foreign investment.
 
A State of Mind
''Banking,'' Sam Kardonski said, ''is a state of mind.''
From behind his empty desk and in front of an empty bookcase in his second floor office, he says the present state of mind is optimistic. Mr. Kardonski, a Russian emigre who arrived in Panama in the 1920's, owns Tower Bank International. The removal of the economic sanctions and restrictions on the withdrawal of deposits promises to bring in much needed foreign investment, he said.
Downstairs, a burly man with a submachine gun in his hands and a pistol on his side patrols the bank. With no adequate police force, the banks have faced a rash of robberies.
''We have no reservations about it: if something we feel is not kosher, we tell them to find another bank,'' Mr. Kardonski said. ''The stigma of money laundering - the medicine is stronger than the sickness. It is more damaging to the industry than anything else. It's immoral.''

GRAPHIC: ''We cannot change our banking laws just because somebody in the United States thinks they are not proper,'' said Ruben D. Carles, Panama's new comptroller. (Agence France-Presse for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;
Industry Is Troubled, but Booksellers Are Thriving

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
THE American Booksellers Association has been around for 90 years, but it is now friskier than ever and brimming with confidence - almost as if its 7,600 members were unaware of the difficulties in the publishing industry.
While some publishers are talking about cutting back the size of their lists and their print runs, the association's membership, staff, budget and activities are all growing at record rates.
What this strongly suggests is that the foundation of the book industry is far stronger than the high rate of book returns and unearned advances indicate.
''In 1983, we were 15 people in a 5,000-square-foot office, living from hand-to-mouth on a gross volume of about $2 million,'' said Bernie Rath, the association's executive director. ''Today we own 13,200 square feet on two floors in a 12-story condominium loft, have a permanent staff of 42 and our gross volume is between $7 million and $8 million.'' 
Moreover, total membership rose 11 percent last year, to 7,600.
Not surprisingly, the association's growth parallels the growth and vitality of the independent bookstores. Dispirited and seemingly facing extinction only a few years ago, when the chain stores were growing rapidly, independent bookstores are now flourishing.
But even when the independents were suffering, Mr. Rath inspired and cajoled them to stop feeling sorry for themselves and begin asserting their power.
That outspokenness did not always endear Mr. Rath to everyone in the association. In fact, his insistence a few years ago that independent booksellers deserved the same discounts that the chain stores received led Waldenbooks to quit the organization.
But it has since rejoined, and last year Waldenbooks and the association successfully challenged the constitutionality of a law in Colonial Heights, Va., that would have forbidden display of such magazines as Playboy and Penthouse in stores.
''When I was hired in 1984, there was a kind of Darwinian theory that if the independent stores were not efficient enough to cut it, too bad,'' said Mr. Rath, a one-time book salesman and the former executive director of the Canadian Booksellers Association. ''The independents have since shown they not only can compete but prosper. The publishers are now more amenable to dealing with us.''
A big reason the publishers are more amenable is that the lawsuits filed by the Northern California Booksellers Association, and supported by the American Booksellers Association, led publishers of rack-sized mass-market paperbacks to stop giving larger discounts to chain bookstores than to independents.
But they are amenable also because they recognize the independents' growing economic strength. In recent years, the independents were largely responsible for the early success of ''A Brief History of Time'' by Stephen W. Hawking (Bantam Books), ''The Closing of the American Mind'' by Allan Bloom (Simon & Schuster), ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers'' by Paul Kennedy (Random House), '' Great Plains'' by Ian Frazier (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) and ''The Tempting of America'' by Robert H. Bork (Free Press).
Lawrence Hughes, the chairman of the Association of American Publishers, is much impressed by Mr. Rath and by Edward Morrow, the president of the booksellers association (and the owner of the Northshire Bookstore in Manchester Center, Vt.). ''The two of them are intelligent, extremely well read and very good business people,'' he said.
The association and the publishers developed a plan that enables bookstores to order minimum quantities of a single title at a high discount rate. (Previously, many publishers would not bother with single orders.) Through a wholly owned subsidiary, Booksellers Order Service Inc., the association sells shopping bags to bookstores at bulk rates. It also sponsors Garrison Keillor's live weekly broadcast, ''The American Radio Company of the Air.''
Moreover, the association recently opened a library of book publishing in its Manhattan headquarters, for the use of scholars and other interested parties. And, in an industry notorious for its lack of statistics, it established a statistical department to compile data on everything from the size of bookstores to sales per store, sales per capita and average pay per bookstore employee. Now Mr. Rath wants the association to start a newsletter to advise its members on First Amendment issues, and he hopes to put together a videocassette on opening and operating a bookstore.
There may be some risk in trying to do too much to quickly; as some publishers have been learning to their sorrow, bigger is not necessarily better. But the association's growth has not seemed to have stifled innovation.
''At a time when there don't seem to be many new ideas coming out of other parts of the book industry,'' said Michael Shatzkin, a publishing consultant, ''the A.B.A. has had one creative idea after another.''

HEADLINE: Business and the Law;
Brokerage Case Goes On and On

BYLINE: By Stephen Labaton

 BODY:
Three years ago the Supreme Court was swayed by arguments of the securities industry that arbitration is swift, relatively inexpensive and fair. In their ruling in Shearson/American Express Inc. v. McMahon, the Justices locked the doors of Federal courthouses to most customers who contend that they were defrauded by stockbrokers.
The case that set the precedent is now entering its seventh year. The couple who brought the action are still pursuing their claim that they were defrauded of $560,000 through ''churning'' - excessive buying and selling to create commissions. The dispute has cost both sides hundreds of thousands of dollars. 
In one of several decisions in the McMahon case, a Federal appeals court said last week that the tactics of Shearson ''unreasonably and vexatiously multiplied'' the proceedings.
The case seems to have fulfilled the prophecy of Justice Harry A. Blackmun, who predicted in his 1987 dissent that the Supreme Court ruling would have the opposite effect of its intentions, actually leading to more litigation over satellite issues.
In its landmark decision, the Supreme Court reversed course on 24 years of rulings. Previously, securities fraud disputes, even those in which the parties had signed agreements favoring arbitration, had been accepted by the courts. But in the McMahon case, the Justices approved standard form agreements signed by customers and brokers that have clauses, usually in fine print, relegating all such disputes to arbitration.
The McMahons had argued that they should be allowed their day in court. Like other customers who challenged the securities industry, they said the arbitration panels, often made up of former securities executives, tend to award smaller damages and favor broker-defendants. But in the McMahon case, the Supreme Court ruling has done little to reduce legal bills or insure swift justice.
''It's getting to be more and more like a court case,'' said Theodore G. Eppenstein, the McMahons' lawyer, who said the two sides are now fighting over what evidence can be obtained.
The plodding pace has not been lost on Wilfred Feinberg, a Federal Appeals judge who was part of the panel from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit that last week issued the ruling on a related aspect of the McMahon case. Told during arguments where the case stands, Judge Feinberg said, ''So much for a speedy and economical method of resolving the dispute.''
Jeffrey L. Friedman, a lawyer for Shearson, declined to comment on the appeals court's unusually critical language regarding his client.
The McMahon proceeding has interested some members of Congress who are examining the arbitration process. Three weeks ago, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce asked the General Accounting Office to review how the industry conducts arbitration.
The latest wrangling in the McMahon dispute has been over a move by Shearson to have Mr. Eppenstein penalized for one aspect of the case.
Mr. Eppenstein said he had elected to file with the American Arbitration Association because he considered it fairer than the New York Stock Exchange, in which a person from the securities industry is included on each panel and the parties in the dispute can challenge the seating of only one member of the three-member panel.
Despite a Federal District Court order saying the McMahons had the right to choose where to file, Shearson filed the arbitration with the Stock Exchange. Mr. Eppenstein then went to New York Supreme Court to stop Shearson's move, provoking Federal District Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon to impose a $1,000 fine on the lawyer.
In a significant decision on Rule 11, the Federal Rule of Civil Procedure that has been increasingly used to penalize lawyers for filing frivolous motions, the appeals panel exonerated Mr. Eppenstein and criticized the brokerage house, saying it had drawn out the legal proceeding.
Quoting Charles Dickens, Federal Appeals Judge Richard J. Cardamone said Rule 11 was motiviated by a fear that lawyers had been engaging in ''stages of an endless cause, tripping one another up on slippery precedents, groping knee-deep in technicalities, running their . . . heads against walls of words, and making a pretense of equity with serious faces, as players might.''
Despite Mr. Eppenstein's vindication on the Rule 11 issue, Shearson has had its way on the forum. The case is in arbitration at the New York Stock Exchange, although not even a pre-arbitration conference has been scheduled.
Asked why the case wound up there, Mr. Eppenstein said that another move in the Federal courts would not be worthwhile for his clients. ''We decided that we didn't want to take that issue up to the Supreme Court,'' he said.

HEADLINE: A Spotlight On Obscure Agency

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
After the upheaval in Eastern Europe and the United States invasion of Panama, the Bush Administration is using a little-known Federal agency as a tool to achieve one of its main international policy goals - market-oriented economic reconstruction.
The disintegration of Communism has given the Overseas Private Investment Corporation probably the greatest opportunity to flex its muscles in its two decades of existence, said its president, Fred M. Zeder.
One of the few Government agencies that actually make money, the agency, among other projects, insures shrimp farms in Haiti, methanol operations in Argentina, brick and tile manufacturing in Botswana, bauxite mining in Guyana and carbon-black production in Indonesia.
 
Protecting Companies
For the insurance protection it offers American companies against nationalization, civil disorder, political unrest, inconvertibility and other foreign investment risks, it charges fees that last year gave it record net income of $122 million, increasing its reserves in the Treasury to nearly $1.5 billion. 
On Friday Mr. Zeder is taking a score of top executives, from companies like A.T.&T., GTE and Unocal Geothermal, to Panama to explore investment opportunities to ''jump start'' that economy.
From a similar mission it took to Poland in November, more than $1 billion in insurance registrations were signed, indicating prospective investments in cable television, telecommunications, light industry, accounting, banking and other financial services.
''We signed up stuff right away,'' Mr. Zeder said. ''Usually it takes up to three or four months.''
 
Contract in Hungary
In February, the agency signed its first insurance contract in Hungary, covering a $150 million investment by the General Electric Company to make light bulbs.
The agency is run by an old friend of the President. Mr. Zeder, a 68-year-old former Dallas venture capitalist and World War II fighter pilot who like Mr. Bush saw action in the Pacific, speaks of his ''rapid deployment force,'' which organizes investment missions in seven weeks rather than the seven months it used to take.
''We are much more conscious of our responsibility of taking an active place behind the President's foreign policy initiatives,'' said the burly executive, who held minor posts in both the Nixon and Ford Administrations and enjoys ''walk in'' privileges at the Bush White House.
The insurance agency, which started in the early 1970's through legislation introduced by Senator Jacob K. Javits, the New York Republican, is getting high grades from American business. Much of the praise now is for Mr. Zeder, who has been in office since June 23.
 
'In Front of the Curve'
''He's doing a bang-up job,'' said Willard A. Workman, director for international policy and programs at the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''They're doing things very aggressively. They're very much in front of the curve.''
But organized labor, which fought Congressional renewal of the agency's operating charter in 1988, continues to harbor fundamental objections to its existence.
''We maintain that the U.S. Government really has no business using public resources to insure U.S. corporations for offshore production,'' said Mark A. Anderson, an international economist at the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Labor's opposition is rooted in fears that agency operations lead to job losses for American workers, a point the agency disputes. Creating Jobs in U.S. Noting that a third of American exports are generally bought by foreign subsidiaries of American companies, Mr. Zeder said the agency actually stimulates exports, leading to net American job creation.
For instance, the agency calculated that the 115 new projects it supported in 35 third world countries last year will yield an annual positive net contribution of $1.6 billion toward the United States balance of trade over the first five years.
Until the tumultuous events of recent months in Eastern Europe, labor fought against the agency's operations in that region on the ground that the old Communist governments violated basic standards of worker rights, like freedom of association, the right to bargain collectively, workplace health and safety and stipulations against forced labor.
In recent weeks, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the agency have reached accords under which the agency will require that language related to worker rights be included in every contract the agency makes with corporate investors.
 
Equity Investments
Besides writing insurance and guaranteeing commercial loans for foreign investments, the agency has now been cleared by Congress to make equity investments for the first time.
''People refer to us as an insurance agency,'' Mr. Zeder said, ''but we're moving away from that concept to become merchant bankers. We're really in the business of encouraging equity capital.''
Now Mr. Zeder is adopting the so-called growth fund concept to pour seed capital into enterprises in Eastern Europe and the third world.
The $30 million Africa Growth Fund is being readied to begin, probably in April. It is managed by the Equator Bank of Hartford, and its limited partners including Citicorp, Coca-Cola, Kellogg and the Rockefeller Foundation.
 
Guaranteed Loan
The partners are expected to put up $10 million. For the other $20 million, the agency will provide a $20 million federally guaranteed loan, which can be sold like a Treasury bond to pension funds and other institutional investors.
Mr. Zeder said the Africa fund, which was started to demonstrate to American business ''that you can make money in Africa,'' will be replicated in Eastern Europe, the Caribbean and Asia. In addition, he is planning another fund to support environmental projects globally.
''Because we're suddenly living in a more peaceful, more trusting world, the demand for our assurances has gone up dramatically,'' Mr. Zeder noted. ''The total market has increased, and we're ready to do business.''

HEADLINE: A Different Drummer in Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 18

 BODY:
So often in Japanese business life, success comes to those who avoid risks and follow the well-trodden paths. Then there are people like Kazuo Wada, chairman of the Yaohan Department Store Company, who personifies another Japanese type: the devoted renegade.
The avuncular Mr. Wada, a trim 61-year-old man with a ready smile who prefers plain gray suits, is an unlikely radical, but in his genteel but determined way he has built one of Japan's most unusual retailers by breaking just about every rule of the game as it is played here.
His guiding business philosophy, he said, has been ''to give my company a special character that nobody else had.'' He has clearly succeeded. 
 
Atypical Geography
Where the economic and Government center of Tokyo has been the focus for most big Japanese retailers, the Yaohan supermarket chain has eschewed the capital for the provinces. While most Japanese companies expanding overseas have gone to the wealthy nations of Europe or the United States, Yaohan has focused on Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Brunei.
Instead of renting landmark locations, Yaohan generally searches for less glamorous but practical sites -the kinds of places where you might find a vegetable stand, which is how Yaohan got started in a provincial town outside Tokyo.
And most Japanese companies have only one ideology: work hard and be loyal. But Mr. Wada and his mother, Katsu, who helped found the company, are leaders in a new Japanese religion, known as Seicho No Ie, which is loosely translated as House of God's Children. It is an amalgam of Shinto, Buddhism and Christianity, which stresses the Confucian ethic of respecting authority and of seeking harmony. Nearly all of Yaohan's managers are members of the sect.
Yet no step has been more unusual, or risky, than the one Mr. Wada announced late last year to move Yaohan's international headquarters from Japan to Hong Kong, the politically fragile British colony that is to revert to Chinese control in 1997.
Many Chinese professionals are fleeing Hong Kong because of concern over how the Communists on the mainland will manage the prosperous capitalist enclave. But where they spot trouble, Mr. Wada says he spots opportunity. As he noted, from his new home in the prestigious Peak district of Hong Kong island, he will look out over the largest potential market in the world.
The headquarters move is partly a matter of thrift. Hong Kong has some of the lowest taxes in the world, and land prices there are considerably cheaper than the inflated levels of Japan.
''Taxes and land are one consideration,'' Mr. Wada admitted. ''But more important was that I see big possibilities in Asia and China in the future. This is the era of Asia.'' Of China, he states bluntly that it is not rich enough yet to support his supermarkets, but that will come. He said that over the next few decades he plans to develop along the country's relatively prosperous coastal regions a huge network for buying goods as well as for a chain of stores. It will all add up to one of the most extensive, if not the largest, distribution systems connecting all of Asia.
''Yaohan has developed into an interesting story, in part because they have realized that there is clearly a higher profit potential overseas than in Japan, given the costs you face here,'' said Mike Allen, a retailing analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, a securities house.
Mr. Allen said he is somewhat skeptical of Mr. Wada's ability to pull off his plan. Two problems are the store's middle-brow image, which may make it hard for it to distribute higher margin goods later, and some labor problems that he said it has had in the United States, reportedly because of its insistence that employees follow the company's rigid tenets. That may make it tough for Yaohan to maintain consistent service outside of Japan. Nonetheless, Mr. Allen said the strategy is potentially attractive in the long run.
Although Mr. Wada's unusual vision is distinctly Asian, it is not being applied only to this part of the world. Yaohan operates six stores in the United States, including a large supermarket in Edgewater, N.J., just across the Hudson River from Manhattan. The store sells Japanese and Asian foods almost exclusively.
In New Jersey, Mr. Wada plans to build Yaohan's first hotel, which will have some unusual features, by Edgewater standards. Its roof will be equipped with a traditionally Japanese pool-sized communal tub. After taking the cedar-scented waters, guests will be able to relax in Japanese cotton robes, yukata, on the traditional straw tatami mats, eating Japanese food and sipping sake as the lights of New York City blink in the background.
In Japan, Yaohan has 55 company-owned stores and another 35 franchised stores around the country. In addition, it has 22 stores overseas, including a big new wholesale distribution center in Singapore.
About a third of the $1.2 billion in sales it registered in the fiscal year that ended May 20, 1989, come from its international business. But it expects the overseas sales to match the domestic sales by 1992. The company reported a profit of $18.5 million in the last fiscal year, a 32 percent jump from the previous year.
 
A Folk Hero
As different as it is in many ways, Yaohan is very much a creature of Japan. Mr. Wada's mother has become something of a folk hero here, with a life story that could have been written by an Asian Horatio Alger. Her tale was told, in fact, in one of the most popular television series ever broadcast in Japan, which gave her the fictional name, Oshin.
It told of how she came from a family so poor she was put to work before she was 10 years old, and of how her hard work and persistence brought her business success and, eventually, a good husband. Together, they started a greengrocer that eventually became the chain of stores in the hands of her dedicated and pious son. It is the sort of tale of struggle and success against long odds that the Japanese immediately identify with.
Although Yaohan is publicly held, members of the Wada family dominate the management and maintain the largest shareholding. One younger brother, Terumasa, is president, and another, Mitsumasa, is senior vice president. Together, the family members own about 13 percent of the company's stock.
For his part, Mr. Wada concedes that, in many ways, he was forced to take the international route. ''The main reason was high land prices'' in Japan, he said. ''If land had been more reasonable, I wouldn't have gone overseas.''
 
Low-Rent Neighborhood
In an interview in the decidedly modest office his company keeps in a low-rent Tokyo neighborhood, he also said: ''I had the choice of opening stores in Osaka, Tokyo or overseas. Given the situation with land prices, I chose overseas.''
After an initial failure in 1971 in Brazil, which has a large Japanese community, he persisted and began to open successful stores around Asia. Yaohan's first American location, at Fresno, Calif., was opened in 1979. Now Yaohan has stores in California in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Costa Mesa and Torrance, as well as the New Jersey store. Mr. Wada admitted that the largest, in Edgewater, was not profitable yet, but he said it was meeting all his projections.
Although the American stores show promise, Mr. Wada said Asia still offers the best prospects for growth because of the region's explosive accumulation of wealth and rising standard of living. He rattles off precise figures of the national income of the nations of Southeast Asia, and clearly specifies Yaohan's prospects in each.
Once he moves to Hong Kong in a couple of months, Mr. Wada will be giving up his new $7 million home on a spectacular seaside site in Atami, a hot spring resort 55 miles southwest of Tokyo. But, as he put it, ''All of Asia will become my home.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Moscow a Year Later: Rutted Streets and Despair

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 16

 BODY:
A few impressions of Moscow after an absence of a year:
The rutted streets and cluttered courtyards of the city center speak of a marked deterioration in the economy, in just a year. Russian friends speak of empty shelves in the stores, which seem about as empty as they were a year ago, and say the reason for this is that nobody sees much point in working hard anymore.
And there is a sense of despair about the process of change that was not evident a year ago.
Echoing several other intellectuals, a friend who works on the staff of the Central Committee of the Communist Party said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev waited too long to try to push through serious economic changes. Now it may be too late. New Executive Powers Diplomats and Russians agree that the Communist Party, whose Central Committee voted last week to give up its constitutional guarantee of the leading role prescribed for it by every Soviet political leader since Lenin, had long ago lost the authority or the ability to put the country's affairs in order. 
It will not collapse suddenly like the Communist parties of East Germany and Czechoslovakia, they say, not in Russia at least, but the parties of the ethnic Muslim republics along the country's southern border are beginning to collapse in a way that looks, from a distance, remarkably like the way the ones in Eastern Europe fell apart.
''Perestroika,'' which has brought a new openness and freedom of debate, seems to have gone seriously wrong as a policy of pulling the country out of economic decline, and Mr. Gorbachev told the elected legislature this week that it was in a critical stage.
Now, too late, some believe, he is asking for sweeping new executive powers. The legislature, several deputies say, talks and talks, just as freely and openly as the House of Commons or the United States Senate does, but unlike them it gets little done. The country needs a strong executive, Mr. Gorbachev told them, because an elected president ought to replace the Communist Party Politburo, which in a democracy should not have such executive powers anyway.
 
Not Yet a Democracy
''A rule-of-law state has no room for dictatorship by any class, and even less so for the power of a management bureaucracy,'' said the party's draft platform that the Central Committee approved last week. But it only recognized a state of affairs that already exists. The party is no longer ''the'' party.
But neither is the Soviet Union, yet, a democracy. ''We don't have a tradition of democracy in this country,'' said the writer Anatoly N. Rybakov, one of the earliest beneficiaries of Mr. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost. ''People don't understand that in a democracy, you can lose elections, and when you lose, you have to submit to the rule of the majority until your turn comes again.''
Mr. Gorbachev has not yet proceeded to serious economic revision. The legislature is still debating whether and how to introduce private property.
But the only kind of private enterprise ordinary people can see around them, they do not like much: private farmers charging 15 rubles a kilogram for hothouse tomatoes, and mafia-like joint-venture businessmen who rent Zil limousines and dine in private restaurants that accept Western currency only, imitating the mores and privileges of the now discredited party elite.
''People in Russia are used to having nothing,'' said Anatoly S. Pankov, a journalist from Siberia. A Central Committee official said, ''The ideal of social justice here is that everybody should have nothing not that entrepreneurs should prosper and spread the wealth.''
 
Mood of Gloom and Anxiety
The party's draft platform puts it this way: ''We have approached a point when the previous system of economic management and government is not operating to a considerable extent, while new mechanisms have not yet started to work at full capacity.''
In plain Russian, to many people, that means that Mr. Gorbachev has wrecked the old system, with its assurances of social and economic stability at the price of intellectual freedom, and given them a half-baked new one that does not work but leaves them free to take to the streets to protest.
And so the mood among the ordinary people in Moscow, unlike the mood in Prague or even East Berlin these days, is not one of eager anticipation of new freedoms but one of gloom and anxiety.
''I hear a million people could be on the streets on Feb. 25,'' a Communist functionary said of a rumored demonstration, though that seemed like just one more rumor. But it seemed credible because several hundred thousand people did take to the streets on Feb. 4, as the Central Committee was gathering for its session, to tell their leaders that they were not happy with the way things were going.
 
Concessions on Arms Control
Small wonder, with all of that going on, that Mr. Gorbachev is making concession after concession in arms control, and even seeming to agree to the idea of German unification in a country that still remembers, painfully, the 20 million dead it suffered at the hands of the Nazis in World War II.
''He has to find some way to sell that to the people at home that doesn't make it sound like a capitulation,'' a Western diplomat said. A Russian journalist friend thought that would be difficult. ''A lot of people think he's wrecked our internal stability, now he's taking away our external security belt,'' he said. ''And maybe they'll decide pretty soon that they don't want him anymore.''
Perhaps. The only thing that is certain in Moscow these days is that everything is uncertain.
 
2,000 NATIONALISTS PROTEST
 MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (AP) - About 2,000 Russian nationalists staged a rally today to complain about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, the warming of relations with the United States and the growing nationalism in non-Russian republics.
The protesters gathered in deep snow near the Soviet television's 1,600-foot-tall transmission tower also heard speakers accuse Mr. Gorbachev of being power-hungry and plunging the Soviet Union into poverty and misery.
The harshest attack on Mr. Gorbachev came from Boris Unko of the United Front of Workers of Russia, a group fighting Gorbachev's market-oriented economic reforms and unhappy about the nationalism in non-Russian republics.
Among the evils wrought by Mr. Gorbachev's reforms, Mr. Unko said, were rock music, ''modernism and pornography,'' ''insults'' to heroes of the Bolshevik Revolution and World War II and others ''who built socialist society.'' He said Mr. Gorbachev had sold out to the elite and forgotten about the working class.
He said Mr. Gorbachev is trying to become a dictator, adding that the Soviet leader should have known his reforms would bring more harm than good.
Mr. Unko said: ''Any grandmother could have predicted the consequences of such a course. But you keep different company, the elite, property-holders. You make friends with President-murderer Bush, also a fighter for democracy who spilled blood in much-suffering Panama.''
