HEADLINE: Rising Hopes for Castro's Fall Have Cubans in Miami Abuzz

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Across South Florida, bumper stickers proclaim the end of the Castro era: ''Next Christmas in Havana.'' On Spanish-language radio, hour after hour is devoted to fevered speculation about a democratic millennium to come in Cuba. Even the Governor has joined in, convening a commission to imagine a Florida after Fidel.
Buoyed by the stunning collapse of Communist governments in Eastern Europe, many of this country's more than one million Cuban-Americans, most of whom live in the Miami area, are abuzz with the notion that Mr. Castro's Government will be next.
From Miami's Little Havana to the suburban enclaves of Hialeah and Hollywood, Fla., the excitement is higher now than anyone can remember since Cuban emigres began pouring into South Florida three decades ago. 
''I am ready to sell all, to sell my business and go back to Cuba,'' said Miguel Alvarez, president and owner of National Distributor Magazines, a $2-million-a-year wholesaler of Hispanic publications in South Florida.
It matters little that most experts see no evidence that the Cuban leader is in any imminent danger of being overthrown, despite shortages of food and consumer goods and the possibility of cuts in Soviet aid. An announcement over the weekend by Cuba's Communist Party leadership, pledging improvements in the system but a continuation of one-party rule, was widely seen as little more than a symbolic response to growing pressures for change.
 
A Longing to Return
None of that has prevented an outbreak of what one Cuban-American commentator calls ''wishful thinking-cum madness'' among many exiles, whose loathing of the Castro Government is exceeded only by their longing to return to their homeland.
Miami's Mayor, Xavier Suarez, who came to the United States from Havana as a child, said any Cuban-American who watched the dramatic television scenes of the dismantling of the Berlin Wall had to be encouraged.
''I think everybody definitely feels a sense of imminence about the situation in Cuba,'' said the Mayor, who is 39 years old. Referring to the high hopes of some Cuban exiles, he added, ''You're almost a conservative in your estimates if you say Castro will last no more than a year.''
While residents of other Communist countries travel with newfound ease, a decision to flee Cuba is still a life-or-death matter, often involving days adrift at sea on makeshift rafts. Coast Guard officials say they picked up 391 refugees last year, five times the number of the previous year.
The new arrivals' tales of economic deterioration only serve to feed the notion here that collapse in Havana is at hand.
Some exiles who have been in Miami for years have reportedly told their families that since Mr. Castro's overthrow is a certainty, it is time to begin selling their homes and other property in anticipation of returning to Cuba.
 
Objections From the Young
In some cases, such plans have come in the face of strenuous objections by their families, especially the younger members, who have grown up here and cannot imagine being uprooted from the United States.
Mr. Alvarez, who said he planned to set up a new magazine distributorship in Cuba, said that his wife and family were behind him 100 percent. But he added that his 19-year-old son ''says he's not going.''
Another businessman, Jesus Fernandez, a 56-year-old Miami developer whose company grossed $12 million last year, said he was also ready to sell his business, return to Cuba and start over in the same line of work.
 
Family Willing to Return
Mr. Fernandez, who backed the Castro Government before becoming disillusioned in the mid-1960's, said his wife and three grown children were willing to return with him.
Still others have rushed to their lawyers for advice about how to relocate their businesses, reinvest life savings or reclaim land and houses confiscated long ago by the Castro Government.
''I'm sure people are looking through their vaults to find the deeds to properties they haven't seen in 30 years,'' said Bernardo Benes, a Miami banker who left Havana in 1960.
Other Florida bankers report some speculating in old Cuban bonds in the hope the Castro Government would be replaced by one that would be more inclined to redeem them in dollars. The bonds include a pre-Batista issue that would have matured in 1977 if they had not been canceled by Mr. Castro.
''When will Castro fall?'' asked Gen. Manuel Benitez, an exile leader whose anti-Castro views are broadcast on Miami's Radio Mambi and in his weekly magazine, De Frente. ''Very soon, but he's going to fall full of blood and our convulsed nation will have to suffer longer because of his wickedness and his cadre of henchmen.''
 
'Free Cuba' Panel Named
Many Cuban-Americans, who make up 60 percent of Miami's population, feel especially encouraged by Gov. Bob Martinez, who announced earlier this month that he had appointed an 18-member ''Free Cuba Commission'' to prepare a report on how the ouster of Mr. Castro would affect the state, especially in terms of commerce, tourism and immigration. One question the panel can be expected to address is: if Cuba is freed, would the flow of people be greater to or from Florida?
''I don't know anyone who believes that Castro and Communism can continue,'' Mr. Martinez said. ''So we should prepare for the moment that they will no longer be there.''
Such optimism, however justified, is in keeping with the intense, deeply rooted patriotism of the Cuban exile community, which has a long history of being willing to try virtually anything to weaken Mr. Castro, including sabotage and murder - or, at the very least, to demonstrate to the world how much he is hated in Miami.
''Cubans are very patriotic, you know,'' said Orlando Padron, who was born in Pinar del Rio, Cuba. ''As soon as they hear Castro's name they go wild.'' Mr. Padron, who came to Miami with his family in 1961, when he was 6 years old, is now assistant manager of his father's cigar-rolling concern, the Piloto Cigar Company.
 
Plans for a Human Chain
On Calle Ocho (Eighth Street), in the heart of Little Havana, storefronts display posters advertising plans to assemble enough anti-Castro protesters next Saturday to make a human chain stretching from Calle Ocho to Key West - about 160 miles.
One Miami-based anti-Castro group announced this month that it had released 1,500 balloons in the hope that they would blow toward Cuba as part of an ''aerial attack'' designed to spark an uprising against Mr. Castro, who was depicted in accompanying flyers hanging, Mussolini-style, from a pole, his ankles and hands bound.
Such symbolic protests have become almost routine over the years, especially among anti-Castro Cubans in Miami. But the more extreme behavior inspired by events in Eastern Europe worries a few Cuban-American leaders, who say they see a kind of hysteria is developing.
Some have criticized Governor Martinez, a Republican, for establishing the Free Cuba Commission, which they say encourages wildly unrealistic expectations.
The Governor has insisted that the panel is nonpolitical, but it could bolster his support among Cuban-Americans who might be expected to back Mayor Suarez if he decides to challenge Mr. Martinez in the gubernatorial primary this year.
 
A Matter for Concern
Sergio Lopez-Miro, a Cuban-American journalist who writes a weekly column for The Miami Herald, said that it was hard to gauge how many Cubans were ready to sell their belongings in anticipation of Mr. Castro's ouster, but added that it was certainly a matter for concern.
''I don't believe that 50 percent of the community is doing it, but if 20 percent or 30 percent is, that's still a substantial number of people whose lives are being disrupted, and that could affect the state's economy in and of itself,'' Mr. Lopez-Miro said. ''The Governor has established this ridiculous commission to study the effects of Castro's supposedly imminent demise,'' he continued. ''But maybe he should be looking instead into the effects of this hysteria on this community.''
Mayor Suarez, who is regarded as a moderate among Cuban-American leaders, said he thought it was unfair to take political advantage of the gullibility of the exile community over the Castro issue.
''I would caution people, politicians and otherwise, to be very careful not to play on people's hopes,'' he said.
Mr. Suarez said that while the idea of a commission to study the impact of Mr. Castro's ouster seemed sensible, ''I do quarrel a little bit with the idea of looking at tourism and commerce, which are really much better left to the private sector, which in the case of Cuba is going to do extremely well.''
 
A Yearning to Return
Mr. Benes, the banker, agreed. ''I know for a fact that if Castro goes tomorrow, the day after tomorrow retail stores in Miami are going be selling goods to five million additional people, which is the population of Cuba,'' he said. ''You don't need to plan for that.''
Norberto Pino, a 61-year-old retired hotel operator who fled Cuba in 1962, says he would love to spend his last years in his homeland. Although he said he was not packing his bags just yet, he remained hopeful that Mr. Castro would go the way of Communist leaders in Hungary, East Germany and Romania.
''I think something has to be happen but I don't know when,'' Mr. Pino said between games of cards and dominoes in Little Havana's tree-shaded Gomez Park, a few blocks from where President Ronald Reagan, a hero among anti-Castro Cubans, once sampled the local cuisine and later had an avenue named after him.
''If I could go back I would stay in Cuba forever,'' Mr. Pino said. ''But my kids - never. They like it in the States.''

An article on Tuesday about Cuban-Americans' hopes for an end of Fidel Castro's rule omitted a word from remarks by a Miami banker, Bernardo Benes. He said ''half'' in his comment: ''I know for a fact that if Castro goes tomorrow, the day after tomorrow retail stores in Miami are going be selling goods to five million additional people, which is half the population of Cuba.''

HEADLINE: Japan's Vote And the U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
As relations between Japan and the United States rapidly deteriorate, officials of both countries today turned to the same question: Will the strong victory posted by Japan's governing party help contain the trade and security disputes tearing at the Pacific alliance?
For the most part, they concluded that the election strengthened the Japanese leadership after a year of scandal and power struggles, doing far better than most people expected and thus making it easier for Japan to offer concessions and compromises that had been politically impossible before the election. Yet Japan's renewed leadership will barely have time to finish counting votes before it heads into its most tense negotiations with the United States in years.
On Tuesday, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney arrives here amid reports that he will announce a 10 percent reduction in the number of American troops in Japan and press for a major increase in military contributions from this country. On Thursday, the two nations resume talks on mutual demands that the other fundamentally reorganize its economy, trying to reconcile two varieties of capitalism that have taken diverging paths. 
And over the next few months, a series of deadlines will arrive for resolving increasingly bitter specific disputes ranging from building satellites to importing rice. Officials on both sides have expressed fear that this will produce a spring of heated polemics and threats of economic retaliation.
''This election should make things a lot easier,'' a senior American official here said today, after a morning poring over the election results. ''They have bitten the bullet before, and made choices that no one thought Japan would make. It can happen again.''
Even with the Liberal Democrats' victory, however, the ruling party still does not control the less powerful upper house of Parliament, which it lost control of last summer.
Thus, the Government can push through changes that require only guidance from Japan's bureaucracy or action only by the lower house - as, for example, the purchase of supercomputers, satellites or certain services that have been major irritants in American-Japanese relations. But the Government is likely to be stymied in any area that requires legislative action by both houses and thus the agreement of the opposition - something that applies to any major piece of domestic legislation.
Over the last year, impatience with Japan has grown in the United States. Japan now evokes a visceral reaction in Congress that one Senator, Tim Wirth, a Colorado Democrat, said on a recent visit here ''often borders on irrationality.'' Japanese officials say they were surprised to discover last week that a poll they commissioned in the United States showed a far greater distrust of Japan's motives abroad than anyone here expected.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll in January found that the percentage of Americans expressing negative views of Japan had significantly increased in recent months, although 67 percent of those polled said they still have generally friendly feelings toward Japan. As these feelings have built, the big Japanese-American trade deficit in Tokyo's favor has not gotten any smaller.
 
Sensitivity to U.S. Criticism
The Japanese, in turn, are increasingly reacting to American criticism with anger, spurring sentiments among nationalists that if Japan is big enough to supply the world with computer chips, cars and even some foreign aid, it is also big enough to to resist demands from the United States, a country some here regard as shrill and undisciplined.
''We are facing the perception here that the only thing we do is concede to American pressure,'' said Mitoji Yabunaka, who heads the division of Japan's Foreign Ministry that handles economic relations with North America. ''Those arguments are beginning to have some influence.''
In subtle ways, the results of the election Sunday bear out that view. According to final returns, the Liberal Democrats won 275 of the 512 seats in the lower house of Parliament, where 257 make up a majority. The party had 295 seats in the last Parliament. The loss of 20 seats was not as severe a setback as most analysts had predicted, and many of the minor opposition party candidates who survived are expected to be forced into some alliances with the conservative Liberal Democrats.
The Socialist Party won 136 seats, up from 83. Rural areas, where farmers have sensed that the ruling Liberal Democrats were preparing to give way on agricultural liberalization, voted heavily for the Socialists, who promised stronger protection from imports. Several prominent members of the party who made names for themselves as ''internationalists,'' like Motoo Shina, a defense expert who also urged a broader view of Japan's role in the world, were unexpectedly defeated.
 
Prefer Own Guidance
''There is a turn inward that is easy to miss at first, but definitely noticeable in the results,'' a senior Japanese diplomat said.
Still, both Japanese bureaucrats and American officials got the result they openly favored: an election decisive enough that Japan's leadership is not likely to be thrown into a crisis or required to form coalitions with opposition parties to pass legislation in the lower house. ''All of the issues that can be solved by bureaucrats alone are past us,'' a top Japanese trade negotiator said the other day. ''The questions that are left are political.''
In some areas, like defense, the election victory will probably make it far easier to avoid conflict. Throughout the campaign, the Liberal Democrats spoke of the need to preserve the mutual security pact that is the centerpiece of the Japanese-American alliance, and Tokyo seems prepared to pay more of the cost of stationing American troops here.
Undoubtedly, however, there will be squabbling over how much to pay, and over the far more difficult question of whether Japan will seek to use more of its own technology to build weapons, rather than continuing a heavy reliance on the United States.
 
Deeper Divisions on Trade
On trade issues, divisions are far deeper. Chief among them is how far Japan is willing to go in fundamental changes in the economy that the United States is demanding in the talks on the two nations' economic systems, the mutual critiques called the ''Structural Impediments Initiative.''
Some of the American complaints strike at the heart of the way Japan organizes itself, such as the extensive cross-holding of stock among companies that tends to create an exclusive club, one that American suppliers have a difficult time breaking into. Other American efforts seem doomed to fail, like the demand that Japan revise laws that make it exceedingly difficult to open a large, competitive, import-oriented department store in neighborhoods of small shops.
''It would require new legislation that has to pass the upper house,'' which has been dominated by the opposition since the election last summer, a senior Japanese official noted. ''The political reality is that it will not pass.''
Another American complaint, that prices of imported goods are far higher in Japan than anywhere else in the world, has been adopted by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu; today, at a news conference after his victory, he again discussed the need to bring prices down.
Gerald Curtis, a Japan scholar at Columbia University, said today that the stage was set for concessions. ''The L.D.P. can now say to Japan, 'We don't want to open markets, but pressure from the U.S. is so great that we have no choice.' '' But he also said that such an often-used tactic could backfire ''because eventually there is an American backlash.''
The sides seem near a solution on supercomputers: the Ministry of International Trade and Industry is barring Japanese companies from offering the 80 percent discounts that kept American makers from selling to Japanese campuses. The satellite issue is more difficult because Japan refuses to back away from a research project that it says will allow the country to build its own.
And on topics like rice and other agricultural products, no solution is in sight.

HEADLINE: Business Taps the East Bloc's Intellectual Reserves

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Most American companies view the Soviet Union and the newly opening nations in Eastern Europe as potential markets for their products or as sources of low-cost manufacturing labor. And a growing number are expected to tap another resource they describe as plentiful and underused: brainpower.
Although most East bloc nations have well-deserved reputations for shoddy consumer goods, they also have scientific research institutions with distinguished academic histories.
Already, the Monsanto Company has signed a three-year contract to finance biological research at the Shemyakin Institute in Moscow in return for the right to market discoveries in the West. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation of Norwalk, Conn., has supplied equipment for the work of a theoretical physicist in Leningrad on analytical instruments. The Du Pont Company has sponsored research at the Institute of Organic Chemistry and Biology in Czechoslovakia on diseases caused by viruses, including AIDS. Du Pont has also collaborated with Prof. Antonie Djordjevic of the University of Belgrade in Yugoslavia to develop computer software and is seeking to set up joint research projects in the Soviet Union in a number of areas. 
 
Advances Languish
The lack of market forces to encourage the development of products in the East bloc has left many scientific advances languishing in academic journals. But the success of the Soviet space and weapons programs demonstrates that high quality and technical sophistication can be achieved if the right incentives are in place.
''Basic research in the East bloc is world class,'' said Deborah Milenkovich, director of the Institute on East Central Europe at Columbia University. ''But they could benefit from partnerships with Americans in applying the research.''
New arrangements of this kind would help bring Eastern European and Soviet scientists back into the mainstream of research after decades of isolation.
Financing research in the East bloc has at least two important advantages for American companies, said Barney O'Meara, an official of Kiser Research, a Washington-based consulting firm specializing in East-to-West technology exchanges. It can be a way of holding down research costs, and a way of repatriating - in the form of scientific developments - profits earned in currencies that cannot yet be converted to dollars.
''It costs $250,000 to $300,000 a year to support a top-level scientist at major American corporations,'' Mr. O'Meara said. ''You can have the same caliber of talent - complete with overhead, lab space, graduate students and so forth - in the East for $25,000 to $30,000.''
A company that has accumulated Soviet rubles or Hungarian forints in trading with the East could finance local research and bring its profits home in the form of new kinds of technology that can be marketed outside the Eastern bloc, Mr. O'Meara said.
Soft-currency transactions of the kind suggested are largely in the future, but they represent a potentially valuable way to use nonconvertible currencies that companies have been accumulating from transactions in the East bloc.
 
Gains for East Bloc Institutions
Academic institutions in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, on the other hand, are eager to earn hard currency and to gain access to advances in scientific equipment through links to the West. So far, most if not all of the deals have been for dollars.
Among the outstanding research organizations in the East bloc, American executives said, are the Shemyakin Institute in the Soviet Union, which concentrates on biology; the Institute of Macromolecular Chemistry in Czechoslovakia, which is said to be a world leader in polymers, and the Institute for Structural Macrokinetics in the Soviet Union, which has developed advanced techniques for fabricating ceramic materials.
In Monsanto's contract with the Shemyakin Institute, the company will provide $500,000 a year to support 10 Soviet scientists and cover their overhead for work in six laboratories.
''This is a way for us to increase our biotechnical research with some of the finest minds on earth,'' said Michael A. Petrilli, director of international development for the St. Louis-based company. He said Monsanto's scientists were familiar with work done at the institute, which is part of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, and had recommended the alliance.
 
'Network of Contacts' Sought
Mr. Petrilli said the company is negotiating with another institute in the Soviet Union for a contract for research on ways to deposit thin films of hard materials on softer substances, like plastics. In addition to the possible fruits of research, Mr. Petrilli said, the academic links help reinforce Monsanto's position in the Soviet Union. ''We need relationships beyond selling and buying raw materials,'' he added. ''We need a network of contacts.''
For more than two decades, Perkin-Elmer has had ties to a theoretical physicist at the Leningrad Polytechnic Institute, Prof. Boris V. L'vov. In the late 1960's, Perkin-Elmer learned that Mr. L'vov had proposed changes in an instrument that it produced, an atomic absorption spectrometer, which measures the concentration of metallic elements in materials.
''His ideas helped make it particularly attractive in chemical applications,'' said Walter Slavin, a senior scientist in the instruments division, ''and since then we have been back in his laboratory each year for 20 years.''
Perkin-Elmer has provided equipment in return for access to Mr. L'vov's research.
 
'Untapped Technical Potential'
''There is a tremendous untapped technical potential in Eastern Europe,'' Mr. Slavin said. ''Their education system is fine, and they produce top theoretical mathematicians and physicists.''
As for Du Pont, ''we are actively talking to the Soviets right now and we will be visited by a delegation of Russian scientists in early March,'' said Richard K. Quisenberry, director of central research.
He said the increase in scientific interchange was related to the increase in sales the company has made in the Soviet Union in the last few years. Because the ruble is not convertible and hard currency is in short supply, ''the Soviets have proposed giving us something back in the form of products or some technology they have that had been invisible to us,'' Mr. Quisenberry said.
Mr. O'Meara said his company had placed five research contracts in Eastern Europe for clients he declined to identify. All five involve polymeric plastics, with three in the Soviet Union and the others in Czechoslovakia and East Germany.
Mr. Slavin said that despite the tottering economies in the Eastern bloc, it is wrong to think of these nations as part of the third world. Countries like Hungary and Czechoslovakia were as advanced as those in Western Europe before the imposition of Communist regimes stifled development, he said.

HEADLINE: Wariness Is Replacing Trust Between Healer and Patient

SERIES: DOCTORS IN DISTRESS: LAST OF THREE ARTICLES.

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
Doctor-patient relationships are becoming a distorted version of the rosy image so many Americans have long held dear.
Both doctors and patients tell of communication gone awry and of warmth and caring replaced by distrust and leeriness.
The widow of a Connecticut cancer patient, embittered by her experiences with what she felt were cold, uncaring doctors, said that what has happened to medical care is ''hideous and grotesque.''
 
'Most Doctors Mean Well'
A Washington doctor, beaten down by what she sees as increasingly hostile patients, complained that more and more people ''think that doctors are the enemy,'' and added: ''Trusting is considered naive and inappropriate. Why is it that society cannot permit itself to accept the fact that most doctors mean well?'' 
Although there are still devoted doctors who cherish life-long relationships with loyal, trusting patients, such doctors and such patients appear to be a diminishing breed.
''I think there is no question that doctor-patient relationships have changed and changed dramatically,'' said Dr. Elliot Leiter, a urologist in private practice in New York. ''The major problem is that there's an adversarial relationship that wasn't there before.''
 
Physicians Feel Loss of Esteem
Opinion polls indicate that doctors feel they are losing the public's esteem, that they believe patients have unrealistic expectations of what medicine can do and that they think patients are demanding more services than are necessary.
Patients, in turn, express dissatisfaction with their doctors in opinion polls. Sixty-seven percent of 1,500 people questioned in a Gallup poll last year for the American Medical Association said that doctors are too interested in making money and 57 percent agreed that ''doctors don't care about people as much as they used to.'' Three-quarters said that doctors ''keep patients waiting too long.''
The poll also found that 26 percent of Americans say they respect doctors less now than they did 10 years ago. The most frequent reasons they cited were that doctors were ''in it for the money'' or lacked concern for their patients.
Fourteen percent, in contrast, said that they respected doctors more now, the most frequent reasons being that doctors are more educated and more knowledgeable or that the respondents were older and needed doctors more.
In interviews, many patients complained that doctors were acting more and more like aloof business people. To insure good treatment, some patients say, they have to learn all they can about their disease and take charge of their own treatment. The Causes Distrust at 2 Ends Of the Stethoscope The fraying of doctor-patient relationships stems from many causes. The fear of malpractice suits has led some doctors to mistrust patients, the consumer movement has led some patients to mistrust their doctors and feel they have to decide for themselves what treatments they need. The growth of prepaid medical plans meant that more and more people are not able to choose their doctors and are encouraged to consider doctors as interchangeable technicians.
Discouraged by the current climate, many doctors are saying they need time for themselves and that they are unwilling to be available 24 hours a day. And doctors who are feeling an economic crunch have tended to overschedule their patients or give each one less time and attention, in order to maintain their income level.
The disintegrating relationship is seen most vividly in doctors' reactions to the threat of malpractice litigation. St. Paul Companies of St. Paul, Minn., a group that claims to be the nation's largest medical malpractice insurer, recorded 13 malpractice claims for each 100 doctors in 1988, a figure that, although it has fluctuated throughout the 1980's, is still about 30 percent higher than it was a decade ago.
Doctors complain that patients no longer trust them and are always ready to sue.
 
Suits Emotionally Devastating
Even if they win, malpractice suits can be emotionally devastating, said Dr. Michael A. Ross, a gynecologist who practices in McLean, Va.
When a patient decides to sue, ''it becomes a hatred, a vindictive thing,'' Dr. Ross said. Doctors feel that the patients suing want vengeance as much as retribution, he added. ''It's a matter of, 'You should rot in hell and all your family members should rot with you,' '' Dr. Ross said.
Dr. Ross said a friend who also is a doctor was sued recently, and although he was vindicated, the suit permanently affected him and his partners. It ''turned a very well-educated, happy-go-lucky bunch of guys into people who are always nervous, looking over their shoulders,'' Dr. Ross said, ''and it took a tremendous amount out of their families.''
Dr. Devra Marcus, an internist in private practice in Washington, said: ''What's happened is that we have antennas out for patients who might sue us. That didn't happen 10 years ago.''
Dr. Marcus said she found this posture particularly disheartening because she went into medicine thinking it was ''a noble profession.''
 
Affected by the Consumer Movement
Patients have changed in other ways too, doctors assert. They say that the growing consumer movement has led patients to think they can decide for themselves what care is needed, leading them to treat doctors as technicians rather than as healers.
Patients hear about medical advances on television or by reading newspapers and magazines and then challenge their doctors, the doctors say. In a Gallup poll conducted last year for the American Medical Association, half the doctors surveyed said patients are demanding more services from them than are necessary.
''You start off with what is a good trend, that people should be aware of what their problems are and that they should understand their bodies and understand what's wrong,'' Dr. Leiter said. ''Then comes a whole trend that supposes that with appropriate explanations people can have the kind of understanding without the background. That they can understand all the nuances and that they have the ability to evaluate the data without having lived through the development of the data and seen trends come and go or seen conflicting manuscripts and reports.''
 
Patient Pressure for Tests
Dr. Stephen Brenner, an internist in private practice in New Haven, Conn., said he is often pressured by patients who demand unnecessary tests and procedures. For example, he said, patients with lower back pain will demand a computerized tomography, or C.T., scan. He said the scan would be ''clearly very inappropriate'' because it would not necessarily show what was wrong and would be an unjustified use of a very expensive technology. Dr. Brenner said that he has to ''delicately negotiate'' with such patients. ''To flatly say no often loses patients,'' he said.
Dr. Brenner said he has been dismayed to find some of his patients even ordering their own laboratory tests. ''I just saw a woman who had been having dizzy spells,'' he said. ''When her lab tests came back, they included a cholesterol test, her blood group and her blood type. That was clearly off the wall. When I called her and asked how those tests got done, she said she asked for them because she was curious.''
Although, in theory, laboratories are supposed to have the doctor's authorization before doing tests, in practice, technicians sometimes do tests at a patient's request, Dr. Brenner said.
 
Masterminding the Treatment
But many patients say they do not fully trust their doctors and feel obliged to mastermind their own treatment.
Barbara Sikes, a freelance photographer who lives in Midland, Tex., said she became cynical and disillusioned during a three-year quest to become pregnant. ''I thought you go in and tell them what's wrong and they will fix it,'' she said of her initial response to the medical profession. But she said the doctor she initially consulted suggested treatments that Ms. Sikes later learned were considered inappropriate.
The doctor ''wanted to do some very drastic things,'' she said, adding, ''I went to the library and got books on infertility and I bought a few books.'' She ended up going to Dallas and waiting six months for an appointment with a highly regarded endocrinologist.
 
'You Can't Depend on Doctors'
''I learned that I have to get other opinions, do research, and then make my own informed decisions,'' she said. ''You can't depend on the doctors to do it for you. If you're not a desperate person and aggressive and well educated, you will have trouble. If you trust doctors blindly, you're going to lose. You need brains and money and a little bit of pushiness. That, to me, is frightening.''
Increasingly, many patients with serious diseases like AIDS say they feel that they have to make themselves at least as informed as their doctors to be sure they get the best treatment. Peter Staley, a New Yorker with the AIDS virus, said that when he learned he was infected in October 1985, he immediately got his own subscription to The New England Journal of Medicine and the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, a publication of the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.
''My doctor was another resource for me, like a medical journal,'' Mr. Staley said.
Mr. Staley added, ''There are certainly huge numbers of AIDS patients who let the doctor control the entire show, but I consider that dangerous since most doctors in this country are terrible AIDS doctors.'' The Loss Relationships Are Impersonal Doctor-patient relationships are often increasingly impersonal in prepaid health plans, like health maintenance organizations, according to both doctors and patients.
Dr. Paul Bearman, the director of urgent care at Park Nicollett Medical Center in Minneapolis, which cares for patients served by H.M.O.'s, said that doctor in these groups ''have to deal with patients more rapidly than is comfortable.''
''The ability to have the same kind of caring relationship, I think that's gone,'' he said. ''There is the feeling that you could just replace one physician with another and that's unfortunate. A lot of the really good doctors feel bad.''
 
Long Relationships Are Rare
Dr. John J. Barton, a professor and the chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at Illinois Masonic Hospital in Chicago, said that prepaid medical plans ''severed the doctor-patient relationship.'' Because long-term relationships with patients are becoming increasinly rare, many doctors say that they are becoming acutely conscious of their own needs to have free time for themselves and to spend with their families. Some are increasingly reluctant to make themselves routinely available to patients.
Dr. Ross said he recently gave up the practice of obstetrics because he wanted more of a personal life. Although he is embittered by the malpractice crisis in obstetrics, he insisted that that alone would not have driven him out of the business of delivering babies.
''When I look back at what I did before, I say, 'How did I ever live like that?' '' he said. ''People respect my evenings now. Before, no matter how educated my patients were, if they had a little problem they did not feel bad about bothering you.''
Dr. Ross said he will now put off calling patients until after he has gone running or after he has returned from watching his daughter's soccer practice.
 
Thinking About Free Time
Young doctors, too, say they are thinking more and more about how they will live and what sort of free time they will have when they plan their careers. Dr. Brendan Magauran, a 28-year-old emergency room doctor at St. Luke's Hospital in New Bedford, Mass., said he became a doctor thinking he would have close, time-consuming, long-lasting relationships with his patients, like his father, a general practioner.
''My Dad was always available,'' Dr. Magauran said. ''You could call him on Christmas Day and he'd be available. I saw him form lifelong relationships with patients. I saw how happy he was, I saw the rewards he got out of his work. I thought that's what I would like.''
Dr. Magauran was accepted in a general surgery program, but he dropped out, deciding that he could not remain in a field where ''you have to be available 24 hours a day.'' He said, ''I felt it fundamentally had come down to a choice of saying, 'What is more important, your family or your work?' ''
Working in an emergency room, Dr. Magauran will not have personal relationships with his patients. But he said, ''The nice thing about it is that when your shift is over, your shift is over.'' The Results Image of Medicine As Just a Business Medical ethicists say that advertising by individual doctors has reinforced the impression that the practice of medicine has become just another business. The American Medical Association reports that 16 percent of doctors are advertising for patients and that more than 20 percent of doctors in general and family practice are doing so.
Advertising ''is undermining the doctor-patient relationship,'' said Dr. Lawrence J. Nelson, an ethicist with the Bioethics Consultation Group in Berkeley, Calif., who has studied physician advertising. Buying medical care begins to look like ''going out and buying a new or used car rather than going to a physician and being sure that he or she is there for your best interests,'' Dr. Nelson said.
 
Like Finding an Auto Repair Shop
In such a setting, ''it is quite reasonable at times for prospective patients to wonder if the doctor is trying to run up the meter,'' he said.
Some doctors, like Dr. Ross, readily admit that the practice of medicine is becoming much more of a business. Patients look at finding a doctor like they look at finding an automobile repair shop, he said. ''You'll go to a car dealer until he scratches your car and then you'll find another,'' he said.
But patients say they are increasingly concerned and bitter about what they see as doctors' excessive interest in the bottom line. They resent it when doctors ask for payment before they will do an expensive procedure, like a magnetic resonance imaging scan. They also resent the time they spend waiting in doctors' offices so that the doctor can be assured that no income is lost through failure to schedule a patient.
Lila Bucklin, a Connecticut woman who has spent the past two years struggling with doctors to get the care she wanted for her husband, who recently died of cancer, is especially bitter about the monetary aspect of the doctor-patient relationship. She felt that the doctors did not seem to care about her husband. The doctors ''never call you and ask how is he doing,'' she said.
 
'Realm of a Medical Industry'
''You have to dog them around for days sometimes,'' to get answers to questions, Ms. Bucklin said. ''It's gotten into the realm of a medical industry or business rather than dealing with human life.''
At one point, Ms. Bucklin said, she had to arrange and pay a round trip fee of $300 for an ambulance to take her husband a half a mile down the road to a doctor who needed to do a simple procedure that took five minutes. The doctor refused to come to see her husband at home, Ms. Bucklin said, adding: ''It's so inhumane. You feel like a commodity, like a way for doctors to make a living.''
Physicians like the Washington internist Dr. Marcus, who say they went into medicine to have long-term personal realtionships with patients, are chilled by the turn that doctor-patient relationships have taken. ''When you start out as idealistic as I was, it's hard not to be disillusioned,'' Dr. Marcus said.

HEADLINE: New York Property Tax Bills Soar As City's Real-Estate Boom Ends

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The owners of cooperatives, condominiums and rental apartments in New York City, who have already seen their property values stung by the stumbling of the local economy, have been getting more bad news in the mail: tax increases now coming due based on the ascent of real-estate values in the mid-1980's.
The New York City Department of Finance has sent out tentative 1991 tax assessments that are up 15 percent for the average apartment owner. That comes after average increases of 20 percent in this fiscal year, which began July 1. These were far higher than increases during most of the 1980's.
''We are definitely in a catch-up situation,'' said Kathleen Grimm, the chief deputy finance commissioner. 
 
Complaining - A National Rite
A chorus of protests from property owners is part of a national rite during tax season. But many experts say the New York City complaints have taken on a special urgency this year because assessments have increased just as the market value of most properties has leveled off or declined.
Many owners, real-estate lawyers and some state officials worry that the tax increases may further weaken an already sluggish market for co-ops and condominiums. When property taxes go up, the costs of paying for an apartment go up. And when costs go up, values tend to sink.
''People are seeing their property values shot out from under them,'' said Dan Baumol, a former Finance Department official who helped draft the city's property tax procedures.
The increase in assessments is not the result of any decision by the city to raise more money, but simply a reflection of the rising market value of most real estate in a boom that has now faded, and the tendency of the assessment on any building to lag behind its market value when values rise steeply.
Some increases also represent, in part, the phasing-in of taxes that had been temporarily excused for thousands of property owners who benefitted during the boom years from city tax-abatement programs intended to encourage housing renovation and new construction.
 
Up From $500 to $7,000
In an extreme example of how taxes can build up, the bills on the 64 apartments in Mr. Baumol's own cooperative, a converted office building at Broadway and Warren Street in lower Manhattan, would increase from an average of under $500 a year to more than $7,000 a year by 1994. The increase is tied both to a rising assessment and the expiration of a 14-year tax exemption.
The increases are also renewing calls by co-op owners and lawyers to overhaul the city's real-estate tax system, which was adopted in the early 1980's. Some critics say it is weighted in favor of small homeowners and residents of wealthier neighborhoods.
The system limits increases in the assessments on one- to three-family homes to 6 percent a year or 20 percent over five years, while allowing much larger increases on co-ops, condominiums and rental buildings.
State officials say the approach has created many inequities, even among the owners of small houses protected by the limits. People in wealthier neighborhoods, whose property values increased at more than 20 percent a year between 1984 and 1987 and whose assessments increased only 6 percent, received the biggest benefits, the critics say.
''Gross inequities in the city's property tax system have gotten much worse,'' said Edward V. Regan, the New York State Comptroller, who wants the system changed.
But apartment owners are already feeling the brunt of a system under which tax bills build up over time.
''We are being drained,'' said Linda O'Keefe, a Manhattan attorney who with her husband, Kevin, a dentist, bought a three-bedroom cooperative on West 82d Street in 1988, even though they knew the real-estate boom had cooled off. They bought, they said, partly because their monthly maintenance charge would be $834, less than those on many three-bedrooms.
But the assessed value of their building, $520,000 in 1988, has been tripled -tentatively assessed at $1.7 million for 1991. Unless it is reduced through a challenge to the city's Tax Commission, the new assessment would mean taxes on each of the 38 apartments, now averaging $1,200 a year, would rise to more than $4,000 by 1994.
New York State law requires that rising property tax bills in large co-ops, condominiums and rental buildings be increased in increments over five years. That means those affected by the current wave of reassessments will not pay the full bill for four more years.
For many owners, other deadlines are approaching. Thousands living in buildings that got temporary tax benefits under city tax abatement programs are finding that full taxes are finally coming due.
 
Untaxed for 14 Years
Mr. Baumol's building was fully renovated in 1980 under the J-51 program, which delayed taxes to encourage renovation - and was almost completely untaxed for 14 years.
But the exemption expires in 1994. Meanwhile, the underlying assessment - the value a city assessor places on the building for tax purposes - has been rising.
''This is not the Trump Plaza, and people in this building are living on a budget,'' said Mr. Baumol, the former Finance Department official, who is now a financial analyst for NYNEX and has two small children. He said he doubted everyone in the building would be able to afford the huge increase. The owners each would be paying thousands more a year in taxes.
''If they can't sell, I don't know what they are going to do,'' he said.
Nor are the increases being felt only in Manhattan or only in buildings where owners would want to sell even if they could.
''We simply don't have the money the city wants us to pay,'' said Irene Rubin, board president at Lyndon Towers Number Five, a middle-income co-op just off the Whitestone Expressway in Flushing, Queens.
She said many of the 206 apartment owners at Lyndon Towers bought in 1960 when the co-op was built and are now retired. The property tax increase sent in January would require the board to raise maintenance payments 25 percent, to roughly $500 a month per apartment.
City officials say the relatively large assessment increases of the last two years were bound to come, and many people benefited by paying too little tax during the mid-1980's.
 
Not Much Sympathy
Nor do City Hall experts harbor much sympathy for those who have already saved thousands of dollars because of tax breaks and should have known through their lawyers, a check of their building records, or a visit to the assessor's office that the benefits were going to expire.
Ms. Grimm, of the Finance Department, said that because of the ''difficult fiscal times'' faced by the city, ''accurate assessments are more important than ever.'' Property taxes, the city's biggest source of revenue, make up 40 percent of its tax revenues.
One of the complexities that slowed city assessors is that different rules are used to determine the assessed value of a one- to three-family home and of a building filled with co-ops and condominiums. Assessors may value houses by looking at the recent selling prices of homes comparable in age, location and condition.
But state law prohibits their assessing co-ops or condominiums the same way. All apartment buildings must be treated as if they were rentals, and assessors must determine how much rent they would take in and how much that would make them worth.
With most property values levelling off and some declining, a small minority of assessed values have been reduced, and more could be in the future. But because of the city's fiscal problems no one holds out hope for a broad reduction in property tax bills. In fact, if the city's fiscal problems are not reversed, even higher tax rates are likely, many experts say.
Mayor Dinkins has already proposed increases in the tax rates. The tax rate is the percent of the assessed value that must be paid.
The Mayor proposed a 9.38 rate for apartment owners in large co-ops and condominiums, up from 9.23; a 9.69 rate for owners of one- to three-family houses, up from 9.45; and a 9.69 rate for the owners of offices and most other commercial properties, up from 9.54. The City Council must vote on the increases.
''If one looks at the condition of the city economy with an eye on what is going into its cash register,'' said Stephen J. Weinstein, executive director of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which oversees the city's finances, ''one quickly sees that there is breathing room to increase the revenue it gets from real-estate taxes.''
Although the state limits the amount New York City can tax its property owners, he said, the rapid rise in values in the 1980's meant that the city is now far below the maximum. In the mid-1970's, city real-estate taxes came to more than 90 percent of the state's ceiling, he said. Now tax bills now are only 70 percent of it.

HEADLINE: Fear of Disorder Shadows the Opposition Campaign in Nicaragua

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 19

 BODY:
In the heated last-minute campaigning for national elections on Sunday, opposition leaders have found themselves confronted by a dark new campaign issue: not whether their fragile coalition would make a good government, but whether it could even survive.
The issue has focused in part on conflicts in the coalition, the National Opposition Union, whose 14 parties remain deeply divided by ideology and personal rivalries. But it has been sharply underscored by senior Sandinista officials, who have openly hinted of chaos and disorder if the opposition wins the vote.
''A lot of people are simply afraid to see the opposition win,'' said a young Nicaraguan businessman, adding that he had decided after much hesitation to vote for the Sandinista National Liberation Front. ''It would mean immediate confrontation with the Sandinistas, and it would put us right back where we started.'' 
 
Outcome Hard to Predict
In a country battered by a decade of war, economic crisis and political polarization, voters remain deeply reluctant to discuss their personal views, and even the best-informed foreign experts say they are at a loss to predict the election's outcome. Diplomats say the problem is not necessarily that the election will be close - there is little reputable polling data and one side or the other could win by a wide margin -but that clues to its outcome are scarce and contradictory.
Now the uncertainties that would accompany an opposition victory have become a conspicuous element in the campaign itself.
Although Sandinista leaders have publicly committed themselves to surrendering the Government if they lose, they have suggested that the military and security forces would remain loyal to the Sandinista revolution regardless of the election outcome. High Sandinista officials like Tomas Borge Martinez, the Interior Minister, have warned that any attempt by an opposition government to dismantle those forces would make the country ''ungovernable.''
''Given the existence of revolutionary armed forces,'' said the official Sandinista newspaper, Barricada, describing Mr. Borge's views, ''how could the officers obey the wild orders of those who were named Minister of Defense and Minister of the Interior?''
The tensions between the two sides have been heightened by the presence in the opposition coalition of several former leaders of the American-backed contra army, against whom the military and security forces have fought a bitter eight-year war. The stakes of a potential post-election dispute have also been raised by the continued presence of more than 10,000 armed contras inside Nicaragua and at camps across the Honduran border.
 
A Risk of Splits
Although most diplomats and outside experts say the contra army would be little match for the Sandinista military in a showdown, few say they believe that Sandinista leaders would flatly repudiate an opposition victory at the polls. Such a move, they say, would risk grave splits in their own ranks and provoke a devastating reaction around the world. Against the fast-changing political backdrop of the Eastern bloc, many diplomats say such a move would be opposed even by crucial Sandinista allies like the Soviet Union, which provides roughly 90 percent of Nicaragua's oil.
''If they tried to keep power by force, they would be absolutely isolated worldwide'' said a European ambassador. ''There would be no need for an outside invasion; the Soviets would just have to stop the oil from coming and that alone would bring them down.''
Far more likely, most diplomats say, would be an attempt, possibly backed by street demonstrations, to preserve the military and security forces as a source of Sandinista power in negotiations over the shape of the new government.
Mr. Borge and other Sandinista leaders have never directly threatened military force to impose such a settlement. But they have repeatedly suggested that the public would rise up to protect Sandinista influence, a suggestion that has widely been understood to refer to action by the ''Turbas Divinas,'' the belligerent pro-Sandinista crowds that were once widely used to exert pressure on the Government's opponents.
 
Reconciliation Is Urged
Some hard-line opposition leaders, like the vice presidential candidate of the National Opposition Union, Virgilio Godoy Reyes, have joined the oratorical fray over the implications of an opposition victory, declaring that anti-Sandinista leaders would take advantage of an election victory to ''settle the score'' with defeated Sandinista officials. Other, lower-ranking opposition leaders have suggested that the contras could be used to enforce an opposition government's will.
But the main opposition presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who is running with Mr. Godoy, has repeatedly said she would seek an immediate reconciliation with Sandinista leaders, and her solution focuses not on the contras but on the Sandinista military.
Although Mrs. Chamorro frequently speaks of her vow to end the military draft, and says she would like to ''send all the weapons to the bottom of the sea,'' her spokesmen have taken great care to point out that although an opposition government would dismiss the highest Sandinista commanders, the rest of the military and security forces would be preserved intact.
''The armed forces will have to understand that they would have to move gradually from a party army to a national army,'' said Alfredo Cesar Aguirre, the chief adviser to Mrs. Chamorro. ''But we would give them that chance.''
Opposition leaders say they hope that in the short run such a policy will enlarge their vote by convincing the large numbers of military personnel that they need not fear dismissal or reprisals after an opposition victory. If the opposition coalition manages to win, they say, the policy could help divide the military and undermine its value as a tool of Sandinista influence.
But diplomats point out that the continued existence of a strong military whose officers would remain loyal to the Sandinistas could greatly inhibit the willingness of the United States to provide vital foreign aid to a government led by Mrs. Chamorro. It would almost certainly be unacceptable to the contras in the field, raising the risk of a continuing rebel war in the countryside.
In addition, they note, the cost of maintaining such a large military apparatus was largely responsible for the country's deep economic problems. And they say it would place an enormous drain on the resources of an opposition regime.

HEADLINE: In School Conflict, Selma Discovers Old Racial Tensions Are Unresolved

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SELMA, Ala., Feb. 15

 BODY:
In the daily rhythms of life here, whether it is the solemnity of the church or the raucous exuberance of a drag race, blacks and whites touch one another, mingle and even seem to tolerate one another.
But the divisions that surfaced 25 years ago in a bloody civil rights march are not gone. Beneath the surface there remains a tension and disquiet that can erupt unexpectedly.
''We're still two separate and paranoid communities, even though the blatancy of the racism has gone,'' said William King, minister of music at Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church.
Mr. King, a black member of the City Council, said there is a blind spot among some whites that still prevents them from seeing blacks in a variety of roles. And many blacks, sensing this like an invisible net around their lives, feel a bitterness and anger. 
These forces were in play over the last few weeks as a racially divisive dispute over the dismissal of Selma's first black school superintendent sparked demonstrations, provoked fears of violence and disrupted schools. But they underscore even more deeply felt attitudes toward race here, and in many similar towns in the South.
 
Gospel That Won't Offend
Our Lady Queen of Peace was formed in 1970 through the merger of an all-white parish and an all-black one. Over the years, Mr. King has spiced the services with black gospel music in recognition of his heritage and that of other parishioners. But he has moved carefully.
''Not hard gospel,'' said Mr. King, who is a professionally trained lyric baritone. ''It's done in a style designed to not offend whites and with the awareness that not everybody can sing or relate to black gospel.''
Just outside the city at Bill Maddox's Selma Dragway, every Saturday the engines roar, tires squeal and the air is redolent with gasoline and exhaust fumes as nearly 1,500 spectators and drivers join in a glorification of the automobile and speed that has long been associated with the white South, rebel yells and good ol' boys.
Last week the disputes and racial tensions surrounding the Selma schools prompted Mr. Maddox to ponder for the first time, he said, the extent to which there are both blacks and whites among his audiences and drivers. That had not been the case in the 1960's, said the 38-year-old former marine, who added that whites did not consider the importance of the black population at all then, and hardly did more recently until they were forced to. But now he finds himself wondering whether the local unrest might thin the crowd or turn the races into bitter grudge matches.
Pointing down the raceway, he said he hoped that would not happen. ''The only battle lines we have out here was the left lane and the right lane,'' he said, ''We don't have a white lane or a black lane here.''
There has been vast change here since the 1950's. Blacks and whites shop at the same stores and often work side by side. While the fancier restaurants in town cater mostly to wealthier whites, fast-food outlets and family restaurants featuring salad bars and childrens's menus are racial melting pots.
 
Blacks Outnumber Whites
But there persists an ''us against them'' atmosphere, made more urgent in the eyes of some whites because they are outnumbered in the ''black belt'' counties clustered near the state's western border, so named because of the region's rich, dark soil. Blacks are 52 percent of Selma's population of 27,000 and account for nearly 60 percent in surrounding Dallas County.
Indeed, though the schools are integrated, both white and black parents can readily tell of incidents in which their child was called a name or beaten up in what they believe was a racial incident.
William Bernard, a professor of history at the University of Alabama, refers to the ''dual view of great change and no change'' in the South. In dozens of towns like Selma,, the laws have changed; there are black faces on the City Council, the school board and the county commission. But the social order and the economic power are unaltered.
''Like Sinclair Lewis's 'Main Street,' there is a group of real estate, banking and other professional people who are the power in town, and much of the way people live is more affected by the decision of the banker than of the City Council,'' said Dr. Bernard. ''You don't have black bankers, but neither do you have white bankers from the wrong side of the tracks.''
In Selma, there are four blacks among the nine City Council members, and five of the 11 members of the appointed school board are black. There were no black members of either panel at the time of the civil rights march in 1965. Blacks make up 30 percent of the police force and 53 percent of all municipal workers, according to the city's 1989 report to the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Both numbers are large increases from the mid-1960's.
 
'White Elites' and 'Blue Bloods'
Yet time and again in interviews over seven days here - in the living rooms of modest homes, in small factories, offices and churches - the issue of what blacks called ''white elites'' and what many whites termed the ''blue bloods'' arose.
Aspiring black business owners spoke of their inability to get loans and financial help, and whites hinted darkly at a group of powerful whites who behind the scenes discouraged the establishment of new businesses that might raise the cost of labor.
The new round of racial unrest here began Dec. 21 when the school board, in a vote along racial lines, decided not to renew the contract of Dr. Norward Roussell, the black superintendent. The decision triggered a walkout by four black board members, daily demonstrations, a school boycott by many black students and a five-day sit-in at the high school. Schools reopened Feb. 13 with the issue of the superintendent's contract still unresolved.
Dallas County, of which Selma is the county seat, is the most densely populated of the 10 counties that make up the ''black belt.'' In all of the counties, blacks are a majority, ranging from 52 percent in Marengo County to nearly 89 percent in Macon County, said Annette Watters, assistant director of the Center for Business and Economic Research at the University of Alabama.
She said the percentages are expected to rise in future years because of high black birth rates and a high rate of migration from the area by whites between 20 and 39 years old. Underlying these figures is the fact that there is little industry and few jobs in the area. Some blacks say this is because the white elite discourages high-paying industry. Some whites say it is because industry is reluctant to locate in areas with black majorities.
 
To Find a Job, Young Move Away
Whatever the cause, said Ms. Watters, the result is unemployment, which in 1988, the latest year for which county figures are available, was 12.1 percent over all in Dallas County, and probably double that for blacks. Statewide, the unemployment rate in 1988 was 7.2 percent and the national rate was 5.5 percent.
''When a young person is looking for their first or second job they know they have to move,'' she said. ''
Fear of their children's moving away is strong for Otey and Diane Crisman, a white couple whom many neighbors and friends view as racial moderates. Mrs. Crisman, who was 15 at the time of the Selma-to-Montgomery march that helped bring about the passage of the Voting Rights Act, said that while she had no black friends then, her children do. They attend a public school system that has a 70 percent black student body.
''We live in an integrated neighborhood, and 25 years ago whites would have moved out when a black moved in,'' she said. ''We fought to overturn the all-white policy at our church. I'm just a different person from the person my mother was back then.''
Mr. Crisman, who owns a small company that makes hickory-shafted golf putters, agreed. He said that whites 25 years ago considered blacks ''lower than them,'' but today they simply consider blacks different.
''There are places where there is openness, and there are places where there isn't openness, and I don't always say it is wrong,'' said Mr. Crisman. ''We have a black Elks Club and a white Elks Club, and that's all right with me. We are differentm and we have different cultures.''
But Mr. King and others said that such views ignore the overwhelming economic domination of whites. ''We win offices and appointed posts, but it just seems that it's all for show and not for the dough,'' he said.
For some whites like Mr. Maddox, the unrest has prompted a closer look at these economic disparities.
''I see that I have white racers who own auto parts stores and garages and black racers who work for somebody as a mechanic or work in the pulp mill,'' he said. ''The white racers can invest more in their cars than the black racers can, for the most part. I just never thought before that race was involved in my business.''

HEADLINE: VETERANS' LOANS FOCUS OF DEBATE

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's proposal to start requiring veterans to make down payments on home loans uses a forecast that a veterans' affairs official says is too pessimistic about foreclosures.
The Administration, in its budget for the 1991 fiscal year, said it wants V.A. loan borrowers to make a 4 percent down payment on loans over $25,000. Currently, the V.A. loan program is distinguished from other mortgage programs by the lack of a required down payment.
The Administration also proposes raising to 1.75 percent from 1.25 percent a loan-making fee that took effect in January. It also wants to limit the number of veterans who can gain exemption from the fee because of disabilities resulting from military service. 
The Department of Veterans' Affairs says the changes are needed to keep the program afloat in the face of rising losses due to foreclosures. Officials attribute the foreclosure problem to national and regional recessions in the past decade.
 
Some Optimistic Projections
According to the Administration's economic projections, personal income is supposed to rise more than one-third over 1988 levels by 1995, while wages and salaries are supposed to rise by more than half. Unemployment, the forecast says, will probably stabilize at 5 percent of the labor force.
The V.A. based its proposals to raise fees on a projection of likely future foreclosure rates of 10 percent to 11 percent over 10 years, said Bill Lutes, assistant director for program management in the V.A.'s loan-guaranty service. He said that figure represents a balance between the relatively low foreclosure rates of the 1970's and the double-digit rates of the 1980's.
But in a hearing last April before the House Veterans' Affairs subcommittee on housing, Keith Pedigo, director of the V.A. loan-guaranty program, said the 11 percent projection was too high.
''My personal opinion is that the actual foreclosure rate will be somewhat less than 11 percent,'' Mr. Pedigo said under questioning by the Representative Harley O. Staggers Jr., the West Virginia Democrat who serves as chairman of the subcommittee.
''I think the range of 7 to 8 percent is probably more realistic than 11 percent,'' said Mr. Pedigo.
 
Criticism From Congress
The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office used a rate of 7 percent over 10 years. Mr. Pedigo, in a recent interview, conceded that the 11 percent figure ''would be on the high side.'' But he maintained the projection was, nevertheless, ''within the reasonable range.'' He insisted that the optimistic economic projection underlying the Bush budget does not apply to the loan program.
Some members of Congress involved in veterans' issues argue that the Administration put the new loan proposal together too hastily. They say it ignores a separate effort by lawmakers to reinvigorate the V.A. program.
''The proposals appear to be a broad attack by the President and the Office of Management and Budget on a 46-year-old program to which Congress overwhelmingly recommitted itself just three months ago,'' said Senator Alan Cranston, the Calfornia Democrat who serves as chairman of the Veterans' Affairs Committee.
Critics of the Administration proposal, both in and out of Congress, as well as various Government audits, say the V.A. has to bear much of the blame for losses because of insufficient staffing and poor management.
They also complain that the V.A. for too long has unloaded V.A. loan portfolios for quick cash, rather than waiting for the loans to mature.
 
Protective Fund Is Created
The money raised by the higher loan-origination fee would go to the Mortgage Guaranty and Indemnity Fund, which was created in January.
Congress said the trust fund would protect the lender, borrower and Government from losses on bad loans and would sustain itself through the decade.
But V.A. officials, in a budget briefing last month, disagreed with Congress on how well the fund would work. They presented a chart showing that the fund would be $193 million in the red by 1995 unless a down payment were required and the loan-origination fee raised.
Congress and the V.A. disagree on the prospects for the fund's success because they disagree on the severity of the foreclosure problem.
An earlier fund that relied on a 1 percent fee was set up differently and made no effort to be self-sufficient. As a result, $2.4 billion in home-loan losses have been absorbed by the Treasury since 1984.

HEADLINE: Coffee, Chrysanthemums and Cocaine

 BODY:
The drug summit meeting in Colombia wasn't just about drugs. Its vital sub-theme was economic survival. What are coca farmers and processors to do for a living if they don't grow coca? Indeed, what will sustain Colombia, Bolivia and Peru? 
The four Presidents addressed the problem with a clear but undetailed commitment to ''economic cooperation, alternative development [and] encouragement of trade and investment.'' Coffee and chrysanthemums are a good place to start.
Colombia is pressing Washington to renew the International Coffee Agreement, which expired last July, and to cancel anti-dumping duties on cut flowers. On coffee, the Colombians have a case against Brazil; on flowers, they have a legitimate gripe against the U.S.
The coffee agreement, which has been on again, off again since 1962, established a price support cartel among 74 producing and consuming countries. Each producer got a set share of the market. Negotiations for a new pact collapsed when the U.S., the largest consumer, sided with producers seeking bigger quotas, which meant less for Brazil.
The key point is taste. Consumer preference has been shifting from Brazilian beans to a milder bean grown in Mexico, Central America and Colombia. But Brazil had the largest quota, 31 percent, and wouldn't cede one bagful. Without an agreement, producer prices have plunged by almost half; consumer prices are down only slightly, which suggests that someone in the coffee chain is profiting handsomely.
Frequent breakdowns of past agreements on coffee and other commodities should be proof that they offer only temporary price support. But they are an article of faith in countries dependent on commodity income, and Washington has pledged support for a new one for coffee. Brazil, awaiting a new president next month, still hasn't budged.
Another agreement would help all producers. An agreement that properly reflected consumer tastes would also help with the battle against drugs, by giving a boost to Colombian coffee. Washington isn't the problem.
Flowers are something else. The Commerce Department made a preliminary finding in December that Colombian chrysanthemums and carnations were being dumped in the U.S. Dumping means selling a product for less than ''fair market value,'' based on estimated costs. If imports are dumped, the Government can impose duties raising the price to the supposed ''fair'' level.
Anti-dumping laws are a favorite weapon of protectionists. There is no agreed formula for determining what's fair, and producers and aggrieved competitors are adept at manipulating the numbers. The Commerce Department insists that it acts solely on facts. But there are few hard facts in these cases, while political pressure from domestic producers is intense. As usual, the consumer pays.
The anti-dumping fees matter to Colombia beause flowers are its third-largest legal export -$200 million a year, mostly to the United States. A final decision is due in April. The department should use its discretionary authority to find a way to reverse itself, putting the interests of American consumers ahead of a handful of politically powerful growers. The national interest recommends encouraging our Latin friends to ship us more chrysanthemums instead of cocaine.

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
Making the New Serve the Old

 BODY:
New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission is scheduled to vote today on a proposed 12-story office building in the South Street Seaport Historic District in lower Manhattan. The vote raises a large issue: whether the Landmarks Commission and the city will embrace a balanced approach to development in historic districts. Such an approach could actually encourage the preservation of older buildings by permitting construction of compatible new buildings.
The owners of the site at 50 Water Street, Paul and Seymour Milstein, have been trying to build there for seven years. The current design, a brick and granite base with stepped-back upper stories in stone and glass, is undeniably sensitive to the architectural spirit of the maritime district. Some fear that the 148-foot structure would overpower the existing buildings, mostly four and five stories. But that ignores reality.
Some of the smaller buildings are crumbling for want of investors. Unless efforts are made to increase the seaport's overall economic vitality, restoration will languish. By any reasonable measure, the proposal now before the Landmarks Commission strikes a laudable compromise between the district's historic scale and the need for modern development.

HEADLINE: Malpractice Report Told but a Part of Grim Story;
Combine Plans

 BODY:
To the Editor:
That David Axelrod, New York State Health Commissioner, proposes a no-fault medical malpractice compensation program (news article, Jan. 25) is welcome news. It would be the perfect adjunct to the Axelrod proposal for a single-payer universal health insurance system for New York State.
The best news is that it might attract strong physician support for the health insurance program, which is critically important for the people and businesses of the state. 
A compensation program for medically caused injuries with a statutory prohibition against malpractice suits could be easily incorporated into a New York universal health insurance plan. Compensation has worked for workplace injuries, and in 1985 Congress enacted a compensation program for vaccine-caused injuries.
A compensation program that is part of universal medical insurance would not be concerned with paying for additional medical services made necessary by medically caused injuries. These would be covered by the health insurance. Compensation for disability could simply extend the principles of social insurance to cover both temporary and extended loss of earning power.
The current system is wasteful. It uses lawsuits to obtain compensation for the few who can afford to sue and the same suits to deter future malpractice. The high legal costs and unnecessary medical tests done to prevent litigation inflate the cost of care. These costs are passed on to the patient and ultimately to the insurers and employers of the state.
A medical injury compensation program would protect patients better: all injuries would be compensated, and universal reporting of injuries would be a fairer and more effective basis for preventing future injuries than a system that attends only to cases in which legal action is taken.
Prevention of medical injuries would make entering the medical care system safer and less expensive. As an adjunct to the single payer insurance plan, a malpractice compensation program would permit elimination of malpractice insurance and some reduction of physician fees. Physicians, no longer caught in the economic squeeze, would welcome the other aspects of Dr. Axelrod's health insurance plan, which guarantees access to and payment for all medical services.
 
ANTHONY ROBBINS, M.D.
Professor of Public Health
Boston University
 Boston, Jan. 27, 1990

HEADLINE: Cuomo Budget, Far From Austere, Exceeds Inflation Increase

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Mr. Cuomo, at Least, Is Serious'' (editorial, Jan. 18) inaccurately states that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget for New York State is ''austere.''
Under Governor Cuomo's proposed budget, state-funded spending (which excludes Federal grants) will rise by 8.2 percent, compared with inflation of 4.2 percent. The Cuomo budget proposes spending levels 104.4 percent higher than when he took office, compared with inflation of 33.7 percent over the same period. The Governor should not seek to obscure these facts or blame others for the spending growth that his plan represents.
If the Governor recommended a budget that limited growth in total state-funded spending, not just the general fund, to inflation, $1.4 billion less in revenues would be needed. This amount is equal to the costs of canceling the tax cut ($400 million) and the many tax and fee increases the Governor has proposed ($1 billion). These tax and fee increases will raise taxes on everything from used cars to phone calls.
Our economic competitiveness lags behind neighboring states, all of which have lower tax rates on personal income. Since 1982, 196,000 people have left New York State on a net basis. New Jersey, which has a top tax rate on personal income of 3.5 percent, gained 109,000 people over the same period.
I don't understand why Governor Cuomo chose to risk the state's economic future with tax increases, rather than living up to his promise to keep spending growth in line with inflation.
 
(State Senator) JOSEPH L. BRUNO
Chairman, Legislative Commission
on Public-Private Cooperation
 Albany, Feb. 5, 1990
