SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 329 words

HEADLINE: Cuomo Budget, Far From Austere, Exceeds Inflation Increase;
A Gift to the Rich

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York State faces new realities as its leaders construct a new budget. The economy is softening all over the Northeast. Revenues fall short of all reasonable expectations. Demands for aid and services multiply. 
We need a new vision to face such realities. The myth of the personal income tax cut contains no such vision. Indeed, the so-called tax cut has become a tax shift. Faced with decreased state aid, increased demands and continuing state mandates, local governments have been forced to raise the regressive property tax to maintain services. We are not paying less in taxes, but simply paying different taxes. And the burden is falling on those who can least afford it.
State Senator Roy M. Goodman writes (Op-Ed, Jan. 13) that the so-called tax cut would benefit middle-income wage earners. But a family with an annual income of $36,000 to $72,000 would save only $62 to $117 in personal income taxes; those with incomes between $18,000 and $24,000 would pay more in personal income tax.
However, those who make $125,000 to $260,000 will see substantial savings from the personal income tax. They will save $466 to $1,499. Add the cost of the property tax shift, and most low- and middle-income wage earners face an increased tax burden. A family of four with a $24,000 income would pay $130 more in taxes. But, even with property taxes added, those with incomes of $260,000 would reap a $770 tax savings.
We have seen this year that the tax cut program has gone too far. The state must fill a $700 million budget gap just to finish the fiscal year. That's before we grasp the problems for fiscal year 1990-91.
New York State's personal income tax may be higher than other states, but then New York is not other states. We have a history of providing quality, broad-based services that make New York State an enviable place to live.
 
JOSEPH E. MCDERMOTT
President, Civil Service
Employees Association
 Albany, Feb. 1, 1990

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
On or Off the World?

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
Awareness is spreading among the public that profound changes are racing through the world, and that they will make a big difference to the U.S. role.
''What should we do?'' was the dominant question among students and others at a five-college forum here, honoring the Nobel Peace Prize and supporting universal human rights. Given the sponsors and the subject, the attitudes were essentially liberal, not widely representative if the opinion polls are correct.
But they showed a convergence of the right and left. For quite different reasons, both are arguing with increasing intensity that it's time for the U.S. to get off the world. One side argues there's no more reason to accept burdensome responsibilities, the other that America should stop interfering with everybody else and look after its own. 
At the extremes, the right is saying the world is too bad a place, with too many hostile conspirators, for the U.S. to be involved. The left says the U.S. is too bad, too arrogant, too flawed to presume to lead. Both are moving toward a new isolationism, laced with resentment at economic challenges from former clients.
The more moderate ask what the U.S. is doing locked into alliances and supporting a huge military establishment if there is no longer a serious Soviet threat. Why are we parading nuclear weapons around the Indian Ocean and exposing our workers to competition from multitudes who have to labor for subsistence wages? said one young man, a teacher.
George Washington and his warning against entangling alliances are back in vogue. (Was that from the right or the left?) People brush aside the fact that in Washington's time, the maximum speed for moving people and information was set by the horse or the sailing ship. They know that makes a difference, but they seem to think it shouldn't.
There is concern about deterioration within American society, the foreign debt, the decaying infrastructure, the huge gap between the comfortable and the underclass. People want it to be addressed, and feel that can be done by shutting off the world and focusing on our own problems -whether poverty and education, or crime and family cohesion.
For so long, national security in terms of military strength has been the justification for U.S. foreign policy that there is confusion about purpose ahead. A threat expressed in guns and missiles provoked a response of guns and missiles. If the threat is gone, why worry about unpronounceable places abroad?
America's leaders have an enormous job now to unravel military and political considerations in people's minds. It is more complicated to explain why America's political and economic interests remain vitally engaged than it was to picture the danger of losing an arms race.
Remember Harlingen, Tex.? One of President Reagan's arguments for the contra war in Nicaragua was to protect Harlingen from Communist attack and invasion by refugees from a Red South. Who believes that now?
The hardest part for Americans in making a transition to the emerging world may be accepting that not being first doesn't end the need for commitment and cooperation.
There is good reason for pride in the overall success of American policy in the last 45 years. There were failures. But it is now clear that the main goals were achieved - no world war, restraint on Soviet expansion, spread of democracy, which means more friends and fewer enemies, therefore more security.
Countries are doing what we urged, taking more responsibility for themselves. There is no reason to say that means they no longer need us and we no longer need them. The success was achieved by joint effort - not, as some Americans like to think, by the U.S. single-handedly. And it will take joint effort to consolidate it and go on to face new, global problems.
The choice isn't between running the world and getting off. The U.S. is too important to try to curl itself up into some kind of Burma or Albania, and even those small countries illustrate the misery and impoverishment of isolation. What should we do? Above all, understand that we still have a lot to do, both at home and abroad, even if we aren't in charge.
The Bush Administration is being criticized for passivity and lack of ''the vision thing.'' The real failure now isn't in not commanding the world but in not giving Americans a clear sense of our new relations with it and why they matter. That should be Washington's new activism.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
But We Close Our Eyes

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
From the Soviet Union to South Africa, societies are confronting their fundamental problems. Immobilism is giving way to change. There has never been a time in the world like this, we say to each other.
But one great country is not confronting its problems. It is avoiding them, refusing to risk the uncertainty of change. That country is the United States. 
America's problems are no secret. Commissions have reported on them, Presidents talked, commentators thundered. But doing something -something meaningful - is another matter. That would take courage, and cost money.
Education is an example. We have become an ill-educated society. Our working population is at a growing disadvantage with the well-schooled people of Japan and other East Asian societies, or of Germany or France.
In our major cities public education is a disaster: starved for funds, mismanaged by bureaucracies. Middle-class families, unlike their counterparts in most places abroad, send their children to private schools. Huge numbers of Americans are functional illiterates.
In his 1988 campaign George Bush said he would be the ''education President.'' His budget last month, discounted for inflation, actually proposed less spending than the previous year for education.
Health is another profound problem. It cuts across lines of class and region, affecting the middle class and the poor, cities and rural areas.
The United States is one of only two industrialized countries that have no national system of health insurance for the entire population. (The other is South Africa.) Most Americans have private insurance - but at ever-higher rates, burdening them and their employers. Medical care for the uninsured is provided, inadequately and at heavy cost, by local hospitals.
Infant mortality is higher in this country than in some less affluent societies. A recent study in Chicago hospitals showed large numbers of children, up to age 5, who had not had the measles immunization that all should have had by 12 to 15 months.
New York City's great teaching hospitals, once well endowed, are in severe financial difficulty now because governments compensate them so badly for the care they give poor patients. The hospitals are overwhelmed, their doctors unable to function properly. And the crisis is not going to be limited to New York.
Then there is homelessness, a largely though not entirely urban problem. How many of us, middle-aged or older, ever thought we would walk down an American street as we would Calcutta, indifferent to desperation because we are so hardened to it?
A host of economic problems menaces our position in the world: slow growth in productivity, inadequate investment and saving, a tax structure and cultural milieu that encourage business to think of the short term instead of the long. Again, there is no sign of a serious effort to address the dangers.
Finally there is the most profound problem of all, the environment. George Bush said he would be the ''environment President,'' too. His record in office is a particularly graphic example of the current American habit of talking about problems without doing anything that would be really difficult.
Mr. Bush has taken a more caring position on the environment than President Reagan. He picked a genuine conservationist, William K. Reilly, to head the Environmental Protection Agency.
But on a succession of tough issues Mr. Reilly has been overruled. When he drafted a Bush speech on the greenhouse effect and global warming, the speech was toned down and those very phrases eliminated. The President did not call for international action, as the State Department as well as the E.P.A. had proposed.
The President promised a strong policy to protect wetlands. But after weeks of delay, the Administration issued wetlands rules that gave way on key points to developers.
The White House chief of staff, John Sununu, has been blamed in the press for those and other retreats on the environment. But of course Mr. Sununu does what his boss wants.
On all the hard issues Mr. Bush is doing fine in the polls by talking but not acting. The public is hardly in a daring mood these days, and doing something always offends someone. But leadership requires more than the attitude of the Victorian verse:
 
Mother, may I go out to swim?
Yes, my darling daughter;
Hang your clothes on a hickory limb,
But don't go near the water.

HEADLINE: Salary Arbitration a Key Factor As Baseball Talks Are Stalled

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Salary arbitration, the system that has resulted in an aggregate 98 percent raise for about one-quarter of all major league players, continued to keep baseball's club owners and players sufficiently apart yesterday to jeopardize the start of the exhibition schedule.
The chief negotiators for both sides reported after a two-hour session that they were still mired in a deadlock over arbitration. The talks had resumed, after a two-day recess, on the fifth day of the owners' spring training lockout.
The talks were held at the commissioner's office in Manhattan. Negotiators will meet again today. 
''It's going to take a lot of flexibility on both sides,'' Charles O'Connor, the owners' labor spokesman, said after the fruitless meeting, discussing the arbitration issue.
Acknowledging the problem, Donald Fehr, his counterpart for the players, said: ''If we are not at the point where we are implicating the first regularly scheduled spring training games, we are very close to that. It takes more than just a day or two or three of tossing on the side for a pitcher to throw in any kind of a game situation. The first games are clearly in jeopardy.''
The exhibition schedule is supposed to begin March 1, and Fehr said both sides would have to reach a settlement this week for the initial games to be played.
No settlement, however, is in sight. Other issues remain to be resolved, particularly the owners' contribution to the players' pension and benefit plans, but for the moment, salary arbitration is the seemingly insurmountable roadblock to a settlement.
The players want to reduce from three years to two the amount of major league service needed for arbitration eligibility. The owners want some way of controlling salaries gained in arbitration.
The owners, in Commissioner Fay Vincent's plan, proposed a 75 percent cap on salary increases in salary arbitration. But O'Connor said yesterday that proposal was more off the bargaining table than on.
''We've heard the union loud and clear,'' he said.
The owners have made it clear that they do not like salary arbitration. The results from this year's salary arbitration proceedings make it clear why the owners don't like it.
With only a handful of cases remaining, the players who filed for arbitration and have negotiated salaries or had them decided by arbitrators have had their salaries increase by an aggregate 98 percent from last year. That is up from a 71 percent increase the arbitration group had last year.
Players who have lost their cases and those who were eligible for arbitration for the first time have fared especially well.
The 10 players who have lost in arbitration have increased their salaries by 110 percent. A year ago, the losers in arbitration gained an aggregate 16 percent increase in salaries. The 51 first-timers have had raises amounting to 162 percent, compared with 137 percent for last year's first-time eligibles.
While the figures explain why the owners would like to eliminate arbitration or at least alter it significantly, they also show why the players are adamant about keeping it intact and want to expand it to more players.
The players want to return the eligibility level to two years, the standard that was in effect until the last negotiations in 1985. The owners' revenue-sharing plan would have eliminated arbitration altogether. Having abandoned that proposal, the owners, through Vincent, went to the idea of a cap on arbitration awards.
''Nothing's going to happen as long as there are caps on the table,'' Paul Molitor, the American League player representative, said before the negotiators resumed talks today. ''There won't be an agreement. There's no number that would be acceptable.''
Of the 20 players whose salaries have been decided by arbitrators, five winning players and five losers have had their salaries rise by more than 75 percent. Numerous other players who have negotiated contracts have had such increases. The players feel that if there were a 75 percent cap on awards, clubs would have little incentive for negotiating such contracts.
As for the players' desire to reduce the eligibility level, Molitor said: ''We made a concession in 1985 based on their revenue projections. They said they had economic problems. Now that that's no longer true, we asked that we get back the year we gave then. Two years is the right way to go.''
''They have to do something,'' said Molitor, whose salary rose 72 percent in average annual contract value this year after he filed for arbitration. ''They haven't come in our direction. We'll just have to wait and listen.''

LENGTH: 3086 words

HEADLINE: Airlines' Big Gamble on Expansion

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The nation's biggest airlines, stung by higher fuel prices and a slowdown in traffic in recent months, are nevertheless gambling on a turnaround and for the most part proceeding with ambitious expansion plans. But with a record number of new planes set for delivery this year, the carriers could find themselves stretched to remain profitable if current conditions continue, analysts say.
Much of the expansion will be focused on international routes and on filling vacuums in the United States that are created as weaker airlines retreat. Analysts expect weaker carriers like Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines to sell off more of their routes if hard times continue. That would only solidify the position of the large carriers that analysts think are most likely to prosper in the near future: American, United, Delta, Northwest and USAir.
Expansion might not seem the best course at a time when the market is weak and retrenchment could prove smarter. But most airline executives say it is worth the risk to grab the limited number of airport gates, landing slots and international routes when they become available. 
Most analysts agree that it is too early to make major cuts in expansion plans, but some warn that if things do not pick up by the second half of this year, there will be cause for worry.
''It's going to be a rough year,'' said Paul Karos, airline analyst at First Boston. ''Fortunes will have to improve or they will have to begin looking at changing expansion plans.''
After a strong first half last year in which their operating profit was $1.2 billion, the industry's major carriers had a loss of $488 million in the fourth quarter, finishing with a loss of $38 million for the second half of the year, estimated Helane Becker, airline analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton. The 1989 operating profit of about $1.2 billion was well below the $2.95 billion in 1988.
Profits will fall 15 to 30 percent more this year, Mr. Karos estimated. His estimate was fairly typical of those by analysts.
The Air Transport Association, the industry trade group, does not yet have profit figures for the entire year 1989, but it found that even without including the fourth quarter -the industry's worst last year - operating profit for the first three quarters had fallen 23 percent, to $2.3 billion, from $3 billion in the period a year earlier. The association's figures include many smaller carriers that Ms. Becker's do not.
 
Caught Off Guard by Fuel Costs
The rapid rise in fuel costs, up by more than 30 percent in the last year, to about 70 cents a gallon, has caught airline management largely off guard and forced fare increases. Traffic, which had risen robustly in 1987 and 1988 in terms of miles traveled by paying passengers, grew by only 2 percent last year, with domestic flights virtually flat.
Those factors, combined with the collapse of the United Airlines buyout in October and a decline in takeover speculation, have contributed to a 35 percent drop in airline-industry stock prices in four months.
Despite the stagnation in traffic, the industry expects to take delivery of a record 250 airplanes this year, up from the 194 delivered last year. Capacity is expected to grow about 3 to 4 percent this year, compared with 1 percent last year, analysts say.
Thus, travelers will probably find plenty of discount fares as airlines compete to fill their extra seats, although the industry is expected to continue to seek fare increases until fuel costs moderate.
 
Vulnerable to a Recession
The industry has ordered or has an option to buy about 2,500 planes worth $130 billion over the next decade. Such a pace of expansion makes airlines more vulnerable in any recession, Ms. Becker said.
''To finance that they will have to do unbelievably well,'' she said. ''I don't think they are going to be able to raise fares to cover a lot of the spending.''
Still, some executives of major carriers are not ready to begin cutting their ambitious expansion plans significantly, although some are becoming more cautious.
''We laid out our growth plan with the idea that things could change,'' said Donald J. Carty, senior vice president for finance and planning at American Airlines. ''We have not had any second thoughts.''
Delta Air Lines has also not changed course, said Al Kolakowski, vice president for sales. ''While this year may be softer, it was not totally unexpected.''
But the surge in the price of fuel has made other carriers, like USAir, a little more cautious. Randall Malin, executive vice president for marketing at USAir, said the airline expected to phase out more of its older planes and fly 2 percent less capacity than it had planned this year.
 
Two-Tier Wage Systems
Since the deregulation of the industry 12 years ago, airlines have sensed that they will not remain viable unless they grow enough to support the frequent-flier programs, computer reservation systems, hub operations and route systems that the biggest carriers use to great advantage. What is more, because many airlines have adopted two-tier wage systems, which pay newer workers on a lower scale, any expansion means that per-employee labor costs go down.
Because airport gate space, landing slots and cities that are well suited to be hubs are limited, the airlines jump at each opportunity to grow.
If high fuel costs and weakness in traffic persist, the biggest airlines stand to fare better than smaller, financially weaker carriers. The fleets of the three weaker carriers -Eastern, T.W.A. and Pan Am - are made up mostly of older airplanes that consume as much as 40 percent more fuel than some of the new planes. What is more, those carriers have fewer new planes on order.
Such weaker carriers may therefore have to sell more of their routes and other assets to raise the cash to keep operating, said George James, president of Airline Economics Inc., a consulting firm in Washington.
The industry enters the 1990's with eight airline companies controlling more than 90 percent of the market. Following are summaries of each company's prospects and maps showing each carrier's major hub cities. No. 1 Carrier Is Set For Still More Expansion Weakness in passenger traffic or not, the nation's largest carrier has been expanding so quickly that it does not have enough planes to reach all the European cities in the way it wants. But help is on the way. American Airlines, owned by the AMR Corporation, has 446 planes on order or on option. It expects most of its expansion in the next decade to be to Europe and Latin America.
Growth has been essential to American's success under deregulation. In 1984 Robert L. Crandall, chairman and president, persuaded his unions to accept a two-tier wage system. Mr. Crandall has since expanded the carrier's work force to 79,000, from 42,000 in 1984. And because most of the new people were hired at what have become known as B-scale wages, American has made itself far more competitive.
To stay on the fast track, Mr. Crandall scored a coup in December when he acquired the Latin American routes of Eastern Airlines for $349 million. Analysts say the deal, while expensive, will pay off handsomely in the long term. Because international routes are governed by agreements between governments and because airports have limited capacity, such routes are difficult to get.
About 8 percent of American's revenue now comes from international routes, up from 3 percent in 1984.
But while expansion has increased AMR's revenues - up 18.8 percent last year, to $10.48 billion - profit has fallen. In the fourth quarter it earned $38.9 million, down from $116.7 million a year earlier. For the year profits were down 4.6 percent, to $454.8 million. Distracted by Buyout Moves In Effort to Get Back on Top The nation's largest airline until American passed it two years ago, United has attempted to regain the lead but has frequently been distracted by turmoil involving the ownership and holdings of the company.
Most recently, Coniston Partners, which owns 11.8 percent of United's parent, the UAL Corporation, has put pressure on the company's board to do more for shareholders. The stock price has fallen 56 percent, to $130.75, from $294 since a buyout deal fell apart in October. The UAL board is considering a large payout to stockholders or a sale of the company, possibly to a group including the carrier's unions. But no bid has materialized.
Whatever is done, United will almost certainly end up with much higher debt and less money to spend on new aircraft and expansion. Management worries that the airline will therefore be at a disadvantage against the likes of American.
 
Difficult in Other Ways
The takeover attempt aside, last year was difficult in other ways for UAL. Fourth-quarter profit fell 67.4 percent, to $6.8 million. For the year the company earned $342.2 million, compared with $1.12 billion in 1988, when the company had extraordinary gains from the sale of assets. Revenue for the year rose 8.9 percent, to $9.8 billion.
United grew by only 2.8 percent last year in terms of available seat miles, compared with 12.9 percent for American. United's expansion plans for this year once again focus on the Pacific and Asia. But the airline will also begin its first flights to Europe on May 15. Strength of Route System Forces Takeover Defenses Delta Air Lines, the nation's third-largest carrier, is considered one of the strongest domestic airlines in terms of financial resources, fleet age and network of hubs and routes. The carrier's strength makes it an attractive takeover target, and Delta has taken some defensive steps, selling 5 percent stakes to Singapore Airlines and Swissair and buying back some of its own shares.
But Delta, which has historically expanded during downturns in the industry and has 517 planes on order or option, could find itself in a difficult position if the current problems last a long time. In its second quarter, the most recent, Delta reported that while revenues rose 10.1 percent, to $2.05 billion, earnings fell 25 percent, to $64.2 million.
 
A Slow Start Globally
The airline also has higher labor costs, a weaker computer reservation system and a slower start on international service than its major rivals.
Delta made an important acquisition in Western Airlines in 1987; the deal transformed Delta into a nationwide carrier and gave it a strong presence in the West. It has built up Salt Lake City as a hub, coordinating flights with its major hub in Atlanta. In the coming year Delta will concentrate on expanding in Europe.
Eastern Airlines, trying to rebuild under the protection of bankruptcy laws, has made Atlanta its major hub, taking on Delta. So far, however, Eastern has had a hard time attracting passengers accustomed to flying Delta. Known for Bouncing Back, But Record Losses Mount Frank Lorenzo's airline group - Eastern and Continental, which together have the fourth-largest share of the market - has surprised some analysts with its resilience. But for 1989 the company reported the largest loss in the history of the industry - $885.6 million, on revenues of $6.7 billion - topping the record loss of $718.6 million it had set only a year before. And analysts worry about whether the Texas Air Corporation can generate the cash to finance its $5.1 billion debt, particularly if Eastern fails to reorganize successfully under bankruptcy protection and has to be liquidated.
Continental has emerged as a nationwide carrier with a major presence in the East. It is also flying routes in the Pacific and to Europe. After large losses while it integrated People Express and Frontier Airlines, the carrier had two profitable quarters last year, and it narrowed its loss in the most recent quarter despite high fuel prices.
But even though the carrier fits Mr. Lorenzo's concept of what an airline should be under deregulation - one that has the lowest labor costs in the industry and well-placed hubs - Mr. Lorenzo has continued to try to sell it. Keeping Continental in the race with its bigger rivals is expensive, and Mr. Lorenzo likes to shop the carrier around to see if an attractive sale can be arranged.
 
Rebuilding Quickly After Strike
Eastern, which is trying to reorganize as a smaller carrier under the protection of the bankruptcy laws, surprised many people by rebuilding so quickly from a strike by machinists, pilots and flight attendants that began last March. But the airline has had rough going of late. While its pilots and flight attendants have called off their strike, the airline's passenger loads have been low and, under pressure from unsecured creditors, Eastern's management has scaled back its plan to rebuild the carrier.
The goal now is to be about two-thirds its former size, compared with more than 80 percent last fall. Eastern lost $852.3 million last year and expects to lose $155 million in the first six months of 1990. The carrier expects to begin to break-even after that.
Eastern will soon file a reorganization plan with the bankruptcy court outlining how it plans to use its cash reserves of $600 million to rebuild around its new hub in Atlanta.
Most analysts say Eastern must win back customers and begin to break-even by this summer if it is to become a viable carrier. Otherwise it will have to be liquidated. Fate Now in Hands of Man With Little Experience The fate of Northwest, the nation's fifth-largest airline company, is now in the hands of a man with almost no airline experience. Alfred A. Checchi, its chairman, who took the carrier private in August, and the man he brought in as president, Frederic V. Malek, have spent much of their careers in the hotel business, at the Marriott Corporation.
Northwest has historically had a strong balance sheet and a well-maintained fleet. Mr. Checchi and Mr. Malek have embraced much of the growth strategy of their predecessor, Steven G. Rothmeier, the former chairman. They have kept in place his orders for aircraft, which total 229 for delivery through the 1990's. This year the company will take delivery of only 12 aircraft, but by 1994 the rate will increase to 51 planes.
The airline is concentrating most of its expansion on routes in the Pacific, where the airline expects capacity to grow by about 20 percent. Northwest expects expansion on its domestic routes to be modest - about 2 to 3 percent a year.
 
An Image for Service
Mr. Checchi and Mr. Malek think their own strength is in improving the airline's image for service, which suffered after a merger with Republic Airlines in 1986. Northwest recently said it would spend $422 million over the next five years to improve service, adding flight attendants, upgrading the food and reconfiguring its planes.
But the carrier, the biggest United States airline across the Pacific, will soon face more competition as routes are awarded to new carriers. And although the airline is strong financially, the takeover has increased its debt, making it more vulnerable during a long downturn. An Uncertain Outlook After Debt Is Piled On After taking over T.W.A. in 1985, Carl C. Icahn helped the airline return to profitability in 1987 and 1988. Then he was distracted by his battle for control of Texaco Inc. and later the USX Corporation. And many of his employees were not pleased when in late 1988 he took the airline private, ending up with $469 million for himself but leaving the company with $2.6 billion in debt.
Now, with growing competition on its routes to Europe and with higher fuel costs for its older-than-average fleet, the nation's sixth-largest airline has an outlook that is uncertain at best. The carrier is expected to report a loss of about $150 million for 1989, and that is after counting a $150 million gain from the interest on its large amount of cash.
While Mr. Icahn, prodded by the airline's unions, placed a $3 billion order for new airplanes a year ago, the first of the planes will not be delivered until 1994. Some analysts worry that by then the airline will be too far behind to catch up. After Piedmont Merger, Big Adjustment Problems USAir, the nation's seventh-largest airline company, is undergoing what has become a rite of passage for a carrier merging with another major carrier to stay in the race with the big airlines. Despite a huge effort to merge smoothly with Piedmont Airlines beginning in August, there have been problems.
The transition cost more than expected. In the fourth quarter the carrier lost $101.7 million, compared with income of $22.8 million a year earlier. And for the year USAir lost $63.2 million, compared with income of $165 million in 1988. Revenues for the year rose 9 percent, to $6.2 billion.
The carrier's service also suffered, and its on-time performance rate plummeted. There have been more than the usual number of canceled flights and misguided bags.
While performance has been improving as USAir has adjusted its timetables to account for delays, the carrier is expected to lose money during the first half of 1990, Ms. Becker said. Still, analysts say the carrier is strong financially and has a dominant position in many Eastern cities.
The airline has concentrated on consolidating the markets it gained with its mergers with Piedmont and with Pacific Southwest Airlines in 1987. It is the largest carrier not to have set its sights on rapid expansion internationally, although it does have some flights to Europe. Slow Liquidation Seen Without Merger Partner Pan American World Airways has survived on money raised by selling assets, but there is general agreement that the carrier will end up slowly liquidating itself unless it can link up with another major airline.
For the first nine months of 1989 Pan Am lost $158.3 million, after losing $21 million a year earlier. The carrier has not reported fourth-quarter results. Revenues for the nine months totaled $2.7 billion, down 2.4 percent from the year-earlier figure.
Thomas G. Plaskett, chairman and chief executive, acknowledges that the carrier has no future unless it can link up with a strong airline. Talks between Pan Am management and each of the major carriers have taken place from time to time. Pan Am's international routes, particularly its operation out of Heathrow Airport in London, are especially attractive. But no carrier has been willing to take on the enormous task of renewing Pan Am's aging fleet and integrating its unionized workers with its own employees.

HEADLINE: Drexel Fall May Push Rates Up

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
While the credit markets appear to have weathered the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. last week, the full fallout from the bankruptcy is likely to include higher interest rates.
One reason for the debt markets' calm response to the liquidation of Drexel's holdings, ranging from Treasury issues to high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds,'' is that not all of the paper was absorbed by investors after the firm's parent, the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., sought protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code on Tuesday.
 
Overhanging Inventory
Some Government securities dealers noted on Friday that while the liquidation of Drexel's holdings was swift, much of the paper from its portfolio remained on the shelves of brokers and other intermediaries. That overhanging inventory will be one factor adding upward pressure on domestic interest rates, since the increase in supply is likely to lower bond prices and raise yields. 
Other pressure on interest rates will come from overseas, because the cost of credit in the United States is increasingly governed by foreign interest rates, which are rising.
''One of the hidden problems facing domestic borrowers is the concern that has gripped the European commercial paper market since the Drexel Burnham bankruptcy,'' said John M. Blin, the president of Advanced Portfolio Strategies, an investment manager for financial institutions.
''It was Drexel Burnham's need to cover some $30 million of maturing commercial paper on Feb. 12 that led to its bankruptcy filing the next day,'' he said. ''How much more Drexel Burnham commercial paper is still uncovered we do not know. What is known is that the European commercial paper market has in recent years become an important source of credit for many domestic corporations, including Wall Street houses such as Drexel Burnham.''
 
Rolling Over Debt
Commercial paper, sometimes termed capital notes, are unsecured i.o.u.'s, generally for 30 days. The paper is continually rolled over so that, in effect, it becomes much longer debt. Corporate borrowers favor such short-term financing because it often does not show up in their statements as debt, as do most other borrowings.
Many Wall Street brokerages also prefer to use the Eurocommercial paper market rather than borrow from banks, which are increasingly expanding into all areas of the securities business.
Because of the collapse of Drexel, once considered a prime name in the Eurocommercial paper market, Mr. Blin said European lenders were wary about extending such credit and would undoubtedly make it more expensive for borrowers.
''All this comes at a time when domestic banks have become far more cautious in extending credit,'' Mr. Blin noted. ''Many of these banks were still reeling from losses on foreign loans, when their real estate and other domestic loans began going bad.''
 
Higher Japan Rates Seen
David M. Jones, the chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston Inc., a primary dealer in government securities, observed: ''Foreign interest rates have become a major influence on the domestic cost of credit. We expect the Bank of Japan to raise its discount rate from its present level of 4.5 percent once their election results are in.''
The Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu was returned to power in Japan's national elections on Sunday. The party has governed for 35 years.
The markets will be watching closely today, as Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testifies before the House Banking Committee about the Fed's projections for economic growth and the money supply.
While the testimony will be closely scrutinized, many economists, including Irwin L. Kellner, the chief economist of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Corporation, contend that the Fed ''has lost most of its control over monetary policy, which is now increasingly governed by developments in foreign markets.''
 
Policies Under Fire
Mr. Greenspan will be facing many legislators who agree with the Bush Adminstration that the Fed is keeping interest rates too high and that this policy is keeping the economy from realizing its potential.
''He will continue to justify the absence of easing and repeat his theme that the specter of a recession is receding and that the economic decline is bottoming out,'' said Philip Braverman, the chief economist of DKB Securities, the domestic arm of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. in Tokyo, the world's largest bank.
Mr. Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston said the Fed faced two vexing problems. ''One, the economy is still strong enough to give the Fed concern about inflation,'' he explained. ''Secondly, if the Fed eases credit, it could weaken the dollar and discourage foreign investors from dollar-denominated securities, including Treasury paper.''
Further upward pressure on interest rates is expected in Europe, particularly in West Germany. The rise in West German rates is fueled by fears there that moves toward monetary and political union with East Germany could cause a sharp rise in inflation. Rising West German interest rates have already driven up the cost of credit in Britain and elsewhere in Europe.
Last week, Canada, the United States' largest trading partner, sharply raised its basic interest rates, and it may have to do so again.
 
Influences on Rates
Mr. Braverman of DKB Securities also noted that the Treasury's auctions of $18 billion in two- and five-year notes tomorrow and Thursday could keep interest rates from falling.
So could the working capital needs of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is expected to announce its short-term cash needs. The agency, which was created in August to sort out the debacles in the savings industry, is expected to tap the credit market for as much as $100 billion by selling short-term paper this year. Its two initial borrowings through selling long-term bonds proved costly.
Mr. Braverman expects Resolution Trust to borrow $11 billion in the balance of the quarter, initially through offerings of cash-management bills. ''Later on,'' he continued, ''the Treasury will help the R.T.C. by adding $1 billion or so each to their weekly auctions of three- and six-month bills.''
Last week, the prices of corporate high-grade and junk bonds were basically firm. In the Treasury market, the 8 1/2 percent bond due in 2020 rose to 8.46 percent, from 8.33 percent, and a modest flight of capital to the short-term market caused a dip of two-hundredths of a percentage point in the discount rate on 90-day bills, to 7.68 percent.

HEADLINE: Billions Elude Dollar Tally; Is Currency in Use Abroad?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Call it the mystery of the missing money.
Why is it, some want to know, that about $1,000 worth of currency is now in circulation for each of the 240 million Americans when the Government estimates that people and businesses hold the equivalent of $250 for each person? What happened to the $180 billion or so of paper money that has been printed over the years and seems to have disappeared?
No one really has the answer. But specialists think most has moved abroad, some in drug transactions but some from other sources like repatriations from immigrants and payment for imported goods.
The flow has been so great, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, told Congress last year, that ''perhaps more than half of U.S. currency is outside the United States.'' 
For most of the last 30 years, the growth of currency in circulation was quite predictable, closely correlated to the amount of personal spending and interest rates - as spending grew, the amount of currency in circulation expanded in kind. But in late 1988, the Federal Reserve found currency growth in recent years to have substantially outpaced increases in personal spending. It called this an unprecedented development, occurring for ''no readily apparent reason.'' Experts are still baffled.
''It's quite a mystery where all the cash is,'' said Gregory E. Elliehausen, a Federal Reserve Board analyst who has studied the phenomenon. ''I think we'd love to know.''
 
Effects Are Not Clear
Another thing that is not clear is whether - if huge amounts of currency are moving abroad - the effects are good or bad.
Although the parallels are rough, the current upheaval in Eastern Europe has directed some attention to the American experience. For example, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany is proposing monetary union with East Germany by making Bonn's mark, which already circulates outside the country to a limited extent, their common currency.
Some economists say such blurring of the currency borders tends to make the world economy less efficient and therefore all of us slightly poorer. One reason could be that in the case of the United States currency, dollars are often not invested in new enterprises that would create wealth.
But others contend that the availability of dollars in financially distressed countries like Argentina -where billions of dollars circulate as a second currency - probably allows transactions that would otherwise not occur and actually increases total wealth.
One thing, though, is sure: The United States makes a profit out of this through seigniorage, the difference between what it costs a Government to print or mint money and the money's face value. Because it costs only about 2 1/2 cents to print a $1 bill, there is a Treasury profit of 97 1/2 cents if this bill winds up, say, under a foreign mattress. For larger denomination bills the production costs are the same and the profit even greater.
Think of it as similar to American Express selling traveler's checks that are never cashed. Is $250 Per Capita Too Low? The explanation that the missing currency is moving overseas arises to some degree through the process of elimination. The other reasons sometimes raised for the discrepancy between the $250 in currency held per capita and the $1,000 printed per capita do not seem to explain much.
The possibility that people fib about how much currency they have seems unpersuasive because there is no obvious motive for them to do so. Those who suggest the huge rise in currency is the result of the proliferation of automatic teller machines come up against the fact that the machines probably reduce the number of people carrying large sums of ''walking around'' money because the machines make cash replenishment easier. Moreover, larger purchases are increasingly made with credit cards and checks.
Do merchants and other businesses have the missing currency? It seems unlikely because most are sophisticated enough to put cash to work earning interest, and they are also generally eager for security reasons to keep cash in stores to the change-making minimum. At most, business holdings match those of individuals, the Federal Reserve has estimated, accounting for about $125 per capita.
Collectors of paper money are assumed to have only negligible amounts.
 
Effect of Illegal Activities
But this leaves no accounting for about 75 percent of the United States currency that has been printed.
Many people attribute the currency explosion to drug traffic and other illegal or underground activities. Among other things, they cite a rapid increase in demand for high-denomination bills, which officials say do not exhibit the seasonal variations in demand of lesser-denomination notes.
Yet a recent Treasury study on whether to withdraw $100 notes as legal tender because of their purported use in illegal activity found that ''the usage of these notes in financial transactions is limited.'' The study also reported that only 12 percent of currency seizures by the Customs Service in 1988 consisted of $50 and $100 bills and that random seizures by the Drug Enforcement Administration from 1986 to 1988 showed a similar pattern.
At the same time, the part of the underground economy consisting of legal activities that typically involve tax evasion may well be growing more slowly. Sharp cuts in Federal income tax rates have reduced incentives for tax cheats.
 
Dollars Abroad
In looking abroad for the explanation, political instability in Eastern Europe and elsewhere may have signficantly increased recent demand for dollars. Mr. Greenspan had said in his testimony last year that dollars had long acted ''as sort of a second currency in a number of countries.''
The Fed chief mentioned, without further identification, one Latin American country in which $5 billion to $7 billion in United States currency was then circulating freely. It may have been Argentina, which recently has considered ''dollarization'' of its economy as a possible remedy for hyperinflation. John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp and an experienced Latin American hand, noted last year that the dollar is so widely used in Argentina now that ''I received U.S. change from a taxi driver.''
Another example is Poland, where the Government in 1988 estimated that $5 billion of dollars was circulating along with other hard currencies.
So now the United States is in the peculiar position of borrowing frantically from abroad to cover its budget deficit while exporting currency to the four corners of the world.
 
New U.S. Printing Plant
This year the Government will spend $182 million to print seven billion notes, a level of demand that has helped force the Treasury to build a new printing plant, its first outside Washington. This plant, in Fort Worth, is expected to open by early 1991. Printing costs are expected to rise sharply from the present $26 per 1,000 notes when new bills designed to foil copy-machine counterfeiters are introduced.
One economist who thinks the effect of huge dollar exports is economically undesirable is John Mueller, chief economist for Bell Mueller Cannon Inc., an Arlington, Va., research firm. He said that while this was a ''pure boon'' to the Treasury because it allowed the Government to spend more than it taxed its citizens or borrowed in capital markets, the overall effect was probably harmful.
He reasons that these dollars are used heavily abroad to store value -a usually lesser characteristic of money than as a means of payment. They are kept under mattresses or exchanged hand-to-hand rather than invested in wealth-creating businesses, he said.
On the other hand, Alan S. Blinder, professor of economics at Princeton University, suggested that the existence of such offshore dollars ''probably increases the efficiency of the world economy'' by allowing transactions that would otherwise not take place.
Richard N. Cooper, a Harvard economics professor and formerly Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, has done some research on the subject and said a flow of dollars into a country shows something is wrong with the foreign economy. This ''makes sensible economic management in those countries more difficult,'' he said, because the supply cannot be controlled and because it contributes to an underground economy that cannot be taxed.
 
Reversal Might Be a Problem
Paul Samuelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said he does not think ''it's anything bad'' for the United States to be sending so much of its currency abroad. He noted that Israeli-held dollars had helped cure that country's triple-digit inflation in the early 1980's. But there might be a problem, the Nobel laureate said, if the dollar became suddenly unpopular and the process ''reversed.''
More technically, however, it is widely accepted that the vast foreign holdings of American currency have rendered the aggregate that the Fed calls the monetary base, the bulk of which consists of currency, nearly useless as an analytical tool, much less a policy target.
One obvious American gain from widespread acceptance of the dollar - the world's principal means of black-market exchange, Professor Blinder called it - is the ego boost and extra convenience for the nation's travelers.
''Our money is universal,'' said Ira M. Polikoff, a spokesman for the Treasury's Bureau of Engraving and Printing. ''There's not one country that won't accept it.''

HEADLINE: Japan Business Leaders Ambivalent on Election

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Japan's worried business community expressed relief but little joy after the election victory Sunday of the pro-business Liberal Democratic Party. Some executives expressed concern over the economic problems that a divided Parliament faces in coming months.
Big business raised more than $200 million and perhaps as much as $1 billion to help the Liberal Democrats fend off a concerted opposition challenge in what was the most expensive election in Japanese history.
But in their comments today, many business leaders were decidedly ambivalent. Although they view the ruling party as preferable to the opposition, some executives said the Liberal Democrats did not have the will or ideas to push through effective legislation that addresses domestic economic problems. 
 
Opportunity Was Lost
''It is not a result we can be happy with,'' said a top auto industry executive. ''It was a brief opportunity for real change, and it was lost. That may be good in the short run, but over time we will pay the price in not reforming the economy, for consumers and for everyone else.''
Eishiro Saito, chairman of the Keidanren, Japan's most politically powerful business group, commented, ''I can breathe a little easier now that political stability is secured, at least for the time being.''
That stability is likely to help Japan address the growing trade tensions with the United States, some executives said. But on the domestic front, economic worries have come to the fore.
The Tokyo stock market reflected this mood. The Nikkei index rose 150 points at the opening today, in a brief flurry of excitement. By midday it was down and closed with a loss of 237.72 points, at 37,222.60. Trading volume was a dull 330 million shares.
Investors apparently focused on nagging inflationary pressures. The economy is growing smartly, but there is a severe labor shortage, which is putting upward pressure on wages. In addition, rising land prices and the weak yen have helped fuel rumors that the Bank of Japan may be prepared to raise interest rates for the fourth time in less than a year.
Inflation is running at only about 2 percent this year, but investors have focused more on the challenges ahead than the current state of affairs.
The bond market took a hammering today. Interest rates on the Government's benchmark 10-year bond jumped to 6.93 percent from 6.87 percent.
 
'An Awful Lot to Do'
''The attitude in the markets was, 'O.K., they won, but now they have to get down to business, and there's an awful lot to do,' '' said Robert Alan Feldman, an economist at Salomon Brothers Asia.
Paul A. Summerville, an economist at Jardine Fleming Securities, observed, ''There's an undercurrent of pessimism that came through once the election was out of the way.''
The Government also faces a number of tough social challenges. Many believe the Parliament must find ways to share the nation's prosperity with consumers by reducing prohibitive land and housing prices and eliminating price differentials that can make many consumer goods significantly more expensive here than overseas. In addition, the Liberal Democrats must find a way to alter the unpopular consumption tax, many in the business community believe.
All that will be difficult because, although the Liberal Democrats held on to the lower house with a reduced majority, they lost a majority in the upper house of Parliament last summer. That split means that the ruling party may face a stalemate on important legislation.
''With the situation between the two houses, it will be very difficult to create aggressive legislation,'' said Takatoshi Ito, an economics professor at Hitotsubashi University. ''There is great uncertainty because of the possibility of deadlock.''
This problem was underscored by the fact that the Japan Socialist Party, the leading opposition group, made sizable gains in the lower house. While many in the business world reject the program offered by the Socialists, they worry that the Liberal Democrats may not be able to fashion creative solutions to the nation's problems, further strengthening the Socialists in later elections.
The Socialists' success, said Eiji Suzuki, president of the Japan Federation of Employers, ''displayed the peoples' strong criticism about the Liberal Democrat's politics.''
And Mr. Saito of the Keidanren said, ''I hope the L.D.P. loses no time in reforming itself and grapples boldly with such problems as political reform, improvement of relations with other countries, and land reform so that we can realize a truly affluent society.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Consultant in Textiles Becomes Manufacturer

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Roger J. Gilmartin, a European textile consultant, will try his hand at running an American textile company, Opp and Micolas Mills Inc., which has mills in Alabama and offices in New York. One of his strategies will be to expand export markets in Europe.
Mr. Gilmartin, 45 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive of Opp and Micolas, a unit of Johnston Industries Inc. He succeeds Gaines R. Jeffcoat, 67, who will remain a vice president and director of Johnston Industries. Philip Stanley, 57, will continue as president and chief operating officer of Opp and Micolas. 
Mr. Gilmartin has been based in Brussels as senior vice president and director of Werner International Inc., management consultants to the textile and clothing industry. Werner is part of Saul Steinberg's Reliance Group Inc.
Mr. Gilmartin said he had been doing things like advising the Australian Government on textile policy. He has also been working closely for the last six years with Opp and Micolas, a Werner client.
The mill, which makes textiles for the industrial and home furnishings markets, has been looking to export markets in the last four years, Mr. Gilmartin said, and he hopes to increase that business by grafting his international experience onto managment.
''Many American mills in the export markets are opportunistic,'' he said, ''going in and out according to economic conditions. We want to have a constant presence.''
Mr. Gilmartin grew up in Britain and received a degree in textile engineering from the Bolton Institute of Technology. He became what is called in Britain a Chartered Textile Technologist.
He had started out wanting to be a journalist, he said, but took a summer job in a textile mill, found that he enjoyed the industry and applied to the textile school. Later, from 1969 to 1973, he worked for Courtaulds, a diversified British giant, as it was building a textile division.
Mr. Gilmartin is spending part of this week in Opp, Ala., population 8,000 and the site of the Opp and Micolas mills. He will be operating mostly from the New York offices and is looking for a home in the region for his wife, Lynn, and their three children.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Aerospace Plays Develop in Japan

BYLINE: By Robert J. Cole

 BODY:
MITSUBISHI HEAVY INDUSTRIES, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries, which are among the biggest foreign suppliers of aircraft components to the Boeing Company, ''are going to be the core of the Japanese aerospace industry,'' Dr. Edward Yardeni, economics director for Prudential-Bache Securities, forecast the other day.
And Donald M. Krueger, the aerospace analyst for Sanyo Securities Ltd. in New York, said aerospace was becoming so crucial to Mitsubishi that there was a strong chance that by the end of the decade the big Japanese company could change its name to Mitsubishi Aerospace Industries.
Mr. Krueger said he expected Mitsubishi's profits to grow sharply this year, reflecting its growth in the aerospace sector. 
For the six months ended Sept. 30, Mitsubishi's net profits soared 90 percent, to 31.2 billion yen (about $215.7 million at current rates). Kawasaki's profits jumped 48.5 percent, to 4.9 billion yen ($33.9 million). Fuji's net profits slumped 18 percent, to 5.1 billion yen ($35.3 million), and it reported a loss on operations for the period of 3.99 billion yen ($27.6 million). Picking Mitsubishi as his favorite among the three, Mr. Krueger said: ''Its stock might not move a lot tomorrow or even in the next year. But just as an investor might want G.E. as a long-term core stock in a U.S. portfolio, he or she might want Mitsubishi Heavy Industries as a long-term fundamental core stock in a Japanese portfolio. We're recommending it.''
Dr. Yardeni said the three Japanese companies are ''completely involved in building the FSX fighter with General Dynamics.'' He said Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry ''has been providing them with lots of seed money to stimulate aerospace.''
The three companies, which have big capitalizations, are ''in a consolidation phase,'' said Masahiko Goto, first vice president of New Japan Securities International of New York, Stocks with big capitalizations, he said, were a major force in the Japanese bull market until the middle of last year, when prices peaked.
As in other markets, he explained, interest rates are a big factor in how Japanese stocks behave. When the official Japanese discount rate was declining, as it was several years ago, he said, big-capitalization issues were big beneficiaries. Now, with rates rising, he said, smaller-capitalized issues lead the market, which is another way of saying that Mitsubishi, Kawasaki and Fuji Heavy Industries are lagging.
Mr. Krueger of Sanyo said he would ''stay away'' from Fuji Heavy Industries because the Subaru, its automotive product, was ''not selling well'' and the company, even though the Nissan Motor Company rejects the idea, might one day merge with Nissan.
He argued that while Kawasaki was similar to Mitsubishi, Mitsubishi ''is a stronger play in aerospace.''
He said he expected ''lackluster growth'' in other Mitsubishi businesses but that aerospace could become its most important sector in the next three years. He forecast that the company's revenues would rise but that profits could lag while it concentrated on getting into the market.
Mitsubishi was trading yesterday on the Tokyo Stock Exchange at 1,070 yen (about $7.40 a share); Kawasaki at 1,010 yen (about $7 a share), and Fuji at 863 yen (about $6).
The long-range Japanese strategy, some analysts argued, is to make aircraft parts now, and, through licensing agreements and joint ventures, to learn what they need to become competitive with the American industry in civil aviation.

HEADLINE: Dollar Rises Against the Yen

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The dollar closed slightly higher today against the yen, which weakened after the Liberal Democratic Party retained power in Japan's general election on Sunday.
The market was generally thin, with the United States markets closed for Washington's Birthday.
Traders said the Liberal Democrats had been widely expected to win the election, and the result was quickly overtaken by renewed speculation that the Bank of Japan would raise interest rates. 
''The next thing on the agenda will be the expected Japanese interest rate hike which will be little more than an official confirmation of what market rates are anyway,'' one trader said.
The market has been expecting Japan to raise interest rates, and traders said the money-supply figures that Japan is to report on Tuesday might give the central bank the opportunity it has been waiting for.
The dollar closed at 1.6759 West German marks in London, down slightly from 1.6777 marks on Friday. Against the yen, the dollar rose to 144.55 yen, from 144.15.
The pound closed at $1.7050, up from $1.6995 on Friday. The dollar fell slightly against the Swiss franc to end at 1.4875, compared with 1.4885. It rose to 5.6915 French francs, from 5.6885.
Gold fell $1, to $416.75 an ounce in London.
In Tokyo stock trading, the key 225-share Nikkei average closed 237.72 points, or 0.63 percent lower, at 37,222.60 after easing 11.67 on Friday.
''An excuse for market weakness has been election anxiety,'' said Marshall Auerback, fund manager at G. T. Management of Japan. ''Now people are saying maybe there's something more fundamental to be anxious about.''
London stock prices fell heavily today, but traders were unable to find any specific reason for the weakness. ''There are just no buyers at all,'' one trader said.
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British shares sank 28.8 points, to 2,297.1, near the day's low of 2,294.9.
West German stocks slumped in a quiet Frankfurt session, depressed by a continued fall in German bonds as traders worried about the economic cost to West Germany of rescuing East Germany's economy. The DAX index of 30 shares fell 24.47 points, to 1,869.19.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
GORBACHEV VOICES NEW RESERVATIONS ON GERMAN UNITY

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 20

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev conceded today that the two Germanys had a right to unity but stressed the Soviet Union's own ''inalienable right'' to insure that reunification does not lead to ''moral, political or economic damage'' for the Soviet Union.
In his longest remarks on the likelihood of a reunified Germany, the Soviet leader seemed to go out of his way to reassure Soviet people, possibly unnerved by the unification of their World War II enemy, that the Germans had changed in the postwar years. Mr. Gorbachev also emphasized that nations like Poland that suffered in the war must not be ''left out'' of the evolving formula for German unity.
 
'Several Years' to Unity
Other qualifications over the fast pace of the moves toward reunification were voiced in a separate interview by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who estimated that reunification would not happen ''as quickly as they imagine in Bonn.'' Many West Germans have talked of unification before the end of this year. 
''It requires several years,'' he said in an interview with the Soviet Government newspaper, Izvestia, again stressing Moscow's concern that a united Germany not be part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Bonn and the Western allies want a united Germany to be part of NATO with the provision that no NATO troops would be stationed in East Germany.
Procedures for German unity were worked out in Ottawa last week, where it was agreed that the two Germanys and the four major Allies from the war - Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States -would be responsible for the details.
 
Broader Approval
After that, there is a general agreement that a 35-nation East-West conference involving the United States, Canada and most of the nations of Europe would be held to give broader approval to a German accord.
Poland, concerned that a unified Germany might seek to regain lands given to Poland at the end of the war, has pleaded to be included in the talks. On this issue the Solidarity Government has sought Soviet backing, even though it has loosened ties with Moscow.
While not backing away from the Ottawa agreement, Mr. Gorbachev apparently sought to reassure the Poles by saying: ''We rule out an approach when three or four will initially arrange things and then tell the other participants the already agreed upon position. This is unacceptable.'' [Excerpts from interview, page A11.] President Gorbachev's long remarks were made in an interview to be published Wednesday in the Communist Party daily newspaper Pravda. The Soviet press agency Tass made the remarks available in advance of publication.
In the interview, the Soviet leader blended favorable observations that ''there is no denying the German people learned lessons from Hitler's rule,'' with cautions that ''no one has a right to ignore the negative potential formed in Germany's past.''
He also took note of his recent sudden acceptance of President Bush's proposal on European troop reductions. He referred to his concession of a numerical advantage to the United States as an ''important and positive'' result of the Malta summit meeting in early December, rather than as a weakening of Soviet defenses.
The Soviet leader's remarks came as the Soviet public prepared for another critical round of competitive regional and local elections in which citizens and politicians have been increasingly outspoken on their concerns over Germany and their responsibility to the millions who died in the war.
 
'Concern Is Understandable'
''This concern is understandable both historically and psychologically,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. But he added that ''new generations matured in both German states.''
''Their view of Germany's role in the world is different from the one that existed over the past 100-odd years and particularly in the period of Nazism,'' he said.
The Ottawa formula is to set up a two-stage process by which West and East Germany first would discuss the domestic details of unity and then meet on the issues of postwar security with the Allied powers that defeated Nazi Germany.
Mr. Gorbachev did not retreat from the Ottawa agreement, asserting that the Soviet Union never opposed German reunification and that ''the Germans should themselves decide on the ways, forms and time-frame of their unification.''
He noted that in the early postwar years, when the focus at international meetings was on how to bring about German unification, the Soviet Union often made proposals toward this end. Efforts to united Germany eventually broke down in the East-West divisions of the cold war. By 1949, separate West and East German states were created, and two opposing military blocs were in place by the mid-1950's.
 
Other Countries' Interests
While asserting that the Germans should decide for themselves on unification, Mr. Gorbachev said ''this is just one side of the matter.'' He repeatedly stressed the importance of approaching the issue ''stage by stage'' with a basic aim toward ''the general European process'' rather than as prematurely determined formula that does not provide full consideration to ''the special interests of other countries.''
''It is very important that Germans, deciding the question of unification, should be aware of their responsibility and of the fact that not only the interests but also the feelings of other peoples should be respected,'' he continued, citing the enduring memory of the horrors of the war.
The Germanys, he added, should be particularly sensitive in this regard toward the people of the Soviet Union, who have ''an inalienable right'' to ''exert efforts to insure that our country should not sustain either moral, political or economic damage from German unification.''
 
Shevardnadze Remarks
The latter concern, economic damage from a dominant unified Germany, is one of the fears being voiced lately by the economically battered Soviet public.
Mr. Shevardnadze, in his separate interview, which may have been aimed as much at a foreign audience, said that while Bonn pushes the drive for reunification, Moscow ''has not yet had its say'' on how the Ottawa formula should be applied.
''Let nobody think that Moscow will remain indifferent if a united Germany joins NATO,'' he said. ''We have some variants to suggest,'' he said, without citing such specifics as the neutrality he previously proposed.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Modest Growth In the Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and the dominant force in economic policy making, told Congress today that the economy's ''weakest point may have passed'' and that the nation could expect ''moderate economic expansion'' this year.
In testimony much more explicit than remarks he made three weeks ago, Mr. Greenspan told a House subcommittee that Federal Reserve officials expected the economy to grow by 1.75 to 2 percent in 1990. In the previous testimony he had said for the first time since the slowdown began in the fall that the chances of recession had diminished.
 
Less Optimistic Than Bush
While slightly more favorable than the consensus of private economists, today's forecast is significantly less optimistic than the Bush Administration's projections. By the Administration's own reckoning, a growth rate in the range Mr. Greenspan suggested would result in a budget deficit in the next fiscal year at least 25 percent higher than the Administration is anticipating. 
Mr. Greenspan's report on monetary policy and the economic outlook, which is required by law every six months and which is watched carefully by the financial markets, implied that the central bank would not move soon to lower interest rates further.
Prices in the stock and credit markets fell sharply today, in apparent reaction to the prospect that the Federal Reserve is not planning to ease interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 38.74 points, and the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell more than $20 for each $1,000 of face value, while its yield jumped to 8.66 percent, from 8.46 on Friday. [Pages D6 and D12.] Testifying before the Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy of the House Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan made these other points:
* The Government never had an ''inclination'' to bail out Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the brokerage house that specialized in high-yield ''junk bonds'' and that collapsed last week.
* The trend toward junk bonds got out of hand in the late 1980's, but such high-yield bonds, which provide financing for high-risk ventures, have a ''logical niche in the system.''
* The high level of corporate debt in the United States threatens economic expansion.
* The inflation and unemployment rates should remain steady in 1990, with inflation running at 4 to 4.5 percent and unemployment in the fourth quarter at 5.5 to 5.75 percent.
* The American economy is influenced much more from abroad than in the past, but interest rates here primarily reflect domestic economic conditions.
* The money supply, by the most common measure, will be allowed to grow by 3 to 7 percent, the same range that was set last summer.
 
Possible Turning Point
Addressing the outlook for the economy, Mr. Greenspan said the anemic growth rate in the fourth quarter of last year, a half of 1 percent, may have marked a turning point.
From recent data, he said, ''one can infer the beginnings of a modest firming in economic activity.'' He added, ''While we cannot be certain we are as yet out of the recessionary woods, such evidence warrants at least guarded optimism.''
Mr. Greenspan said an inflation rate in the neighborhood of 4 percent was too high and the Fed was determined to bring it down.
An annual growth rate of 1.75 to 2 percent would be about the same as the 2.4 percent rate in 1989, if the agricultural rebound from the drought in 1988 is discounted, he said.
The Bush Administration is basing its estimate of a $63 billion deficit in the 1991 fiscal year on a 2.6 percent growth rate in the 1990 calendar year.
 
Deficit Would Be Larger
In the budget documents it sent Congress last month, the Administration estimated that a growth rate of 1.9 percent, at the upper end of Mr. Greenspan's range, would result in a deficit more than $14 billion larger.
That is because the Government receives more tax revenue in a stronger economy. In addition, if the diminished concern about recession results in the Federal Reserve raising interest rates to restrain inflation, that could lead to an even larger deficit, since the Government would have to pay higher interest on the securities it issues.
The average forecast of 50 private economists polled 10 days ago by Blue Chip Economic Indicators was that the gross national product would rise by 1.6 percent this year.
So far this year, Mr. Greenspan observed today, the central bank has left the interest rates it directly controls unchanged, but the rates on Treasury securities and private loans have risen because of favorable economic data, a rise in energy prices and higher rates in Europe.
