HEADLINE: Japan's Status Quo;
Economic Interests Stifle the Outrage In the Electorate Caused by Scandals

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 20

 BODY:
In the last year, Japan has experienced the downfall of two Prime Ministers, widespread outrage over the official and after-hours behavior of politicians, protests by women and other events suggesting that this most stable of nations was on the verge of great political change.
Yet today, as the governing Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu savored its sweeping victory in the elections on Sunday, many Japanese were asking a new question. Why did voters cap an extraordinarily turbulent year with a resounding endorsement of the status quo?
The clear consensus among analysts, even in the governing party, is that after a year of scandal and criticism of its policies, the party's victory was less an affirmation for its record than a reflection of voter uneasiness with the ideologically splintered and querulous opposition.
''The Liberal Democratic is not a party of strong supporters, but a strong party of weak supporters,'' said Gerald L. Curtis, director of the East Asia Institute at Columbia University. He said voters ''held their noses'' and did what they have done for 35 years - keep the party in power. 
 
Economics and Outrage
Japan also proved no exception to the axiom that it is difficult to reject an incumbent party at a time of peace and prosperity. Despite many concerns about growing economic inequities, Japan's economic growth has pleased its citizens no less than it has astonished the world.
As for peace, security concerns were not an issue, except insofar as they worked against the Socialist Party's doctrine of favoring cutbacks in the military partnership with the United States. Partly because it is a key to Japan's economic success, that partnership enjoys broad public support.
In a broader sense, many analysts said the potential for change had been exaggerated this year, as it often has been in the past. ''There was indignation among the voters,'' a Government official said. ''But people responded more to their economic interests than their sense of outrage.''
More than any political party in the world's major industrial democracies, the Liberal Democratic Party has faithfully represented the views and interests of the conservative establishment. For its service, the party has never been turned out of office since its inception in 1955.
 
Sales Tax and Women
Last year, however, the party plummeted in the public's esteem and, for the first time in its history, it lost an election for the upper house of Parliament. Thanks to its continuing majority in the more powerful lower house, the party held on to the Government and the post of Prime Minister.
After the elections, Prime Minister Kaifu promised changes, but most did not take place. The electorate did not seem to care, and the system worked in the party's favor. Although the Liberal Democrats won less than half the total vote, they captured most seats because the opposition was divided.
For example, women were at the forefront last year of protests against the newly enacted sales tax and the disclosures of extramarital affairs of senior politicians. Mr. Kaifu responded by promising to bring more women into government, and myriad articles were written about feminist fury in Japan.
The governing party ended up fielding only one woman of 337 candidates, and she lost on Sunday. The Socialist Party did only a little better, somewhat to the embarrassment of Takako Doi, the Socialist leader who had advanced farther than any woman in Japanese politics.
 
Campaign Contributions
''The number of women is not that large, in fact it's rather small,'' Miss Doi said, adding that lower-house candidates are drawn from the ranks of local organizations less concerned with social revolution than with who can be most effective in channeling patronage to the district.
Mr. Kaifu and party leaders also promised that there would be less reliance on party factions and on money from business and special interests. There too, their promises were ignored, and again the voters did not seem to care.
Because most of Japan's 130 parliamentary districts elect three to five members, voters seem to think that fights within the governing party are inevitable, and that joining a faction continues to be a local way for a candidate to get access to money and electoral organizational help.
The governing party won the election not only because it was the best-organized party, with ties patiently cultivated over the years to countless local organizations, but because it was also the richest.
 
Role of Recruit Scandal
It raised $200 million in bank loans and industry contributions, a sum said to represent only a fifth of the total raised from small businesses and individuals. Direct corporate contributions are not illegal in Japan, unless it can be proved in court that a specific favor was done in return.
The Socialists tried to make an issue of those contributions, but they did not succeed in stirring widespread resentment of the corporate sector in a country that owes so much of its prosperity to big-business success.
After a huge amount of publicity and hand wringing, the corruption issue of last year, centering on millions of dollars in cash and stock distributed by the Recruit Company, the information-services conglomerate, failed to backfire even on the politicians named as recipients. Even one politician who was indicted was re-elected.
Indeed, this week, those same candidates said they had been exonerated by the voters, as if all the acts of contrition - the apologies, resignations and demands for reform - had suddenly been rendered irrelevant.
 
Money and Political Influence
Tolerance of such behavior seems related to a feeling that it is all right for politicians to receive gifts of cash or stock as long as the funds do not benefit them personally. Indeed, the evidence is that the electorate can be impressed that the flow of money is a sign of political influence.
Mr. Curtis of Columbia University, a longtime observer of Japanese elections, said he found a case where a politician told constituents he had not accepted money from Recruit and then apologized, saying that did not mean that he should be criticized for lacking influence.
Another issue that appears to have been smothered by the election was the widely unpopular 3 percent tax on goods and services enacted in defiance of public opposition in late 1988. Liberal Democrats appear to have won their wager that eventually, voters would come round to accept it.
The Socialists and other opposition parties are still vowing to repeal the tax. But the electorate now seems aware that doing so would only mean increasing some other tax to pay for badly needed social programs. As a result, a compromise on the tax seems most likely.
 
Farmers' Revolt Dissolves
A final feature of the winds of change of last year was the threat by farmers to bolt from the Liberal Democratic Party because of fears that the party would yield to American pressures and allow in more farm imports.
In fact, the Socialists did best among farmers by putting forward a frankly protectionist program, despite the fact that many people found it odd for left-leaning politicians to favor producers over consumers.
One reason for the Socialist strategy was that Japan remains a country of imbalanced representation, with some farm districts fielding as many legislators as urban districts with three times the population.
It appeared today that farmers came home to the Liberal Democrats, in part because they did not believe the Socialists could carry out their promises.
As for the population imbalance between disticts, the Government has repeatedly promised to rectify the inequities but never followed through. No action is expected now.

HEADLINE: Drugs Pit Baker vs. Third World at U.N.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d called on the General Assembly today to adopt a global program against drug traffickers. But third-world speakers demanded that the United States and its industrialized allies curb demand for drugs and help poorer nations cut production.
Mr. Baker spoke at the opening of a four-day special session of the Assembly called to improve the United Nations anti-drug effort and focus political attention on the trade in illegal narcotics, which is now estimated to be worth $500 billion a year, more than the world trade in oil and second only to the arms trade.
He urged the Assembly to adopt a drug control program ''that commits us to concrete activities, that is fully implemented by the agencies of the United Nations system and that is backed by complementary efforts at the national and regional levels.'' 
Speaking the week after President Bush signed an anti-drug pact with the leaders of Bolivia, Colombia and Peru in the Colombian resort of Cartagena, Mr. Baker urged countries to follow America's lead in ratifying the 1988 Vienna convention against trafficking in illegal narcotics, which makes it more difficult for smugglers to protect their fortunes against seizure.
 
Richer Nations Faulted
The United States today became the fifth country to formally ratify the convention when Mr. Baker deposited the signed instrument of ratification with the United Nations. The convention has been signed by 89 countries.
While Mr. Baker called for rapid international action, speakers from countries in Latin America and Asia where drugs are produced accused the richer, industrialized nations of not bearing their fair share of the burden.
Although Foreign Minister Julio Londono Paredes of Colombia said the Cartagena meeting last week showed ''a change is beginning,'' he still accused the United States and its allies of ''sneaking away from the dock where they really belong'' by attacking production rather than demand and by failing to give producing countries the economic assistance their farmers need to stop growing drug crops.
Mexico's Attorney General, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, said both suppliers and consumers are responsible for the international drug crisis. But he asked industrialized countries to do more to limit the availability of chemicals used in drug manufacturing and control sales of modern arms to drug-smuggling cartels.
 
Lack Of Resources Cited
He said ''unilateral mesures, positions that slander and intimidate, threats that offend the sovereignty of peoples and the dignity of individuals, must not be tolerated.'' This was a clear reference to President Bush's plan to use aircraft carriers to form a ''radar net'' that would track drug flights. Colombia has objected to the idea, and Mr. Bush chose not to raise the issue at Cartagena.
Jamaican Foreign Minister David Coore of Jamaica said many third world producers are ''engulfed in a multiplicity of development programs and do not have access to the necessary financial, technical and human resources to actively confront the onslaught of drug trafficking and transhipment.''
Since it was launched by Britain and the United States last year, the effort to involve the United Nations more heavily in the war on drugs has been plagued by the divisions between industrialized and third world nations.
Originally Britain and the United States wanted the Security Council to oversee a new international drive against drug smuggling; they argued that drug traffickers' efforts to destabilize the Colombian Government meant that the smugglers have become a ''threat to international peace and security'' under the United Nations Charter.
But third world countries oppose any expansion of the Security Council's authority, arguing that it is an undemocratic body controlled by the five permanent members, including Britain and the United States, who hold a veto over decisions. Led by Brazil, the developing countries promoted the idea of a special General Assembly session instead.

HEADLINE: CANADA PRESENTS AUSTERITY BUDGET

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney unveiled austerity measures today intended to bring down a budget deficit that is proportionately one of the highest among industrial countries and to ease the financial markets' recent concern about the management of the Canadian economy.
Presented to Parliament today by Finance Minister Michael Wilson, the budget proposal includes a two-year freeze on federal payments to the 10 provinces to help finance health care programs and post-secondary education, the virtual elimination of cash grants to businesses, and a cap of 5 percent a year on increases in military and foreign aid spending.
The package also includes plans to privatize Petro-Canada, Canada's biggest domestically owned oil company. Market analysts say the sale could bring $3.3 billion. 
But with Canadians already burdened by high taxes and with signs of a revolt looming over a 7 percent consumption tax due to be imposed next January, Mr. Wilson chose not to raise any taxes or impose new ones.
 
Some Criticism Voiced
While the spending cuts were generally praised by the financial community, they were strongly criticized by labor and some business leaders. John Bulloch, president of the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, said Mr. Wilson's measures were taken ''to satisfy the international community, but there's a tough price to be paid by all Canadians.''
The budget proposal follows several weeks of pressure on Ottawa in international financial markets. A brief attempt by the Bank of Canada last month to bring down domestic interest rates prompted heavy selling of the Canadian dollar, which has lost more than 3 United States cents since it reached a peak of 86.5 United States cents late in December.
Since then, Ottawa has been forced to push up interest rates again. Banks last week lifted their prime lending rate to a seven-year high of 14.25 percent. Canadian short-term interest rates are now about 5 percentage points higher than their American counterparts compared with the 1.5- to 2-point spread once considered normal.
Mr. Wilson predicted in his budget speech that the federal deficit would edge down from $25.3 billion (American) in the year ending March 31 to $23.7 billion in fiscal 1991 and $8.3 billion by 1995.
 
Public Debt Up Sharply
According to the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, Canada's budget deficit stood at 4 percent of gross domestic product last year compared with 2.9 percent for the United States.
Canada's public debt has ballooned in the last five years from $166 billion (American) to $290 billion. More than 80 percent of the increase has been in the form of compounding interest.
William Walton, economics professor at McGill University in Montreal, cautioned that Mr. Wilson's deficit projections may be proved wrong by over-optimistic assumptions, including an expected fall in short-term interest rates from an average of 12.2 percent last year to 9.5 percent in 1991. ''The markets may catch on that this is not as tough as it looks,'' he said.
The sale of Petro-Canada would be by far the biggest step in a privatization program that has so far seen Ottawa dispose of its holdings in 18 companies, including Air Canada and the Toronto-based aircraft maker De Havilland, bought by Boeing Company of Seattle.
Petro-Canada produces about 5.5 percent of Canada's oil and 6 percent of its natural gas. Its five refineries account for more than one-fifth of domestic capacity, while its 3,400 retail outlets have a 19 percent share of the gasoline market.
Mr. Wilson said the Government also plans to privatize Telesat Canada, a highly regarded satellite operator.
The budget proposal's casualties also include a $565 million (American) icebreaker, known as the Polar 8, which was intended as a way for Canada to assert its sovereignty over parts of the Arctic Ocean, notably the Northwest Passage. The icebreaker project began in 1985 after a United States Coast Guard vessel sailed through the Northwest Passage without asking Ottawa's consent.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 23, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the unveiling of Canada's budget misidentified a Canadian economics professor who commented. He is William Watson.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. CHIEF WARNS OF RESOLUTE K.G.B.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Soviet Union's primary intelligence service, the K.G.B., has not slackened its espionage and other actions against the United States under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but it has become less ''blatant and flat-footed'' at what it does, the senior American intelligence official said today.
Speaking to the Baltimore Council on Foreign Affairs, William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, said American counterintelligence experts saw ''robust intelligence activity by the K.G.B. throughout the world'' even as East-West tensions continue to ease.
''On the other hand, the sort of clumsy intimidation associated for many years with the K.G.B. in certain areas seems to have diminished,'' he said. He did not elaborate. The Soviet spy agency was long known for its ruthless suppression of internal dissent and, in previous years, for its occasionally ham-handed efforts to recruit agents in the West. 
 
Sophisticated Soviet Agents
In recent years, however, American intelligence analysts have described Soviet espionage agents as among the most sophisticated and well informed of all Russians active abroad.
Mr. Webster touched on the K.G.B. in a brief review of developments in the Eastern bloc, in which he also forecast a ''deep and prolonged'' economic and social crisis in the Soviet Union under President Gorbachev or his successors.
He also said that several Eastern European nations in the process of political change appeared to be reassessing their policy of conducting espionage activities on behalf of the Soviet Union.
In particular, he said, Hungary's new Government has denounced the nation's participation in the recruitment and handling of a United States Army sergeant, Clyde Lee Conrad, who was arrested in 1988 and charged with stealing top-secret war plans from NATO.
 
Soviet-Trained Bureaucrats
''The new political leadership in Eastern Europe will also bring in new oversight mechanisms'' for eastern spy agencies, Mr. Webster said. ''We hope oversight will reduce some hostile intelligence activity, such as passing sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, an activity which is incompatible with requests for U.S. loans.''
Mr. Webster added, however, that significant changes in the ties between the Soviet espionage services and the Eastern bloc were unlikely as long as Soviet-trained bureaucrats continued to run the Eastern bloc spy services and the Warsaw Pact remained in force.
The treaty requires Eastern bloc nations to share with the Soviets any military intelligence they gather.
Mr. Webster has frequently warned in recent months that Soviet intelligence activity against the West is likely to increase as relations between the two nations thaw. Today, he said American counterintelligence experts had concluded that the K.G.B. had stepped up its work, ''particularly in the United States, where recruiting of people with technical knowledge or access to technical knowledge has increased.''
He attributed the increase in part to the Soviet Union's economic problems, which he said required it to collect more technical and scientific information lest it fall further behind the West in industrial and military prowess.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;
Bush Praises Havel and His 'New Page'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
President Bush welcomed Czechoslovakia's leader, Vaclav Havel, to the White House today, promising his country new trade benefits and hailing his journey from political prisoner to President as the symbol of Eastern Europe's dramatic transformation in the past year.
Mr. Bush, noting that Czechoslovakia has not asked the United States for any economic aid but only the opportunity to trade freely, said he was immediately waiving trade restrictions that had been imposed on Prague when emigration was sharply curtailed under Communist rule. As soon as a new trade agreement can be negotiated between the two countries, Czechoslovakia will be given most-favored-nation trade benefits, meaning that its exports will be subject to the the lowest possible tariffs.
The President also authorized the Export-Import Bank to help finance trade with Czechoslovak companies and said Washington would back Czechoslovakia's request for readmission to the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. In addition, Mr. Bush said Peace Corps volunteers would be sent to Czechoslovakia by autumn to teach English. 
Mr. Havel's appearance in Washington, though, was less an occasion for business than for celebration - both for him and his hosts. Only a year ago the 53-year-old playwright and human rights campaigner was imprisoned by the Communists then ruling Prague for trying to lay a wreath at the grave of Jan Palach, a student who burned himself to death as a protest after the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia.
 
'Miraculous Transformations'
Addressing Mr. Havel on the White House lawn after their two and a half hours of talks, Mr. Bush said: ''Mr. President, your life has been one of miraculous transformations, from the world of drama to the world of dissent; from the life of the artist to the life of the activist; and of course in the space of just one short year, the most miraculous journey of all, from prison to the presidency. President Havel, Czechoslovakia has turned to you to lead the way. And is it not fitting for a nation that each day writes a new page in its history, to have elected a playwright as its President?''
Mr. Havel was the first of Eastern Europe's new rulers to visit Washington since the upheavals there last year, though Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, who holds no formal government post in Poland, came last November following an itinerary similar to that scheduled for Mr. Havel.
The Czechoslovak President and his entourage, which included not only cabinet ministers but also some of the student leaders who sparked the revolution that toppled the Communists and brought him to power on Dec. 29, evinced a combination of ingenuousness rare in political figures and steely conviction.
 
Uncomfortable in Ties
An awareness of their remarkable change of fortunes was apparent in the bemused, can-you-believe-all-this looks Mr. Havel and his aides kept shooting at one another as they were escorted around town by brawny Secret Service agents talking into their wired lapels. It was also apparent in the discomfort Mr. Havel and his associates seemed to feel at having to wear suits and ties, rather than their customary blue jeans and leather jackets - a fact which Mr. Bush himself could not resist commenting on.
Speaking to Mr. Havel on his departure from the White House, Mr. Bush said: ''For years as a dissident subject to arrest and imprisonment at any time, you could never go out without your toothbrush in your pocket, but now as President you can never go out without one of these neckties.''
Mr. Havel began his stay in Washington not by meeting with power figures, but by going to Georgetown University and answering students' questions with the same mixture of insight and irony that characterize his plays.
When one student asked Mr. Havel if the Czechoslovak embassy in Washington would continue representing Cuba, he answered with a mischievous smile: ''When I was elected President all the ambassadors in Prague congratulated me; all of them were smiling at me except one: the Cuban ambassador. Maybe there was a frown on his face because he could forsee that the relations between my country and his would have a different character from that which they used to have under my predecessors.''
 
Freedom to Publish, Even Havel
Asked by another student whether there would be full freedom of speech in Czechoslovakia, Mr. Havel answered: ''The time when some clerks or officials can direct what is allowed and what isn't allowed is gone. From now on there will be no directions for publishing houses. They will be independent and free to publish what they want, so that works by authors like Kundara, Kafka, and even by Havel, will be published too.''
Mr. Bush also told Mr. Havel that the Atlantic Alliance ''will continue to play a vital role in assuring stability and security in Europe,'' and ''America will continue to play its part, including a strong military presence for our security and for Europe's.''
Mr. Havel and his Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, have said that both the United States and the Soviet Union need to eventually remove all their troops from Europe and that both NATO and the Warsaw Pact need to dissolve into some sort of pan-European security organization.
Briefing reporters after Mr. Havel's meeting with the President, the Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, Raymond G. H. Seitz, said that the Czechoslovak leader did not make any requests for American toops to leave Europe, or for NATO to dissolve along with the Warsaw Pact. Rather, said Mr. Seitz, Mr. Havel affirmed that for now both NATO and American troops played an important ''stabilizing role'' in Europe.

HEADLINE: Smoking's Cost to Society Is $52 Billion a Year, Federal Study Says

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Federal officials estimated today that that cigarette smoking costs the nation $52 billion in health expenses or time lost from work, about $221 per person, each year.
The estimate, which was announced by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, is the highest official figure yet given by the Government. It was disclosed in a new report, ''Smoking and Health: a National Status Report.'' It is the second such report given by the Bush Administration to Congress, but it is the first time the economic costs of smoking have been calculated by the Health and Human Services Department. 
While giving the new figures at a hearing of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, Dr. Sullivan attacked cigarette makers as immoral and irresponsible. ''Cigarettes are the only legal product that when used as intended cause death,'' he said, adding that the companies were ''trading death for corporate profits.''
 
Anti-Smoking Campaign
Dr. Sullivan said he would begin a campaign to stop cigarette smoking in all Federal buildings and in all hospitals. The health secretary said he would write letters to hospital administrators asking that the hospitals be declared smoke-free zones. Dr. Sullivan directed the head of the Health Care Financing Administration, which oversees Medicare, to ask all hospitals receiving Medicare financing to ban smoking.
He said he would also write to all those who receive grants from the Department of Health and Human Services, asking them to ban smoking where they work.
Officials said the new estimate accounts for health care and insurance costs of diseases directly linked to smoking, as well as time lost from work.
Brennan Dawson, an official of the Tobacco Institute, a trade association for the tobacco industry, said today that the Federal estimates were flawed in two important ways. ''There are no data to back up claims that smokers overutilize the health-care system,'' she said. ''Secondly, people's productivity and life style are personal matters and do not result in a cost to society. Smokers pay their own way.''
But Dr. John Banzhaf, head of Action on Smoking and Health, a nonprofit anti-smoking group, disagreed, saying the Federal figures underestimated the health risks. Saying that the true figure was closer to $100 billion, Dr. Banzhaf asserted that the Government did not take into account diseases of nonsmokers that could be attributed to smoking by others. He said such ''passive smoking'' was responsible for thousands of cancer deaths each year and numerous deaths of infants whose mothers smoke.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, the chairman of the committee, said today that 1,000 Americans died each day from diseases caused by smoking, and that the tobacco industry spent $6.9 million a day in advertising to replenish the supply of smokers who quit or were killed by cigarettes.
Mr. Kennedy has introduced legislation that would raise the current Office on Smoking and Health at the national Centers for Disease Control two levels to become a separate center that would give grants for advertisements to discourage smoking. The legislation would give the center power to regulate cigarette content similar to that exercised by the Food and Drug Administration over other products.
 
Benzene in Cigarettes
The bill would also require cigarette labels to list dangerous additives, Mr. Kennedy said. ''Perrier water was pulled from the shelves recently in response to an E.P.A. and F.D.A. action when it was discovered that it had 16 to 26 parts per billion of benzene,'' he said, adding, ''The 1986 Surgeon General's report noted that the benzene content in a range of cigarettes studied, varied from 11,000 to 43,000 parts per billion, or almost 2,000 times the content of the Perrier water.''
Mr. Kennedy also accused tobacco companies of targeting women, teen-agers and minority groups for their new products and advertising. Two new products, ''Superslims'' and ''Newport Stripes,'' were designed for women, he said.
Four weeks ago, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company halted its plans to test market a cigarette called ''Uptown'', which was designed specifically for blacks, after Dr. Sullivan assailed the company publicly. The company said this week that it will market a new brand called ''Dakota,'' which critics say is aimed at encouraging smoking by young blue-collar women.

HEADLINE: Francis Keppel Dies at Age of 73; Was Commissioner of Education

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Francis Keppel, a former United States Commissioner of Education who was a strong proponent of programs to improve learning opportunities for poor children, died of cancer Monday at Harvard University's Stillman Infirmary in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Cambridge.
Mr. Keppel, a former sculptor who preferred the name Frank and who never bothered to acquire more than a bachelor's degree in a doctorate-conscious profession, was dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Education for 14 years before he was appointed to the country's highest educational post by President John F. Kennedy in 1962.
For the next four years, into the Administration of Lyndon B. Johnson, he pursued a policy of encouraging the myriad school districts throughout the country to introduce programs aimed at improving the education of children most in need. 
He led the drive for passage of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, which focused resources on classroom assistance for poor children. He was also closely involved in enforcement of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 as it dealt with equal access to education, and he created the National Assessment of Educational Progress.
 
Director of Aspen Institute
Mr. Keppel continued to shape educational policy until his death as the longtime director, since 1974, of the education policy program of the Aspen Institute and as an adviser to libraries, art centers, the World Bank and the governments of many developing countries around the world.
Mr. Keppel was born into the academic world on Manhattan's Morningside Heights in a house provided to his father, Frederick P. Keppel, who was then dean of Columbia College and later became president of the Carnegie Corporation. He grew up in Montrose, N.Y., where several Columbia faculty members had summer cottages that later became year-round residences.
He studied at Harvard, where he majored in English literature and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa upon his graduation in 1938. He interrupted his academic studies and enrolled at the American Academy in Rome, hoping to determine whether he could become an accomplished sculptor.
A year later, after deciding that he could never become a first-rate sculptor, he returned to Harvard as assistant dean of freshmen. In the early years of World War II he was secretary of the Joint Army and Navy Committee on Welfare and Recreation before enlisting in the Army and rising from private to first lieutenant.
 
Pioneer Influence at Harvard
In 1948, at the age of 32, Mr. Keppel was appointed dean of Harvard's Graduate School of Education, where he sponsored experimental programs in team teaching, programmed learning, the use of television in education and curriculum reform. He was also a leader in devising Harvard's Master of Arts in Teaching Program, which gave outstanding liberal arts graduates a year of study in education and an extended internship to improve the caliber of those who chose to become public school teachers.
After he left government service in 1966, Mr. Keppel became chairman of the General Learning Corporation, a joint venture of General Electric and Time Inc. He also participated in a number of educational review boards, including the Fleischmann and Rockefeller Coammissions dealing with education in New York State.
In 1967 Mr. Keppel was appointed vice chairman of New York City's Board of Higher Education, which supervises the City University. From 1967 to 1973 he was an Overseer of Harvard, and he remained a senior lecturer there until his death.
He leaves his wife, the former Edith Sawin; two daughters, Edith Drury of Waterbury Center, Vt., and Susan Keller of Winchester, Mass.; a brother, Charles, of Montrose, N.Y., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: The West Has a Stake in Perestroika's Success

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Soviets' Terminal Crisis'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 4) caused consternation and controversy around the world. Written by an anonymous contributor calling himself ''Z,'' adapted from a longer article in the journal Daedalus, where it was titled ''To the Stalin Mausoleum,'' it predicted a pessimistic future for perestroika and the Soviet Union.
Z's point is that no matter whether President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is trying to make the socialist system more humane and reform it economically or whether his efforts will lead to its replacement by a market and Western-style democracy, there is no reason anyone should help him or even wish him success. The ''party-state'' system, as the author calls it, is a monster. This is why the West should leave Mr. Gorbachev to his fate, and allow his reforms to end in failure and East European socialism to die. 
Never has the position of perestroika's gravediggers been expressed in such a talented, solid and pseudo-scholarly form. Never has it been so formulated as to resemble an ideological manifesto. The article shows that influential forces still regard the Soviet Union as something diabolic.
Ideas formulated in ''To the Stalin Mausoleum'' have long been held by those high-ranking officials of the United States Administration who are referred to as hard-line skeptics. These people tried to prevent the team of President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d from believing that Mr. Gorbachev was sincere in his intentions. Later they arrived at the conclusion that, irrespective of the ultimate fate of perestroika, it served Western interests well.
One of the article's critical features is its timing. Perestroika is going through its most severe crisis. During all of this President Gorbachev has shown flexibility and persistence, both indispensable. Kremlin officials have denied reports that he is going to leave the post of general secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee shortly and retain only the post of president. However, the Soviet leader and his cause are clearly in danger. ''What should we do?'', Western leaders are asking themselves worriedly. ''Nothing, please,'' say the friends of Z. Z's stand is a hybrid of far-right extremism and naivete. He would like to push our country into chaos, perhaps even wipe it from historical records. At the same time, he believes the West should retain the coolness of a pathologist waiting for another corpse to be delivered to the mortuary.
Meanwhile, equally conservative political scientists - Zbigniew Brzezinski, for one - realize only too well that a failure of perestroika would mean dramatic consequences for the West. A sick Soviet Union is an unpredictable Soviet Union.
Z does not realize that democracy is increasingly being viewed, in the West and the East, as a product of our civilization and a universal human value. One should not hoist state flags over it. Conservative people in the Soviet Union are terribly afraid of ''Western'' democracy, as if it were the biblical serpent tempting the Russian virgin.
For now, though Z wants it to be the opposite, the West's tendency is to consider that what coincides with the interests of perestroika coincides with the interests of the industrialized nations.
 
VLADIMIR SIMONOV
Moscow, Feb. 6, 1990
 The writer is a political analyst for Novosti, the Soviet press agency.

HEADLINE: Weary Of J.F.K.? This Field Hopes So

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn.

 BODY:
Bradley International Airport, New England's perpetual No. 2 airfield after Logan International in Boston, has never escaped the fact that for most travelers Connecticut is a place to be flown over and looked down upon on the way to somewhere else.
But as delays worsen at Logan and New York's airports, and the specter of maximum capacity comes within view - especially at Logan - state officials and some aviation experts are beginning to think that congestion-free Bradley could emerge as an alternative for travelers from the urban fringes.
Their hopes rest heavily on the belief that from Fairfield County, Conn., to southern Maine, millions of minds are poisoned against the big city airports, and that their ranks will grow as Logan and Kennedy International in Queens undertake huge, disruptive programs to rebuild old terminals and roadways.
 
Foreign Route Would Help
Every time someone is stuck in traffic to those airports, the theory goes, another convert is made to the idea that time can be saved by driving to Bradley, which is 90 minutes from Boston and two and a half hours from New York City. Travel agents say such a shift is under way. 
''There are more and more people who will say, 'Oh, don't route me out of Boston,' '' said David M. Boardman, president of Heritage Travel in South Woodstock, in Connecticut's northeast corner.
Officials here say the balance would shift even more dramatically if Bradley could win a regular European route, since all passenger and freight traffic to Europe now must go through Boston or New York. And industry experts say such a route has become much more likely in the last year with the easing of Federal regulations for foreign airlines.
With about 5 million passengers a year, compared with 23 million at Logan, Bradley has dominated the suburban and rural areas that extend from central Connecticut up through western Massachusetts. There are 360 flights a day on 16 airlines, with nonstop flights to most major cities in the eastern United States and Canada.
Through passenger surveys, officials estimate that perhaps 350,000 travelers a year who do not use Bradley might consider it an option if there were flights to Europe.
 
'Not Even on the Map'
Beyond the issues of money and jobs, there is status. Gov. William A. O'Neill, who has met with executives of K. L. M. Royal Dutch Airlines, which is considering a Bradley-to-Amsterdam route, has made a point of publicizing the European effort.
''It's everything,'' said Edward M. Archibald, a deputy commissioner in charge of aeronautics at the State Department of Transportation. ''Without international service, you're nowhere. You're not even on the map.'' Some hard economic realities still lie in the way, however. K.L.M., for example, is considering at least 10 other airports that might be eligible for European service.
And some of those other airports serve far more passengers, like Dulles International near Washington, or are hubs for domestic airlines that could supply enough travelers bound for Europe to make a route profitable immediately, analysts say.
Bradley, by contrast, relies heavily on business travelers who are fed into the hubs, meaning it handles few passengers transferring from one airline to another.
 
Some Dashed Expectations
''The immediate new service will go more to the hubs than the spokes,'' said Helane Becker, a senior vice president at Shearson, Lehman Hutton, the stock brokerage firm.
Ms. Becker, who follows the airline industry, said she thought the new Federal rules would ultimately make it ''easier and easier'' for airports like Bradley, but not immediately.
''Over the next five years or so, but not in the current round,'' she said.
Susan B. Jollie, a Washington lawyer who specializes in aviation, said: ''We will see a reasonable growth in services and that will happen because there is a shrinking globe. But those cities who think they're going to get service instantaneously may have those expectations dashed.''
The new rules, released by the Department of Transportation last month, allow airlines from some countries to apply for new routes without negotiations between the State Department and their government. If all the prerequisites in the rules are met, a new route could begin within 90 days, compared with months or years under the old system.
 
'On Our Wish List'
A spokeswoman for K.L.M., Odette Fodor-Gernaert, said ''Bradley is one of the airports on our wish list'' but no decisions have been made.
Travel agents also said that even Bradley's opportunities for capturing domestic travelers from Boston or New York are not without risk. Green Airport near Providence, R.I., for instance, has been aggressively seeking part of Logan's overflow, as have smaller regional airports.
Bradley's main hope rests on the belief that the world will be increasingly populated by people like Dave Valentine, who was recently waiting on stand-by for a flight to West Palm Beach, Fla., and Dolores A. Lemay, who often flies to Aruba from Bradley.
''If I could avoid Kennedy, at all costs I would,'' said Mr. Valentine, an engineer with Pratt & Whitney in East Hartford. ''Kennedy I consider to be a nightmare.''
Mrs. Lemay, of Watertown, Conn., said, ''I hate that ride,'' explaining why she abandoned use of New York's airports about five years ago.
The other main pillar of faith at Bradley is that with a $100 million expansion of the airport completed just three years ago, passenger volume could increase by 40 percent and still be below what would bring on serious flight congestion or traffic jams.
''We have no illusions that we're going to be a J.F.K. or a Logan,'' said Robert F. Juliano, Bradley's administrator. But he sees the airport's future every time another passenger comes to complain. ''They say, 'Why do we have to go to New York? Why do we have to go through that ordeal?' '' he said.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Capitalism Course May Be Canceled

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Feb. 20

 BODY:
An American graduate degree program that teaches Western-style capitalism to students in China is in peril. But it is unclear whether the threat comes from Federal budget cutters or a White House sensitive to hard-liners in China.
Officials at the State University of Buffalo, which offers a master's degree in business administration in a program financed by the Chinese and American Governments, were notified on Feb. 5 that $400,000 in United States Commerce Department money for the program was in jeopardy and would probably be canceled April 1. The Chinese Government provides the remaining $200,000. 
Instead, university officials were told, the money would be diverted to Eastern European countries.
But The Buffalo News, quoting an unnamed diplomatic source, reported Sunday that the White House had ordered the program terminated because its free-enterprise curriculum had been increasingly criticized by hard-liners in the Chinese Government.
The diplomat said the Chinese Government had singled out the business course as ''highly subversive'' and a ''Western-oriented operation incompatible with the aims of the present Chinese leadership.''
 
Not Yet Canceled
A senior Bush Administration official said today that the program had not yet been officially canceled, but that the Administration was considering switching it to the more politically compatible ground of Eastern Europe.
''Given the atmosphere in China, with the Chinese reform movement not proceeding well,'' he said, ''and given the fact that there is a great need for similar programs in Eastern Europe, and given the fact that the Commerce Department is stuck holding the bill for this program, it might be better suited to change it to Eastern Europe.''
University officials have mounted a letter-writing campaign to the Commerce Department to protest the cuts and received support from some corporations represented on the degree program's board, including the Xerox Corporation, the General Electric Company and the Union Carbide Corporation.
''One could conjure up a scenario that the Chinese want to terminate the program but do not want to say so,'' said Dr. Joseph Alutto, head of the university's School of Management. ''It's not any information we have received. Our continuing contacts with the Chinese Government say that is not the case.
''All the information we have says there are two issues involved. One is the budget problem in the Department of Commerce and the desire to respond to initiatives in the Eastern bloc. The second is a sense, perhaps, in the Department of Commerce that China may no longer be a primary area of interest.''
 
Temporary Halt in Classes
Dr. Alutto said Chinese Government officials have been questioning him about how soon the degree program would be back in full operation. The university had temporarily halted classes following Beijing's crackdown on students in Tiananmen Square last June. Students have recently returned to classes, but are expected to lose about a year of course work altogether.
The program, the only one at college level financed by both Governments, has awarded 131 M.B.A. degrees to Chinese students since 1984.
Currently 89 students are enrolled in the program, offered at the National Center for Industrial Science and Technology Management Development in Dalian, a seaport community in Lyaoning province. The classes, which originally were taught by both American and Chinese professors, are now taught by Chinese faculty, many of whom have done postdoctoral work at the Buffalo University.
 
Breach in Protocol, Some Say
University officials said a cut in financing by the United States would represent a breach of the protocol signed by the two Governments when the program was established in 1984. It stipulates that if a country withdraws from the agreement, it must pay to complete the educations of those students currently enrolled.
''I feel it would be unfortunate for all parties concerned to precipitously cancel the program,'' said Dr. Steven B. Sample, the university president. ''Educationally, it would be a grave mistake.''
Dr. Alutto said: ''My only hope is that the long-term issue is kept in mind here. If the United States is at all serious about the modernization of China, it has to continue supporting programs like that. Essentially our graduates are providing the future economic leaders of China.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Nominee for M.I.T. Presidency Backs Out of Post

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
A highly regarded biologist nominated last week to be president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology backed out of the job yesterday, saying he could not bear to give up his research.
Phillip A. Sharp, the chairman of university's Center for Cancer Research, said that after the announcement of his nomination last Wednesday he balked when it came time for him to separate himself from his scholarship and his students.
''I came reluctantly to the realization that I could not fill that void in my life with anything else,'' Dr. Sharp said in a statement released by the university.
 
A Series of Setbacks
Dr. Sharp's decision was the latest in a series of setbacks to efforts by M.I.T., perhaps the nation's premiere institution of scientific learning, to find a strong new leader. 
An early front-runner for the job withdrew amid controversy over his ties to military and business interests, while a second top candidate, a close friend of Dr. Sharp's took the presidency of another university where he would not be expected to abandon his research.
Dr. Sharp declined to answer any questions about his decision. But friends, scientific colleagues and students said they had no doubt that the 46-year-old scholar had simply been overcome by his love for science.
''There is no hidden agenda,'' said Dr. Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics who headed the faculty search committee that nominated Dr. Sharp. ''As far as I can tell, it was simply a matter of a guy who has devoted his life to biology finding that he was absolutely haunted at the notion that he was giving it up.''
A colleague who spoke to Dr. Sharp yesterday said the professor began to rethink his decision to accept the presidency of the Cambridge, Mass., university after telling his graduate students last Wednesday that he would be leaving.
 
A Surprise Nominee
''In their eyes, he was abandoning them and abandoning science,'' the colleague said, ''and he couldn't bring himself to do it.''
Dr. Sharp had been a surprise choice to lead the university of nearly 10,000 students, nearly half of them graduate students, for several reasons, especially his record as a pure scientist with relatively little background in administration or academic politics.
Widely considered to be a candidate for the Nobel Prize in biology, Dr. Sharp has won several major scientific awards for his contributions to the understanding of how genetic material comes together and works inside cells.
In the 1970's, Dr. Sharp helped discover how ribonucleic acid, RNA, is spliced into a genetic message used to build proteins, including enzymes, which are necessary to the activities and growth of cells.
 
Originally Trained as Chemist
Originally trained as a chemist at Union College in his native Kentucky and at the University of Illinois, where he received his doctoral degree Dr. Sharp moved toward biology in post-doctoral studies at the California Institute of Technology.
Colleagues and scientists around the country said he is recognized as one of the foremost biologists in the world. He joined the faculty of M.I.T. in 1974 and is a resident of Newton, Mass.
Dr. Solow, who said he had not previously known Dr. Sharp well, initially made him vice chairman of the faculty search committee when it convened late last spring. Dr. Solow subsequently asked his deputy to step down and be considered for the presidency himself.
During interviews, Dr. Sharp explicitly told the faculty search committee that he was prepared to give up his research, said Kenneth D. Campbell, a spokesman for the university.
Dr. Sharp was widely described a forceful, outgoing man. In discussing his selection, several of his colleagues linked his personality to university's interest in reasserting the importance of science in the national politics.
The early front-runner for M.I.T.'s presidency, chemist John Deutch, withdrew as a candidate after strong criticism from some students and faculty members of his close ties to the military and private businesses.
Dr. Sharp is a co-founder, member of the board and chairman of the scientific board of Biogen Inc., a biotechnology research concern based in Cambridge. A 1988 registry researchers listed his holdings in the company as 322,000 shares of stock, which was valued then at $2.6 million. The company employs more than 300 people.
Mr. Campbell, the M.I.T. spokesman, said that Dr. Sharp could have remained a member of both bodies and would not have been compelled to divest his stock holdings in the company.
Dr. David Baltimore, a close colleague of Dr. Sharp's who also spoke with him yesterday, said that his friend ''clearly jumped before he completely thought through the implications in terms of his own long-term satisfaction.
''As he began to unravel his scientific involvement, he realized that meant more to him, and he couldn't see leaving that behind,'' Dr. Baltimore said. ''It came as much a surprise to me as anybody.''
Dr. Baltimore, who directs the Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research at M.I.T., had also been a top candidate for the institution's presidency. But he was chosen to become president of Rockefeller University in New York City this summer, where he will be allowed to continue his research.
Dr. Solow said the search committee had idea yet what candidate might substitute for Dr. Sharp, who was expected to be confirmed by the the university's governing board on March 2. The university's president, Paul E. Gray, was expected to retire in June.

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
Knowing Nutrition A Gallup survey on diet and health has found that most Americans have a good idea about sensible eating. Ninety-five percent said balance, moderation and variety were the keys to healthy eating, and 77 percent were familiar with the four basic food groups.
Despite these findings, Nancy S. Wellman, the president of the American Dietetic Association, a professional organization of nutritionists, concluded that Americans still opt for fads and quick fixes. She based this conclusion on the fact that more than half - 52 percent - said they were increasing consumption of oat bran, and 48 percent said they were using more dietary supplements; she pointed out that only 8 percent said they were eating more vegetables. 
The survey did not ask specifically about vegetables, but did ask about oat bran and dietary supplements. The 8 percent figure represented a voluntary response to the question, ''Is there anything else you're increasing?''
The survey was commissioned by the association and the International Food Information Council, a nonprofit organization financed by food and beverage companies. It was based on 772 telephone interviews between Dec. 11 and 18 of people age 18 or older; it had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Thomas E. Stenzel, the executive director of the food information council, said the survey showed that Americans were confused when it came to eating fat. They are ''needlessly eliminating certain foods from their diets,'' he said, since 45 percent said they were eliminating red meat and 36 percent said they were cutting out dairy foods. ''These are important sources of iron, calcium, vitamin B12 and zinc,'' he said.
The survey found that women were better informed about nutrition than men, but seemed to be doing more to modify their diets. For instance, 53 percent of the women said they were eliminating red meat, compared with 36 percent of the men. Women were also more likely than men to say they felt guilty about eating the foods they liked (44 percent to 28.) 544 Pages of Food Terms At 544 pages, ''The Food Lover's Companion,'' by Sharon Tyler Herbst, is as thick and satisfying as a well-stuffed sandwich. Published this year by Barron's at $10.95, it is a glossary of more than 3,000 culinary and wine terms, providing simple definitions and, where necessary, concise technical or historic background.
 
Student Food in Hartford
The Connecticut Culinary Institute, established two years ago in Farmington, a suburb of Hartford, has opened a restaurant in downtown Hartford. The restaurant, Cafe on the Park, is in the Ramada Inn-Capitol Hill, at 440 Asylum Street, overlooking Bushnell Park. The institute owns and manages the food and beverage operations, including catering and room service, for the inn.
The restaurant is a teaching center for the school and is staffed by teachers and students. The Cafe on the Park will also offer courses for amateur cooks. It is open for breakfast, lunch and dinner every day; the telephone number is 203-524-8274.
 
Soup on the West Side
Just as West 46th Street is known as Restaurant Row, West 55th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue is becoming Soup Row. A new storefront soup stand, Kate's Kettle, opened last week at No. 255, a few doors from the Soup Kitchen International, at No. 259-A.
Kate's Kettle is owned by Geoff Lissauer, who also owns Jose Sent Me and Possible 20, two restaurants on the block. It offers four or five soups daily, at $2.75 to $5.75 for portions of 8 to 12 ounces. The vegetarian chili, often on the menu, was well seasoned and thick with ingredients, but the yellow split pea was bland and the New England clam chowder tasted more like a creamy vegetable soup with some clams in it. The soups come with a piece of Eli's Sourdough Bread and a packet of croutons.
The stand, which is open from 7 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday through Friday, also sells sandwiches and will be adding breakfast items.
Soup Kitchen International is known for its savory, chunky and inventive soups, but also for its long lines, strict rules and the occasional irascibility of Al Yeganeh, the owner. Mr. Yeganeh is starting a subscribers' club, offering 32 portions of soup (eight large and eight small of seafood, eight large and eight small of non-seafood) for $191, about the price of 33 portions. Subscribers get a card that is punched with each purchase.
Membership might be a hedge against inflation, since the prices at Soup Kitchen International have crept up steadily over the years and now start at $4.25. It will save time, and Mr. Yeganeh also regards it as a guarantee of good service.
 
Shad (Rhymes With Glad)
PREDICTIONS of an early spring, based on a shadowless Groundhog Day, are being confirmed in the marketplace. Shad, a traditional harbinger, are already available in some fish stores. So far the shad are from the Carolinas, and the early prices are high, ranging from $7.95 to $12.95 a pound for fillets. As the shad move up the East Coast, prices should drop.
Because shad have such a complex network of bones, they are usually sold filleted. The rich pale salmon-colored flesh is delicious baked or broiled. A sauce seasoned with tart sorrel puree is a classic complement. Markets that sell shad also carry shad roe. The roe, sold in pairs, are best lightly sauteed.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
Weidenfeld Galaxy Losses and disappointing sales led Ann Getty and George Weidenfeld to merge Weidenfeld & Nicolson and Grove Press into a single house last year, and rumors still crop up that the merged house - Grove Weidenfeld - will be shut down. But those rumors now surface much less often, and in the meantime the house has been signing important authors and selling reprint rights for respectable money.
Among its recently signed authors are these:
* Milan Kundera, whose new novel, ''Immortality,'' is expected to be published here early next year. The book, recently published in France, is already a best seller there. 
* Harold Pinter, the playwright, who in the 1950's wrote a novel, ''The Dwarfs,'' that was not published and that he forgot about after his success on the stage. Mr. Pinter recently discovered ''The Dwarfs'' in a drawer, and did a bit of rewriting. Grove Weidenfeld will publish it in the fall; it will also be published in Britain by Faber & Faber.
* Alfred Kazin, the literary critic, whose book subject the company will not disclose, except to say that the work will be nonfiction and will be be published in 1991.
Meanwhile, a number of Grove Weidenfeld books have received good reviews, have been sold to book clubs and have been bought for paperback reprint. ''The Last World,'' a forthcoming first novel by Christoph Ransmayr, has a $200,000 floor (i.e., minimum guarantee) for paperback rights, and there is a $100,000 floor for ''Lakota Woman,'' by Mary Crow Dog, with Richard Erdoes. The latter is an account of the author's impoverished childhood on the Rosebud reservation in South Dakota and her life of delinquency in various Indian ghettos in big cities.
Aaron Asher, Grove's publisher, acknowledged that some literary agents had been frightened away by the house's uncertain past, and that some were still skittish about submitting books. But he noted that several important agents had brought in books recently, including Lynn Nesbit, who represented the Kazin book.
 
Mandela Speeches
The authorized biography of Nelson Mandela is scheduled for publication this spring, but part of the Mandela story is available now in ''Nelson Mandela: The Struggle Is My Life,'' published by Pathfinder Press.
The book - a collection of speeches, writings and historical documents - was first published in this country in 1986. After a first press run of 10,000, there are now almost 75,000 copies in print, including two printings just this year. Helen Meyers of Pathfinder said the house specialized in the writings of such figures as Che Guevara, Fidel Castro and Malcolm X. Lincoln in Polish When some Polish teachers aligned with the Solidarity movement visited Albany last summer, they asked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to recommend a book about democracy. He suggested the writings of Abraham Lincoln, and promised to have such a volume translated into Polish.
But when the Governor and his staff members did not find a volume they considered adequate, they decided to compile their own. They asked 45 Lincoln and Civil War scholars to suggest appropriate material, and arranged for introductions to the book's various sections by such figures as James McPherson, a professor of history at Princeton University; Richard Current, who wrote ''The Lincoln Nobody Knows''; Hans Trefousse, whose books include ''The Radical Republicans: Lincoln's Vanguard for Racial Justice,'' and Mark E. Neely Jr., author of ''The Abraham Lincoln Encyclopedia.''
The result is ''Lincoln on Democracy,'' edited by Governor Cuomo and Harold Holzer, to be published in the fall by Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper & Row.
The book is being translated into Polish, but because of changes in Poland in the interim, publication plans there are uncertain, said Mr. Holzer, who is a special counselor to the New York State director of economic development as well as the author of ''The Lincoln Image.'' Therefore, the translation may be published by an emigre press in London or by a Polish-language press in the United States, Mr. Holzer said. ''But one way or another,'' he added, ''the book will be available in Poland.''
 
A New Kennedy Byline
Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of the late President, will co-write a book commemorating the 200th anniversary of the adoption of the first 10 Amendments to the Constitution. The book, with Ellen Alderman, is to be entitled ''The Bill of Rights,'' and is to be published next January by William Morrow & Company. Both authors are graduates of the Columbia University Law School, and will explain each amendment by focusing on one or two major cases.
 
Plunging Into Poetry
Chronicle Books of San Francisco, the publisher of well-regarded art books and full-color food books, branched out into fiction last summer and has now decided to publish poetry. Its first titles, to be published in April, are ''Who Will Know Us?'' by Gary Soto, who has published four previous books of poetry, and ''Body in Flames/Cuerpo en Llamas,'' an English-Spanish edition by Francisco Alarcon, translated by Francisco Aragon. HEADLINE: Japan's Lead in Computer Research Grows

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATSUGI, Japan

 BODY:
In a sprawling laboratory complex here, Japanese researchers are working on an ambitious program that demonstrates how - and how quickly - Japan is widening its lead over the United States in certain crucial fields of electronics technology. It also underlines the contrast in the way the two nations are pursuing a promising but costly frontier of industrial expertise.
Researchers at the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company are developing a new X-ray technology to make computer chips, starting in the mid-1990's, that scientists predict will be many times more powerful than those in use today. The technology, called X-ray lithography, employs ultra-fine X-ray beams instead of light to make chips far more densely packed with electronic circuits.
The race for X-ray technology, Japanese and American executives agree, will significantly affect industrial competitiveness in many fields that depend on semiconductors, or chips, which are the building blocks of computers. The typical personal computer now uses chips with a storage capacity one-thousandth that of those that may eventually be made through X-ray lithography. A Sharp Contrast in Programs The N.T.T. project at Atsugi is just one of more than a dozen programs, trying many different approaches, that Japan has already mounted in an effort to build the ultra-dense chips that will make up smaller computers and far smarter consumer electronic goods. 
By contrast, the United States has one major project, at an International Business Machines Corporation plant in upstate New York that is still under construction. ''Ours is a rifle shot,'' explained William Siegle, the director of I.B.M.'s project in East Fishkill, N.Y. To share the risk, I.B.M. recently added the Motorola Corporation as a partner.
The Japanese companies working on X-ray lithography, Mr. Siegle acknowledged, ''have a couple of different cracks at it,'' noting that they can afford the luxury of making mistakes. In addition to the I.B.M project, the United States can claim a series of small efforts financed by the Navy's research laboratories. Other American companies have dropped out, deciding they could not afford to develop this pioneering technology.
At a time that American chip makers are fearful that they are increasingly dependent on Japan for the tools of chip making, the comparatively small amount of work being done in the United States on X-ray lithography points to the pace at which the research gap between the United States and Japan is widening.
''The research gap is very, very big,'' Toyoki Kitayama, the senior researcher in charge of N.T.T.'s project, said the other day as he walked through the sprawling research center here. ''I am afraid that it is getting bigger.''
Its second-place status in the X-ray lithography race hardly counts the United States out in electronic competitiveness; it still leads Japan in some major semiconductor technologies, particularly microprocessors, the logic chips at the core of personal computers and more powerful desktop computers called work stations.
Yet both statistics and anecdotal evidence suggest that America's research efforts are slipping, even as Japan is accelerating its push into selected high-technology fields. A recent survey by the National Science Foundation showed that a wide variety of American companies, wary of a recession and worried about profitability, are leveling off their spending for research and development. At the same time Japan's biggest companies are pouring more money than ever into new technologies and production techniques.
 
Japanese Spending Is Greater
Last November, a report to President Bush by the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors said that research spending by the five biggest Japanese chip makers was nearly double that spent by the five top American merchant suppliers, which excludes I.B.M.
''The United States is holding its technological position in only a few areas, and gaining position nowhere,'' the report concluded.
Moreover, Japan's push to develop technologically advanced products, ranging from luxury automobiles to new supercomputers, has made research and development budgets virtually sacrosanct, the last budget items to be cut. In a report two months ago, Japan's Science and Technology Agency said its recent survey of industry here showed that two-thirds of Japanese corporate managers now identify ''strengthening R.&D.'' as their No. 1 objective, up from a little over half of those surveyed three years ago.
Between 1982 and 1987, the Science and Technology Agency found, research and development spending by Japanese companies rose 60 percent, compared with a 20 percent rise at American companies in that period.
Accordingly, Japanese executives say they are mystified that the United States would permit the demise of chip consortiums like U.S. Memories, which was abandoned for lack of financing last month, or let efforts in areas like high-definition television falter in the midst of debates over industrial policy.
 
'The U.S. Is Still Debating'
''It is hard to believe that the United States is still debating whether it is wise to cooperate on research,'' a senior executive of Hitachi said. ''Almost no one can afford to do this kind of research alone now. That does not mean you cannot compete strongly in the marketplace later on. But you have to be foolish to do this research alone.''
Japan's core critique of American research is twofold: that American companies fail to foresee the long-term harm in giving up on specific products that are test vehicles for new technology, and that they remain far too reluctant to invest in projects that may not pay off for a decade, if ever.
In the Japanese view, America's problem is that when the country abandoned the memory chip market in the mid-1980's it did not realize that it was also abandoning an enormously complex manufacturing technology.
''Only if you are good and fruitful in a previous generation can you afford to go ahead in the next stage,'' Joichi Aoi, the president of the Toshiba Corporation and the largest maker of one-megabit chips, said recently. ''But as we proceed from generation to generation in electronics, the number of ventures that can afford to participate will decline. The number of companies making top-level products now is very limited, and it is not getting bigger.''
The major reason is the heavy cost of staying in chip making. A single semiconductor fabrication plant for state-of-the-art chips can cost $200 million to $400 million.
But Japan's experience with X-ray lithography illustrates that cash is only part of the equation. So far, Japanese companies investing in X-ray lithography have pursued two strategies simultaneously. With Government help, they have created a consortium that is testing new equipment and trying basic processes. With their own funds, most of the major companies are also building operations of their own to begin etching test circuits and develop a range of new production equipment. Thus, the Government is orchestrating the effort to create core technologies that all the Japanese companies can then use to move toward commercial development of X-ray lithorgraphy.
The joint project, called Sortec, has been financed by 13 of Japan's biggest electronics and semiconductor equipment makers and the Government. The project's financing is just $100 million over 10 years, but the participating companies are donating the scientists and much of the equipment. It is housed in a new building on the edge of Tsukuba Science City, an hour north of Tokyo.
The core of the Sortec consortium - and all X-ray lithography projects - is a giant synchrotron, a circular or oval ring of magnets that accelerate a flow of electrons and shoot the X-rays they produce into a series of pipes. The X-rays, in turn, will be pumped into clean rooms built in a circle around the synchrotron, where the rays will expose the image of a chip on silicon.
Until now, ordinary light has done that job. In chip fabrication labs from Japan to Silicon Valley to Germany, chips have been produced in ''optical steppers'' that work much like a photographic enlarger. Light passes through a ''mask'' that is analogous to a photographic negative, and is then exposed onto the surface of a silicon wafer. The process is repeated for up to 20 layers of circuitry.
But as the size of circuitry has shrunk - today the circuits are less than a micron, or a thousandth of a millimeter, wide - ordinary light has become increasingly unsuitable. While optical lithography will probably be used to fabricate 16-megabit chips - I.B.M. and several Japanese makers have already produced prototypes - most experts expect that excimer lasers will be required to pack enough circuits on a chip for 64 megabits. By the time 256-megabit chips come along, probably after 1996 or so, the circuits will be as small as a quarter of a micron wide.
''You can't do that with ordinary light, or even lasers,'' said Tsutomu Noguchi, director of the Sortec research lab.
The difficulties lie in the fact that X-rays are impossible to manipulate with ordinary lenses, meaning that all new equipment is needed. So are new clean rooms; by some estimates a single X-ray chip fabrication plant will cost upwards of $1 billion in the mid-1990's.
 
A Miniature Industry
Not surprisingly, X-ray lithography has produced a miniature industry in Japan, with a network of suppliers rushing to build entirely new types of equipment. Fujitsu, NEC and Hitachi have all invested heavily, and Nikon and Canon are experimenting with new models designed to use X-rays as a light source. So is Matsushita, the the world's largest consumer electronics producer.
Several months ago Sumitomo Heavy Industries, which made its name as a shipbuilder, introduced a ''compact ring'' synchrotron, called the Aurora. Most synchrotrons are at least 50 feet in diameter; Sumitomo's is about the size of an office conference table. But the Aurora's development has been delayed by technical problems and it is still untested for chip making. For its part, I.B.M. is buying its synchrotron from Oxford Instruments, a British supplier.
So far, the most progress has come from the laboratory of Mr. Kitayama, who is working with a giant, racetrack-shaped synchrotron that N.T.T. has sunk into the basement of his laboratory, surrounded by giant superconductive magnets that are chilled to extremely low temperatures.
''We've built a clean room and already have some test circuitry,'' said Mr. Kitayama, who has been working on these problems for 10 years. ''But we are still a long, long way off.''

HEADLINE: Rates Soar To Highest Since May

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of both short- and long-term Treasury securities plunged. Dealers largely blamed concern that rising interest rates overseas would further increase the cost of borrowing in the United States.
The sharp selloff caused the price of the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond to drop more than $20 for each $1,000 of face value and its yield to rise to its highest level since last May. High-grade corporate bonds fell almost as much. But dealers said that high-yielding ''junk bonds,'' already deeply discounted, posted only minimal, if any, losses. 
The most immediate impact of the surge in interest rates was in the stock market, where prices slumped, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 38.74 points, to 2,596.85. [Page D6.] If the level of current interest rates is sustained, upward pressure should soon be felt on credit costs generally.
 
Yield Is Up to 8.66%
The Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 8 1/2 percent issue maturing in 2020, was being offered late yesterday at 98 9/32, down 2 5/32 since Friday, the biggest one-day decline in six months. The yield on the long bonds, which serve as a surrogate for the Treasury's long-term debt, soared to 8.66 percent from 8.46 percent.
In New York, the selling began with the start of trading as the market reacted to sharp drops in Treasury bond prices being quoted in Tokyo and later in Europe. At that time, news tickers were reporting that yields on Japanese and West German bonds were at their highest levels since mid-1982.
Japanese and West German bond prices were affected not so much by selling from investment portfolios, as was the case here, as by hedging by financial houses seeking insurance against rising interest rates and fears of inflation in those countries.
 
Futures Used as Hedge
To hedge, a portfolio manager normally sells equivalent amounts of securities in the futures market as insurance against a price drop. If prices do fall, the loss should be offset by gains on the futures contracts.
New York dealers said the traders overseas found buyers willing to take the risk, but at a price.
''Sentiment in the domestic bond market was not helped subsequently when Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan told a Congressional panel that inflation remained his primary concern,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''That appeared to dash any lingering hopes the Fed would ease credit in the foreseeable future.''
Less unsettling, Mr. Sullivan said, was a Treasury announcement that it would need to raise borrowings by $6 billion, to $47.6 billion, during the current quarter. ''The market fully expects the Treasury to increase its weekly and monthly bill auctions as well as place cash management bills to help the strapped Resolution Trust Corporation try to bail out sinking thrift institutions,'' he said.
Expected or not, the news weighed heavily on a market still trying to absorb the debt securities being liquidated by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street firm whose parent filed for bankruptcy protection last week.
 
Currency Rate Is a Factor
Mr. Sullivan said the credit market must now focus even more on currency exchange rates as well as interest rates, especially those in Japan and West Germany. Rising yields on debt securities in those two countries are drawing an increased amount of foreign investment.
At yesterday's weekly bill auctions, the Treasury's borrowing cost continued to rise. The average discount rate on the 90-day bills soared to 7.80 percent, from 7.65 percent the week before, while that on the six-month bills climbed to 7.77 percent from 7.65 percent. The auctions, usually held on Mondays, were postponed a day because of the Washington's Birthday holiday.
The bill rates are still well below levels a year ago, when they were 8.51 and 8.50 percent, respectively. In all, the Treasury sold $15.2 billion of three- and six-month bills, and it announced yesterday that the total would rise to $16 billion next week.
Interest rates are also expected to rise sharply at today's auction of $10 billion of two-year notes, which traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.49 percent, up from 8.32 percent last Friday. Tomorrow, the Treasury plans to auction $8 billion of five-year notes; the yield on them climbed yesterday to 8.55 percent from 8.34 percent.
The Treasury's 10-year notes, the 8 1/2's of the year 2000, dropped 31/32, to 99 6/32, as the yield climbed to 8.62 percent from 8.41 percent.
Following are the results of the Treasury's weekly bill auctions:
