HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Fiercer Rivals, Friendlier Skies

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
''THE idea,'' suggests one airline executive, ''was to throw eight pounds of paper at the guys who want to re-regulate.''
But you do not have to be a cynic to appreciate the eight-volume assessment of the domestic airline industry released last week by the Transportation Department. For in spite of the impression left by chaotic airports, sloppy cabin service and musical-chair corporate reorganizations, there is impressive evidence that the airlines are still disciplined by competition.
The one false note in this careful research effort is the analysis of what Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner's task force delicately labels airline ''marketing practices.'' The Bush Administration, it appears, is not ready to challenge the mega-carriers' use of frequent-flier bonuses and computerized reservation systems to frighten away potential competitors. 
Anyone who has braved the crowds at O'Hare or La Guardia knows that more people than ever are flying. What may surprise, though, is that small towns as well as big ones are enjoying better service. Flight frequency to 382 rural communities is up 44 percent since 1978, and a dozen medium-sized cities - like Charlotte, N.C.; Dayton, Ohio, and Memphis - have reaped spectacular tenfold or twentyfold gains.
The report notes, moreover, that the percentage of passengers with a choice of carriers grew sharply in the early 1980's and then held steady through the wave of mergers and bankruptcies. The resulting competitive pressures have forced carriers to pass through most of the gains from higher productivity. Adjusted for inflation, average fares are down 15 percent since 1984 and 26 percent since 1981. One key to greater airline efficiency is the switch to hub-and-spoke route structures, which allow major carriers to provide one-stop service between thousands of pairs of cities but fewer nonstops between others. The new route systems choke big airports with peak-hour traffic and limit the choice of carriers for residents of a few cities dominated by single carriers - notably St. Louis, Minneapolis and Pittsburgh. But for a great majority of travelers the shift assured greater competition, even as the number of airlines fell.
In 1979, for example, the Albany-Minneapolis route was served only through Buffalo or Chicago. By 1988 it was practical to connect through Pittsburgh and Detroit as well, increasing the number of competitors on the route from two to four.
The report acknowledges that competition is ever more dependent on airline access to major airports. Not every big-league carrier needs a hub in, say, Atlanta. But every carrier with a national route system does need a few gates to link Atlanta with 50 other cities through Dallas or Denver or Detroit. And that alone would be sufficient reason to push ahead with expansion of airports and air traffic control systems. Oddly missing from the report, however, are any tough words about airline marketing strategies intended in large part to cool the heated competition.
Frequent-flier programs buy the loyalty of business travelers at the expense of their employers. And the United States Treasury: Nobody, after all, pays taxes on all those ''free'' trips to Paris and Hawaii. As significant, the bonuses make it more difficult for upstart airlines to invade new turf. What sane traveler, on the verge of earning two first-class tickets to Bali on Tyrannosaurus Air, is likely to be won over by mere promises of faster and cheaper service?
Subtler but arguably as serious threats to new entry are the computerized reservation systems controlled by the major carriers and used by travel agents. These marvels of technology, able to regurgitate instant information on everything from available aisle seats to requests for kosher meals, are potent sources of growth in productivity. But they can also serve as potent weapons for repelling competitors.
Government rules prohibit gross biases in the way the screens display flight information. If the Eastern flight is quicker and leaves at the preferred time, it must show up ahead of the competition on American's computer system.
But the Transportation Department acknowledges that the systems can still be used to grant favors to deep-pocket clients and to bribe travel agents by tying commissions to bookings on heavily contested routes. And the report carefully skirts the question of corporate divestiture, the one policy fix that could guarantee the benefits of computerization without the costs to competition.
As measured by the vital statistics, airline competition is alive and well. But deregulators never contended that wide-open competition was in the interest of the sellers. And as the Transportation Department suggests, few industries have worked so hard or so cleverly to tame it. If no one keeps tabs on the airlines' high jinks, they may yet succeed.

HEADLINE: Chevron Cut May Total 1,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Chevron Corporation said today that it would trim up to 1,000 jobs this year, or 12 percent of the payroll of its domestic exploration and production unit. The oil giant also said it would sell more than $700 million worth of its domestic properties in the next two years.
The changes will result in charges of $25 million to $30 million against first-quarter earnings, the company said. 
Chevron, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, said it would continue to expand its search for oil and natural gas overseas.
 
A Meeting With Analysts
The announcement came the day before Kenneth T. Derr, Chevron's chairman and chief executive, was scheduled to talk to industry analysts in New York.
Mr. Derr succeeded George Keller in the Chevron posts a year ago. Analysts have criticized Mr. Derr for moving too slowly in trimming excess operations that remain from Chevron's acquisition of the Gulf Oil Corporation six years ago.
''Chevron has been making a number of statements saying they were in the process of restructuring,'' said Simon Trimble, who follows international oil companies for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. ''This is clearly one of the elements now in place.''
 
Shares Close Lower
After the announcement was made in the last hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Chevron's shares climbed 62.5 cents, but that was not enough to recover earlier losses and the shares ended the day down 50 cents, at $69.375.
Some analysts had expected Chevron to take the bigger step of selling some refineries or service stations, and using the proceeds to repurchase stock. Putting more shares in the company's hands could help defend against a possible takeover.
In December, the Pennzoil Company announced it held 8 percent of Chevron's common shares. Chevron immediately took legal action, which has not been resolved, to block further purchases by Pennzoil. Pennzoil said it was a long-term investor and did not intend to acquire Chevron.
In its statement today, Chevron said the Government's refusal to expand oil-drilling rights to some offshore and coastal areas in the United States had been ''a critical factor'' in its decision to scale back its domestic exploration activities.
Last month, Chevron said it had written off $445 million of its huge investment in the Point Arguello field, off the California coast near Santa Barbara. Production at the site has been delayed by protests from environmentalists and regulatory actions.
 
Interests in Alaska
Chevron also has large lease rights it shares with British Petroleum in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northeast Alaska, where Congress has banned drilling. A Chevron spokesman, Larry Shushan, said that even though the United States imported 54 percent of its oil needs in January, Chevron does not expect regulators to give permission to drill in the Alaska field soon.
In the changes announced today, Chevron is ending the practice of having three regional headquarters for all operations. Instead, production activities will be overseen by five regional offices, and the exploration business will be split between offices in Houston and New Orleans, with land sales and purchases managed in Houston.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drop on Rate Fears; Dow Off 38.74

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks fell across a broad front yesterday as traders worried about rising interest rates here, as well as in West Germany and Japan.
Strong signs that interest rates may be moving up in both Japan and West Germany pushed up interest rates in the credit markets here yesterday, but traders voiced concern that to remain competitive they may have to be raised further.
And in remarks that many traders took to be a big hint that no interest-rate relief was on the way, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress that the economy had probably passed the danger point. 
After falling 45 points in early afternoon, the Dow Jones industrial average ended the session off 38.74, or 1.5 percent, to 2,596.85. Trading was relatively light.
 
Nervous Analysts
Several market analysts have been advising clients to lighten up on stock positions, suggesting that Wall Street could be facing further declines.
A. Marshall Acuff Jr., an investment strategist for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, told the Reuters news agency that he had advised clients yesterday to trim stock holdings slightly and to build up cash.
Gene Seagle, technical research director at Gruntal & Company, attributed the market slump to weakness in the bond market and ''fears that the Japanese and Germans will raise interest rates again.''
The Dow transportation index slid 11.38 points yesterday, or nearly 1.1 percent, to 1,067.92, largely because of a 3 5/8 decline in UAL, to 127 1/8. Analysts said UAL directors would convene tomorrow for a regularly scheduled meeting to review union proposals to buy the company.
Trading volume, which just a week ago reached a low for the year of 118.4 million shares, stood yesterday at 148.2 million, down from 166.8 million on Friday.
The most active issue on the Big Board was Great Northern Nekoosa, which rose 1 1/2, to 65 3/8, after Georgia-Pacific increased its offer for the paper company to $65.75 a share, from $63, and the two signed an agreement to merge. More than two million shares changed hands.
In the strongest decline among the active issues, United Telecom slid 1 3/8, to 31 7/8, largely in response to a Wall Street Journal article yesterday on an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into reported spying by U S Sprint into rival phone bids. Sprint is part of United Telecom. Among the strongest gainers, McClatchy Newspapers rose 2 1/4, to 21 5/8, in heavy trading; in Sacramento, McClatchy told the New York Stock Exchange that it never commented on such matters.

HEADLINE: C.D. Yields Are Unchanged

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.
At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction held yesterday, the interest rates on three- and six-month bills were up sharply. The auction results are considered an influence on what many banks pay their depositors. 
The three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.80 percent, up from 7.65 percent a week ago and the highest rate in two weeks.
The six-month bills rose to 7.77 percent from 7.65 percent, the highest since the Oct. 2 auction, when it was 7.92 percent.
 
Bank Rates Called Stable
Robert J. Hutchinson, senior vice president and director of retail marketing at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, noted that bank C.D. rates during the last two weeks have stabilized, especially those in the New York market.
Some bank analysts say the Federal Reserve Bank, by not easing credit, has allowed interest rates to rise. As a result, people with maturing C.D.'s are parking their money in liquid accounts instead of rolling the certificates over, hoping to catch a higher rate. ''Some of those people often make the mistake of parking too long,'' one banker said.
The weekly survey of New York area banks shows C.D. yields offered at commercial banks mixed, while those at savings institutions were unchanged to slightly lower.
Yields on commercial bank money market accounts declined by 3 basis points, to 6.43 percent, with the average yield for a three-month certificate unchanged at 7.82 percent. A six-month certificate increased 2 basis points, to 7.90 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Slight Drop at Savings Units
At the savings institutions, yields on money market accounts were unchanged at 6.58 percent. Yields on three- and six-month ceriticates declined by a basis point, to 8.05 percent and 8.07 percent, respectively.
Among 20 large banks nationwide, yields on deposits remained mixed for the third straight week, with money market accounts unchanged at 6.31 percent and six-month certificates down 2 basis points, to 7.77 percent.
Yields at some large credit unions were mixed, with shorter-term rates up slightly and longer term certificates down. Money market accounts and one-year certificates gained a basis point, to 6.69 percent and 8.12 percent, respectively. While six-month certificates were unchanged, the two-and-a-half-year C.D. declined 4 basis points, to 8.22 percent, and the five-year slipped a basis point, to 8.23 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Against Pound; Gold Prices Are Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday in moderate trading, as the British pound took center stage, reaching a 10-month high against the dollar in the United States and abroad.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $419.90 an ounce, $2.80 higher than Friday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $419.90 an ounce, up $2.65 from Friday.
Foreign-exchange dealers said concerns about higher interest rates abroad, particularly in Britain, West Germany and Japan, were largely responsible for the dollar's drop.
 
Remarks by Greenspan
They said comments from the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, at a Congressional hearing yesterday, were shrugged off by traders even though the remarks seemed to be bullish for the dollar. Mr. Greenspan expressed guarded optimism that the country could avoid a recession, decreasing the prospects for lower interest rates.
Higher interest rates in Britain -around 15 percent for bank lending -helped support the pound.
In London, 1 cost $1.7040 late yesterday, up from $1.7030. Sterling fetched $1.7115 in New York, up from $1.6972 Friday. The pound is now at its highest level since the end of April, traders said.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.66835 West German marks, down from 1.6758; 1.4785 Swiss francs, down from 1.4910; 5.6670 French francs, down from 5.6950; 1,237.50 Italian lire, down from 1,243.25, and 1.20075 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1998.
In New York, the dollar closed at 145.155 yen, up from 144.13 Friday.
Silver prices gained. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $5.332 an ounce, up from $5.328 Friday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum and Copper Rise On Concern About Supply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting strong demand for the metal amid uncertainty about inflation, stock prices and South Africa.
On other commodity markets, copper futures rose and energy futures were mixed.
Platinum futures settled $8.40 to $9 higher, with the contract for delivery in April up $9 at $534.40 an ounce, its highest daily finish since Nov. 27. 
 
Fears About South Africa
Analysts linked the platinum rally to a spurt in purchases of physical platinum in East Asia and to renewed investment demand for the metal. In the background are continuing fears of supply disruptions in South Africa, the world's leading platinum producer, stemming from the threat of violence by followers of Nelson Mandela and the African National Congress.
Platinum for April delivery has risen more than $20 an ounce since Mr. Mandela's release on Feb. 11.
''There are people in the world who, for one reason or another, fear supply disruptions in the future and keep buying platinum,'' said John Sak, first vice president in charge of precious metals futures with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
Copper futures advanced for the fifth straight session on New York's Commodity Exchange amid continuing signs of dwindling supplies.
The London Metal Exchange on Monday reported that its warehouse stocks of copper declined last week by 5,425 tons, to 88,300 tons.
Yesterday, the Commodity Exchange said the level of copper stocks that are registered with it fell 609 tons on Friday, to 3,020 tons.
 
Oil Mostly Lower
Concerns about tightening supplies have helped increase the price for March delivery of copper by nearly 13 cents a pound in the last week.
Copper futures finished 0.2 cent to 1.7 cents higher, with March at $1.13 a pound.
Most petroleum futures retreated on the New York Mercantile Exchange, partly in reaction to analysts' projections for increased crude oil production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in the first half of 1990.
West Texas intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 23 cents lower, with March at $22.19 a barrel; heating oil futures ended 0.1 cent to 0.25 cent lower, with March at 57.38 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.18 cent lower to 0.21 cent higher, with March at 60.20 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Havel's 'Paradoxical' Plea: Help Soviets

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia told a joint meeting of Congress today that the best way the United States could aid his country and the rest of Eastern Europe in their quest for freedom was by helping the Soviet Union navigate the ''immensely complicated'' road to democracy.
Giving advice he acknowledged was a bit unusual coming from a longtime victim of Soviet domination, Czechoslovakia's playwright-turned-President told the Representatives, Senators and Cabinet members, ''I often hear the question: How can the United States of America help us today? My reply is as paradoxical as the whole of my life has been: You can help us most of all if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy.''
The sooner and the more peacefully the Soviet Union begins to move toward genuine political pluralism and a market economy, Mr. Havel added, ''the better it will be not just for Czechs and Slovaks, but for the whole world.'' 
 
Reducing the Burden
''And the sooner you yourselves will be able to reduce the burden of the military budget borne by the American people,'' he said. ''To put it metaphorically: the millions you give to the East today will soon return to you in the form of billions in savings.'' [Excerpts, page A14.] Mr. Havel's hourlong speech, which he said he wrote himself in an afternoon, was greeted by five standing ovations and repeated shouts of ''Bravo!'' from the standing-room-only crowd, which included the Czechoslovak-born tennis star Martina Navratilova and the film director Milos Forman. He responded with shy nods and a single, stiff V-for-victory sign.
At one point he practically apologized to his audience of professional politicians, saying: ''I have not attended any schools for presidents. My only school was life itself.''
Mr. Havel's speech was essentially a personal reflection on how the cold war can be replaced by ''an era in which all of us - large and small - former slaves and former masters - will be able to create what your great President Lincoln called the family of man.''
 
Tears and Pride
Throughout, his audience sat in rapt attention, with Czechs in the visitors gallery occasionally wiping away tears and Mr. Havel's aides drinking in the scene with that mixture of pride and bemusement that has characterized their rapid journey from prison cell to presidential castle.
''When they arrested me on Oct. 27, I was living in a country ruled by the most conservative Communist Government in Europe, and our society slumbered beneath the pall of a totalitarian system,'' Mr. Havel began, speaking in his native Czech and having an interpreter translate each paragraph. ''Today, less than four months later, I am speaking to you as the representative of a country that has set out on the road to democracy. It is all very strange indeed.''
But the 53-year-old Mr. Havel, Czechoslovakia's first non-Communist President since 1948, quickly added that he had come to the halls of Congress to speak not about his life but rather about his times.
''The human face of the world is changing so rapidly that none of the familiar political speedometers are adequate,'' he said. ''We playwrights, who have to cram a whole human life or an entire historical era into a two-hour play, can scarcely understand this rapidity ourselves.''
He then sought to explain why the changes taking place in Eastern Europe should be of concern to people around the globe. With the Soviet Ambassador, Yuri V. Dubinin, sitting with other diplomats in the audience, Mr. Havel observed that in the last century, when the United States was making ''enormous strides,'' the Soviet Union was transforming ''the enormous sacrifices of its people under totalitarian rule into a strength that, after World War II, made it the second most powerful nation in the world.''
''It was a country that rightly gave people nightmares, because no one knew what would occur to its rulers next and what country they would decide to conquer and drag into their sphere of influence. All of this taught us to see the world in bipolar terms, as two enormous forces, one a defender of freedom, the other a source of nightmares.''
 
Europe's Search for Identity
But now, said Mr. Havel, this bipolar world is breaking down, with the ''first act in this remarkable drama'' opening with the changes initiated by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
In light of these changes, Mr. Havel said, Czechoslovakia is returning to Europe and Europe itself is beginning to seek its own identity again ''without being compelled to be a divided armory any longer.''
Mr. Havel said he understood that for logistical and political reasons Mr. Gorbachev could not pull his 75,000 troops out of Czechoslovakia overnight, but added, ''Nevertheless, we would like to have as many Soviet units as possible moved out of our country before the elections.'' These are scheduled for June.
As for the future of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, Mr. Havel insisted that he was not calling for their dissolution tomorrow, but simply arguing that Europe has to eventually assume responsibility for its own security and stability.
 
Responsibility Above All
The second half of Mr. Havel's address was more of a philosophical meditation on the role of intellectuals in shaping the new Europe.
''A person who cannot move and live a somewhat normal life because he is pinned under a boulder has more time to think about his hopes than someone who is not trapped this way,'' he said. ''What I'm trying to say is this: We must all learn many things from you, from how to educate our offspring, how to elect our representatives, all the way to how to organize our economic life so that it will lead to prosperity and not to poverty. We, too, can offer something to you, our experience and the knowledge that has come from it.''
The specific wisdom he was referring to, Mr. Havel said, is what he and his colleagues have learned from fighting totalitarianism: that ''the salvation of this human world lies nowhere else than in the human heart, in the human power to reflect, in human meekness and in human responsibility.''
''The only genuine backbone of all our actions - if they are to be moral -is responsibility. Responsibility to something higher than my family, my country, my firm, my success.''
 
Shouldering the Burden
This, he said, is ''why I ultimately decided - after resisting for a long time - to accept the burden of political responsibility.''
''If the hope of the world lies in human consciousness, then it is obvious that intellectuals cannot go on forever avoiding their share of responsibility. When Thomas Jefferson wrote that 'Governments are instituted among men deriving their just powers from the consent of the governed,' it was a simple and important act of the human spirit. What gave meaning to that act, however, was the fact that the author backed it up with his life. It was not just his words, it was his deeds as well.''
At the invitation of President Bush, Mr. Havel returned to the White House after his address to complete their talks on economic issues. On Tuesday, Mr. Bush promised Czechoslovakia freer trade arrangements and a range of new investment and economic incentives.

LENGTH: 1464 words

HEADLINE: High Court Decides Budget Office Exceeded Power in Blocking Rules

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Dealing an unexpected setback to the deregulatory efforts of the Reagan and Bush administrations, the Supreme Court ruled today that the White House budget office lacked statutory authority to block certain regulations issued by other Federal agencies.
The Court held that the White House agency, the Office of Management and Budget, overstepped its authority two years ago when it disapproved parts of a Labor Department regulation requiring nearly all employers to warn their workers about the prospect of exposure to hazardous substances on the job.
The 7-to-2 decision applies to a broad category of regulations over which the budget office has asserted control, affecting areas like food ingredients, housing inspections and pensions.
The budget office refused in 1987 to permit the Labor Department regulation, known as the Hazard Communication Standard, to apply to the construction industry, and it did not take effect in construction. As its legal authority to limit the regulation, the budget office relied on the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1980. 
The standard itself was the result of a long political struggle during Ronald Reagan's Administration. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration, a unit of the Labor Department, at first issued narrow disclosure rules, limited to manufacturing industries. A group of labor unions as well as a consumer group sued successfully in 1983 to force the agency to issue a broader standard. The regulations issued in 1987, before the budget office's disapproval, applied to work sites in all sectors of the economy.
The Paperwork Reduction Act, which the Supreme Court had never interpreted before today, requires Federal agencies to get the budget office's approval before issuing regulations that required the collection of information. Aimed at relieving the public of the growing burden of filling out Federal forms, the law was passed in the final months of Jimmy Carter's Administration.
During the Reagan Administration, the Office of Management and Budget relied strongly on the paperwork law as the basis for taking control of the Federal regulatory process, a role that was much disputed by critics of the office.
 
Brennan Writes Opinion
In an opinion by Justice William J. Brennan Jr., the Court today said that the budget office's authority under the Paperwork Reduction Act is considerably more limited than the office had supposed.
The paperwork law applies only to regulations that require information to be reported to the Government itself, Justice Brennan said. He said the law does not give the O.M.B. authority over the Hazard Communication Standard or similar regulations, which require private parties - in this case, employers - to disclose information, not to the Government, but to other private parties, their employees.
 
Bush Argument Dismissed
Justice Brennan said the Administration's argument that the statute gave the budget office broader authority was untenable under a careful reading of the Paperwork Reduction Act.
He said the purpose of the act was to limit the increasing burden of filling out Federal forms and providing information to the Government, as well as minimizing the cost to the Government of handling the information.
Justice Brennan said, ''Because Congress expressed concern only for the burden imposed by requirements to provide information to a Federal agency, and not for any burden imposed by requirements to provide information to a third party, O.M.B. review of disclosure rules would not further this Congressional aim.''
He said the paperwork law was so clear that ''we decline to defer to O.M.B.'s interpretation.''
Barbara Clay, a spokeswoman for the budget office, said today there would be no comment on the Supreme Court decision.
 
Labor Pleased With Decision
In Bal Harbour, Fla., where the leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations are holding their annual meeting, news of the court's decision was greeted happily.
Margaret Seminario, health and safety director for the federation, said the decision should speed up the process of issuing regulations, including some that have been blocked at the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and others that she said agencies had watered down to accommodate the budget office. She said one is an OSHA-prepared requirement that cancer warnings be put on containers of the chemical formaldehyde.
The Court's decision upheld a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia. The budget office's action had been challenged by a labor union, the United Steelworkers of America, and by Public Citizen Inc., an organization affiliated with Ralph Nader.
 
Administration Appealed Decision
In its 1988 decision, the appeals court said that the O.M.B. had attempted to exercise ''substantive lawmaking authority'' that Congress had not given it.
When the Bush Administration appealed the third circuit's ruling early last year, its brief warned that the decision would have a drastic result and if not overturned ''would effectively invalidate O.M.B. authority to review a wide range'' of agency regulations beyond the Hazard Communication Standard. The brief said the Hazard Communication Standard itself imposed ''one of the most significant paperwork requirements in regulatory history.''
According to the Government's brief, the budget office has recently been in the process of review a wide range of disclosure rules covering areas like food ingredients, housing inspections, pension benefits, hearing aids, funeral services and lead-based paint.
 
Rehnquist and White Dissent
Justice Brennan's opinion, Dole v. Steelworkers, No. 88-1434, was joined by Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy.
Justice Byron R. White wrote a dissenting opinion that Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist joined. They said the Court had failed to give proper deference to the budget office's interpretation of the paperwork law.
The Office of Management and Budget was established in the Executive Office of the President in 1970 under executive orders that authorize it to supervise and coordinate the preparation of the budget among other executive branch agencies.
 
O.M.B. Viewed as Intrustive
Congress - not the Executive Office - created the Occupational Safety and Health Administration as well as dozens of other Federal regulatory agencies. OSHA's mandate since its birth in 1970 has been to improve safety on the job through its power to issue regulations.
Agency heads have occasionally chafed at what they have viewed as intrusions by the O.M.B. beyond budget questions into areas of policy. The clashes have been particularly pointed when the agency heads believed the budget office was frustrating their efforts to carry out Congressional mandates. But Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush both supported the budget office in its exercise of broad managerial powers over the other departments and agencies in the executive branch.
In its decision today limiting the budget office's authority under one statute, the Paperwork Reduction Act, the Supreme Court did not address broader questions about the budget office's role within the executive branch or its authority under various Presidential directives to oversee the work of other agencies.
The Court also issued this decision today: Rails to Trails The Court unanimously upheld the constitutionality of a 1983 law designed to facilitate the conversion of unused railroad tracks into scenic trails.
The law, an amendment to the National Trails System Act, permits the Interstate Commerce Commission, which regulates railroads, to transfer the rights of way of unused tracks to local governments or organizations for operation as trails. But in many instances, the railroads seeking to abandon their tracks do not actually own the property but have simply used it under easements granted in earlier years by the property owners.
A Vermont couple who owned several hundred feet along an abandoned branch line sued the commerce commission on the ground that the property's conversion into a bicycle path was an unconstitutional taking of their private property without compensation.
In an opinion by Justice Brennan, the Court said the law presented no constitutional problem because property owners could sue for damages in the United States Claims Court under a Federal law known as the Tucker Act. The opinion also said that the law was a valid exercise of the power of Congress to regulate interstate commerce.
The decision, Preseault v. I.C.C., No. 88-1076, upheld a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN JANUARY BY A SHARP 1.1%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Heavily affected by harsh early-winter weather, consumer prices soared 1.1 percent in January, the biggest monthly advance in more than seven years, the Labor Department reported today.
The increase in the Consumer Price Index was at the upper edge of the range of expectations, and analysts said it appeared to extinguish any remaining chance that the Federal Reserve Board would seek further cuts in interest rates anytime soon.
Until recently the widespread assumption among analysts was that the Federal Reserve was inclined to nudge rates down to counter weakness in the economy. But the latest economic reports suggest that the risk of recession has abated. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, told Congress on Tuesday that 1990 is likely to be a year of moderate expansion. 
 
Banks Feeling Rate Pressure
Pressure is even building in the banking system to reverse the half-point cut in the prime lending rate, to 10 percent, made in early January. Since then some rates that banks pay to attract short-term funds, like those on certificates of deposits, have climbed significantly. At the same time, however, the overnight loan rate, which is closely controlled by the Federal Reserve, has remained steady at about 8.25 percent.
Japan and West Germany are raising their interest rates to combat the threat of inflation, and these increases in turn tend to pull up rates here. Further easing of credit by the Federal Reserve, analysts agree, could cause an unwanted drop in the dollar if interest rates in the United States become relatively unattractive to investors.
 
Core Inflation Also Jumps
Without the categories of energy and food, which were influenced the most by supply shortages resulting from the record cold in late December, the January increase was six-tenths of 1 percent. This is the largest increase in this important gauge, which economists call the underlying, or core, inflation rate, since January 1984.
Yet the increase in the underlying rate also reflected special factors, involving automobile and tobacco prices, and analysts said they doubted that any worrisome surge in inflation is under way. ''We are starting to see it beginning to nose up a little bit, but it's not anything too disturbing,'' said John D. Paulus, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. He said it was clear that the outlook for the core rate is not anything like the January level.
Traders said the price jump contributed to a decline in both stock and bond prices as the two markets opened. But the Dow Jones industrial average managed to regain some of its losses and finish the session off 13.29 points, to 2,583.56. And the Treasury's benchmark long bond, which had plummeted in price on Tuesday, managed a gain on the day.
At the White House, the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, called today's report ''disappointing news,'' but in accord with the views of most private-sector economists, he said inflation would probably not continue at such a rate.
''We are hopeful that this is a bulge that will be temporary in nature,'' he said. ''But inflation requires eternal vigilance.''
In his Congressional testimony on Tuesday, Mr. Greenspan said that he expected inflation to remain steady in 1990 at 4 to 4.5 percent but that an inflation rate in that neighborhood was too high and the Fed was determined to bring it down.
Prices for heating oil and other products that surged in January have already receded, analysts said.
Prices in the New York metropolitan area, one of five city tabulations made on a monthly basis, jumped 1.4 percent in January, with an increase in transit fares accounting for a bit more than 10 percent of the advance.
 
Prices in Urban Areas
Prices climbed 1.3 percent in Chicago, 1.1 percent in Los Angeles, 1 percent in Philadelphia and nine-tenths of 1 percent in San Francisco.
The rise of 1.1 percent in the overall Consumer Price Index - which covers all urban consumers, or about 80 percent of the population - was the biggest since June 1982 and followed a 1.8 percent jump reported earlier this month in January's Producer Price Index for Finished Goods.
The Labor Department said energy and food accounted for more than 60 percent of the increase as fuel oil soared 26.3 percent and fruits and vegetables jumped 10.2 percent, both records. Gasoline climbed 7.7 percent after falling in November and December. The price of tomatoes rocketed 75.6 percent, bringing the retail price to more than $1 each in some stores.
Many consumers no doubt refused to pay such a price and bought something else instead, but this is not captured by the price index because it measures a fixed market basket of goods and services. The Consumer Price Index makes no allowance for consumers shifting buying habits, such as switching from steak to hamburger.
 
Transportation Costs
Among the main statistical categories, transportation showed the biggest increase, 2.1 percent, with motor fuels accounting for nearly 75 percent of it. Public transportation rose 1.9 percent because of increases in airline fares and intracity charges, like the rise in New York City transit prices, which included increases in taxi and commuter railroad fares and a subway and bus fare jump from $1 to $1.15. The transportation category rose three-tenths of a percent in December.
Somewhat surprising to some analysts was another rise, six-tenths of 1 percent, in prices of new cars. Analysts had expected a drop, largely because auto makers had resumed incentive programs, but a Labor Department official explained that the 1990 models were introduced more slowly than usual and thus their higher prices are still being incorporated into the figures.
Food and beverage prices climbed 1.8 percent, with grocery-store foods up 2.9 percent, the biggest increase since a 7.1 percent surge in August 1973. About two-thirds of the advance was in fruits and vegetables, but dairy products were up 2.4 percent and the category that includes meats, poultry, fish and eggs were up 1.9 percent. Egg prices themselves leapt another 9.1 percent. In December, the food and beverage category rose four-tenths of a percent.
Housing, which accounts for 42 percent of the consumer price index, rose seven-tenths of 1 percent after three straight months with advances of four-tenths of 1 percent. Nearly half the rise reflected fuel and other utilities. Prices of hotel and motel rooms rose 2.9 percent.
 
Other Categories
Apparel prices were unchanged last month, compared with a decline of three-tenths of a percent in December, and medical care and other goods and services rose by the same amounts as in December, six-tenths and eight-tenths of 1 percent, respectively.
Other goods include tobacco, which posted a 1.3 percent increase that analysts had not expected in light of a big jump in December. An official said a tobacco price increase at the end of the year was partially reflected in the January figures because of the way data are collected and that state and local tax increases would take effect at the beginning of a year.
The entertainment category rose six-tenths of 1 percent in January with increases for reading materials, club memberships and tickets to cultural, sporting and entertainment events accounting for the bulk of the advance. This category rose four-tenths of a percent in December.
Before rounding, the consumer price index for all urban consumers rose 1.1084719 last month, to 127.4 percent of its 1982-1984 base. This means that a group of goods and services that then cost $10 now costs $12.74. Without seasonal adjustment, the index rose 1 percent last month.
A second index, which covers urban wage earners and clerical workers, or 32 percent of the population, also rose 1.1 percent when seasonally adjusted and 1 percent without such adjustment.

HEADLINE: Japan to Give Tax Benefits For Charitable Aid in U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Worried about mounting hostility to Japan's huge investments in the United States, the Japanese Government will offer Japanese companies a large tax deduction if they give money to hospitals, schools or philanthropic activities in the United States, Government officials say.
Japan has made no formal announcement of the move, but it was discussed at length during a highly unusual meeting of 300 of the country's top business executives, who were summoned to the Foreign Ministry last Friday.
The tax break - effectively a Japanese Government subsidy to American organizations - is the latest and most significant move yet to try to defuse tension with the United States over Japan's growing presence there, which Japan now fears may be poisoning relations between the two countries.
 
Joining the Community
Moreover, the tax deduction for charitable donations seems to be part of a broader effort by the Government and industry to burnish the image of Japanese as solid citizens in the American communities where Japanese companies have built plants. Indeed, the tax breaks are merely one element in the drive to encourage Japanese expatriates working in the United States to become more involved in their communities. 
In recent days, for example, the Japanese Chamber of Commerce has begun distributing 5,000 copies of an 85-page handbook containing advice to Japan-based companies in America on supporting local charities and volunteering to work for local organizations.
Tsutomu Karino, an executive director, explained that the handbook had been issued because the American tradition of volunteerism was not much developed in Japan.
''Most Americans feel this is common sense,'' Mr. Karino said. ''Most Japanese feel this is not common sense, this is unusual.''
Published with Japanese and English text on facing pages, the book is entitled, ''Joining In! A Handbook for Better Corporate Citizenship in the United States.'' Among other suggestions, it urges Japanese executives to make sure they promote their community efforts. ''It is important in American society to take credit for good works accomplished,'' the handbook says. ''This is not bragging; it is a matter of getting deserved credit.''
Japanese officials gave few details about the tax deduction, which is expected to go into effect next year. But they said that until now, Japanese companies operating abroad received tax deductions only for contributions that helped explain Japanese culture, like exchange programs or museum exhibitions. In most cases, there were no deductions for contributions to the communities surrounding Japan's growing number of auto plants, electronics factories or real estate holdings in the United States.
''This is not an effort to buy opinions,'' said Masaki Okada, a Foreign Ministry official working on the tax plan. ''We think that it is important to pay for things other than building a Japanese garden.''
The Government's tax incentive was paired with a bluntly worded message that Japanese companies have themselves to blame for much of the tension with the United States. ''There are an increasing number of Americans who think 'the Japanese are faceless' or 'there is no knowing what they are thinking.' '' Taro Nakayama, Japan's Foreign Minister, told the executives in a statement read at the meeting.
Americans fear ''that it is impossible to guess where Japan's huge economic power is headed, and under what philosophy or principles,'' he said. ''It is worth noting that now people in the U.S. are feeling less threatened by the U.S.S.R., and some are expressing the view that the economic threat from Japan is more serious than the military threat from the Soviet Union.'' Mr. Nakayama's statement was read to the executives by a Foreign Ministry official.
Executives who attended the meeting said they thought the Government's wording, far harsher than ever before, was an effort to persuade Japanese companies to use their profits to defuse American fears that the Japanese presence is ominous.
 
Second Tax Incentive
The tax benefit for local donations is the second tax incentive the Japanese Government has used to try to ease trade tensions in the last three months. In late December, the Government said it would offer tax credits to companies that greatly increase their imports of foreign-made machinery, computers, autos and other manufactured goods.
The tax exemption for donations has already received the approval of the Japanese Finance Ministry, officials said, and the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which was returned to power with a comfortable majority in the general election on Sunday. Accordingly, approval by the Parliament is virtually assured.
In contrast to the Japanese gesture, charitable contributions by American corporations to overseas institutions are generally not deductible from United States taxes, said Sheldon N. Weinberg, a senior manager at Deloitte & Touche. The only exception occurs when a donation can be claimed as an advertising expense or otherwise justified as a necessary cost of doing business, which is seldom easy, he said.
Although the meeting with the Foreign Ministry officials occurred two days before the election, some executives here speculated that the tax deduction was not announced earlier for fear it would appear to be a concession to the United States and would hurt the Liberal Democrats' chances, especially among farmers and others who are angry about increased imports of American goods by Japan.
''It's a somewhat desperate move,'' a senior executive who attended the meeting said. ''But Japan is in desperate trouble.''
 
Some Critics in Japan
Even in Japan, the tax move has come under some criticism as an attempt to solve the problem of United States-Japanese relations with money. ''What companies really need to do is give their employees more time to really become active in their communities,'' a senior executive of a major automobile manufacturer said today. ''But they are made to work like dogs, and with the time difference they spend their evenings getting instructions from Tokyo.''
The intervention of the Foreign Ministry in the activities of Japanese companies abroad was somewhat unusual, because that role is ordinarily filled by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry or the Ministry of Finance. But a recent poll commissioned by the Foreign Ministry about America vis-a-vis Japan convinced diplomats here that tensions between the two countries were threatening the stability of their postwar relationship.
 
Warning From Auto Executive
At times, the meeting on Friday took the form of a primer on how to behave in the United States, some participants said. One speaker, Shoichiro Toyoda, the president of the Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's biggest car maker, warned executives that Japanese companies did far too little to contribute to the communities where they build factories and research labs.
''The extent and scope of the social contribution required of individuals and enterprises in the U.S. are much wider than and different from the case of Japan,'' Mr. Toyoda said. ''In the U.S., it is the individual who plays a key role in voluntary work or financial contributions. That stems from their different social and historical background. Japanese people are more likely to identify with their places of work, while Americans are more likely to identify with the communities they live in.''
Mr. Toyoda said that Japanese must ''contribute on the same level as Americans'' as long as they are ''enjoying the benefits of American society.''
Some executives questioned whether the tax deductions would be large enough to make a great change in American attitudes toward Japan. Moreover, they suspected that the contributions could be resisted by many in Japanese industry, who prefer to make flashy contributions in the United States - endowing chairs at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, underwriting research institutes that work in areas relating to Japan or sponsoring big sports events.
So far, their contributions to ordinary community causes signficantly trail those of American companies, officials here say. Because the companies are not required to report such contributions, exact figures are difficult to find. In Japan, companies often lump charity and political donations into one accounting line of their balance sheet.

HEADLINE: Role Playing and Oratory Limits at This U.N.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The mock crisis went this way: Shortly after 2 A.M. on Sunday, the Security Council's 15 members were roused from their beds here for an emergency session to review the worsening situation in Nicaragua.
President Daniel Ortega Saavedra had declared an emergency and canceled elections next week after several United Nations observers were killed. American forces in Panama were moving northward into Nicaragua. 
But by 9 A.M. an exhausted Council had accomplished little, with the United States blocking condemnation of its action and members unable to agree on a role for the United Nations.
''Frustrating but realistic,'' said Marc S. Sabartini, a Harvard biochemistry student playing the role of Secretary General at this 36th annual Harvard National Model United Nations, the largest in the country.
 
Uncanny Realism
For three days, about 1,800 students from more than 140 American, Canadian and Mexican universities transformed a hotel here into a mini-United Nations, organizing meetings of the Security Council, the General Assembly, the Economic and Social Council and the International Court of Justice, among other bodies.
Each university, fielding teams of about 18 students, pretended to be a country - the University of Western Ontario was the United States this year while Siena College in Loudonville, N. Y., played the Soviet Union - first studying its policies and interests and then promoting them in the United Nations forums.
The atmosphere was uncannily realistic, with student-delegates rushing in and out of meeting rooms.
The concluding General Assembly called for a compulsory public register of international arms sales, said assets of drug traffickers should finance the anti-drug war and asked the United Nations to also help internally displaced refugees.
Only occasionally did delegates stretch the bounds of political probability, as when Turkey (the State University of New York at New Paltz) resolved the Cyprus crisis by withdrawing its forces in a bargain with Greece (Kean College of New Jersey in Union) that allowed it to join the European Community.
''What talent for compromise, what grace they treat each other with,'' said Jonathan Moore, an American deputy representative at the real United Nations, and a guest at the meeting.
The Harvard Model United Nations is one of about 150 such meetings organized each year by high schools and universities around the world. Harvard takes credit for the idea, having organized the first Model League of Nations in the 1920's.
Teachers who brought their students to the Harvard meeting said the experience encourages debating skills besides teaching them a global approach to current problems and providing an insight into the complexity of international relations.
''It breaks down American parochialism,'' said Thomas Ilger of Pitzer College in Claremont Calif., whose students represented Britain.
But best lesson of all for the real United Nations was the speaking time allowed: a maximum of just two and half minutes per speaker.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Excerpts From Czech Chief's Address to Congress

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an address by President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia today to a joint meeting of Congress, as translated by an interpreter and provided by Federal News Service, a transcription company.
 
The last time they arrested me, on Oct. 27 of last year, I didn't know whether it was for two days or for two years. Exactly one month later, when the rock musician Mikhail Koscak told me that I would be probably proposed as a presidential candidate, I thought it was one of his usual jokes. On the 10th of December, 1989, when my actor friend Jiri Bardoska, in the name of the Civic Forum, nominated me as a candidate for the office of President of the Republic, I thought it was out of the question that the Parliament we had inherited from the previous regime would elect me. 
Nineteen days later, when I was unanimously elected President of my country, I had no idea that in two months I would be speaking in front of this famous and powerful assembly, and that what I say would be heard by millions of people who have never heard of me. . . .
When they arrested me on Oct. 27, I was living in a country ruled by the most conservative Communist Government in Europe, and our society slumbered beneath the pall of a totalitarian system. Today, less than four months later, I am speaking to you as the representative of a country that has set out on the road to democracy, a country where there is complete freedom of speech, which is getting ready for free elections and which wants to create a prosperous market economy and its own foreign policy. It is all very extraordinary. ...
 
Century of Catastrophe
Twice in this century, the world has been threatened by catastrophe. Twice this catastrophe was born in Europe, and twice you Americans along with others were called upon to save Europe, the whole world and yourselves. The first rescue mission among other things provided significant help to us, Czechs and Slovaks. Thanks to the great support of your President Wilson, our first President, Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, could found our modern independent state. . . .
In the meantime, the United States made enormous strides. It became the most powerful nation on earth, and it understood the responsibility that flowed from this. Proof of this are the hundreds of thousands of your young citizens who gave their lives for the liberation of Europe and the graves of American airmen and soldiers on Czechoslovak soil. But, something else was happening as well. The Soviet Union appeared, grew, and transformed the enormous sacrifices of its people suffering under totalitarian rule into a strength that, after World War II, made it the second most powerful nation in the world. It was a country that rightly gave people nightmares because no one knew what would occur to its rulers next and what country they would decide to conquer. . . .
All of this taught us to see the world in bipolar terms as two enormous forces - one, a defender of freedom, the other, a source of nightmares. Europe became the point of friction between these two powers, and thus, it turned into a single enormous arsenal divided into two parts. In this process, one half of the arsenal became part of that nightmarish power, while the other, the free part, bordering on the ocean and having no wish to be driven into it, was compelled, together with you, to build a complicated security system to which we probably owe the fact that we still exist. ...
 
Breakdown of a System
And now, what is happening is happening. The totalitarian system in the Soviet Union, and in most of its satellites, is breaking down and our nations are looking for a way to democracy and independence. ...
This is, I am firmly convinced, an historically irreversible process, and as a result, Europe will begin again to seek its own identity without being compelled to be a divided armory any longer. Perhaps this will create the hope that sooner or later your voice will no longer have to stand on guard for freedom in Europe or come to our rescue because Europe will at last be able to stand guard over itself.
But that is still not the most important thing. The main thing is, it seems to me, that these revolutionary changes will enable us to escape from the rather antiquated straitjacket of this bipolar view of the world, and to enter at last into an era of multipolarity; that is, into an era in which all of us, large and small, former slaves and former masters, will be able to create what your great President Lincoln called the family of man. ...
 
Help From United States
I often hear the question, how can the United States of America help us today?
My reply is as paradoxical as the whole of my life has been. You can help us most of all if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy. ...
Sooner or later, Europe must recover and come into its own and decide for itself how many or whose soldiers it needs so that its own security and all the wider implications of that security may radiate peace into the whole world. ...
Without a global revolution in the sphere of human consciousness, nothing will change for the better in the sphere of our being. . . . ...
We still don't know how to put morality ahead of politics, science and economy. We are still incapable of understanding that the only genuine backbone of all our actions, if they are to be moral, is responsibility -responsibility to something higher than my family, my country, my company, my success. ...
 
Political Responsibility
If I subordinate my political behavior to this imperative, mediated to me by my conscience, I can't go far wrong. If, on the contrary, I were not guided by this voice, not even 10 presidential schools with 2,000 of the best political scientists in the world could help me.
This is why I ultimately decided, after resisting for a long time, to accept the burden of political responsibility. I am not the first; nor will I be the last intellectual to do this. ...
When Thomas Jefferson wrote that governments are instituted among men deriving their just powers from the consent of the governed, it was a simple and important act of the human spirit. What gave meaning to that act, however, was the fact that the author backed it up with his life. It was not just his words; it was his deed as well.
